Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ Eucerinae: Eucerini
Ww The tribe Eucerini (“long-horned” bees) is a distinctive group. Males have elongate antennae
(Fig. ##) and females have a characteristic w-shaped gradulus on S2 (Figs. 253, 254). Once you
~ become familiar with recognizing these features, it becomes easy to distinguish Eucerini from

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
aa other large, hairy, apid bees. The taxonomy of this group has been a challenge, to put it mildly.
~ The generic and subgeneric boundaries are difficult to define and, while recent phylogenetic
U studies have significantly improved our understanding of relationships (Dorchin et al. 2018a,b;
/ Freitas et al. 2020) and historical biogeography (Freitas et al. 2022), the morphological features

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ that allow generic or subgeneric identification remain extremely subtle. For this reason, we have
~ separated Eucerini out from the main key (see Chapter 9), to facilitate revisions to the key as the
oe taxonomy changes. Our key (Chapter 9) is based on the key provided in Dorchin et al. (2018a).
~ 50. Agapanthinus LaBerge: Moderate-sized, euceriform, with pale tergal hair bands; aspect of

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ Melissodes. Floral hosts unknown but compound eyes and ocelli enlarged suggesting matinal or
ww crepuscular foraging. Rare; one species, A. callophila (Cockerell). Baja California and
U California deserts. See LaBerge (1957). (couplet ## in the Key to Genera of Eucerini)
~ fs Eucera Scopoli: Small to large, anthophoriform or euceriform, hairy, fast-flying bees. North

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
ww ~American subgenera include Tetralonia (including Tetraloniella), Peponapis, Xenoglossa,
oe Cemolobus, Syntrichalonia, Synhalonia, and Xenoglossodes (including Pectinapis). This is a
mainly Holarctic group, ranging across our area from Canada to Central America, with few
~ species in South America, most diverse in temperate areas. Around 400 species worldwide with

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ approximately 115 species in our area. Many subgroups are narrowly oligolectic, including
¥ Cemolobus (oligolectic on Ipomoea), and Peponapis and Xenoglossa (oligolectic on Cucurbita).
This is a challenging group and there is currently no key to the subgenera of North America.
~ (couplet ## in the Key to Genera of Eucerini)

two in our area. Widespread in neotropics, ranging in humid and mesic areas through Antilles
~ and Mesoamerica to central and eastern USA, north to Colorado, Nebraska, and New Jersey.

~ 480], with weak tergal hair bands. Uncommon; 36 species, two in our region.. Neotropical,

(1958a). (couplet ## in the Key to Genera of Eucerini) ~

54. Martinapis Cockerell: Moderate-sized euceriform or anthophoriform, males with yellow =
antennae. Rare; three species, two in our area. Kansas and Texas to California, south to Puebla, ww
disjunct to Argentina. Matinal, commonly associated with Psorothamnus and related Fabaceae. vw
Our species belong to the subgenus Martinapis s.str. Revision: Zavortink and LaBerge (1976).

Title: MMD

(couplet ## in the Key to Genera of Eucerini) ~

less commonly without bands of pale hair on terga. Common; 129 species, with 122 in our area.

US species, The most common eucerine genus in most of North America. Canada and the ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
Antilles to Argentina but rare in tropics. Some species nest communally with several individuals baad

sharing a burrow entrance. Most species in the large subgenus Eumelissodes are oligolectic on w

Asteraceae while members of Melissodes s. str. are all polylectic. Other species are oligoletic on Y

Malvaceae, Pontederiaceae, Onagraceae. Revision: LaBerge (1956a,b; 1961); Svastra was

58. Protohalonia Dorchin: Originally referred to as the “venusta-group” of Synhalonia, this ~
genus was recently recognized based on a molecular phylogeny of the Eucera complex (Dorchin ~
et al. 2018a). Moderate-sized to large, euceriform; metasoma with pale white apical hairbands ~~

(P. venusta and P. amoena) or entirely dark (P. carinata); pygidial plate strongly elevated along w

midline. Rare; primarily distributed in the southwestern USA (including Mojave, Sonoran,

Chihuahuan, and Great Basin deserts) and Baja California, Mexico; P. venusta occurs as far ~

north as Oregon. The three species of Protohalonia are spring-active and all are reported to be ~

~ 59. Svastra Holmberg: Large to moderate-sized, euceriform, commonly with tergal hair bands

~ or terga suffused with pale hair; aspect is that of large Melissodes. Common. 23 species, 20 in

Ww our area. Throughout southernmost Canada, USA, and Mexico south to Argentina and Chile, rare
in tropics. Some species have communal nests, several individuals using one burrow. Many

Title: MMD

Text Content:

w (oligolectic on Ferocactus), were treated as genera in the first edition of this book but are now

w considered subgenera of Svastra. A recent molecular study (Freitas et al, 2021) indicates the

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.

7 North American species placed in Svastra are not closely related to the South American Svastra
s. str. If this result is supported, the North American species will become the genus

~ Epimelissodes. Revisions: Laberge (1955) subgenus Anthedonia; LaBerge (1956a, 1958b),

60. Thygater Holmberg: Moderate-sized to rather large, euceriform, hairy, with strongly

~ protuberant clypeus, long mouthparts, very long black antennae in males, and without metasomal

ad hair bands. Uncommon to common; 31 species, eight in our area. Like some Svastra, vibratile

Title: MMD

~ Eucerinae: Exomalopsini

w 61. Anthophorula Cockerell: This group was historically included in Exomalopsis until Silveira
(1993a,b) recognized it as a distinct genus. Anthophorula includes minute to moderate-sized

~ (2.5-8mm), compact, rotund, hairy, anthophoriform bees with two or three submarginal cells

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ (hence, this genus comes out in two places in the Key to the Genera); a few species have a red

VY metasoma. Distributed across the western US as far north as Oregon and eastward to Indiana and
south to Veracruz and Oaxaca, Mexico. As in Exomalopsis, nests of Anthophorula are usually

~ communally occupied burrows, each being inhabited by several females (Rozen, 1984). Floral

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ associations poorly known for most species, some polylectic but others oligolectic on

w Amaranthaceae, Asteraceae, Euphorbiaceae or Scrophulariaceae. Michener (2007) provides a

vw key to subgenera. Revisions (as Exomalopsis): Timberlake 1980a).

~ 62. Exomalopsis Spinola: Small to moderate-sized (4-12mm), chubby, hairy, anthophoriform

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
wv [Figs. 485 and 486] bees. Common in tropics north to southwestern USA, moist tropics to desert,

e uncommon elsewhere. Present from Baja California and Sonora, Mexico; Arizona, New Mexico,
southern Texas and southern Florida, USA; and the Bahamas south through Mesoamerica, the

~ Antilles and into South America. Nests are communal with multiple females sharing a burrow.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ All species appear to be polylectic. (Rozen 1984). Revisions: Timberlake (1947, USA only;

YY 1980a). Michener (2007) provides a key to subgenera. (couplets 127 and 199)

~ Eucerinae: Tapinotaspidini

¥ Almost all members of the Tapinotaspidini, like most Centridini, are oil-collecting bees. In our
area, females of Monoeca have combs of specialized hair on their fore- and mid-basitarsi while

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content: ~ both males and females of Paratetrapedia have combs only on their fore-basitarsi. Female

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
Monoeca are known to collect oils of Malpighiaceae and most floral oil records for female ~
Paratetrapedia are for Malpighiaceae as well. Oils are used to line the brood cells and are mixed ~
with pollen as larval food. ~
63. Monoeca Lepeletier and Serville: Moderate-sized, anthophoriform, like a large Exomalopsis Y

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
without metasomal hair bands; head and thorax hairy; metasoma sometimes red. Rare. Nests
excavated in soil. Tropical America, north in tropical Mexico to Jalisco. Revision: None. ~
(couplet 128) ww
The synonymous name Fiorentinia Dalla Torre has sometimes been used for this genus. v
64. Paratetrapedia Moure: Small to moderate-sized (6-12mm), somewhat shiny, nonhairy, ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
trigoniform [Fig. 487]. Strikingly mimetic of various species of Trigona—black, largely or Y
wholly yellow or testaceous, black with red metasoma, and so forth; face of male with yellow or Y
white areas. Moderately common. Widespread in neotropics, extending into tropical Mexico at
least to San Luis Potosi and Jalisco; also Jamaica. Females of the subgenus Xanthopedia nest in ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
earth banks; females of other subgenera probably nest in preformed holes in wood. Revision: Vv
Aguiar & Melo 2011. (couplets 114 and 128) wy
Variation and intermediacy in the shape of the posterior thoracic profile (couplet 108) leads to 7
the appearance of Paratetrapedia twice in the Key to the Genera.

~ 67. Brachynomada Cockerell: Small to moderate-sized (3.5-9mm), nomadiform, black,

ws Anthophorula (Exomalopsini). Revision: Snelling and Rozen (1987). (couplets 33 and 192)

~ instead of three submarginal cells. Brachynomada therefore appears twice in the Key to the

~ Genera.

v 68. Paranomada Linsley and Michener: Moderate-sized (5-1 1mm), smooth and shiny, black or
red, nomadiform [Fig. 500], with some areas of dense pubescence. Thorax dorsoventrally

~ flattened, unlike any other bee, presumably to allow it to spend extended periods in the

~ communal nests of its hosts.. Rare. Deserts of southwestern USA and northern Mexico. Brood

~ darkened with distinct pattern of light and dark areas; extremely long sting. Rare; one species in

wy our area, C. punctipennis Cresson. Widespread in American tropics, north into tropical Mexico

~ 71. Epeolus Latreille: Small to moderate-sized, epeoliform, patterned like Triepeolus.

~ Moderately common. Southern Canada through USA, Antilles, Mesoamerica, and South

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ Amercia (holarctic, neotropical, and African). Brood parasites of Co/letes. Revisions: Onuferko

~ (2017) for Canada; Onuferko (2018) for the Nearctic region (north of Mexico); and Onuferko
(2019) for the Caribbean, Central America and Mexico. (couplet 112)

~ Most species have three submarginal cells and run directly to couplet 112, but a few have only

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.

~ Epeolus has, in the past, been divided into two subgenera: Epeolus s.s. and Trophocleptria
(sometimes also treated as a genus). A recent phylogentic study by Onuferko et al. (2019)

~ identified six discrete monophyletic groups within Epeolus but did not designate new subgenera

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
based on these groupings. Before such a subgeneric classification is proposed, we prefer not to
recognize subgenera of Epeolus, as recommended by Onuferko et al. (2019). ~

72. Odyneropsis Schrottky: Moderate-sized to rather large (9-1 7mm), slender epeoliform or ww
nomadiform, nonhairy, wasplike, largely black or brown. Rare. Widespread in neotropics,
ranging north through Mexico to southern Arizona. Brood parasites of Ptiloglossa. Revision: ~
None. (couplet 111) ~

The moderate-sized species, known north only to Panama, have been placed in the genus Ww
Parammobates Friese, but this group does not seem to differ at the generic level from the larger, v
typical Odyneropsis.

one species, 7. smaragdina Smith. South America northward to Costa Rica. Brood parasites of ~

of bands and spots produced by areas of short pale pubescence; males almost indistinguishable
from those of Epeolus. Common in nearctic region, rare in tropics. Largest genus of Epeolini in ~
our area with over 130 species. Southern Canada, USA, Antilles, and Mexico, south to Central ~

and South America (few species also in palearctic region). Brood parasites of diverse hosts us
including Dieunomia (Halictidae), Protoxaea (Andrenidae), Ptiloglossa (Colletidae) but mostly
of Eucerini (Apidae), Revision: Righmyer (2008); provides keys to all female Triepeolus ~
(excluding the verbesinae and simplex species groups) for western North and Central America. bad

few have two submarginal cells and run to couplet 112 via couplet 181. ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
75. Epeoloides Giraud: Rather small (7-10 mm), dark, nonhairy, epeoliform; body all black. ~
Extremely rare; only one species, E. pilosulus (Cresson). Northeastern and central USA and ~
across southern Canada from Alberta to Nova Scotia (holarctic). Brood parasite of Macropis. ad
(couplet 115) v)

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
E. pilosulus is one of the rarest bees in North America. It was, in fact, thought to be extinct
because specimens had not been collected since the 1960s. However, a number of reports from ~
Alberta to Connecticut between 2002 and 2021 have documented that Epeoloides pilosulus is ~
still present, but remains extremely rare (Sheffield et al. 2004, Sheffield and Heron 2018, Wood w

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
et al. 2019, Wagner & Ascher 2008, Gibbs et al. 2021). The biology of the European E.
coecutiens (Fabricius) was described by Bogush (2005). Its presumed host, Macropis, remains ~
widespread but localized to patches of its required host-plant, Lysimachia (Primulaceae). ~

76. Acanthopus Klug: Very large (20-25 mm), dark blue (resulting from appressed blue

ww 97. Tetrapedia Klug: Rather small, shining, trigoniform, resembling a rather elongate, unusually
hairy (in ours) black Trigona; appearance similar to that of black Paratetrapedia but more hairy,

~ face of male black. Moderately common. Widespread in tropical America, north to Tamaulipas

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:

w Centridini are “oil bees”. Both males and females have unusually modified forebasitarsi for oil

vu collection and modified scopal hairs for transporting floral oils. Unlike other oil-collecting bees,
female Tetrapedia forage from beneath the flower when harvesting oils of Malpighiacae. Oils are

w distinguishes this genus from all others. Common or moderately common in tropics. Tropical

= Family Colletidae

‘oe Glossa short, broadly truncate to bifid. Labial palpus with segments similar, none of them
elongate and sheathlike.

~ NOTES ON THE BIOLOGY, PHYLOGENY, AND CLASSIFICATION. This family is most

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
wo abundant and diverse in Australia and South America. In Australia, 50% of native bee species
are in the family Colletidae (Houston 2018). Colletid diversity in North and Central America is,

- by comparison, limited. Two genera (Colletes and Hylaeus) comprise the bulk of colletid

~ diversity in our area. In addition to Colletinae and Hylaeinae, three additional subfamilies are

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
VY represented in North and Central America: Diphaglossinae (three genera), Neopasiphaeinae

U (Eulonchopria) and Xeromelissinae (Chilicola). Phylogenetic studies of the family include
Almeida and Danforth (2009) and Almeida et al. (2012, 2019). For a review of nesting biology

~ see Almeida (2008). Colletids are unique among bees in lining their brood cells with a

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ “cellophane” coating derived from the Dufour’s gland. Females provision their brood cells with a

Ww liquid mix of nectar and pollen that is likely rich in fermentative yeasts (Almeida 2008, Danforth
et al. 2019). Among the colletid bees distributed in the region, there are no social nor brood

~ parasite species, although several colletids are hosts of Nomadinae (Apidae).

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
Colletinae ~
99. Colletes Latreille: Rather small to moderate-sized or a few rather large; moderately hairy, VY
andreniform [Fig. 417] to apiform, usually with pale tergal hair bands, superficially similar to
Halictus and Andrena but with head in facial view more tapering below, inner orbits of eyes ~
converging strongly below; glossa short and shallowly bilobed and metasoma more strongly ™

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
tapering posteriorly?. Common in our area with over 140 described species; boreal to deserts to ww
moist tropics (cosmopolitan except Australia). Nests excavated in soil. The majority of species VU
are polylectic, but many oligolectic on wide range of families including Asteraceae, Solanaceae,
Fabaceae, Ericaceae, Campanulaceae, Sapotaceae, and Malvaceae. Revision: Stephen (1954), ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
USA and Canadian species; Balboa et al. (2017) revised part of the Mexican and Central Y
American fauna. (couplet 25) w,
This is the only genus of bees with the second recurrent vein arcuate distad in its posterior half
[Fig. 79]. See Ferrari et al. (2020) and Ferrari & Packer (2020) for recent phylogenetic studies of ~
Colletes. ad

~ Hylaeinae

~ 104. Hylaeus Fabricius: Minute to small; slender, non-hairy, hylaeiform [Fig. 420]; black or

Ww rarely partly red, usually with limited yellow or white areas on face, thorax, and legs, rarely on
metasoma, some with red on metasoma; aspect that of small black wasp; glossa broadly truncate;

~ scopa of female entirely absent (pollen transported in crop). Common in temperate areas,

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ uncommon to rare in tropics. Boreal Canada to Panama and Antilles (cosmopolitan). Nests in

w~ hollow twigs or stems, occasionally in preformed burrows in banks. All North American species

v appear to be polylectic. Some Hawaiian species inferred to be brood parasites as they lack the
usual pollen collecting hairs on their fore-tarsi. (Daly & Magnacca 2003). Revisions: Snelling

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ (1966b, 1968, 1970), Daly (1973); none of these papers covers Mesoamerican species

ww adequately; Hawaiian species were revised by Daly & Magnacca (2003). (couplet 177)

w The subfamily Hylaeinae, and the genus Hy/aeus, are most diverse in Australia, their likely
place of origin (Almeida et al. 2012; Kayaalp et al. 2013). Hylaeus is estimated to have dispersed

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ from Australia approximately 22 million years ago (Kayaalp et al. 2013) and is now one of the

w few cosmopolitan bee genera.

U Neopasiphaeinae (formerly referred to as “Paracolletinae”)

~ 105. Eulonchopria Bréthes: Small to moderate-sized; coarsely sculptured, sparsely hairy,

w robust andreniform or apiform, with yellow integumental tergal bands; forewings often folded

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
wv longitudinally like those of vespid wasps (Danforth and Michener 1988). Uncommon. Xeric
neotropical regions, South America, Nicaragua to western Mexico (Oaxaca to Nayarit), north to

~ southern Arizona. Nests unknown but presumbly excavated in soil. Usually associated with

~ mimosoid legumes. Revisions: Michener (1963, 1985b). (couplet 123)

~ Xeromelissinae (synonym: Chilicolinae)

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ 106. Chilicola Spinola: Minute to small; slender, nonhairy, hylaeiform; black, without yellow

wu marks except on clypeus of some males; glossa broadly truncate; scopa limited, sparse on hind
femora and perhaps tibiae, better developed on S1—-S3 (especially S2). Uncommon in our area.

~ Neotropical, in xeric or montane regions, north to states of Hidalgo and Jalisco, also Lesser

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ Antilles. Nests in stems and holes in wood. Revisions: Michener (1994); Toro and Michener

kg (1975). See Packer (2008) and Almeida et al. (2008) for phylogenetic analyses of
Xeromelissinae. Packer (2008) provides a revised subgeneric classification and a key to the

~ subgenera of Chilicola. (couplet 177)

v Family Halictidae

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
v Family Halictidae

~ Glossa short to rather long, pointed, without flabellum. Labial palpus with segments similar,

~ none of them elongate and sheathlike or first sometimes elongate. Mentum membranous; lorum

Ww weakly sclerotized or sclerotized only laterally; mentum and lorum not forming lobe projecting

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content: _ behind proboscis (Michener 1985a). Lacinia a small lobe on base of proboscis, well separated

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
from rest of maxilla (Michener and Greenberg 1985). One subantennal suture. Facial fovea
absent. See Moure and Hurd (1987) for a catalog of species of the Western Hemisphere. ~
NOTES ON THE BIOLOGY, PHYLOGENY, AND CLASSIFICATION. The family Halictidae
includes a diverse array of solitary, communal, semisocial, primitively eusocial, brood parasitic ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
and socially parasitic species. The largest genus, Lasioglossum, includes over 400 species in ~
North America and is a model for understanding the evolution of social behavior in bees (Gibbs Y
et al. 2012). Molecular phylogenetic studies have provided a powerful tool for understanding YU
phylogenetic relationships among subfamilies, tribes, and genera in this difficult group (Danforth

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
et al. 2004, 2008, Patiny et al. 2008, Gibbs et al. 2012). ~
Halictinae: Augochlorini UY
The tribe Augochlorini was originally revised by Eickwort (1969) and, later, Engel (2000). The
phylogeny of Augochlorini was analyzed most recently by Goncalves (2016) based on molecular a
and morphological data. We follow the Goncalves (2016) generic classification below. ad

any pronotal or anterior scutal modifications and in the nonpetiolate metasoma of males. The ww

provide a phylogenetic analysis of the species with an examination of nesting and sociality. ~

The subgeneric classification of Lasioglossum has been extraordinarily difficult to resolve and bed
highly unstable. Gibbs (Gibbs 2018 and Gibbs et al. 2013) recently developed a classification Y
based on a robust phylogeny for the genus that recognizes 8 subgenera in North America: U

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
Lasioglossum s.str., Leucalictus, Dialictus, Eickwortia, Evylaeus, Hemihalictus, Sphecodogastra,
and Habralictellus. The latter is likely a deriviative of Hemihalictus s.l. Socially parasitic species bal
previously placed in Paralictus are polyphletic and now included within Dialictus. In general, Y
the subgenera Dialictus, Evylaeus, and Sphecodogastra include many primitively eusocial ws

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:

of Lasioglossum species nest in the soil but a few species of Dialictus have switched to nesting ~
in soft, pulpy, rotting wood (e.g., Lasioglossum [Dialictus] coeruleum). For keys to the species bd
within our area, see: McGinley (1986) for Lasioglossum sensu stricto; Gibbs (2010 and 2011) for w

130. Microsphecodes Eickwort and Stage: Similar to minute Sphecodes in appearance but often UY
paler in color; sculpturing often weaker than usual in Sphecodes; free part of marginal cell three
times as long as part subtended by submarginal cells. Rare. Widespread in neotropical region, as al
far north as Guatemala (Packer et al. in press?). Brood parasites or social parasites in nests of ad

Habermannovéa et al. (2013) suggests that Microsphecodes arose from within Austrosphecodes, a
Neotropical lineage of Sphecodes s./. Due to its current usage and distinctive form, we recognize ~
Microsphecodes here at the generic level until a more robust classification is available. Revision: nd

hair bands; punctation of most species very coarse, as is pitting at base of propodeum. Extremely
broad head (couplet 52) is distinctive. Common in temperate regions, uncommon in tropics. ~

Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.

Boreal to tropical, Canada to Panama and Antilles (cosmopolitan). Sphecodes s./. is rendered bad

within our Sphecodes s./. Some characters used to define Melissocleptis, like the short scape, also

~ Nomiinae

~ The subfamily Nomiinae includes solitary or communal, ground-nesting bees. They are most

‘oS diverse in the Old-World tropics with many genera in tropical Africa and Asia (Michener 2007).
In our area, we have only two genera: Dieunomia (tribe Dieunomiini) and Nomia (tribe

bead Nomiini). Bossert et al. (2021) published a phylogeny of Nomiinae which supports the two

ww tribes.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.

ww tribes.

~ 134. Dieunomia Cockerell: Moderate-sized to large; andreniform; usually with apical tergal hair

~ bands, without colored integumental bands; metasoma sometimes partly or wholly red. Common

a in central and southwestern USA, elsewhere uncommon. Nests excavated in soil, all oligolectic

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.

alfalfa pollination. Common, western USA, elsewhere in our area uncommon. USA south to

- Veracruz and Guerrero, not or scarcely in tropics; Antilles (cosmopolitan except South America).

— Revision: Ribble (1965). (couplet 36)

-—

Family Megachilidae w
Proboscis as in Apidae. One subantennal suture. Facial fovea absent. Labrum longer than broad ~
and widened to broad articulation with clypeus. Two submarginal cells in forewing, usually ~
about equal in length. Pygidial plate usually absent. ww
—
NOTES ON THE BIOLOGY, PHYLOGENY, AND CLASSIFICATION. Megachilidae had

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
includes both solitary and brood parasitic groups. Among the solitary species there is an os
extraordinary diversity of nesting habits, including wood-nesters, stem and cavity nesters that use ee
leaves, flower petals, plant fibers, and resins to build their nests, and even above-ground builders
that use resins, sand, and stones (Danforth et al. 2019 provides an overview of the varied nesting -

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
habits in this family). Floral preferences range from broadly polylectic species to narrow host- ~
plant specialists. The phylogeny and classification of Megachilidae has undergone significant ed
revisions due to analyses of morphological and molecular data. Higher level classification was
revised by Litman et al. (2011) and Gonzalez et al. (2012). Generic relationships in Osmiini were ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
reanalyzed by Praz et al. (2008), in Anthidiini by Litman et al. (2016), and in Megachilini by =
Trunz et al. (2016) . We follow these studies in our classification of North and Central American ee
bees (Table 2-1). w

147. Austrostelis Michener and Griswold: Small heriadiform bees; flat projection at the apex of

group ranges northward to central Mexico (San Luis Postosi). Austrostelis was originally treated ~
as a subgenus of Hoplostelis (Michener & Griswold 1994) but has since been elevated to generic S

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:

Stelis), female Austrostelis lack a scopa. Hosts are largely unknown, except for one confirmed ~
record of Austrostelis catamarcensis emerging from nests of Epanthidium tigrinum (Zanella & ~
Ferreira 2005). Revision: Parizotto et al. (2018); see also Michener and Griswold (1994). vw

168. Osmia Panzer: Small to moderate-sized, rarely large, megachiliform [Fig. 472], usually bal
metallic (sometimes brilliantly so like chrysidids or Augochlora), rarely black in boreal and Ww
montane environments, usually without appreciable tergal hair bands. Common in western North U
America (rare in deserts), moderately common in east, uncommon in Mexico. This is the largest

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
osmiine genus in our area with over 148 species. Alaska, Canadian northern territories, south ~
through most of Canada, entire USA and mountains of Mexico to Costa Rica; some desert ~
species in northwestern Mexico and southwestern USA; absent in tropics (holarctic). Females w
exhibit diverse nesting habitats. Nests can be constructed in pre-existing cavities, old nests

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.

nests de novo in sand, soil or even dung pats; others construct exposed nests. Females construct ”
brood cells using a pulp of finely masticated leaf tissue, mud. or a combination of leaf masticate ~

~ arms slender as in long-tongued bees; mentum and lorum forming long lobe projecting behind

~ proboscis when proboscis is folded. One subantennal suture. Facial fovea absent.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 2 in the manuscript by John I Huber, published in MMD, focuses on the anatomical features of the head capsule in a specified insect species. The figure provides a detailed illustration of the malar area, which is defined as the space between the eye and the mandible. The malar area's significance lies in its use for taxonomic differentiation, as its length is measured as the shortest distance from the eye to the base of the mandible. Additionally, the figure highlights the foveae on the face and the sides of the second metasomal tergum (T2). These foveae are depicted as shallow depressions and are typically black in color, serving as critical identifiers for species classification. This visual representation aids in understanding the spatial relationships and morphological characteristics critical for scientific and educational purposes in entomology.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 3 from the manuscript by John I Huber in the journal MMD focuses on the anatomical features of the bee's head, particularly the genal area and the preoccipital ridge. This figure provides a detailed illustration of the bee's head highlighting the genal area, which is located behind the eye and in front of the preoccipital ridge. The preoccipital ridge itself is depicted as a prominent structure encircling the posterior part of the head, characterized by its concavity and sometimes featuring a preoccipital carina, which is a ridge found on the preoccipital ridge. Additionally, the figure includes a depiction of the proboscidial fossa, a significant groove on the underside of the head where the proboscis retracts. This visual representation is crucial for understanding the spatial relationships and morphological details of these components, which are essential for studies related to bee anatomy and physiology. The clear labeling and distinct illustration of each part make this figure a valuable resource for researchers focusing on entomological and anatomical studies of bees.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 4, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, focuses on the anatomical details of the malar area in an insect head capsule. This figure is pivotal for understanding the spatial relationship between the eye and the mandible of the insect, highlighting the shortest distance from the eye to the mandible and the width of the base of the mandible. Additionally, it illustrates the genal area, which is located behind the eye and in front of the preoccipital ridge. The figure effectively delineates the boundaries and features of these areas, crucial for studies in entomology related to insect head morphology. The clear labeling and detailed depiction serve as a valuable reference for identifying and comparing these anatomical features across different insect species.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 5, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the detailed anatomy of bee mandibles, focusing on their structural components as per the naming conventions of Michener and Fraser (1978). This figure is central to understanding the functional morphology of bee mouthparts, specifically highlighting the mandibles used for chewing. Key labeled components include the preapical teeth and various other mandibular structures, each annotated clearly to show their relative positions and interactions. These components are crucial for the bees' ability to process food materials, playing a significant role in their feeding mechanism which involves both lapping and sucking nectar. The diagram serves as an essential reference for entomologists and researchers studying hymenopteran mouthpart mechanics and their evolutionary adaptations.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 6, sourced from MMD and authored by John I. Huber, illustrates the specialized structure of bee mouthparts, focusing particularly on the labial palpus. This figure is essential for understanding the morphological differences in the labial palpus among various bee families. It specifically highlights the first two segments of the labial palpus, which are depicted as elongated, flattened, and sheath-like, contrasting sharply with the shorter, more typical last two segments. This configuration is significant as it demonstrates adaptation in the feeding mechanism of bees, supporting efficient nectar and pollen collection. The detailed labeling and differentiation in the figure provide a clear visual comparison, aiding in the identification and study of bee species based on mouthpart morphology. This figure is a key reference for entomologists and researchers studying the functional anatomy and evolutionary biology of bees.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 7, as presented in the Molecular and Morphological Diversity (MMD) publication by John I. Huber, focuses on the detailed anatomy of bee mouthparts, specifically highlighting the maxillary palpus and the clypeus. This figure is essential for understanding the morphological variations and functional aspects of these components. The maxillary palpus, depicted with six distinct segments, plays a crucial role in sensory functions, allowing bees to taste and manipulate their environment. The clypeus, shown with a strongly irregular rugosopunctate texture, is significant for its protective role and its involvement in the structural integrity of the head. This figure serves as a critical reference for entomologists and researchers studying the intricate structures and evolutionary adaptations of bee mouthparts.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 7, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, visually details the complex structure of bee mouthparts, specifically focusing on the maxillary palpus and its connection to the surrounding components. This figure is central to understanding the functional morphology of bee feeding mechanisms. It illustrates a six-segmented maxillary palpus, each segment distinctly labeled and differentiated by size and shape, which highlights its articulation and potential for movement. Adjacent to the maxillary palpus, the figure also shows the clypeus characterized by a strongly irregular rugosopunctate texture, providing insights into the tactile interfaces of the bee's mouthparts. The detailed labeling and clear depiction serve as a crucial reference for entomologists studying the anatomical precision of bee feeding apparatus and its evolutionary adaptations. This figure encapsulates key anatomical features that are essential for grasping the mechanical and sensory capabilities of bee mouthparts.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 7, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the detailed anatomy of bee mouthparts, focusing on the maxillary palpus and the clypeus. The figure is a close-up view highlighting the maxillary palpus, which is notably segmented into six parts, and the clypeus, characterized by its strongly irregular rugosopunctate texture. These components are crucial for understanding the feeding mechanics and sensory capabilities of bees. The maxillary palpus, with its multiple segments, suggests flexibility and potential for fine sensory functions, while the textured clypeus may play a role in protection and sensory input. This figure is essential for entomologists studying insect morphology, particularly those interested in the functional adaptations of bee mouthparts.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 8, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the unique morphology of the glossa and labial palpus in the Colletidae family of bees, contrasting with other bee families. This figure is pivotal for understanding the structural adaptations in bee mouthparts, specifically focusing on the Colletidae compared to long-tongued bees such as Apidae and Megachilidae. The glossa in Colletidae is depicted as broader and less elongate than in other families, which typically feature a slender and elongate glossa. Additionally, the labial palpal segments in Colletidae are shown as similar and cylindrical, which contrasts with the varying segment morphology seen in other bee families where the first two segments can be distinctly different. This figure effectively highlights the evolutionary diversification in mouthpart structures among different bee families, emphasizing the functional and ecological implications of these variations.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 9, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the detailed anatomy of bee mouthparts, specifically focusing on the proboscis mechanism. This figure is crucial for understanding how bees ingest nectar and other liquids, a key aspect of their feeding behavior and ecological role. The diagram clearly labels and highlights several critical components: the glossa, which is the central tongue-like structure used for sucking up nectar; the labial palps, which help in manipulating the proboscis; and the maxillae, which support the glossa and contain sensory hairs. This figure is essential for entomologists and biologists studying insect anatomy and feeding mechanisms.

The figure also highlights the radial vein, an essential component for wing strength and flexibility. This diagram is significant for entomologists studying wing morphology and its implications on the flight capabilities and evolutionary adaptations of Lasioglossum bees. The clear labeling and focused depiction provide a valuable visual reference for understanding the complex venation patterns typical of this genus.

This guide is intended to familiarize the reader
with the families of Hymenoptera, not hymen-
opteran morphology. We therefore attempt to use
the simplest acceptable terms for structures. Terms Gi
used in the keys are defined and illustrated in the
glossary. A brief overview of hymenopteran
morphology, accompanied by labeled drawings of
bodies and wings representing some major groups

Title: Hymenoptera of the World
Author: Charles D. Michener
Text Content:
When the reader goes beyond this guide to
identify specimens to the level of genus or species, a
plethora of other, often synonymous, morphological
terms will be encountered. In part, this occurs
because over many years various terms have been
replaced by more exact or more generalized terms
and different terms have been applied to
homologous structures in various groups.

USA. 840 pp.
The most comprehensive reference book in
English for entomological terms.

Title: Hymenoptera of the World

Title: Hymenoptera of the World
Author: Charles D. Michener

A general work on insect morphology.
