Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Pararhophitini (Megachilidae), Based on Adult Females: One subantennal suture below each antenna (Fig. 332d)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Pararhophitini (Megachilidae), Based on Adult Females: Body largely yellow; labrum with basolateral angles strongly developed, thus broadest at extreme base where articulated to clypeus (as in Fig. 33-2a); subantennal suture short, directed toward outer margin of antennal socket (pygidial and prepygidial ﬁmbriae absent) (Palearctic deserts)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Rophitinae (Halictidae), Based on Adult Females: Scopa, consisting of hairs for carrying pollen, present (Figs. 6-4, 8-5b, 8-7b, 10-11a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Rophitinae (Halictidae), Based on Adult Females: Scopa variable, but hairs not erect, not longest, and branched on S2

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Rophitinae (Halictidae), Based on Adult Females: Scopa on hind legs (Figs. 6-4, 8-5b, 10-11a), sometimes also on sterna

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Rophitinae (Halictidae), Based on Adult Females: Scopa (sometimes as a tibial corbicula) on hind tibia and usually basitarsus, elsewhere not well developed, tibial scopa thus looking considerably larger than that of femur (Figs. 6-4, 10-11a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Rophitinae (Halictidae), Based on Adult Females: Facial fovea absent or vaguely deﬁned; one subantennal suture below each antenna (Fig. 33-2d) or if two, then the two nearly meeting on clypeal margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Rophitinae (Halictidae), Based on Adult Females: One subantennal suture below each antenna (Fig. 332d)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Rophitinae (Halictidae), Based on Adult Females: Body usually exhibiting little or no yellow; labrum with basolateral angles little developed, thus not broadest at extreme base and articulation with clypeus shorter (as in Fig. 33-2b); subantennal suture usually directed toward middle or inner margins of antennal socket

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Rophitinae (Halictidae), Based on Adult Females: Episternal groove extending below scrobal groove (as in Fig. 20-5b) although frequently shallow (antennae arising below middle of face)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Stenotritidae, Based on Adult Females: Glossa short, apex broadly rounded (inner hind tibial spur pectinate) (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Apidae, Based on Adult Females: L-T bees, ﬁrst two segments of labial palpus elongate, ﬂattened (Figs. 10-4a, 19-1b); episternal groove commonly present down to or curving into and joining scrobal groove (Fig. 20-5c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Melittidae, Based on Adult Females: S-T bees, ﬁrst two segments of labial palpus similar in form to subsequent segments (Figs. 10-4c, 19-5b); episternal groove almost completely absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Andreninae (Andrenidae), Based on Adult Females: Facial fovea well developed, covered with short hairs (two subantennal sutures below each antenna, often difﬁcult to see) (Fig. 33-2c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family 13 13(12). Stigma absent (Fig. 60-2a); two subantennal sutures below each antenna (as in Fig. 51-1a) (Western Hemi- sphere) .......................... Oxaeinae (Andrenidae), Based on Adult Females: Facial fovea absent or not well deﬁned, not bearing distinctive short hairs, but if deﬁned, then bare

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Diphaglossinae (Colletidae), Based on Adult Females: Stigma almost always shorter than prestigma, vein r arising almost at its apex, margin of stigma in marginal cell concave or straight and not much longer than width of stigma (Fig. 43-1); large, robust, euceriform, hairy bees (Western Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Nomiinae (Halictidae), Based on Adult Females: Episternal groove extending little below scrobal groove

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Colletinae (Colletidae), Based on Adult Females: Basal vein only feebly arcuate (Fig. 39-5); glossa bilobed (Fig. 19-2a, b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Halictinae (Halictidae), Based on Adult Females: Glossa pointed (Fig. 19-2c, d); basal vein strongly curved (Fig. 65-5); submarginal cells usually three

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Nomioidinae (Halictidae), Based on Adult Females: T5 with prepygidial ﬁmbria weak but continuous (Eastern Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Cleptoparasites in Halictinae, both tribes  (Halictidae), Based on Adult Females: Glossa pointed (Fig. 19-2c, d); basal vein strongly curved (Fig. 65-5); submarginal cells usually three

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Hylaeinae (Colletidae), Based on Adult Females: Scopa, consisting of hairs for carrying pollen, present (Figs. 6-4, 8-5b, 8-7b, 10-11a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Hylaeinae (Colletidae), Based on Adult Females: Supraclypeal area elevated abruptly above level of antennal sockets (Fig. 47-3a); pygidial plate usually absent, but ifpresent, then broad, its margins converging posteriorly; anterior surface of T1 usually lacking longitudinal median groove

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Euryglossinae (Colletidae), Based on Adult Females: Scopa, consisting of hairs for carrying pollen, present (Figs. 6-4, 8-5b, 8-7b, 10-11a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Euryglossinae (Colletidae), Based on Adult Females: Supraclypeal area sloping up from level of antennal sockets; pygidial plate present, the apical part slender, parallel-sided or spatulate; anterior surface of T1 with longitudinal median groove

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Nomadinae (Apidae), Based on Adult Females: Scopa, consisting of hairs for carrying pollen, present (Figs. 6-4, 8-5b, 8-7b, 10-11a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Nomadinae (Apidae), Based on Adult Females: S6 retracted under S5 except for apex, metasomal venter thus appearing to be ﬁve-segmented; apex of S6 bilobed, bifurcate, or produced to median spine, frequently bearing rows or clumps of stiff setae (Fig. 91-2)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Cleptoparasites in Megachilinae, all tribes  (Megachilidae), Based on Adult Females: Scopa, consisting of hairs for carrying pollen, present (Figs. 6-4, 8-5b, 8-7b, 10-11a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Cleptoparasites in Megachilinae, all tribes  (Megachilidae), Based on Adult Females: Labrum with basolateral angles strongly developed, labrum thus broad at extreme base, where articulated to clypeus (Fig. 33-2a); labral shape more or less rectangular and usually longer than broad (forewing with two submarginal cells)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Social parasites within Allodapini (Apidae), Based on Adult Females: Scopa, consisting of hairs for carrying pollen, present (Figs. 6-4, 8-5b, 8-7b, 10-11a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Social parasites within Allodapini (Apidae), Based on Adult Females: Epistomal suture between lateral extremity and subantennal suture arcuate, upper part of clypeus thus almost parallel-sided (Fig. 90-2); submarginal cells two (Eastern Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Cleptoparasites and social parasites within Apinae  (Apidae), Based on Adult Females: Scopa, consisting of hairs for carrying pollen, present (Figs. 6-4, 8-5b, 8-7b, 10-11a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Family Cleptoparasites and social parasites within Apinae  (Apidae), Based on Adult Females: Epistomal suture not arcuate upward in such a way that upper part of clypeus is almost parallel-sided; submarginal cells usually three

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ctenocolletes of the Stenotritidae: T7 of male usually with well-developed pygidial plate; S7 of male a transverse band sometimes broadened and produced apically at each side, leaving large median emargination (Fig. 36-1c), with hairs on apical margin or projections; basal elevation of labrum of female undivided; inner hind tibial spur of female thickest at basal onefourth to one-half, with long, coarse teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stenotritus of the Stenotritidae: T7 of male with bare area representing pygidial plate but not deﬁned by carinae; S7 of male with disc greatly reduced, connecting long laterobasal apodemes and a pair of hairy apical lobes (Fig. 36-1f); basal elevated area of labrum of female binodulose; inner hind tibial spur of female tapering from base, with moderate-sized to coarse teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Diphaglossinae, of the Colletidae: Body usually hairy, female with well-formed scopa enclosing corbicula on underside of hind femur; prepygidial ﬁmbria (apical hair band of T5) of female much stronger (hairs longer and denser) than hair bands (if any) of preceding terga, and T6 with abundant hair (pygidial ﬁmbria) lateral to pygidial plate (except in genera that lack both ﬁmbriae and pygidial plate); pygidial plate of female, if present, usually broad and tapering posteriorly; forewing with three submarginal cells or, if two, then second at least two-thirds as long as ﬁrst, as though second submarginal crossvein is lost; distal submarginal crossvein sinuate, at acute angle to distal part of radial sector forming free part of marginal cell (Fig. 38-17)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Diphaglossinae, of the Colletidae: Stigma small, shorter than prestigma, as wide as prestigma measured to costal wing margin (Figs. 43-1, 44-1, 45-1); glossa deeply biﬁd with apical lobes commonly directed strongly apicolaterally (Western Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Colletinae, of the Colletidae: Body usually hairy, female with well-formed scopa enclosing corbicula on underside of hind femur; prepygidial ﬁmbria (apical hair band of T5) of female much stronger (hairs longer and denser) than hair bands (if any) of preceding terga, and T6 with abundant hair (pygidial ﬁmbria) lateral to pygidial plate (except in genera that lack both ﬁmbriae and pygidial plate); pygidial plate of female, if present, usually broad and tapering posteriorly; forewing with three submarginal cells or, if two, then second at least two-thirds as long as ﬁrst, as though second submarginal crossvein is lost; distal submarginal crossvein sinuate, at acute angle to distal part of radial sector forming free part of marginal cell (Fig. 38-17)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Colletinae, of the Colletidae: Stigma usually large, at least longer than prestigma, usually wider than prestigma measured to wing margin (Figs. 39-2a, 39-5, 39-11, 41-1); glossa weakly bilobed to deeply biﬁd but, if the latter, then lobes commonly directed more apicad than laterally (except apicolaterally in Leioproctus tomentosusHouston from Western Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xeromelissinae, of the Colletidae: Body with hairs short and relatively sparse, female lacking scopa or with a sparse or short scopa forming corbicula on underside of hind femur; prepygidial and pygidial ﬁmbriae of female nearly always absent; pygidial plate of female absent or, if present, then usually narrow and parallel-sided posteriorly, or spinelike; forewing with two submarginal cells, second usually much shorter than ﬁrst, as though ﬁrst submarginal crossvein is lost; second submarginal crossvein usually not sinuate, usually at right or obtuse angle to distal part of radial sector (Fig. 47-2)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xeromelissinae, of the Colletidae: Facial fovea absent or broad, at least one-third as wide as long; female with sparse scopa on S1 to S3 and outlining ventral corbicula on hind femur (Fig. 43-1); longitudinal part of hypostomal carina usually longer than clypeus but, if not, then clypeus protuberant and its lower lateral extremities bent back around ends of labrum (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Hylaeinae, of the Colletidae: Body with hairs short and relatively sparse, female lacking scopa or with a sparse or short scopa forming corbicula on underside of hind femur; prepygidial and pygidial ﬁmbriae of female nearly always absent; pygidial plate of female absent or, if present, then usually narrow and parallel-sided posteriorly, or spinelike; forewing with two submarginal cells, second usually much shorter than ﬁrst, as though ﬁrst submarginal crossvein is lost; second submarginal crossvein usually not sinuate, usually at right or obtuse angle to distal part of radial sector (Fig. 47-2)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Hylaeinae, of the Colletidae: Facial fovea usually a narrow groove, sometimes a broader area, wider than diameter of scape, absent in a few females and some males (Figs. 47-4, 47-6, 47-7); scopa absent; longitudinal part of hypostomal carina usually not longer than clypeus; clypeus usually not protuberant, not much bent back around ends of labrum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Hylaeinae, of the Colletidae: Supraclypeal area elevated abruptly above level of antennal socket (Fig 47-3a); pygidial and basitibial plates usually absent but, if present (as in a few Australian and New Guinea species), then pygidial plate of female broad, its margins converging posteriorly; anterior surface of T1 usually without longitudinal median groove; posterior (lower) surface of prementum with longitudinal, usually spiculate depression or fovea (Fig. 41-3a) (weak in a few males) margined by ridges that diverge on basal half of prementum and meet near base of subligular process

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Euryglossinae, of the Colletidae: Body with hairs short and relatively sparse, female lacking scopa or with a sparse or short scopa forming corbicula on underside of hind femur; prepygidial and pygidial ﬁmbriae of female nearly always absent; pygidial plate of female absent or, if present, then usually narrow and parallel-sided posteriorly, or spinelike; forewing with two submarginal cells, second usually much shorter than ﬁrst, as though ﬁrst submarginal crossvein is lost; second submarginal crossvein usually not sinuate, usually at right or obtuse angle to distal part of radial sector (Fig. 47-2)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Euryglossinae, of the Colletidae: Facial fovea usually a narrow groove, sometimes a broader area, wider than diameter of scape, absent in a few females and some males (Figs. 47-4, 47-6, 47-7); scopa absent; longitudinal part of hypostomal carina usually not longer than clypeus; clypeus usually not protuberant, not much bent back around ends of labrum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Euryglossinae, of the Colletidae: Supraclypeal area sloping up from level of antennal socket; apical part of pygidial plate of female slender, sometimes a spine, its margins parallel or converging slightly toward apex or spatulate; basitibial plate usually indicated in female, sometimes only by one or more tubercles; anterior surface of T1 with longitudinal median groove; posterior (lower) surface of prementum lacking longitudinal medial fovea but with comparable spiculate area (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Scraptrini, of the Colletinae: Basitibial and pygidial plates present, at least in females (pygidial plate absent in most males; basitibial plate absent in both sexes of a few Australian taxa); prepygidial and pygidial ﬁmbriae of female present; S7 of male with apicolateral lobes of moderate size (Figs. 13-2a; 39-1, -3, -7, -9, -10, etc.) (sometimes greatly reduced or absent), disc of sternum and apodemes thus constituting the major part of S7

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Scraptrini, of the Colletinae: Posterior (lower) surface of prementum with a broad longitudinal depression or fovea margined by shiny ridges (Fig. 41-3b) that diverge on basal part of prementum and converge near base of subligular process; galeal comb reduced to three or four small bristles (Fig. 41-2b) (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Paracolletini, of the Colletinae: Basitibial and pygidial plates present, at least in females (pygidial plate absent in most males; basitibial plate absent in both sexes of a few Australian taxa); prepygidial and pygidial ﬁmbriae of female present; S7 of male with apicolateral lobes of moderate size (Figs. 13-2a; 39-1, -3, -7, -9, -10, etc.) (sometimes greatly reduced or absent), disc of sternum and apodemes thus constituting the major part of S7

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Paracolletini, of the Colletinae: Posterior (lower) surface of prementum lacking a fovea or with only a narrow medial groove; galeal comb usually well developed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eulonchopria of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Preoccipital carina strong, often lamella-like; pronotum dorsolaterally with strong transverse carina or lamella extending onto pronotal lobe; hind tibial hairs of female shorter than tibial diameter (neotropical to Arizona)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Lonchorhyncha of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Preoccipital and pronotal carinae (or lamellae) absent; many hind tibial hairs of female as long as or longer than tibial diameter

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Lonchorhyncha of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Malar space nearly as long as or longer than eye; S8 of male weakly sclerotized, lacking apical process (Fig. 3913c) (Ecuador)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Niltonia of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Preoccipital and pronotal carinae (or lamellae) absent; many hind tibial hairs of female as long as or longer than tibial diameter

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Niltonia of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Malar space little if any longer than ﬂagellar width, usually virtually absent; S8 of male with strong median apical process

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Niltonia of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Labial palpi enormous, 8-9 mm long, in repose reaching S3 or S4; claws of both sexes deeply cleft, the two rami similar in shape and of almost equal length (Brazil)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Lonchopria of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Preoccipital and pronotal carinae (or lamellae) absent; many hind tibial hairs of female as long as or longer than tibial diameter

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Lonchopria of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Malar space little if any longer than ﬂagellar width, usually virtually absent; S8 of male with strong median apical process

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Lonchopria of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Labial palpi unremarkable; claws with inner rami shorter than outer and differently shaped, at least in female, or, rarely, claws simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Lonchopria of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with three submarginal cells, second usually about as long as third on posterior margin (but see subgenus Lonchoprias. str.); apical process of S8 of male lacking ﬂat apical region resembling a pygidial plate; inner hind tibial spur of female coarsely palmate-pectinate, bases of teeth close together and diverging from thick part of spur (Fig. 39-8e); tibial scopa (except in subgenus Lonchoprella) extremely dense, hiding tibial surface; hind basitarsus of female weakly concave on outer surface near upper margin, this surface unlike that of tibia in appearance, the surface easily visible among hairs that are usually shorter than those of inner surface (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Brachyglossula of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Preoccipital and pronotal carinae (or lamellae) absent; many hind tibial hairs of female as long as or longer than tibial diameter

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Brachyglossula of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Malar space little if any longer than ﬂagellar width, usually virtually absent; S8 of male with strong median apical process

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Brachyglossula of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Labial palpi unremarkable; claws with inner rami shorter than outer and differently shaped, at least in female, or, rarely, claws simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Brachyglossula of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two or three submarginal cells, if with three, then second much shorter than third on posterior margin (except in Leioproctus subgenus Cephalocolletes and most specimens of subgenus Reedapis); apical process of S8 of male with ﬂat, bare apical region on upper side, superﬁcially resembling a pygidial plate and usually exposed at apex of metasoma; inner hind tibial spur of female ciliate to coarsely pectinate, not at all palmate and not thickened medially; scopa not hiding tibial surface; hind basitarsus of female ﬂat or convex on outer surface, this surface superﬁcially similar to that of tibia, its hairs longer than those of inner surface (ignoring hairs of upper margin)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Brachyglossula of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Stigma small, vein r arising well beyond middle; costal margin of marginal cell 2.5-3.0 times as long as stigma; propodeum almost wholly declivous in proﬁle; volsella of male large, vertically expanded, reaching dorsum of genital capsule, biﬁd (Fig. 39-1a); mandible of male tridentate (Fig. 39-1e) [middle and both hind tibial spurs strongly curved and coarsely pectinate (Fig. 39-8d) or outer hind spur of male sometimes dentate or almost simple; forewing with two submarginal cells] (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Leioproctus (in part) of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Preoccipital and pronotal carinae (or lamellae) absent; many hind tibial hairs of female as long as or longer than tibial diameter

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Leioproctus (in part) of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Malar space little if any longer than ﬂagellar width, usually virtually absent; S8 of male with strong median apical process

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Leioproctus (in part) of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Labial palpi unremarkable; claws with inner rami shorter than outer and differently shaped, at least in female, or, rarely, claws simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Leioproctus (in part) of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two or three submarginal cells, if with three, then second much shorter than third on posterior margin (except in Leioproctus subgenus Cephalocolletes and most specimens of subgenus Reedapis); apical process of S8 of male with ﬂat, bare apical region on upper side, superﬁcially resembling a pygidial plate and usually exposed at apex of metasoma; inner hind tibial spur of female ciliate to coarsely pectinate, not at all palmate and not thickened medially; scopa not hiding tibial surface; hind basitarsus of female ﬂat or convex on outer surface, this surface superﬁcially similar to that of tibia, its hairs longer than those of inner surface (ignoring hairs of upper margin)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Leioproctus (in part) of Paracolletini of the WesternHemisphere: Stigma elongate, vein r arising at or slightly beyond middle (Fig. 39-5d-l); costal margin of marginal cell 1.5-2.0 times as long as stigma; propodeum usually with subhorizontal or sloping basal part curving onto steeply declivous posterior surface; volsella of male more or less horizontal, ventral, not attaining dorsum of genital capsule; mandible of male simple or bidentate (tibial spurs not curved and coarsely pectinate, or, ifso, as in some species of subgenus Reedapis, then forewing with three submarginal cells) (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Callomelitta of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Marginal cell with apex on wing margin (Fig. 39-2a); facial fovea linear or nearly so (often very short or absent in male); mandible of female two to three times as long as basal width, ending in three equally conspicuous teeth; pygidial plate of female with lateral margins concave, the apex very slender and parallel-sided (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paracolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Marginal cell bent away from wing margin at apex (Figs. 39-5, 39-11), sometimes, as in Leioproctus (Euryglossidia), only slightly so; facial fovea broad or absent; mandible of female usually four or more times as long as basal width, bidentate, lower tooth much longer than upper (upper tooth bilobed, giving a tridentate appearance, inParacolletes); pygidial plate of female with lateral margins not strongly concave, apex neither slender nor parallel-sided (except in a few Leioproctus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paracolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Stigma small, parallel-sided, truncated (in some cases obliquely) at base of vein r or rarely shortly beyond that point, not or scarcely tapering to apex within marginal cell; marginal cell on costal edge of wing 2.75 to 5.0 times as long as stigma; bare part of labrum uniformly convex, one to ﬁve times as broad as long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paracolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Inner hind tibial spur of female ﬁnely serrate, rarely ﬁnely pectinate with slender teeth of approximately uniform length arising from a shaft that tapers rather uniformly toward apex (as in Fig. 39-8c); basitibial plate of female and sometimes of male fully deﬁned, in some cases visible without removal of hairs, apex of plate rounded or blunt (angulate in Paracolletes montanus Rayment); mandible slender near base, usually expanded apically, female with upper apical tooth bidentate in unworn mandibles, mandibular apex of female thus tridentate; eyes parallel or converging below (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Trichocolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Marginal cell bent away from wing margin at apex (Figs. 39-5, 39-11), sometimes, as in Leioproctus (Euryglossidia), only slightly so; facial fovea broad or absent; mandible of female usually four or more times as long as basal width, bidentate, lower tooth much longer than upper (upper tooth bilobed, giving a tridentate appearance, inParacolletes); pygidial plate of female with lateral margins not strongly concave, apex neither slender nor parallel-sided (except in a few Leioproctus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Trichocolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Stigma small, parallel-sided, truncated (in some cases obliquely) at base of vein r or rarely shortly beyond that point, not or scarcely tapering to apex within marginal cell; marginal cell on costal edge of wing 2.75 to 5.0 times as long as stigma; bare part of labrum uniformly convex, one to ﬁve times as broad as long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Trichocolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Inner hind tibial spur of female coarsely pectinate, shaft thick near base and narrowing in region where most of teeth arise (Fig. 39-8f); basitibial plate of female deﬁned only along posterior margin, or, at least apex not deﬁned, plate never visible without removal of hairs; basitibial plate of male variable, acutely pointed if deﬁned; mandible approximately parallel-sided, apex bidentate; eyes often diverging below (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Neopasiphae of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Marginal cell bent away from wing margin at apex (Figs. 39-5, 39-11), sometimes, as in Leioproctus (Euryglossidia), only slightly so; facial fovea broad or absent; mandible of female usually four or more times as long as basal width, bidentate, lower tooth much longer than upper (upper tooth bilobed, giving a tridentate appearance, inParacolletes); pygidial plate of female with lateral margins not strongly concave, apex neither slender nor parallel-sided (except in a few Leioproctus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Neopasiphae of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Stigma usually larger (Fig. 39-5) and usually not parallel-sided, apex usually tapering to a point on costal edge of marginal cell, vein r thus arising near middle of stigma; marginal cell on costal edge of wing 1.3 to 2.5 times as long as stigma; bare part of labrum usually with transverse ridge or otherwise not uniformly convex, usually more than ﬁve times as broad as long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Neopasiphae of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Metasoma with transverse, pale-yellow, integumental bands, broken or narrowed sublaterally, on subapical parts of terga; clypeus yellow in both sexes; scape of male greatly broadened (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Phenacolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Marginal cell bent away from wing margin at apex (Figs. 39-5, 39-11), sometimes, as in Leioproctus (Euryglossidia), only slightly so; facial fovea broad or absent; mandible of female usually four or more times as long as basal width, bidentate, lower tooth much longer than upper (upper tooth bilobed, giving a tridentate appearance, inParacolletes); pygidial plate of female with lateral margins not strongly concave, apex neither slender nor parallel-sided (except in a few Leioproctus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Phenacolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Stigma usually larger (Fig. 39-5) and usually not parallel-sided, apex usually tapering to a point on costal edge of marginal cell, vein r thus arising near middle of stigma; marginal cell on costal edge of wing 1.3 to 2.5 times as long as stigma; bare part of labrum usually with transverse ridge or otherwise not uniformly convex, usually more than ﬁve times as broad as long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Phenacolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Metasoma without yellow integumental bands, yellowish-brown bands occasionally present but not emarginate or broken sublaterally; clypeus dark in female, rarely yellow in male; scape of male usually unmodiﬁed, sometimes thickened but not ﬂat

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Phenacolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Basal vein basal to cu-v of forewing; maxillary palpus about as long as width of galea, four-segmented; ﬁrst recurrent vein received near basal one-third or one-fourth of second submarginal cell (Fig. 39-5b) (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Glossurocolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: S8 of male with two ﬂat, delicate, apical processes, longer than body of sternum (Fig. 39-4b); supraclypeal area with longitudinal, strongly elevated, impunctate, shining carina or broad ridge extending from frontal carina down to upper margin of clypeus; distal three antennal segments of male modiﬁed (Fig. 39-4d) (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hesperocolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: S8 of male ending in the usual single, commonly heavily sclerotized, apical process; supraclypeal area broadly convex, median part sometimes impunctate; apical antennal segments of male unmodiﬁed or rarely crenulate, or last one rarely broadened and ﬂattened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hesperocolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Claws (at least of male, those of female unknown) each with broad, ﬂat inner ramus arising near base (Fig. 394g); episternal groove below scrobal groove represented only by weak, short depression; strong carina just behind posterior orbit (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chrysocolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: S8 of male ending in the usual single, commonly heavily sclerotized, apical process; supraclypeal area broadly convex, median part sometimes impunctate; apical antennal segments of male unmodiﬁed or rarely crenulate, or last one rarely broadened and ﬂattened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chrysocolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Claws cleft apically in male and usually in female, inner ramus pointed like outer ramus or sometimes in female reduced to a tooth or absent (in one undescribed species ofLeioproctus somewhat like those of Hesperocolletes); episternal groove distinct below scrobal groove; no strong carina behind posterior orbit

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chrysocolletes of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: S8 of male with median apical process slender and hairy at apex, pale, not exposed (Fig. 39-3b); volsella large, produced posteriorly, reaching beyond apex of articulated gonostylus (Fig. 39-3a); stigma less than onehalf as long as marginal cell, measured on wing margin (Fig. 39-5a); apex of marginal cell bent gradually from wing margin for about one-sixth length of cell and bearing long appendage; proﬁle of propodeum nearly vertical (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Leioproctus of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: S8 of male ending in the usual single, commonly heavily sclerotized, apical process; supraclypeal area broadly convex, median part sometimes impunctate; apical antennal segments of male unmodiﬁed or rarely crenulate, or last one rarely broadened and ﬂattened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Leioproctus of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: Claws cleft apically in male and usually in female, inner ramus pointed like outer ramus or sometimes in female reduced to a tooth or absent (in one undescribed species ofLeioproctus somewhat like those of Hesperocolletes); episternal groove distinct below scrobal groove; no strong carina behind posterior orbit

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Leioproctus of Paracolletini of the Australian Region: S8 of male with median apical process robust, heavily sclerotized (Fig. 39-6c, g), its apex suggesting a pygidial plate and commonly exposed in repose, or (in some species of subgenus Goniocolletes) process broadened and appearing as extension of elongated disc (Fig. 39-7e); volsella not reaching gonostylus or reaching only its basal part, gonostylus fused to gonocoxite; stigma usually larger; apex of marginal cell only minutely bent away from wing margin; proﬁle of propodeum usually with sloping or subhorizontal basal zone (Australian area)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Ethalonchopria) of Eulonchopria: Facial fovea absent; omaulus not carinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Eulonchopria s. str.) of Eulonchopria: Facial fovea distinct; omaulus carinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Nomiocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: T1-T4 in female and T1-T5 or T6 in male with enamellike apical marginal zones of yellowish, green, bluish, or whitish, these zones usually at least partly impunctate and hairless

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Halictanthrena) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Halictanthrena) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein distal to or rarely meeting ﬁrst sub-marginal crossvein; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex, the latter elevated above level of antennal sockets; hind tibial spurs slender, not strongly curved apically, outer one not coarsely toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Halictanthrena) of Leioproctus of South America: Dorsolateral angle of pronotum produced as small tooth projecting upward and outward (smallest in male); basitibial plate of female not easily seen because its hairs are erect, similar to those of adjacent parts of tibia, largely hiding marginal carinae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Reedapis) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Reedapis) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein distal to or rarely meeting ﬁrst sub-marginal crossvein; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex, the latter elevated above level of antennal sockets; hind tibial spurs slender, not strongly curved apically, outer one not coarsely toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Reedapis) of Leioproctus of South America: Propodeum with broad basal subhorizontal or horizontal zone, curving onto vertical posterior surface; stigma large, not parallel-sided, at least two-thirds as long as marginal cell on costal margin of wing (Fig. 39-5e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Reedapis) of Leioproctus of South America: Jugal lobe of hind wing short, not attaining level of cu-v (Fig. 39-5e); inner hind tibial spur of female usually pectinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Reedapis) of Leioproctus of South America: Mandible of male with preapical tooth; outer hind tibial spur of female pectinate, although more ﬁnely so than inner spur; metasoma with at least weak blue reﬂections

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Cephalocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Cephalocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein distal to or rarely meeting ﬁrst sub-marginal crossvein; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex, the latter elevated above level of antennal sockets; hind tibial spurs slender, not strongly curved apically, outer one not coarsely toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Cephalocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Propodeum with broad basal subhorizontal or horizontal zone, curving onto vertical posterior surface; stigma large, not parallel-sided, at least two-thirds as long as marginal cell on costal margin of wing (Fig. 39-5e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Cephalocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Jugal lobe of hind wing short, not attaining level of cu-v (Fig. 39-5e); inner hind tibial spur of female usually pectinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Cephalocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Mandible of male simple; outer hind tibial spur of female coarsely ciliate; metasoma black

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (T orocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (T orocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein distal to or rarely meeting ﬁrst sub-marginal crossvein; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex, the latter elevated above level of antennal sockets; hind tibial spurs slender, not strongly curved apically, outer one not coarsely toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (T orocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Propodeum with broad basal subhorizontal or horizontal zone, curving onto vertical posterior surface; stigma large, not parallel-sided, at least two-thirds as long as marginal cell on costal margin of wing (Fig. 39-5e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (T orocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Second submarginal cell on posterior margin much shorter than third (as in Fig. 39-5d, f ); second submarginal crossvein usually straight, at least not curved parallel to third, anterior margin of third submarginal cell usually less than two-thirds as long as posterior margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (T orocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Thorax dull, minutely roughened, almost lacking punctures; malar area as long as minimum diameter of ﬂagellum; clypeus protuberant in lateral view by fully eye width

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Holmbergeria) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Holmbergeria) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein distal to or rarely meeting ﬁrst sub-marginal crossvein; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex, the latter elevated above level of antennal sockets; hind tibial spurs slender, not strongly curved apically, outer one not coarsely toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Holmbergeria) of Leioproctus of South America: Propodeum with broad basal subhorizontal or horizontal zone, curving onto vertical posterior surface; stigma large, not parallel-sided, at least two-thirds as long as marginal cell on costal margin of wing (Fig. 39-5e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Holmbergeria) of Leioproctus of South America: Second submarginal cell on posterior margin much shorter than third (as in Fig. 39-5d, f ); second submarginal crossvein usually straight, at least not curved parallel to third, anterior margin of third submarginal cell usually less than two-thirds as long as posterior margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Holmbergeria) of Leioproctus of South America: Arolia present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Holmbergeria) of Leioproctus of South America: Basitibial plate present (but anterior side not deﬁned in one species of Lamprocolletes); pygidial plate of female broad, sides converging posteriorly [except in L. (Protomorpha) fallax (Cockerell)]; basal vein slanting 45 o or more to costal margin of wing, and much longer than ﬁrst abscissa of Rs (Fig. 39-5d-f )

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Holmbergeria) of Leioproctus of South America: Subantennal suture little over half as long as diameter of antennal socket; supraclypeal and subantennal areas impunctate, shining, hairless, in conspicuous contrast to adjacent areas

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leioproctus s. str.) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leioproctus s. str.) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein distal to or rarely meeting ﬁrst sub-marginal crossvein; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex, the latter elevated above level of antennal sockets; hind tibial spurs slender, not strongly curved apically, outer one not coarsely toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leioproctus s. str.) of Leioproctus of South America: Propodeum with broad basal subhorizontal or horizontal zone, curving onto vertical posterior surface; stigma large, not parallel-sided, at least two-thirds as long as marginal cell on costal margin of wing (Fig. 39-5e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leioproctus s. str.) of Leioproctus of South America: Second submarginal cell on posterior margin much shorter than third (as in Fig. 39-5d, f ); second submarginal crossvein usually straight, at least not curved parallel to third, anterior margin of third submarginal cell usually less than two-thirds as long as posterior margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leioproctus s. str.) of Leioproctus of South America: Arolia present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leioproctus s. str.) of Leioproctus of South America: Basitibial plate present (but anterior side not deﬁned in one species of Lamprocolletes); pygidial plate of female broad, sides converging posteriorly [except in L. (Protomorpha) fallax (Cockerell)]; basal vein slanting 45 o or more to costal margin of wing, and much longer than ﬁrst abscissa of Rs (Fig. 39-5d-f )

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leioproctus s. str.) of Leioproctus of South America: Clypeus and supraclypeal area not ﬂat, usually punctate, suture separating them distinct [weak or absent but whole area uniformly punctate in L. (Protomorpha) tarsalis Rayment]; anterior basitarsus of female with ordinary vestiture

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leioproctus s. str.) of Leioproctus of South America: Gonoforceps hairy to base; gonobase one-half as long as gonoforceps; apex of S6 with broad, shallow emargination; metasoma with pubescence all blackish

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Chilicolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: S2-S4 with apical bands of sparse, simple hairs not hiding surfaces of sterna

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sarocolletes) (in part) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sarocolletes) (in part) of Leioproctus of South America: Metasoma rather broad and ﬂattened, resembling that of female in shape

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Actenosigynes) of Leioproctus of South America: Inner hind tibial spur ﬁnely pectinate (almost ciliate) with over 25 teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Chilicolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: S2-S4 with apical bands of sparse, simple hairs not hiding surfaces of sterna

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sarocolletes) (in part) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sarocolletes) (in part) of Leioproctus of South America: Metasoma rather broad and ﬂattened, resembling that of female in shape

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Hoplocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Tibial scopal hairs dividing to form few major branches; the sternal scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Protodiscelis) of Leioproctus of South America: Glossal lobes not much longer than basal width; scopal hairs of tibia and sterna with numerous short, ﬁne branches (Fig. 13-1e); clypeal margin of male unmodiﬁed, truncate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (T etraglossula) of Leioproctus of South America: Glossa deeply divided, the lobes elongate, seven to ten times as long as basal width (as in Fig. 39-12); scopal hairs of tibia and sterna simple, or those of tibia with a few major branches; clypeal margin of male with short median lobe overhanging base of labrum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Glossopasiphae) of Leioproctus of South America: Glossa deeply biﬁd, lobes about ﬁve times as long as basal width (Fig. 39-12a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Pygopasiphae) of Leioproctus of South America: S2-S5 of female covered with short, unbranched, erect hairs enlarged and curved posteriorly at tips and of uniform length except longer on S2; pygidial plate of male deﬁned, at least posterior end limited by carina; hind tarsus of male elongate, segment 2 well over three times as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sarocolletes) (in part) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sarocolletes) (in part) of Leioproctus of South America: Metasoma rather broad and ﬂattened, resembling that of female in shape

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Perditomorpha)(in part) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Perditomorpha)(in part) of Leioproctus of South America: Inner rami of claws strong, longer than basal diameters of outer rami, claws thus biﬁd; body lacking metallic coloration

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Kylopasiphae) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Kylopasiphae) of Leioproctus of South America: T7 with shiny, hairless, irregularly rough pygidial area, not narrowed posteriorly, deﬁned across posterior border by weak carina, this area occupying much of dorsum of tergum; S7 with apical lobes much reduced, all in a single plane

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Spinolapis) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Spinolapis) of Leioproctus of South America: Body metallic bluish or greenish; margin of S6 produced midapically as rounded hairy lobe about one-third as wide as sternum, notched medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Perditomorpha)(in part) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Perditomorpha)(in part) of Leioproctus of South America: Inner rami of claws strong, longer than basal diameters of outer rami, claws thus biﬁd; body lacking metallic coloration

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Kylopasiphae) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Kylopasiphae) of Leioproctus of South America: T7 with shiny, hairless, irregularly rough pygidial area, not narrowed posteriorly, deﬁned across posterior border by weak carina, this area occupying much of dorsum of tergum; S7 with apical lobes much reduced, all in a single plane

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Spinolapis) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Spinolapis) of Leioproctus of South America: Body metallic bluish or greenish; margin of S6 produced midapically as rounded hairy lobe about one-third as wide as sternum, notched medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sarocolletes) (in part) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sarocolletes) (in part) of Leioproctus of South America: Metasoma rather broad and ﬂattened, resembling that of female in shape

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Perditomorpha) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Perditomorpha) of Leioproctus of South America: Metasoma commonly rather slender , not ﬂattened, usually distinctly different in shape from that of female

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Albinapis) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Albinapis) of Leioproctus of South America: Labial palpus 5-segmented; apicolateral lobes of S 7 of male small, rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Baeocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Baeocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein basal to ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (Fig. 39-5h); clypeus and supraclypeal area usually ﬂat, depressed, shining, largely impunctate; hind tibial spurs robust, curved apically, outer one nearly as coarsely toothed as inner

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Andrenopsis) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Andrenopsis) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein distal to or rarely meeting ﬁrst sub-marginal crossvein; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex, the latter elevated above level of antennal sockets; hind tibial spurs slender, not strongly curved apically, outer one not coarsely toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Andrenopsis) of Leioproctus of South America: Propodeum almost wholly vertical in proﬁle; stigma small, nearly parallel-sided, little more than half as long as marginal cell on costal margin of wing (Fig. 39-5g)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Colletellus) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Colletellus) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein distal to or rarely meeting ﬁrst sub-marginal crossvein; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex, the latter elevated above level of antennal sockets; hind tibial spurs slender, not strongly curved apically, outer one not coarsely toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Colletellus) of Leioproctus of South America: Propodeum with broad basal subhorizontal or horizontal zone, curving onto vertical posterior surface; stigma large, not parallel-sided, at least two-thirds as long as marginal cell on costal margin of wing (Fig. 39-5e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Colletellus) of Leioproctus of South America: Jugal lobe of hind wing extending well beyond level of cu-v; inner hind tibial spur of female ciliate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Filiglossa) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Filiglossa) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein distal to or rarely meeting ﬁrst sub-marginal crossvein; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex, the latter elevated above level of antennal sockets; hind tibial spurs slender, not strongly curved apically, outer one not coarsely toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Filiglossa) of Leioproctus of South America: Propodeum with broad basal subhorizontal or horizontal zone, curving onto vertical posterior surface; stigma large, not parallel-sided, at least two-thirds as long as marginal cell on costal margin of wing (Fig. 39-5e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Filiglossa) of Leioproctus of South America: Jugal lobe of hind wing short, not attaining level of cu-v (Fig. 39-5e); inner hind tibial spur of female usually pectinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Filiglossa) of Leioproctus of South America: Galea with several very long apical hairs and labial palpus ﬁlamentose, about as long as face (Fig. 19-6)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Euryglossidia) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Euryglossidia) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein distal to or rarely meeting ﬁrst sub-marginal crossvein; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex, the latter elevated above level of antennal sockets; hind tibial spurs slender, not strongly curved apically, outer one not coarsely toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Euryglossidia) of Leioproctus of South America: Propodeum with broad basal subhorizontal or horizontal zone, curving onto vertical posterior surface; stigma large, not parallel-sided, at least two-thirds as long as marginal cell on costal margin of wing (Fig. 39-5e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Euryglossidia) of Leioproctus of South America: Jugal lobe of hind wing short, not attaining level of cu-v (Fig. 39-5e); inner hind tibial spur of female usually pectinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Euryglossidia) of Leioproctus of South America: Mouthparts unmodiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Urocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Urocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein distal to or rarely meeting ﬁrst sub-marginal crossvein; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex, the latter elevated above level of antennal sockets; hind tibial spurs slender, not strongly curved apically, outer one not coarsely toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Urocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Propodeum with broad basal subhorizontal or horizontal zone, curving onto vertical posterior surface; stigma large, not parallel-sided, at least two-thirds as long as marginal cell on costal margin of wing (Fig. 39-5e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Urocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Second submarginal cell on posterior margin much shorter than third (as in Fig. 39-5d, f ); second submarginal crossvein usually straight, at least not curved parallel to third, anterior margin of third submarginal cell usually less than two-thirds as long as posterior margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Urocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Arolia absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Excolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent
