Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Excolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein distal to or rarely meeting ﬁrst sub-marginal crossvein; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex, the latter elevated above level of antennal sockets; hind tibial spurs slender, not strongly curved apically, outer one not coarsely toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Excolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Propodeum with broad basal subhorizontal or horizontal zone, curving onto vertical posterior surface; stigma large, not parallel-sided, at least two-thirds as long as marginal cell on costal margin of wing (Fig. 39-5e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Excolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Second submarginal cell on posterior margin much shorter than third (as in Fig. 39-5d, f ); second submarginal crossvein usually straight, at least not curved parallel to third, anterior margin of third submarginal cell usually less than two-thirds as long as posterior margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Excolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Arolia present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Excolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Basitibial plate of female and some males absent; pygidial plate of female with apical part slender, parallelsided or slightly narrowed preapically; basal vein more or less transverse, slanting about 30o to costal margin of wing, and little if any longer than ﬁrst abscissa of Rs (Fig. 39-5l)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Cladocerapis) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Cladocerapis) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein distal to or rarely meeting ﬁrst sub-marginal crossvein; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex, the latter elevated above level of antennal sockets; hind tibial spurs slender, not strongly curved apically, outer one not coarsely toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Cladocerapis) of Leioproctus of South America: Propodeum with broad basal subhorizontal or horizontal zone, curving onto vertical posterior surface; stigma large, not parallel-sided, at least two-thirds as long as marginal cell on costal margin of wing (Fig. 39-5e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Cladocerapis) of Leioproctus of South America: Second submarginal cell on posterior margin much shorter than third (as in Fig. 39-5d, f ); second submarginal crossvein usually straight, at least not curved parallel to third, anterior margin of third submarginal cell usually less than two-thirds as long as posterior margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Cladocerapis) of Leioproctus of South America: Arolia present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Cladocerapis) of Leioproctus of South America: Basitibial plate present (but anterior side not deﬁned in one species of Lamprocolletes); pygidial plate of female broad, sides converging posteriorly [except in L. (Protomorpha) fallax (Cockerell)]; basal vein slanting 45 o or more to costal margin of wing, and much longer than ﬁrst abscissa of Rs (Fig. 39-5d-f )

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Cladocerapis) of Leioproctus of South America: Clypeus and supraclypeal area ﬂat, depressed, shining, at least partly impunctate, sometimes longitudinally striate, suture separating them weak; anterior basitarsus of female with long coarse bristles on outer surface

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Colletopsis) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Colletopsis) of Leioproctus of South America: First recurrent vein distal to or rarely meeting ﬁrst sub-marginal crossvein; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex, the latter elevated above level of antennal sockets; hind tibial spurs slender, not strongly curved apically, outer one not coarsely toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Colletopsis) of Leioproctus of South America: Propodeum with broad basal subhorizontal or horizontal zone, curving onto vertical posterior surface; stigma large, not parallel-sided, at least two-thirds as long as marginal cell on costal margin of wing (Fig. 39-5e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Colletopsis) of Leioproctus of South America: Second submarginal cell on posterior margin much shorter than third (as in Fig. 39-5d, f ); second submarginal crossvein usually straight, at least not curved parallel to third, anterior margin of third submarginal cell usually less than two-thirds as long as posterior margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Colletopsis) of Leioproctus of South America: Arolia present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Colletopsis) of Leioproctus of South America: Basitibial plate present (but anterior side not deﬁned in one species of Lamprocolletes); pygidial plate of female broad, sides converging posteriorly [except in L. (Protomorpha) fallax (Cockerell)]; basal vein slanting 45 o or more to costal margin of wing, and much longer than ﬁrst abscissa of Rs (Fig. 39-5d-f )

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Colletopsis) of Leioproctus of South America: Clypeus and supraclypeal area not ﬂat, usually punctate, suture separating them distinct [weak or absent but whole area uniformly punctate in L. (Protomorpha) tarsalis Rayment]; anterior basitarsus of female with ordinary vestiture

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Colletopsis) of Leioproctus of South America: Dorsolateral angles of pronotum much elevated above adjacent scutal surface so that dorsal pronotal margin between them is concave

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Nesocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Malar area more than half as long as broad; S7 of male with apical lobes reduced (New Zealand)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lamprocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lamprocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Metanotum with median tubercle (in some cases weak), projection, spine, or biﬁd process; propodeum as seen in proﬁle vertical or nearly so, without subhorizontal basal area (nearly always metallic species)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ceratocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ceratocolletes) of Leioproctus of South America: Metasoma, including apical marginal zones of terga, densely punctate; last antennal segment sometimes enlarged and ﬂattened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Goniocolletes) (in part) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Goniocolletes) (in part) of Leioproctus of South America: Facial fovea commonly impressed; stigma small, slender, parallel-sided, little (if any) more than one-half as long as that part of marginal cell on wing margin (as in Fig. 39-5g); metasomal terga often with basal hair bands and often with very broad translucent apical marginal zones; S7 produced posteriorly as slender neck to which apical lobes are attached (Fig. 39-7f)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leioproctuss. str.) of Leioproctus of South America: T erga without enamel-like apical marginal zones, with hairs and punctures near apical margins that are concolorous with other parts of terga, or translucent or brownish, or, rarely [in L. (Perditomorpha) eulonchopriodes Michener], with apical yellow bands, but the band of T2 absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leioproctuss. str.) of Leioproctus of South America: Facial fovea not impressed; stigma usually not parallelsided, more than one-half as long as that part of marginal cell on wing margin (Fig. 39-5k) [except in L. subpunctatus (Rayment)]; metasomal terga without basal hair bands, apical marginal zones rarely broadly translucent; S7 with median portion not so slender and elongate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ctenosibyne) of Lonchopria: Mandible of male with large tooth or process on lowermargin; clypeus of female without or with weakly differentiated, closely punctate, upper median area; the lateral and apical clypeal areas, if differentiated, then merely less closely punctate than upper median area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ctenosibyne) of Lonchopria: Preapical tooth of male mandible enormous, separated from apical part of mandible (rutellum) by curved emargination (Fig. 39-9g); S8 of male with apical process downcurved, apex expanded and quadrangular; mandible of female unusually slender, preapical (pollex) tooth weakly developed (Fig. 39-9f)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lonchopria s. str.) of Lonchopria: Mandible of male with large tooth or process on lowermargin; clypeus of female without or with weakly differentiated, closely punctate, upper median area; the lateral and apical clypeal areas, if differentiated, then merely less closely punctate than upper median area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lonchopria s. str.) of Lonchopria: Preapical tooth of male mandible absent; S8 of male with apical process short, pointed, scarcely downcurved; mandible of female more robust with well-developed preapical tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Porterapis) of Lonchopria: Mandible of male often with obtuse preapical angle on lower margin but without large tooth or process; clypeus of female with ﬂat or depressed, relatively closely punctate, upper median area contrasting with impunctate or sparsely punctate, convex, U-shaped lateral and apical region

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Porterapis) of Lonchopria: Glossa deeply biﬁd (Fig. 39-12b), each lobe longer than prementum; apex of mandible scoop-shaped, the preapical (pollex) tooth reduced in female, absent in male

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lonchoprella) of Lonchopria: Mandible of male often with obtuse preapical angle on lower margin but without large tooth or process; clypeus of female with ﬂat or depressed, relatively closely punctate, upper median area contrasting with impunctate or sparsely punctate, convex, U-shaped lateral and apical region

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lonchoprella) of Lonchopria: Glossa of the usual bilobed form (sometimes rather deeply so), each lobe less than one-third length of prementum; apex of mandible pointed, preapical tooth (which is sometimes double) usually strong

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lonchoprella) of Lonchopria: Tibial scopal hairs sparse (as in Leioproctus), not hiding tibial surface, which is therefore not greatly different from that of basitarsus; body length 7.5-9.0 mm; jugal lobe of hind wing reaching or surpassing vein cu-v, over two-thirds as long as vannal lobe measured from wing base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Biglossa) of Lonchopria: Mandible of male often with obtuse preapical angle on lower margin but without large tooth or process; clypeus of female with ﬂat or depressed, relatively closely punctate, upper median area contrasting with impunctate or sparsely punctate, convex, U-shaped lateral and apical region

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Biglossa) of Lonchopria: Glossa of the usual bilobed form (sometimes rather deeply so), each lobe less than one-third length of prementum; apex of mandible pointed, preapical tooth (which is sometimes double) usually strong

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Biglossa) of Lonchopria: Tibial scopal hairs extremely dense, hiding tibial surface, which therefore contrasts strongly with more sparsely haired basitarsus; body length variable but in most species over 9 mm; jugal lobe of hind wing usually not reaching vein cu-v and usually less than two-thirds as long as vannal lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Anthoglossa) of Paracolletes: Metasoma with apical tergal hair bands [except in P. cygni (Cockerell) and montanus Rayment]; basitibial plate of male completely deﬁned, of female usually exposed, rounded apically (angulate in montanus), one-ﬁfth as long as tibia or less (but one-fourth in montanus); jugal lobe of hind wing little more than half as long as vannal lobe (but nearly two-thirds in cygni and montanus); ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment of male longer than broad; apical lobes of S7 of male broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Paracolletes s. str.) of Paracolletes: Metasoma without hair bands; basitibial plate of male not or scarcely deﬁned anteriorly, of female hidden by hairs, bluntly rounded apically, nearly one-fourth as long as tibia; jugal lobe of hind wing about two-thirds as long as vannal lobe; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment of male broader than long; apical lobes of S7 of male linear

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Trichocolletes s. str.) of Trichocolletes: Hind tibial spurs of male present; basitibial plate of female deﬁned only posteriorly, apex not evident

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Callocolletes) of Trichocolletes: Hind tibial spurs of male absent; basitibial plate of female complete except for indeﬁnite apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Colletes of the Tribe Colletini: T1 with anterior surface not broadly concave, often with a longitudinal median concavity; dorsal surface of T1 about as long as exposed part of T2 and at least two-thirds as long as anterior surface of T1, as seen in proﬁle; second recurrent vein usually sigmoid with posterior half arcuate distad (Fig. 40-3), rarely angulate distad at alar fenestra on ﬂexion line; base of propodeum with short, subhorizontal to vertical basal zone usually deﬁned posteriorly by a carina (Fig. 37-3) or exhibiting a sharp change in slope or sculpture and divided by longitudinal carinae that may delimit strong pits (worldwide except Indo-Australian region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mourecotelles of the Tribe Colletini: T1 with anterior surface broadly concave; dorsal surface of T1 much shorter than exposed part of T2 and less than two-thirds as long as anterior surface of T1, as seen in proﬁle; second recurrent vein with posterior half straight or gently arcuate (as in Fig. 39-5), its anterior part not curved in the reverse direction, vein thus not sigmoid; base of propodeum with sloping basal zone nearly smooth, not traversed by longitudinal carinae (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Hemicotelles) of Mourecotelles: Basal zone of propodeum margined posteriorly by weak carina; middle ﬂagellar segments of male about twice as long as wide (claws of female simple)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Xanthocotelles) of Mourecotelles: Basal zone of propodeum not margined posteriorly by carina; middle ﬂagellar segments of male less than twice as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Xanthocotelles) of Mourecotelles: Claws of female simple; tibiae and tarsi reddish yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Mourecotelles s. str.) of Mourecotelles: Basal zone of propodeum not margined posteriorly by carina; middle ﬂagellar segments of male less than twice as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Mourecotelles s. str.) of Mourecotelles: Claws of female cleft; tibiae and tarsi largely blackish

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Caupolicanini, of the Diphaglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1986b): Episternal groove complete; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment nearly as long as, to longer than, scape, much longer than subsequent segments, petiolate (Fig. 42-1a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Diphaglossini, of the Diphaglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1986b): Episternal groove absent below scrobal groove; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment much shorter than scape, less than twice as long as middle ﬂagellar segments, not or only moderately petiolate (Fig. 42-1b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Diphaglossini, of the Diphaglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1986b): Notaulus represented by deep groove in anterior part of mesoscutum; malar space nearly one-third as long as eye or longer

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Dissoglottini, of the Diphaglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1986b): Episternal groove absent below scrobal groove; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment much shorter than scape, less than twice as long as middle ﬂagellar segments, not or only moderately petiolate (Fig. 42-1b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Dissoglottini, of the Diphaglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1986b): Notaulus weak or absent; malar space short or absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ptiloglossa of the Caupolicanini: Outer hind tibial spur of male immovably fused to tibia (Fig. 43-2a); hind basitarsus of female less than twice as long as broad, second hind tarsal segment broader than long; metasomal terga usually weakly metallic bluish or greenish

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Crawfordapis of the Caupolicanini: Outer hind tibial spur of male articulated at base; hind basitarsus of female more than twice as long as broad (Fig. 43-2c), second hind tarsal segment longer than broad; metasomal terga usually nonmetallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Crawfordapis of the Caupolicanini: S7 of male with no paired apical lobes; base of marginal cell prolonged as narrow sinus to apex of stigma (as in Fig. 43-1b) (Mesoamerica)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Caupolicana of the Caupolicanini: Outer hind tibial spur of male articulated at base; hind basitarsus of female more than twice as long as broad (Fig. 43-2c), second hind tarsal segment longer than broad; metasomal terga usually nonmetallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Caupolicana of the Caupolicanini: S7 of male with paired apical lobes; base of marginal cell not prolonged as narrow sinus (Fig. 40-1a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ptiloglossa of the Caupolicanini: Outer hind tibial spur of male immovably fused to tibia (Fig. 43-2a); hind basitarsus of female less than twice as long as broad, second hind tarsal segment broader than long; metasomal terga usually weakly metallic bluish or greenish

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Crawfordapis of the Caupolicanini: Outer hind tibial spur of male articulated at base; hind basitarsus of female more than twice as long as broad (Fig. 43-2c), second hind tarsal segment longer than broad; metasomal terga usually nonmetallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Crawfordapis of the Caupolicanini: S7 of male with no paired apical lobes; base of marginal cell prolonged as narrow sinus to apex of stigma (as in Fig. 43-1b) (Mesoamerica)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera C. (Zikanapis) of the Caupolicanini: Outer hind tibial spur of male articulated at base; hind basitarsus of female more than twice as long as broad (Fig. 43-2c), second hind tarsal segment longer than broad; metasomal terga usually nonmetallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera C. (Zikanapis) of the Caupolicanini: S6 of male with weak median apical projection that has a broad, median, V-shaped notch; ventrolateral extremities of T2-T4 of male with large areas of dense short hair of uniform length; clypeus of male about 0.85 times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera C. (Alayoapis) of the Caupolicanini: Outer hind tibial spur of male articulated at base; hind basitarsus of female more than twice as long as broad (Fig. 43-2c), second hind tarsal segment longer than broad; metasomal terga usually nonmetallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera C. (Alayoapis) of the Caupolicanini: S6 of male with apex rounded, apex rarely with broad, median, V-shaped notch but no produced region; ventrolateral extremities of T2-T4 lacking specialized regions; clypeus of male not over 0.76 times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera C. (Alayoapis) of the Caupolicanini: Inner orbits of male strongly converging above; ocellocular distance one-fourth of an ocellar diameter or less (Greater Antilles)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera C. (Caupolicana s. str.) of the Caupolicanini: Outer hind tibial spur of male articulated at base; hind basitarsus of female more than twice as long as broad (Fig. 43-2c), second hind tarsal segment longer than broad; metasomal terga usually nonmetallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera C. (Caupolicana s. str.) of the Caupolicanini: S6 of male with apex rounded, apex rarely with broad, median, V-shaped notch but no produced region; ventrolateral extremities of T2-T4 lacking specialized regions; clypeus of male not over 0.76 times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera C. (Caupolicana s. str.) of the Caupolicanini: Inner orbits of male not or weakly converging above; ocellocular distance over one-third of an ocellar diameter and usually nearly equal to an ocellar diameter

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Diphaglossa of the Diphaglossini: Malar space about two-thirds as long as eye in female, three-fourths in male; S3 of male with broad, median, apical projection bearing stiff, basally directed setae (Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Cadegualina of the Diphaglossini: Malar space about one-third as long as eye; S3 of male simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Cadegualina of the Diphaglossini: Third submarginal cell much smaller than second; apex of marginal cell obliquely, and conspicuously, truncate; S7 of male with a small lobe broadly attached on each side at apex (Fig. 44-2a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Cadeguala of the Diphaglossini: Malar space about one-third as long as eye; S3 of male simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Cadeguala of the Diphaglossini: Third submarginal cell about as large as second (Fig. 441a, b); apex of marginal cell narrow, the truncation inconspicuous or absent; S7 of male with three lobes, two of them large, on each side at apex (Fig. 44-2b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ptiloglossidia of the Dissoglottini: Arolia absent; glossa moderately biﬁd, its apicolateral lobes longer than wide but not attenuate or pointed (Argentina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mydrosomella of the Dissoglottini: Arolia present; glossa strongly biﬁd, its apicolateral lobes attenuate, pointed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mydrosomella of the Dissoglottini: Second submarginal cell smaller than third; basitibial plate of female complete, margined (although hidden by hairs) (Argentina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mydrosoma of the Dissoglottini: Arolia present; glossa strongly biﬁd, its apicolateral lobes attenuate, pointed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mydrosoma of the Dissoglottini: Second submarginal cell larger than or rarely the same size as third (Fig. 45-1); basitibial plate of female at most a slightly elevated area with an elevated posterior margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Geodiscelis of Xeromelissinae (modiﬁed fromMichener and Rozen, 1999): Paraocular area produced down as lobe (along with groove representing tentorial pit) invading clypeus; glossa with slender apicolateral lobes; metasoma with ivory integumental bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Xenochilicola of Xeromelissinae (modiﬁed fromMichener and Rozen, 1999): Paraocular area not produced downward as lobe into clypeus; glossa of usual short hylaeine or xeromelissine type; metasoma usually without ivory integumental bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Xenochilicola of Xeromelissinae (modiﬁed fromMichener and Rozen, 1999): Basal sloping part of propodeum about as long as metanotum, less than half as long as declivitous vertical surface (as seen in proﬁle); inner orbits of eyes nearly straight, not emarginate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Chilicola of Xeromelissinae (modiﬁed fromMichener and Rozen, 1999): Paraocular area not produced downward as lobe into clypeus; glossa of usual short hylaeine or xeromelissine type; metasoma usually without ivory integumental bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Chilicola of Xeromelissinae (modiﬁed fromMichener and Rozen, 1999): Basal sloping or subhorizontal part of propodeum longer than metanotum, often as long as scutellum, half as long as vertical surface or frequently longer (as seen in proﬁle); inner orbits of eyes emarginate or at least slightly concave at about upper third or fourth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Chilimelissa of Xeromelissinae (modiﬁed fromMichener and Rozen, 1999): Anterior tentorial impression slanting down almost to apex of clypeus (Fig. 46-5a, b); labial palpus 4-segmented; maxillary palpus consisting of 6 easily seen segments, the ﬁrst three markedly broader than the distal three

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Xeromelissa of Xeromelissinae (modiﬁed fromMichener and Rozen, 1999): Anterior tentorial impression not approaching apex of clypeus (Fig. 46-1c, d); labial palpus three-segmented; maxillary palpus consisting of three large segments followed, at least sometimes, by two to ﬁve extremely minute segments (these are easily broken off)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Chilicola s. str.) of Chilicola: Hind tibial spurs strong and curved; clypeus and supraclypeal area rather ﬂat and depressed, face thus seemingly slightly concave

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Chilicola s. str.) of Chilicola: Episternal groove extending down to lower part of thorax; claws cleft; hind tibia of male usually showing a transverse or slanting preapical cleft or depression on inner margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Chilioediscelis) of Chilicola: Hind tibial spurs strong and curved; clypeus and supraclypeal area rather ﬂat and depressed, face thus seemingly slightly concave

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Chilioediscelis) of Chilicola: Episternal groove not extending below level of scrobe; claws of female simple; hind tibia of male somewhat thickened but ordinary in shape

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Hylaeosoma) of Chilicola: Hind tibial spurs slender and almost straight; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Hylaeosoma) of Chilicola: Face with depression extending from antennal base toward area between ocelli and upper end of eye (Fig. 463d); second submarginal cell usually not extending beyond apex of stigma (Fig. 46-2b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Prosopoides) of Chilicola: Hind tibial spurs slender and almost straight; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Prosopoides) of Chilicola: Face without depression slanting upward from antennal base; second submarginal cell ending distal to apex of stigma (Fig. 46-2a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Prosopoides) of Chilicola: Anterior tentorial pit extended apicad as deep, shining groove along epistomal suture to area near clypeal apex, where suture bends laterad toward mandibular base (Fig. 46-3c, f); head over 1.5 times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Prosopoides) of Chilicola: A conspicuous, smooth, shining, well-deﬁned facial fovea (less than three times as long as wide) near emargination in inner orbit (Fig. 46-3c); malar space broader than long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Pseudiscelis) of Chilicola: Hind tibial spurs slender and almost straight; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Pseudiscelis) of Chilicola: Face without depression slanting upward from antennal base; second submarginal cell ending distal to apex of stigma (Fig. 46-2a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Pseudiscelis) of Chilicola: Anterior tentorial pit extended apicad as deep, shining groove along epistomal suture to area near clypeal apex, where suture bends laterad toward mandibular base (Fig. 46-3c, f); head over 1.5 times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Pseudiscelis) of Chilicola: No clearly recognizable facial fovea (Fig. 46-3f); malar space about 1.5 to 3.0 times as long as broad (Fig. 46-3g)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Oroediscelis) of Chilicola: Hind tibial spurs slender and almost straight; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Oroediscelis) of Chilicola: Face without depression slanting upward from antennal base; second submarginal cell ending distal to apex of stigma (Fig. 46-2a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Oroediscelis) of Chilicola: Anterior tentorial pit not greatly extended along epistomal suture; head wider than long to about 1.2 times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Oroediscelis) of Chilicola: Malar space 0.4 to 1.2 times as long as broad; line perpendicular to costal forewing margin at apex of stigma crossing submarginal cells near ﬁrst transverse submarginal vein; S4 of male with two strong tubercles or projections. (hind femur of male not greatly enlarged)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Oediscelis) of Chilicola: Hind tibial spurs slender and almost straight; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Oediscelis) of Chilicola: Face without depression slanting upward from antennal base; second submarginal cell ending distal to apex of stigma (Fig. 46-2a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Oediscelis) of Chilicola: Anterior tentorial pit not greatly extended along epistomal suture; head wider than long to about 1.2 times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Oediscelis) of Chilicola: Malar space linear, nearly absent; line perpendicular to costal forewing margin at apex of stigma usually crossing submarginal cells at or beyond middle of second submarginal cell; S4 of male without tubercles or projections

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Oediscelis) of Chilicola: Hind femur of male greatly swollen, as long as or longer than tibia, which is enlarged and modiﬁed distally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Anoediscelis) of Chilicola: Hind tibial spurs slender and almost straight; clypeus and supraclypeal area convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Anoediscelis) of Chilicola: Face without depression slanting upward from antennal base; second submarginal cell ending distal to apex of stigma (Fig. 46-2a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Anoediscelis) of Chilicola: Anterior tentorial pit not greatly extended along epistomal suture; head wider than long to about 1.2 times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Anoediscelis) of Chilicola: Malar space linear, nearly absent; line perpendicular to costal forewing margin at apex of stigma usually crossing submarginal cells at or beyond middle of second submarginal cell; S4 of male without tubercles or projections

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Anoediscelis) of Chilicola: Hind femur of male not greatly swollen, shorter than tibia,which is also not or little modiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hyleoides of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Anterior tibial spine prolonged into long curved process, at least as long as basitarsal diameter (Fig. 47-3p); stigma with edge within marginal cell straight (Fig. 47-5a); posterior margin of T1 angulate near apex of lateral carina; apex of S1 transverse; S2 strongly produced downward at base (Fig. 47-3i) (Australian region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pharohylaeus of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Anterior tibial spine small or absent; stigma with edge within marginal cell usually convex (Figs. 47-2; 47-5b); posterior margin of T1 straight or with broadly rounded posterior lateral angle; apex of S1 with median cleft or slit; S2 not produced downward at base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pharohylaeus of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): T1-T3 enormous, enclosing apical segments (Fig. 473b); basal vein meeting cu-v or nearly so; second recurrent vein beyond second submarginal crossvein; gradulus of T2 absent, faintly indicated laterally, pregradular area densely hairy, especially laterodorsally (preoccipital carina present) (Australia, New Guinea)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xenorhiza of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Both recurrent veins outside limits of second submarginal cell or meeting submarginal crossveins; mesepisternum in front of middle coxa sometimes with strong spine or projection (New Guinea)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Calloprosopis of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Base of hind tibia with elongate, glabrous ridge on outer side probably representing basitibial plate; propodeal triangle nearly all on dorsal surface (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hylaeus of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Anterior tibial spine small or absent; stigma with edge within marginal cell usually convex (Figs. 47-2; 47-5b); posterior margin of T1 straight or with broadly rounded posterior lateral angle; apex of S1 with median cleft or slit; S2 not produced downward at base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hylaeus of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): T1-T3 of ordinary size, not hiding apical segments; basal vein distal to cu-v; second recurrent vein often meeting or basal to (although in some cases beyond) second submarginal crossvein (Figs. 47-2; 47-5); gradulus of T2 present, pregradular area not densely hairy

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hylaeus of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hylaeus of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Glossa usually broader than long, gently roundedtruncate to weakly bilobed at apex (a small median point on otherwise subtruncate apex in Hylaeus, subgenus Hylaeorhiza, Fig. 47-1g)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hylaeus of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Bees nonmetallic or less brilliant blue or green; second recurrent vein and usually ﬁrst received by second submarginal cell (except when submarginal and second medial cells are conﬂuent, Fig. 47-5b); propodeal triangle with dorsal and posterior surfaces not separated by a carina, or, if so, then dorsal surface usually only a short zone

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hylaeus of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Gonobase large, forming a cuplike base to genital capsule

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hemirhiza of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Gena and scutum with yellow maculations; propodeal triangle smooth, shiny, and evenly rounded in proﬁle; T6 with a distinct pygidial plate; ﬁrst metasomal segment slightly constricted in lateral view (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Amphylaeus of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Anterior tibial spine small or absent; stigma with edge within marginal cell usually convex (Figs. 47-2; 47-5b); posterior margin of T1 straight or with broadly rounded posterior lateral angle; apex of S1 with median cleft or slit; S2 not produced downward at base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Amphylaeus of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): T1-T3 of ordinary size, not hiding apical segments; basal vein distal to cu-v; second recurrent vein often meeting or basal to (although in some cases beyond) second submarginal crossvein (Figs. 47-2; 47-5); gradulus of T2 present, pregradular area not densely hairy

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Amphylaeus of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Amphylaeus of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Glossa usually longer than broad, apex acute (Fig. 47-1h-j) or, at least with preapical margins meeting to form obtuse apical angle (in Amphylaeus s. str., Fig. 471e, f)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Amphylaeus of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Fovea of T2 linear

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Amphylaeus of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Gena and scutum without pale maculations; ﬁrst metasomal segment not appearing constricted in lateral view (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Meroglossa of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Anterior tibial spine small or absent; stigma with edge within marginal cell usually convex (Figs. 47-2; 47-5b); posterior margin of T1 straight or with broadly rounded posterior lateral angle; apex of S1 with median cleft or slit; S2 not produced downward at base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Meroglossa of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): T1-T3 of ordinary size, not hiding apical segments; basal vein distal to cu-v; second recurrent vein often meeting or basal to (although in some cases beyond) second submarginal crossvein (Figs. 47-2; 47-5); gradulus of T2 present, pregradular area not densely hairy

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Meroglossa of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Meroglossa of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Glossa usually longer than broad, apex acute (Fig. 47-1h-j) or, at least with preapical margins meeting to form obtuse apical angle (in Amphylaeus s. str., Fig. 471e, f)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Meroglossa of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Fovea of T2 punctiform or absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Meroglossa of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Face with large lateral depressions from sides of clypeus to above antennal sockets (Fig. 47-4i); gradulus of T2 exposed and arcuate posteriorly (i.e., recurved) medially; preoccipital carina absent; hind tibia with one or two spines on outer apical margin (Fig. 47-3o) (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Palaeorhiza of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Propodeal triangle nearly all on dorsal surface of propodeum except in species with protuberance on dorsum of propodeum; body usually bright metallic blue or green or with abundant white to yellow maculations on gena and mesothorax; vertical ridge in front of middle coxa usually strongly developed (New Guinea area, Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xenorhiza of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Both recurrent veins outside limits of second submarginal cell or meeting submarginal crossveins; mesepisternum in front of middle coxa sometimes with strong spine or projection (New Guinea)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Palaeorhiza of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Propodeal triangle nearly all on dorsal surface of propodeum except in species with protuberance on dorsum of propodeum; body usually bright metallic blue or green or with abundant white to yellow maculations on gena and mesothorax; vertical ridge in front of middle coxa usually strongly developed (New Guinea area, Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hylaeus (in part) of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Propodeal triangle having less than three-quarters of its length on dorsal surface of propodeum; body rarely brilliant metallic, gena and mesothorax usually without extensive white to yellow maculations; ridge in front of middle coxa weak or absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hemirhiza of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Gena and scutum with yellow maculations; propodeal triangle smooth, shiny, and evenly rounded in proﬁle; T6 with a distinct pygidial plate; ﬁrst metasomal segment slightly constricted in lateral view (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Calloprosopis of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Base of hind tibia with elongate, glabrous ridge on outer side probably representing basitibial plate; propodeal triangle nearly all on dorsal surface (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera (in part) of the Hylaeinae(Based in part on Houston, 1975a, and Michener,1965b): Base of hind tibia without glabrous ridge; propodeal triangle partly on declivous surface of propodeumHylaeus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Amphylaeus s. str.) of Amphylaeus: Male with clypeus and supraclypeal area indistinguishably fused, subantennal suture and upper lateral part of epistomal suture united as one strongly arcuate suture from tentorial pit to antennal base (Fig. 47-4a); interantennal distance of female equal to minimum clypeocular distance (Fig. 47-4b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Agogenohylaeus) of Amphylaeus: Male with complete epistomal suture of ordinary form joining subantennal sutures in usual way (Fig. 47-4c); female with interantennal distance nearly twice minimum clypeocular distance

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Analastoroides) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): T1 of male, viewed laterally, constricted apically, and T2 strongly humped (Fig. 47-3k); T2 of female moderately humped (Fig. 47-3g)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Analastoroides) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Metasoma with bands of dense orange tomentum across apical margins of T1 and T3; terga with even, dense, ﬁne pitting

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Euprosopellus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): T1 of male, viewed laterally, constricted apically, and T2 strongly humped (Fig. 47-3k); T2 of female moderately humped (Fig. 47-3g)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Euprosopellus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Metasoma without bands of orange tomentum; terga with irregular pitting, the pits of two sizes and partially conﬂuent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Xenohylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): T1 of male, viewed laterally, not constricted apically, and T2 not strongly humped; T2 of female not at all humped (Fig. 47-3h)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Xenohylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Clypeus of female with ﬁne longitudinal median carina (strongest apically); lower face longitudinally striate; face of male with very large depression on each side, from clypeus to well above antennal sockets; scape of male greatly expanded and ﬂattened; subapical metasomal segments of male with large, expanded, pubescent, pregradular areas

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Euprosopis) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): T1 of male, viewed laterally, not constricted apically, and T2 not strongly humped; T2 of female not at all humped (Fig. 47-3h)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Euprosopis) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Clypeus of female without median carina; lower face striate or not; face of male lacking depressions; scape of male not greatly expanded and ﬂattened [except in H. (Prosopisteron) semipersonatus Cockerell, which lacks expanded, pubescent, pregradular areas]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Euprosopis) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Propodeum almost wholly vertical, dorsal surface shorter than metanotum and bearing a single row of regular pits bounded posteriorly by a carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Euprosopis) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Upper end of raised interantennal area about as wide as an antennal socket and merging with frons; posterior surface of scape of male without pits; female with distinct mesosternal brush-hairs, and outer apical spines of fore and middle tibiae unmodiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Euprosopoides) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): T1 of male, viewed laterally, not constricted apically, and T2 not strongly humped; T2 of female not at all humped (Fig. 47-3h)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Euprosopoides) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Clypeus of female without median carina; lower face striate or not; face of male lacking depressions; scape of male not greatly expanded and ﬂattened [except in H. (Prosopisteron) semipersonatus Cockerell, which lacks expanded, pubescent, pregradular areas]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Euprosopoides) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Propodeum almost wholly vertical, dorsal surface shorter than metanotum and bearing a single row of regular pits bounded posteriorly by a carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Euprosopoides) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Upper end of raised interantennal area much narrower than an antennal socket and usually distinct from frons; posterior surface of scape of male with one or two distict pits; female without mesosternal brush-hairs, but outer apical spines of fore and middle tibiae modiﬁed into longitudinal carinae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Euprosopoides) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Scutellum and metanotum usually with yellow areas; malar area of male no longer than one-fourth width; S8 of male with apex deeply biﬁd, hairy (Fig. 47-9g)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Laccohylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): T1 of male, viewed laterally, not constricted apically, and T2 not strongly humped; T2 of female not at all humped (Fig. 47-3h)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Laccohylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Clypeus of female without median carina; lower face striate or not; face of male lacking depressions; scape of male not greatly expanded and ﬂattened [except in H. (Prosopisteron) semipersonatus Cockerell, which lacks expanded, pubescent, pregradular areas]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Laccohylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Propodeum almost wholly vertical, dorsal surface shorter than metanotum and bearing a single row of regular pits bounded posteriorly by a carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Laccohylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Upper end of raised interantennal area much narrower than an antennal socket and usually distinct from frons; posterior surface of scape of male with one or two distict pits; female without mesosternal brush-hairs, but outer apical spines of fore and middle tibiae modiﬁed into longitudinal carinae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Laccohylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Scutellum and metanotum without pale areas; malar area of male about one-half as long as width; S8 of male with apex simple, usually hairless

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeorhiza) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): T1 of male, viewed laterally, not constricted apically, and T2 not strongly humped; T2 of female not at all humped (Fig. 47-3h)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeorhiza) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Clypeus of female without median carina; lower face striate or not; face of male lacking depressions; scape of male not greatly expanded and ﬂattened [except in H. (Prosopisteron) semipersonatus Cockerell, which lacks expanded, pubescent, pregradular areas]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeorhiza) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Propodeum variable, but dorsal surface never very short or bearing such a row of pits bounded posteriorly by a carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeorhiza) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Precoxal ridge of mesosternum distinct (propodeum almost entirely vertical, triangle smooth and shiny; scutellum and metanotum bright yellow)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Prosopisteroides) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Dorsal surface of propodeum as long as scutellum, triangle nearly all subhorizontal, smooth and shining to microtesellate and somewhat dull; maxillary palpus as long as thorax or longer (New Guinea)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Sphaerhylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Mandibles elongate, pollex forming the usual upper mandibular tooth; mandible broadest basally; scape of male almost hemispherical (Fig. 47-7f); frons of male with cavity above each antennal socket

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Gnathoprosopis) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Dorsal surface of propodeal triangle entirely areolate and usually delimited laterally and posteriorly by carina [carina absent in H. amiculus (Smith)]; S7 of male with single pair of apical lobes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Gnathoprosopoides) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Dorsal surface of propodeal triangle largely smooth and not at all delimited by carina; S7 of male with two pairs of apical lobes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Meghylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Prestigma about as long as stigma from its base to vein r; interantennal area strongly elevated and separated from frons by distinct edge (Fig. 47-7g); propodeum without a median prominence; mesosternum of female with brush-hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Macrohylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Prestigma much shorter than stigma from its base to vein r; interantennal area convex but not delimited from frons (Fig. 47-7a, b); propodeal triangle with shiny median prominence; mesosternum of female without brush-hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Rhodohylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Propodeal triangle areolate or coarsely roughened and delimited laterally and posteriorly by a carina; pronotal collar almost as high as scutum, contiguous laterally with the pronotal lobe through a carinate ridge; body at least partly yellow-brown to red-brown

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Pseudhylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Mandible bidentate, the lower tooth usually longest by far; interantennal area not delimited from frons; hind margins of metasomal terga usually translucent and with laterally directed setae; outer margin of fore tarsus with long setae; apex of S8 of male biﬁd, dorso-apical lobes of S7 with acute apices

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeteron) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Mandible of female tridentate, of male acutely bidentate; interantennal area elevated and delimited from frons by distinct edges; hind margins of metasomal terga rarely translucent and with laterally directed setae; outer margin of fore tarsus without long setae; apex of S8 of male not biﬁd, dorso-apical lobes of S7 rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Planihylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Lower face ﬂat, longitudinally striate; propodeum with steeply sloping dorsal surface, triangle usually areolate anteriorly; lateral fovea of T2 large and rounded; subapical metasomal segments of male with large expanded pubescent pregradular areas; apex of S8 of male biﬁd and apex of dorso-apical lobes of S7 of male acute

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Edriohylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Second submarginal and second medial cells of forewing conﬂuent (Fig. 47-5b); minute, slender bees with T1, at least in male, much longer than broad, as seen from above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Edriohylaeus) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Body very slender; T1 of male 1.5 times longer than broad, of female nearly as long as broad; propodeum with long, smooth, horizontal dorsal surface rounding evenly onto vertical posterior surface; S7 of male with only one pair of apical lobes broadly fused to broad body of sternum (Fig. 47-9c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Prosopisteron) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Second submarginal and second medial cells of forewing conﬂuent (Fig. 47-5b); minute, slender bees with T1, at least in male, much longer than broad, as seen from above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Prosopisteron) of Hylaeus of the Australia-New Guinea Area(Modiﬁed from Houston, 1981a): Body seldom very slender; T1 of male usually not longer than broad, of female usually much broader than long; propodeum variable, dorsal surface sometimes roughened anteriorly; S7 of male with two pairs of apical lobes narrowly connected to narrow body of sternum (Fig. 479f, j)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Gongyloprosopis) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Frons largely covered with conspicuous mat of short, dense, highly plumose pilosity, partly hidden behind swollen scape (neotropics)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Spatulariella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Frons without dense mat of short, plumose pilosity; scape swollen or not

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Spatulariella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Omaulus, at least below level of lower end of episternal groove, carinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Spatulariella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Apical process of S8 ﬂattened and broadly spatuliform, always visible in ventral view; side of propodeum never pruinose (introduced from Eurasia to southern California, central Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeopsis) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Frons without dense mat of short, plumose pilosity; scape swollen or not

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeopsis) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Omaulus, at least below level of lower end of episternal groove, carinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeopsis) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Apical process of S8 not ﬂattened and spatuliform; side of propodeum often densely pruinose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeopsis) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Spiracular area of propodeum enclosed by carina; propodeal triangle with coarse, more or less longitudinal rugae; thorax and/or metasoma usually coarsely punctate; omaulus with carina extending above lower end of episternal groove to pronotal lobe (neotropics)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeana) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Frons without dense mat of short, plumose pilosity; scape swollen or not

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeana) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Omaulus, at least below level of lower end of episternal groove, carinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeana) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Apical process of S8 not ﬂattened and spatuliform; side of propodeum often densely pruinose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeana) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Spiracular area open or, if enclosed, then propodeal triangle lacking coarse longitudinal rugae and thorax ﬁnely punctate; omaulus without carina above lower end of episternal groove (neotropics to southwestern USA)

Title: Bees Of The World

Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Omaulus rounded

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Cephalylaeus) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Antennal scape much broader than long; S6 elevated along midline; pronotum black (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Prosopella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeus s. str.) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeus s. str.) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Margins of interantennal elevation nearly parallel between antennal sockets, terminating on frons well above level of upper margins of antennal sockets; apical lobes of S7 laterally pectinate (Fig. 47-10g) (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Metziella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Margins of interantennal elevation sharply convergent between antennal sockets and ending little, if any, above level of upper margins of antennal sockets; apical lobes of S7 not pectinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Metziella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Outer margin of front coxa with sharp laterobasal angle or tooth; apical process of S8 short, triangular, broad at base and tapering to blunt apex (ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment shorter than second) (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Cephylaeus) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Margins of interantennal elevation sharply convergent between antennal sockets and ending little, if any, above level of upper margins of antennal sockets; apical lobes of S7 not pectinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Cephylaeus) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Outer margin of front coxa without sharp laterobasal angle or tooth; apical process of S8 slender at least basally, usually parallel-sided for most of its length or biﬁd at apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Cephylaeus) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: S7 with apical lobes rather small, ﬂat, broadly attached to and on same plane as body of sternum; process of S8 with basal half slender, distal half robust and expanded distally to shallowly emarginate apex (Brazil)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Prosopis) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Apical process of S8 entire, more or less parallel-sided for most of its length and usually subapically broadened, apex rounded or truncate; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment about as long as second (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Paraprosopis) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Males) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling)For illustrations of male genitalia and hidden sterna ofNorth American forms, see Metz (1911), Mitchell(1960), and the more specialized papers referred to underthe subgenera.: Apical process of S8 deeply biﬁd at apex; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment distinctly shorter than second (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Spatulariella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Omaulus, at least below lower end of episternal groove, carinate; spiracular area of propodeum usually enclosed by carina; anterior margin of pronotal collar often carinate or with distinct crest; metasomal sterna often very ﬁnely microstriate and weakly iridescent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Spatulariella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Labrum with single median tubercle; pronotal collar rounded in front; metasomal terga more or less polished and with sparse, ﬁne, sharply deﬁned punctures (introduced from Eurasia to southern California and Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeana) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Omaulus, at least below lower end of episternal groove, carinate; spiracular area of propodeum usually enclosed by carina; anterior margin of pronotal collar often carinate or with distinct crest; metasomal sterna often very ﬁnely microstriate and weakly iridescent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeana) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R.
