Snelling): Labrum with paired submedian longitudinal tubercles; pronotal collar with transverse carina or crest or, if rounded, metasomal terga microlineolate, satiny, without obvious punctures

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeana) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Omaular carina absent above lower end of episternal groove; spiracular area of propodeum open or,if enclosed by carina, then basal area of propodeum not rugulose and metasomal terga without obvious punctures; pronotal collar not carinate or with weak anterior carina; thoracic punctures ﬁne to moderate in size (neotropics to southwestern USA)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeopsis) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Omaulus, at least below lower end of episternal groove, carinate; spiracular area of propodeum usually enclosed by carina; anterior margin of pronotal collar often carinate or with distinct crest; metasomal sterna often very ﬁnely microstriate and weakly iridescent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeopsis) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Labrum with paired submedian longitudinal tubercles; pronotal collar with transverse carina or crest or, if rounded, metasomal terga microlineolate, satiny, without obvious punctures

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hylaeopsis) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Omaular carina extending up to pronotal lobe; spiracular area of propodium enclosed by carina and basal area of propodeum usually coarsely rugose; pronotal collar usually anteriorly carinate or crested; thoracic (and often metasomal) punctures moderate to coarse (neotropics)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Gongyloprosopis) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Omaulus without carina; spiracular area of propodeum open or enclosed; anterior margin of pronotal collar rounded; metasomal sterna never ﬁnely microstriate and never iridescent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Gongyloprosopis) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Dorsolateral angle of pronotum, in dorsal view, distinctly angulate or protuberant; anterior margin of pronotal collar sometimes with short, low, sublateral carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Gongyloprosopis) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Dorsolateral angle of pronotum slightly protuberant; propodeal triangle with transverse subbasal ridge, behind which surface is largely without rugulae; lateral carina of propodeum prominent along spiracular area (neotropics)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Prosopella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Omaulus without carina; spiracular area of propodeum open or enclosed; anterior margin of pronotal collar rounded; metasomal sterna never ﬁnely microstriate and never iridescent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Prosopella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Dorsolateral angle of pronotum, in dorsal view, distinctly angulate or protuberant; anterior margin of pronotal collar sometimes with short, low, sublateral carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Prosopella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Dorsolateral angle of pronotum abruptly angulate (truncate) but not protuberant; entire propodeal triangle rugulose, rugulae primarily transverse; lateral carina of propodeum absent along spiracular area (southwestern USA, Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Metziella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Omaulus without carina; spiracular area of propodeum open or enclosed; anterior margin of pronotal collar rounded; metasomal sterna never ﬁnely microstriate and never iridescent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Metziella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Dorsolateral angle of pronotum rounded in dorsal view; anterior margin of pronotal collar rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Metziella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Gena as wide as eye or wider in lateral view, and mesepisternal punctures distinct; lateral propodeal carina absent or present only posteriorly; metasomal terga with only scattered, minute punctures

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Metziella) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Front coxa with large, triangular lateral process or stout spine; upper end of facial fovea much nearer to inner eye margin than to lateral ocellus; side of face and pronotal lobe with pale markings (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Cephalylaeus) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Omaulus without carina; spiracular area of propodeum open or enclosed; anterior margin of pronotal collar rounded; metasomal sterna never ﬁnely microstriate and never iridescent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Cephalylaeus) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Dorsolateral angle of pronotum rounded in dorsal view; anterior margin of pronotal collar rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Cephalylaeus) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Gena as wide as eye or wider in lateral view, and mesepisternal punctures distinct; lateral propodeal carina absent or present only posteriorly; metasomal terga with only scattered, minute punctures

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Cephalylaeus) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): Front coxa without lateral process; facial fovea ending about midway between eye and lateral ocellus; side of face and pronotal lobe immaculate (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Paraprosopis)(in part) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): T1 (and often T2) densely punctate, T1 almost always lacking apicolateral pubescent patch; spiracular area of propodeum often enclosed by carina, and mesepisternum ﬁnely punctate; facial fovea often ending at or mesal to midpoint between inner eye margin and lateral ocellus (Fig. 47-11l) (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Paraprosopis)(in part) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): T1 (and often T2) densely punctate, T1 almost always lacking apicolateral pubescent patch; spiracular area of propodeum often enclosed by carina, and mesepisternum ﬁnely punctate; facial fovea often ending at or mesal to midpoint between inner eye margin and lateral ocellus (Fig. 47-11l) (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Prosopis) of Hylaeus of the WesternHemisphere (Females) (See account of Orohylaeus)(By R. R. Snelling): T1 sparsely to densely punctate, in latter case apicolateral pubescent patch present; if spiracular area of propodeum enclosed, then mesepisternum coarsely punctate; facial fovea always ending nearer to inner eye margin than to lateral ocellus (as in Fig. 47-11m) (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Palearctic Subgenera H. (Abrupta) of Hylaeus (Males)(By H. H. Dathe)For additional illustrations of male genitalia and otherstructures, see Méhelÿ (1935), Dathe (1980a), and otherpapers referred to under the subgenera. Illustrations ac-companying this key (Figs. 47-10 and 47-11) are by H.Dathe.: Face entirely black, and frons broadly concave and shining between ocelli and antennal bases; middle basitarsus dilated at base; gonostylus truncate, the long, stiff bristles on lateral part of transverse margin nearly as long as gonoforceps (Fig. 47-10a) (scape conically swollen, white; S7 with apical lobes well developed, truncate at hairless tips; S8 with long spiculum and apical process, the latter bifurcate, hairy)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Palearctic Subgenera H. (Prosopis) of Hylaeus (Males)(By H. H. Dathe)For additional illustrations of male genitalia and otherstructures, see Méhelÿ (1935), Dathe (1980a), and otherpapers referred to under the subgenera. Illustrations ac-companying this key (Figs. 47-10 and 47-11) are by H.Dathe.: Face with white or yellow areas, or, if entirely black, then frons convex and densely punctured medially; middle basitarsus normal; gonostylus apically rounded or pointed, its bristles shorter than gonoforceps

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Palearctic Subgenera H. (Prosopis) of Hylaeus (Males)(By H. H. Dathe)For additional illustrations of male genitalia and otherstructures, see Méhelÿ (1935), Dathe (1980a), and otherpapers referred to under the subgenera. Illustrations ac-companying this key (Figs. 47-10 and 47-11) are by H.Dathe.: Gonostylus and gonocoxite distinctly separated by oblique constriction; outer margin of gonostylus convex, protruding; apical hair tufts of gonostylus dense and feathered (Fig. 47-10b), in normal position projecting from metasomal apex (genital capsule extraordinarily large; S7 with apical lobes ﬁnely punctate; S7 with apical lobes reduced, compact, with hairs (Fig. 47-11h) that may be short and sparse

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Abrupta) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Mandible tridentate, inner tooth sometimes short (Fig. 47-11i)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Abrupta) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Clypeus with broad, transverse, saddle-like depression below transverse supraclypeal projection and above two lower lateral clypeal projections; epistomal suture largely unrecognizable; face entirely black

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Mehelyana) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Mandible tridentate, inner tooth sometimes short (Fig. 47-11i)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Mehelyana) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Clypeus slightly convex, without projections or teeth; supraclypeal projection absent; epistomal suture complete; face usually with yellow on paraocular area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Mehelyana) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Anterior coxa with obtuse process (Fig. 47-11k); clypeus rather rectangular, the middle evenly domed as seen from side

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Dentigera) (brevicornis group) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Mandible tridentate, inner tooth sometimes short (Fig. 47-11i)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Dentigera) (brevicornis group) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Clypeus slightly convex, without projections or teeth; supraclypeal projection absent; epistomal suture complete; face usually with yellow on paraocular area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Dentigera) (brevicornis group) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Anterior coxa without process; clypeal outline trapezoidal; clypeus ﬂat or asymmetrically domed as seen from side

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Dentigera) (brevicornis group) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Paraocular spots often elongate, contiguous with inner orbits, or, if face entirely black, then T1 transversely obsoletely reticulated; T1 with lateral fringes, partly indistinct

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Lambdopsis) (in part) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Mandible tridentate, inner tooth sometimes short (Fig. 47-11i)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Lambdopsis) (in part) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Clypeus slightly convex, without projections or teeth; supraclypeal projection absent; epistomal suture complete; face usually with yellow on paraocular area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Lambdopsis) (in part) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Anterior coxa without process; clypeal outline trapezoidal; clypeus ﬂat or asymmetrically domed as seen from side

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Lambdopsis) (in part) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Paraocular spots usually rounded, contiguous with clypeal margin or, if face entirely black, then T1 integument smooth; T1 without lateral fringes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Dentigera) (brachycephalus group  and Hylaeus rubicola Saunders) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Mandible with two teeth or apex bilobate (Fig. 47-11j)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Dentigera) (brachycephalus group  and Hylaeus rubicola Saunders) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Vertex swollen, in frontal view surpassing upper ocular margins by ocular width; head in frontal view nearly circular; inner margins of eyes not or only slightly convergent below; genal area broad, or, if head conspicuously rectangular and gena narrow, then thorax red (small species)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Spatulariella) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Mandible with two teeth or apex bilobate (Fig. 47-11j)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Spatulariella) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Vertex convex as usual; head in frontal view rounded or trapezoidal, never rectangular; inner margins of eyes markedly convergent below; genal area narrow; thorax black, with red marks in only a few large species

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Spatulariella) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Omaulus carinate or lamellate; malar area at least as long as basal ﬂagellar diameter; thorax and clypeus mostly strongly punctate; propodeal triangle with coarse wrinkles

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Koptogaster) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Mandible with two teeth or apex bilobate (Fig. 47-11j)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Koptogaster) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Vertex convex as usual; head in frontal view rounded or trapezoidal, never rectangular; inner margins of eyes markedly convergent below; genal area narrow; thorax black, with red marks in only a few large species

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Koptogaster) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Omaulus rounded or merely angular; malar area shorter than basal ﬂagellar diameter, rarely longer, in which case another character given above does not agree

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Koptogaster) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Head conspicuously longer than broad in frontal view; pronotum thickened, dorsolateral angle square-truncate; mesoscutum coarsely and strongly wrinkled-punctate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Paraprosopis) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Mandible with two teeth or apex bilobate (Fig. 47-11j)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Paraprosopis) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Vertex convex as usual; head in frontal view rounded or trapezoidal, never rectangular; inner margins of eyes markedly convergent below; genal area narrow; thorax black, with red marks in only a few large species

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Paraprosopis) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Omaulus rounded or merely angular; malar area shorter than basal ﬂagellar diameter, rarely longer, in which case another character given above does not agree

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Paraprosopis) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Head shorter, circular or trapezoidal in frontal view; pronotum short, dorsolateral angle rounded or pointed; if mesoscutum coarsely punctate, then head always short

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Paraprosopis) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Facial fovea elongate, somewhat surpassing upper ocular margin, converging strongly toward ocelli, terminating closer to ocelli than to compound eye (Fig. 4711l)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Prosopis) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): Larger species (body length 5-9 mm) usually with short head; facial fovea usually with upper end well separated from eye; propodeum short, at least lateral and posterior surfaces mostly rounded, not delimited by carinae, with ﬁne sculpture and covered with white feltlike hairs; T1 often with lateral fringe of white hairs, but if fringe absent, then metasomal base sometimes red

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Hylaeus s. str.) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): T1 usually without lateral fringe and propodeum usually sharp-edged or carinate; if fringe on T1 present, then following terga without hair bands and propodeum rounded, with ﬁne sculpture

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic Subgenera H. (Lambdopsis) (in part, East Asian species) of Hylaeus (Females)(By H. H. Dathe): T1 and T2 with lateral fringe, margins of T3 and T4 with bands of white hairs; propodeum rounded, partially with weak radial carinae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera H. (Prosopisteron) of Hylaeus(Partly modiﬁed from Snelling, 1985)The Prosopisteron species in the Australian region donot all agree with the characterization in couplet 1. TheAfrican species was introduced and is known only fromthe south coast of Cape Province.: The African species was introduced and is known only from the south coast of Cape Province. 1. Supraclypeal area gently sloping from midline to antennal sockets, not laterally margined; propodeum smooth, densely tessellate, without deﬁned basal area; entire body densely tessellate, with conspicuous punctures; S7 of male with four similar, hairy apical lobes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera H. (Nothylaeus) of Hylaeus(Partly modiﬁed from Snelling, 1985)The Prosopisteron species in the Australian region donot all agree with the characterization in couplet 1. TheAfrican species was introduced and is known only fromthe south coast of Cape Province.: Supraclypeal area elevated between antennal sockets and laterally margined; propodeum with deﬁned basal area, usually coarsely rugose or roughened or sharply punctate, at least in part; S7 of male with two apical lobes or four that are dissimilar, at least one pair hairless

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera H. (Nothylaeus) of Hylaeus(Partly modiﬁed from Snelling, 1985)The Prosopisteron species in the Australian region donot all agree with the characterization in couplet 1. TheAfrican species was introduced and is known only fromthe south coast of Cape Province.: Apex of mandible acute, without distinct teeth; mandible elongate, slender, without grooves and ridges on outer surface

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera H. (Metylaeus) of Hylaeus(Partly modiﬁed from Snelling, 1985)The Prosopisteron species in the Australian region donot all agree with the characterization in couplet 1. TheAfrican species was introduced and is known only fromthe south coast of Cape Province.: Supraclypeal area elevated between antennal sockets and laterally margined; propodeum with deﬁned basal area, usually coarsely rugose or roughened or sharply punctate, at least in part; S7 of male with two apical lobes or four that are dissimilar, at least one pair hairless

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera H. (Metylaeus) of Hylaeus(Partly modiﬁed from Snelling, 1985)The Prosopisteron species in the Australian region donot all agree with the characterization in couplet 1. TheAfrican species was introduced and is known only fromthe south coast of Cape Province.: Apex of mandible transverse or oblique, twoor threetoothed; mandible short and broad, with the usual grooves and ridges on outer surface

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera H. (Metylaeus) of Hylaeus(Partly modiﬁed from Snelling, 1985)The Prosopisteron species in the Australian region donot all agree with the characterization in couplet 1. TheAfrican species was introduced and is known only fromthe south coast of Cape Province.: Integument very coarsely punctate; scutellum and metanotum each usually with a pair of spines (Fig. 4712b); occipital carina present, sharp; omaulus sharply carinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera H. (Alfkenylaeus) of Hylaeus(Partly modiﬁed from Snelling, 1985)The Prosopisteron species in the Australian region donot all agree with the characterization in couplet 1. TheAfrican species was introduced and is known only fromthe south coast of Cape Province.: Supraclypeal area elevated between antennal sockets and laterally margined; propodeum with deﬁned basal area, usually coarsely rugose or roughened or sharply punctate, at least in part; S7 of male with two apical lobes or four that are dissimilar, at least one pair hairless

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera H. (Alfkenylaeus) of Hylaeus(Partly modiﬁed from Snelling, 1985)The Prosopisteron species in the Australian region donot all agree with the characterization in couplet 1. TheAfrican species was introduced and is known only fromthe south coast of Cape Province.: Apex of mandible transverse or oblique, twoor threetoothed; mandible short and broad, with the usual grooves and ridges on outer surface

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera H. (Alfkenylaeus) of Hylaeus(Partly modiﬁed from Snelling, 1985)The Prosopisteron species in the Australian region donot all agree with the characterization in couplet 1. TheAfrican species was introduced and is known only fromthe south coast of Cape Province.: Integument variously punctate; scutellum and metanotum without lateral spines; occipital carina often absent; omaulus not sharply carinate but sometimes with an obscure ridge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera H. (Alfkenylaeus) of Hylaeus(Partly modiﬁed from Snelling, 1985)The Prosopisteron species in the Australian region donot all agree with the characterization in couplet 1. TheAfrican species was introduced and is known only fromthe south coast of Cape Province.: S7 with two apical lobes, these small, directed laterally or basolaterally, with only small setae; gonoforceps of male with distal one-ﬁfth or more narrowed, attenuate, much exceeding apex of penis valve

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Michenerapis) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Preoccipital carina absent; space between clypeus and compound eye narrower than width of middle ocellus; inner hind tibial spur of male strongly modiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Eusphecogastra) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Preoccipital carina present; space between clypeus and compound eye at least about as broad as middle ocellus; inner hind tibial spur of male slender and simple as usual

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Eusphecogastra) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Surface of propodeal triangle strongly convex in middle, or with a conical projection

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Eusphecogastra) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Propodeal triangle convex in middle; T1 small, its basal portion distinctly constricted and subpetiolate; large, more or less slender and nonmetallic species

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Ceratorhiza) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Preoccipital carina present; space between clypeus and compound eye at least about as broad as middle ocellus; inner hind tibial spur of male slender and simple as usual

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Ceratorhiza) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Surface of propodeal triangle strongly convex in middle, or with a conical projection

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Ceratorhiza) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Propodeal triangle with rounded conical projection; T1 not constricted; large and robust species, with head and thorax black (with yellow markings) and metasoma bluegreen

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Gressittapis) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Preoccipital carina present; space between clypeus and compound eye at least about as broad as middle ocellus; inner hind tibial spur of male slender and simple as usual

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Gressittapis) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Surface of propodeal triangle not convex in the middle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Gressittapis) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Propodeal triangle densely ﬂuted longitudinally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Gressittapis) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): T2 and T3 each with band of short, dense, appressed white hair across base; anterior surface of T1 covered with dense, scale-like white hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Heterorhiza) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Preoccipital carina present; space between clypeus and compound eye at least about as broad as middle ocellus; inner hind tibial spur of male slender and simple as usual

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Heterorhiza) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Surface of propodeal triangle not convex in the middle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Heterorhiza) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Propodeal triangle densely ﬂuted longitudinally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Heterorhiza) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): T1 to T3 without short, dense pubescence as described above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Heterorhiza) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Integument of head and thorax strongly sclerotized, with dense, usually strong punctures on the latter; inner hind tibial spur of female distinctly serrate; male T7 with a pair of long spines at apex, the spines broadly separated from each other; male mandible simple at apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Paraheterorhiza) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Preoccipital carina present; space between clypeus and compound eye at least about as broad as middle ocellus; inner hind tibial spur of male slender and simple as usual

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Paraheterorhiza) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Surface of propodeal triangle not convex in the middle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Paraheterorhiza) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Propodeal triangle densely ﬂuted longitudinally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Paraheterorhiza) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): T1 to T3 without short, dense pubescence as described above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Paraheterorhiza) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Integument of head and thorax appearing softer; inner hind tibial spur of female simple; male T7 with or without a pair of projections, these not broadly separated when present; male mandible bidentate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Noonadania) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Preoccipital carina present; space between clypeus and compound eye at least about as broad as middle ocellus; inner hind tibial spur of male slender and simple as usual

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Noonadania) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Surface of propodeal triangle not convex in the middle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Noonadania) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Propodeal triangle not ﬂuted

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Noonadania) of Palaeorhiza(Modiﬁed from Hirashima and Lieftinck, 1982, with cer-tain subgenera added on the basis of literature only): Posterior surface of propodeum hexagonal, surrounded by strong carina connected to longitudinal carinae separating dorsal, dorsolateral, and lateral areas, dorsal area divided by longitudinal median carina; upper portion of mesepisternum ﬂat, depressed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pachyprosopis of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): First abscissa of vein Rs transverse (Fig. 48-4b), so that posterior basal angle of ﬁrst submarginal cell (often also apex of cell R1) is about 90o; lower end of eye of female protruding mesad above mandibular base [only slightly inEuryglossula and Euryglossina (Microdontura)], so that anterior mandibular articulation is usually on a line with median axis of eye; posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell straight (Fig. 48-4) (lateral fovea of T2 well deﬁned, linear, rarely punctiform or absent in minute species; ﬁrst recurrent vein joining ﬁrst submarginal cell or rarely meeting ﬁrst submarginal crossvein)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pachyprosopis of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Second submarginal crossvein about one-third longer than ﬁrst (as in Fig. 48-3b); costal margin of second submarginal cell sloping apically toward costa (as in Fig. 483b); labrum of female nearly always with strong apical spine (mandible of female bidentate, rarely simple)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Euryglossula of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): First abscissa of vein Rs transverse (Fig. 48-4b), so that posterior basal angle of ﬁrst submarginal cell (often also apex of cell R1) is about 90o; lower end of eye of female protruding mesad above mandibular base [only slightly inEuryglossula and Euryglossina (Microdontura)], so that anterior mandibular articulation is usually on a line with median axis of eye; posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell straight (Fig. 48-4) (lateral fovea of T2 well deﬁned, linear, rarely punctiform or absent in minute species; ﬁrst recurrent vein joining ﬁrst submarginal cell or rarely meeting ﬁrst submarginal crossvein)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Euryglossula of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Second submarginal crossvein usually little longer than ﬁrst or absent; costal margin of second submarginal cell subparallel to costal margin of stigma; labrum usually without apical spine (minute species)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Euryglossula of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Basitibial plate of female deﬁned (though in some cases very indistinctly and incompletely), one-fourth to onesixth of length of tibia; eye of female protruding but little mesad over mandibular base; clypeus of female not strongly sloping inward but forming continuous arc with supraclypeal area, as seen in proﬁle (Fig. 48-5a); marginal cell pointed on costa (Fig. 48-4b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Euryglossina of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): First abscissa of vein Rs transverse (Fig. 48-4b), so that posterior basal angle of ﬁrst submarginal cell (often also apex of cell R1) is about 90o; lower end of eye of female protruding mesad above mandibular base [only slightly inEuryglossula and Euryglossina (Microdontura)], so that anterior mandibular articulation is usually on a line with median axis of eye; posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell straight (Fig. 48-4) (lateral fovea of T2 well deﬁned, linear, rarely punctiform or absent in minute species; ﬁrst recurrent vein joining ﬁrst submarginal cell or rarely meeting ﬁrst submarginal crossvein)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Euryglossina of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Second submarginal crossvein usually little longer than ﬁrst or absent; costal margin of second submarginal cell subparallel to costal margin of stigma; labrum usually without apical spine (minute species)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Euryglossina of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Basitibial plate of female not clearly deﬁned, but margin indicated (often vaguely) by tubercles and ending near middle of tibia; eye of female strongly protruding mesad over mandibular base (except in subgenus Microdontura); clypeus of female sloping inward, at least below, usually at distinct angle to supraclypeal area (Fig. 48-5b); apex of marginal cell separated from costa, sometimes by less than width of a vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Brachyhesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): First abscissa of vein Rs oblique (Figs. 48-2, 48-3, 484a), so that posterior basal angle of ﬁrst submarginal cell and apex of cell R1 are nearly always acute; lower end of eye (except in females of Hyphesmaand Tumidihesmaand males of Brachyhesma ) not protruding mesad above mandible, anterior mandibular articulation therefore usually in line with inner orbit; posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell sinuate (Figs. 48-2, 48-3) [except in Brachyhesma(Fig. 48-4a) and Euhesma hemixantha (Cockerell)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Brachyhesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Clypeus more than 3.5 times as broad as long, as seen from front; scape at least two-thirds as long as eye (Fig. 48-5c, d); antennal bases more than three times as far from median ocellus as from lower edge of clypeus; eye of male usually produced mesad above anterior mandibular anticulation (minute, largely yellow forms, antennal sockets immediately above epistomal suture and subantennal sutures thus absent)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hyphesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): First abscissa of vein Rs oblique (Figs. 48-2, 48-3, 484a), so that posterior basal angle of ﬁrst submarginal cell and apex of cell R1 are nearly always acute; lower end of eye (except in females of Hyphesmaand Tumidihesmaand males of Brachyhesma ) not protruding mesad above mandible, anterior mandibular articulation therefore usually in line with inner orbit; posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell sinuate (Figs. 48-2, 48-3) [except in Brachyhesma(Fig. 48-4a) and Euhesma hemixantha (Cockerell)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hyphesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Clypeus usually less than 3.5 times as broad as long; scape usually not much more than one-half as long as eye; antennal bases not much more than twice as far from median ocellus as from lower edge of clypeus; eye of male not produced mesad above anterior mandibular articulation

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hyphesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Costal margin of second submarginal cell distinctly sloping apically toward costa (Fig. 48-3b), the cell having more or less the same shape as that of Pachyprosopis; facial fovea of female with lower end curved mesad toward antennal base; eye of female strongly protruding mesad above anterior mandibular articulation (body black, without yellow markings)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Heterohesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): First abscissa of vein Rs oblique (Figs. 48-2, 48-3, 484a), so that posterior basal angle of ﬁrst submarginal cell and apex of cell R1 are nearly always acute; lower end of eye (except in females of Hyphesmaand Tumidihesmaand males of Brachyhesma ) not protruding mesad above mandible, anterior mandibular articulation therefore usually in line with inner orbit; posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell sinuate (Figs. 48-2, 48-3) [except in Brachyhesma(Fig. 48-4a) and Euhesma hemixantha (Cockerell)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Heterohesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Clypeus usually less than 3.5 times as broad as long; scape usually not much more than one-half as long as eye; antennal bases not much more than twice as far from median ocellus as from lower edge of clypeus; eye of male not produced mesad above anterior mandibular articulation

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Heterohesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Costal margin of second submarginal cell usually subparallel to costal margin of stigma (Fig. 48-2); facial fovea of female not curved mesad toward antennal base; eye of female not protruding mesad above anterior mandibular articulation [except in Tumidihesmaand Euhesma hyphesmoides (Michener)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Heterohesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): T1 about as broad as long, as seen from above; body wholly black; distal part of pygidial plate of female narrower than last tarsal segment, apex upturned; inner hind tibial spur ﬁnely ciliate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dasyhesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): First abscissa of vein Rs oblique (Figs. 48-2, 48-3, 484a), so that posterior basal angle of ﬁrst submarginal cell and apex of cell R1 are nearly always acute; lower end of eye (except in females of Hyphesmaand Tumidihesmaand males of Brachyhesma ) not protruding mesad above mandible, anterior mandibular articulation therefore usually in line with inner orbit; posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell sinuate (Figs. 48-2, 48-3) [except in Brachyhesma(Fig. 48-4a) and Euhesma hemixantha (Cockerell)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dasyhesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Clypeus usually less than 3.5 times as broad as long; scape usually not much more than one-half as long as eye; antennal bases not much more than twice as far from median ocellus as from lower edge of clypeus; eye of male not produced mesad above anterior mandibular articulation

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dasyhesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Costal margin of second submarginal cell usually subparallel to costal margin of stigma (Fig. 48-2); facial fovea of female not curved mesad toward antennal base; eye of female not protruding mesad above anterior mandibular articulation [except in Tumidihesmaand Euhesma hyphesmoides (Michener)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dasyhesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): T1 much broader than long or body largely yellow; if distal part of pygidial plate of female narrower than last tarsal segment, then inner hind tibial spur pectinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dasyhesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Second submarginal cell strongly narrowed toward costa, about half as long on anterior side as on posterior side (Fig. 48-2d); second submarginal crossvein strongly curved or sinuate and at an angle of about 45o to ﬁrst; head and thorax strongly and closely punctate, metasoma dull with dense, minute punctures

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sericogaster of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): First abscissa of vein Rs oblique (Figs. 48-2, 48-3, 484a), so that posterior basal angle of ﬁrst submarginal cell and apex of cell R1 are nearly always acute; lower end of eye (except in females of Hyphesmaand Tumidihesmaand males of Brachyhesma ) not protruding mesad above mandible, anterior mandibular articulation therefore usually in line with inner orbit; posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell sinuate (Figs. 48-2, 48-3) [except in Brachyhesma(Fig. 48-4a) and Euhesma hemixantha (Cockerell)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sericogaster of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Clypeus usually less than 3.5 times as broad as long; scape usually not much more than one-half as long as eye; antennal bases not much more than twice as far from median ocellus as from lower edge of clypeus; eye of male not produced mesad above anterior mandibular articulation

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sericogaster of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Costal margin of second submarginal cell usually subparallel to costal margin of stigma (Fig. 48-2); facial fovea of female not curved mesad toward antennal base; eye of female not protruding mesad above anterior mandibular articulation [except in Tumidihesmaand Euhesma hyphesmoides (Michener)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sericogaster of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): T1 much broader than long or body largely yellow; if distal part of pygidial plate of female narrower than last tarsal segment, then inner hind tibial spur pectinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sericogaster of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Second submarginal cell little shorter on anterior side than on posterior side, second submarginal crossvein only gently curved and subparallel to ﬁrst or at an angle of less than 40o to ﬁrst (Fig. 48-2a-c); head and thorax with punctures ﬁne or well separated, metasoma not dull with minute, dense punctures, although sometimes dulled by other sculpturing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sericogaster of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Basitibial plate in both sexes indicated by two rows of large tubercles, the rows nearly meeting and terminating the “plate” well beyond middle of tibia (Fig. 48-5g); median ocellus closer to antennae than to posterior edge of vertex in female (Fig. 48-5e), and midway between these points in male

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stenohesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): First abscissa of vein Rs oblique (Figs. 48-2, 48-3, 484a), so that posterior basal angle of ﬁrst submarginal cell and apex of cell R1 are nearly always acute; lower end of eye (except in females of Hyphesmaand Tumidihesmaand males of Brachyhesma ) not protruding mesad above mandible, anterior mandibular articulation therefore usually in line with inner orbit; posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell sinuate (Figs. 48-2, 48-3) [except in Brachyhesma(Fig. 48-4a) and Euhesma hemixantha (Cockerell)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stenohesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Clypeus usually less than 3.5 times as broad as long; scape usually not much more than one-half as long as eye; antennal bases not much more than twice as far from median ocellus as from lower edge of clypeus; eye of male not produced mesad above anterior mandibular articulation

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stenohesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Costal margin of second submarginal cell usually subparallel to costal margin of stigma (Fig. 48-2); facial fovea of female not curved mesad toward antennal base; eye of female not protruding mesad above anterior mandibular articulation [except in Tumidihesmaand Euhesma hyphesmoides (Michener)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stenohesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): T1 much broader than long or body largely yellow; if distal part of pygidial plate of female narrower than last tarsal segment, then inner hind tibial spur pectinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stenohesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Second submarginal cell little shorter on anterior side than on posterior side, second submarginal crossvein only gently curved and subparallel to ﬁrst or at an angle of less than 40o to ﬁrst (Fig. 48-2a-c); head and thorax with punctures ﬁne or well separated, metasoma not dull with minute, dense punctures, although sometimes dulled by other sculpturing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stenohesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Basitibial plate not extending beyond middle of tibia, although a single row of tubercles may extend beyond middle; vertex less produced posteriorly so that median ocellus is at or behind midpoint between antennae and posterior edge of vertex in female and behind midpoint in male

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stenohesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Body slender, T1 seen from above little broader than long (extensive yellow pattern on body; mandible simple in both sexes)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Melittosmithia of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Clypeus with strong longitudinal median carina (mandible simple) (male unknown)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Euryglossa of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Anterior end of scutum, especially in female, nearly as broad as scutal width at anterior ends of tegulae; front of scutum curved down rather sharply and usually differently sculptured than rest of scutum; scutum coarsely punctured, in female with large, shining interspaces or smooth impunctate areas; basitibial area of female deﬁned by large tubercles or basally by carinae, a particularly strong tubercle at apex (Fig. 48-5h) (inner hind tibial spur of female strongly pectinate; body usually without yellow markings)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Callohesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Apex of marginal cell rounded or somewhat pointed, bent well away from wing margin; outer surface of hind tibia of female covered with simple bristles (integument yellow or with yellow markings)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Tumidihesma of the Euryglossinae(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1965b): Mandible of female (male unknown) tridentate; facial fovea linear, not bent toward ocelli; lower end of eye protruding mesad above anterior mandibular articulation

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Brachyhesma s. str.) of Brachyhesma, Based on Males(Modiﬁed from Exley, 1977): Supraclypeal area and upper part of clypeus protruding strongly forward between antennal bases (Fig. 48-5d); clypeus, in frontal view, a mere strip across lower end of face, its major area reﬂexed and exposed ventrally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Brachyhesma s. str.) of Brachyhesma, Based on Males(Modiﬁed from Exley, 1977): Reﬂexed part of clypeus forming a ﬂattened or concave triangular plate; scape nearly as long as to longer than eye (Fig. 48-5d)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Microhesma) of Brachyhesma, Based on Males(Modiﬁed from Exley, 1977): Supraclypeal area and upper part of clypeus protruding strongly forward between antennal bases (Fig. 48-5d); clypeus, in frontal view, a mere strip across lower end of face, its major area reﬂexed and exposed ventrally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Microhesma) of Brachyhesma, Based on Males(Modiﬁed from Exley, 1977): Reﬂexed part of clypeus convex, not forming triangular plate; scape much shorter than eye.....B. (Anomalohesma) 3(1). Metasoma yellow with transverse brown tergal bands; proﬁle of clypeus strongly convex (Fig. 48-5c); gonobase almost one-half length of genitalia (Fig. 48-5n)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Parahesma) of Euhesma: Basitibial area of female margined by large tubercles and reaching middle of tibia, apex of area marked by strong tubercle; disc of scutum almost impunctate, smooth and shiny, in female; inner hind tibial spur of female coarsely pectinate as in Callohesma and Euryglossa (male unknown)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Euhesma s. str.) of Euhesma: Basitibial area of female shorter, apex usually not marked by large tubercle, margins usually indicated by carinae that are sometimes mostly absent, sometimes broken into large tubercles; disc of scutum punctate and usually minutely roughened and dull; inner hind tibial spur of female ciliate, serrate, or weakly pectinate, that is, with teeth short

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Microdontura) of Euryglossina: Hind tibia (both sexes) with row of suberect, scalelike and spinelike setae on outer surface from near base to apex; apex of pygidial plate of female elongate, upturned

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Quasihesma) of Euryglossina: Hind tibiae without such setae, usually with scattered small tubercles, largest one (near middle of tibia in females, slightly basal to middle in males) probably representing apex of otherwise undeﬁned basitibial plate; apex of pygidial plate of female not upturned

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Quasihesma) of Euryglossina: Costal edge of marginal cell distinctly shorter than stigma (as in Fig. 48-6a); ﬁrst recurrent vein, if present, entering ﬁrst submarginal cell near middle; vein M/H11001Cu between basal vein (M) and vein m-cu of forewing longer than basal vein; claws of female with small preapical tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Quasihesma) of Euryglossina: S7 of male with small to moderate-sized, laterally directed, apical lobes and broadly expanded, triangular basolateral apodemes; face of male with minute pit (“glandular opening”) above and lateral to antennal base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Euryglossella) of Euryglossina: Hind tibiae without such setae, usually with scattered small tubercles, largest one (near middle of tibia in females, slightly basal to middle in males) probably representing apex of otherwise undeﬁned basitibial plate; apex of pygidial plate of female not upturned

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Euryglossella) of Euryglossina: Costal edge of marginal cell distinctly shorter than stigma (as in Fig. 48-6a); ﬁrst recurrent vein, if present, entering ﬁrst submarginal cell near middle; vein M/H11001Cu between basal vein (M) and vein m-cu of forewing longer than basal vein; claws of female with small preapical tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Euryglossella) of Euryglossina: S7 of males almost without small posteriorly directed apical lobes or with small ones, basolateral apodemes normal, almost straplike form; face of male lacking pit above and lateral to antennal base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Euryglossina s. str.) of Euryglossina: Hind tibiae without such setae, usually with scattered small tubercles, largest one (near middle of tibia in females, slightly basal to middle in males) probably representing apex of otherwise undeﬁned basitibial plate; apex of pygidial plate of female not upturned

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Euryglossina s. str.) of Euryglossina: Costal edge of marginal cell equal to or slightly longer than stigma; ﬁrst recurrent vein, if present, entering ﬁrst submarginal cell near apex or in distal one-ﬁfth; vein M/H11001Cu between basal vein (M) and vein m-cu of forewing about one-third as long as basal vein; claws of female simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Euryglossina s. str.) of Euryglossina: Labrum of female without median apical spine; second submarginal cell usually not shaped as in Pachyprosopis

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Pachyprosopina) of Euryglossina: Hind tibiae without such setae, usually with scattered small tubercles, largest one (near middle of tibia in females, slightly basal to middle in males) probably representing apex of otherwise undeﬁned basitibial plate; apex of pygidial plate of female not upturned

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Pachyprosopina) of Euryglossina: Costal edge of marginal cell equal to or slightly longer than stigma; ﬁrst recurrent vein, if present, entering ﬁrst submarginal cell near apex or in distal one-ﬁfth; vein M/H11001Cu between basal vein (M) and vein m-cu of forewing about one-third as long as basal vein; claws of female simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Pachyprosopina) of Euryglossina: Labrum of female with median apical spine; second submarginal cell shaped like that of Pachyprosopis (as in Fig. 48-3b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pachyprosopis s. str.) of Pachyprosopis (Females): Facial fovea with upper end on level of, or below, upper end of eye, nearer eye margin than to lateral ocellus, not curved mesad; margin of basitibial plate represented by tubercles that extend beyond middle of tibia; clypeus more than three times as wide as median length

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Argohesma) of Xanthesma: First recurrent vein entering apex of ﬁrst submarginal cell; stigma as long as or longer than costal edge of marginal cell

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Xenohesma) of Xanthesma: First recurrent vein entering base of second submarginal cell or meeting ﬁrst submarginal crossvein; stigma shorter than costal edge of marginal cell

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Xenohesma) of Xanthesma: Eyes of male strongly converging above, upper end of eye less than ocellar diameter from lateral ocellus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Chaetohesma) of Xanthesma: First recurrent vein entering base of second submarginal cell or meeting ﬁrst submarginal crossvein; stigma shorter than costal edge of marginal cell

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Chaetohesma) of Xanthesma: Eyes of male subparallel or converging below, upper end of eye more than ocellar diameter from lateral ocellus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Chaetohesma) of Xanthesma: Mandible of female with weak preapical tooth; male without vertical groove on paraocular area; front coxa of female with several distinctive bristles on apex mesal to base of trochanter

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Xanthesma s. str.) of Xanthesma: First recurrent vein entering base of second submarginal cell or meeting ﬁrst submarginal crossvein; stigma shorter than costal edge of marginal cell

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Xanthesma s. str.) of Xanthesma: Eyes of male subparallel or converging below, upper end of eye more than ocellar diameter from lateral ocellus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Xanthesma s. str.) of Xanthesma: Mandible of female simple; many males with vertical groove in paraocular area midway between antennal base and eye, and tuft of hair at lower end of groove (Fig. 472e); front coxa of female without such bristles

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Oxaeinae, of the Andrenidae: Stigma essentially absent; marginal cell over seven times as long as broad and only half as wide as widest submarginal cell (Fig. 60-2a); mentum absent or fused to ﬂat lorum; proboscidial lobe absent; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment as long as scape (Western Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Andreninae, of the Andrenidae: Stigma present; marginal cell shorter and broader, about as wide as widest submarginal cell; mentum and lorum both present, forming proboscidial lobe; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually shorter than scape

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Andreninae, of the Andrenidae: Apex of marginal cell pointed or narrowly rounded on or near wing margin (Fig. 51-2) (facial fovea not or weakly evident in male, in female, when present, slightly depressed, covered with short hairs; gonobase of male distinct and large, reduced to narrow ring or almost absent in Megandrena)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Alocandreninae, of the Andrenidae: Stigma present; marginal cell shorter and broader, about as wide as widest submarginal cell; mentum and lorum both present, forming proboscidial lobe; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually shorter than scape

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Alocandreninae, of the Andrenidae: Apex of marginal cell truncate, sometimes obliquely so, cell thus pointed well away from wing margin (Figs. 501f, 53-1)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Alocandreninae, of the Andrenidae: Facial fovea of both sexes a distinct deep pocket with short hairs (Fig. 50-1a, b); gonobase of male distinct and large (Fig. 50-1c-e) (Peru)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Panurginae, of the Andrenidae: Stigma present; marginal cell shorter and broader, about as wide as widest submarginal cell; mentum and lorum both present, forming proboscidial lobe; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually shorter than scape

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Panurginae, of the Andrenidae: Apex of marginal cell truncate, sometimes obliquely so, cell thus pointed well away from wing margin (Figs. 501f, 53-1)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Panurginae, of the Andrenidae: Facial fovea hairless and shining, often absent in males, rarely also in females (Melitturga); gonobase of male absent or nearly so

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ancylandrena of the Andreninae (Females): Facial fovea depressed, velvety (Fig. 51-1a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ancylandrena of the Andreninae (Females): Hairs of hind trochanter rather dense, short, the longer ones simple, not much curved; anterior surface of T1 broadly concave, much longer than dorsal surface of T1 (Fig. 51-1c, d) (southwestern North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Andrena of the Andreninae (Females): Facial fovea depressed, velvety (Fig. 51-1a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Andrena of the Andreninae (Females): Some hairs of hind trochanter long, curved distad, plumose, forming a ﬂoccus (Fig. 51-1b) closing basal end of femoral corbicula; anterior surface of T1 with smaller concavity or groove, surface shorter than to slightly longer than dorsal surface of T1 (Fig. 51-1e, f)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Andrena of the Andreninae (Females): Hind basitarsus more than half as long as hind tibia; stigma often broader than prestigma (measured to wing margin), margins usually converging basad from vein r (Fig. 51-2a, b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megandrena of the Andreninae (Males): Gonobase a narrow ring or essentially absent (Fig. 51-7a, b); mandible simple or with weak preapical shoulder on upper margin (southwestern USA)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Andrena of the Andreninae (Males): Gonobase with broad dorsal surface; mandible with preapical tooth on upper margin (except in Euherbstia from Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Andrena of the Andreninae (Males): Anterior surface of T1 largely convex, the concavity a median, longitudinal groove or depression, this surface shorter than to slightly longer than distance from its upper end to apex of T1; hind basitarsus ﬁve or more times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Euherbstia of the Andreninae (Males): Gonobase with broad dorsal surface; mandible with preapical tooth on upper margin (except in Euherbstia from Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Euherbstia of the Andreninae (Males): Anterior surface of T1 largely ﬂat (in Euherbstia) or concave, the concavity a median, longitudinal line or groove, this surface usually longer than distance from its upper end to apex of T1; hind basitarsus less than ﬁve times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Euherbstia of the Andreninae (Males): Mandible simple; inner subantennal suture converging below toward outer suture, so that subantennal area has only short margin on epistomal suture (Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Orphana of the Andreninae (Males): Gonobase with broad dorsal surface; mandible with preapical tooth on upper margin (except in Euherbstia from Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Orphana of the Andreninae (Males): Anterior surface of T1 largely ﬂat (in Euherbstia) or concave, the concavity a median, longitudinal line or groove, this surface usually longer than distance from its upper end to apex of T1; hind basitarsus less than ﬁve times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Orphana of the Andreninae (Males): Mandible with preapical tooth on upper margin; inner subantennal suture not converging strongly below toward outer suture

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Orphana of the Andreninae (Males): S7 a broad plate with large median apical process (anterolateral processes partly hairy, not comparable to anterolateral apodemes, Fig. 51-6h); epistomal suture separated from antennal socket by much less than diameter of socket (Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ancylandrena of the Andreninae (Males): Gonobase with broad dorsal surface; mandible with preapical tooth on upper margin (except in Euherbstia from Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ancylandrena of the Andreninae (Males): Anterior surface of T1 largely ﬂat (in Euherbstia) or concave, the concavity a median, longitudinal line or groove, this surface usually longer than distance from its upper end to apex of T1; hind basitarsus less than ﬁve times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ancylandrena of the Andreninae (Males): Mandible with preapical tooth on upper margin; inner subantennal suture not converging strongly below toward outer suture

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ancylandrena of the Andreninae (Males): S7 with a relatively small body, large anterolateral apodemes, and two small apical lobes (Fig. 51-3d); epistomal suture separated from antennal socket by about diameter of socket (Fig. 51-3e) (southwestern North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeal triangle coarsely sculptured

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Aporandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Aporandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Aporandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Thoracic dorsum with hairs short, forming a dense mat

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Charitandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Charitandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Charitandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Thoracic dorsum with normal, long, plumose hairs not at all forming a mat obscuring surface

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeum outside of triangle with punctures moderately roughening surface; dorsal femoral hairs often with abundant short, S-shaped branches bent away from rachis, appearing highly plumose; galeal blade generally narrow, its outer margin in apical half usually straight

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Leucandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Leucandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Leucandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Malar area extremely short, linear, its length onesixth to one-tenth of its width; dorsolateral angle of pronotum weak; basal area of labrum simple, as long as broad or longer, strap-shaped or U-shaped with sides diverging slightly basad; propodeal triangle roughened at least mediobasally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oligandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oligandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oligandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur long, slender, not bent nor markedly twisted at apical third

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oligandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Facial quadrangle broader than long; propodeal corbicula poorly formed, lacking long internal hairs, dorsal hairs extremely short, not ﬂexed down over corbicular area (terga without pale apical fasciae)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Callandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Callandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Callandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Scopal hairs largely plumose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A.
