(Iomelissa) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Labial palpus elongate, but ﬁrst two segments not unusually long nor much ﬂattened; maxillary palpus elongate, more than half as long as galeal blade; basal area of labrum distinctly raised above general level of surface

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Iomelissa) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Maxillary palpus with second segment at least 1.5 times as long as ﬁrst; stipes distinctly narrowed medially and tapering apically, the apical third thus less than half as broad as basal third, with weak, plumose hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Erandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Labial palpus elongate, but ﬁrst two segments not unusually long nor much ﬂattened; maxillary palpus elongate, more than half as long as galeal blade; basal area of labrum distinctly raised above general level of surface

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Erandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Maxillary palpus with second segment about as long as ﬁrst; stipes linear, tapering from base to apex, with abundant, long, spinelike hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scrapteropsis) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): T2-T4 with depressed marginal zones less than half length of exposed part of each tergum medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Trachandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): T2-T4 with depressed marginal zones half or more length of exposed part of each tergum medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Tylandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Pronotum laterally with deeply impressed groove cutting diagonally up and forward from pronotal spiracle to near midline anteriorly, this groove crossing and strongly depressing ridge extending down from dorsolateral angle; T2-T4 without apical pale fasciae or these weak and broadly interrupted; genal area broader than eye in side view; ocelloccipital distance about one and one-half to two and one-half ocellar diameters

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Diandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Diandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Integument often metallic blue or blue-green; propodeum outside of triangle roughened by punctures

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Parandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeal triangle ﬁnely tessellate; propodeal corbicula complete anteriorly, with few or no internal hairs; integument black or in part red, not metallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hesperandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hesperandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeum with lateral surface completely set off from dorsal and posterior surfaces by a carina, proﬁle declivous from base to apex; clypeus short

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Celetandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Subgenal coronet absent; vestiture largely black or dark brown (Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ptilandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ptilandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Scopal hairs entirely or mostly dark brown to black; pronotal dorsolateral ridge close to pronotal lobe; ﬁrst recurrent vein usually meeting second submarginal cell near middle of cell

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Archiandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Archiandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeal corbicula complete anteriorly, with few or no internal hairs; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment scarcely, if any, longer than second segment

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ptilandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ptilandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Scopal hairs entirely or mostly dark brown to black; pronotal dorsolateral ridge close to pronotal lobe; ﬁrst recurrent vein usually meeting second submarginal cell near middle of cell

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Belandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Belandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Belandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur long, slender, not bent nor markedly twisted at apical third

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Belandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Labial palpal segments 2 and 3 each with next segment attached subapically, the third segment attached to second near middle of second segment; integument bright metallic blue-black; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell about two-thirds of cell length from base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scoliandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scoliandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Galeal blade with abundant short, hooked hairs; body usually ll mm long or more (integument usually metallic blue or black)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Derandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Derandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Middle and hind tibial spurs long and slender, their apices usually evenly curved

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Derandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Pronotum with weak dorsolateral angle, the dorsoventral ridge absent or extremely weak; face below ocelli tessellate, without distinct longitudinal rugulae or punctures

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oxyandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oxyandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Facial fovea extremely elongate, almost reaching vertex above, occupying most of paraocular space below; ocelloccipital distance half an ocellar diameter or less; terga impunctate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Geissandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Geissandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Hypostomal carina with longitudinal part longer than lateral part, lamellate, as high as two-thirds length of last labial palpal segment (clypeus with free apical margin elongate, moderately upturned; T2-T4 with pale apical fasciae interrupted medially)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dactylandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dactylandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dactylandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Malar area at least half as long as broad; propodeal corbicula incomplete, male-like; vestiture black

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Conandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Conandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Malar area about half as long as broad; pleural hairs pale ochraceous to white

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cnemidandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cnemidandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Middle basitarsus expanded medially (T2-T4 and usually T1 with complete apical pale fasciae of hairs with close-set, short barbs, giving them a dull appearance; basal area of labrum strongly bidentate and reﬂexed)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Larandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Larandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Median third of clypeus impunctate, shiny; tibial scopal hairs weakly plumose throughout; scutellum shiny, unshagreened at least medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Xiphandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Xiphandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Xiphandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): First ﬂagellar segment only slightly longer than second, about as long as third segment; propodeal triangle with distinct longitudinal rugulae ending posteriorly in irregularly reticulate rugulae (propodeal corbicula incomplete anteriorly, with abundant internal hairs)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhaphandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhaphandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhaphandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeal triangle with coarse longitudinal rugulae; metasomal terga distinctly punctate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Nemandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur neither bent nor broadened near base, or if so, then tibial scopal hairs plumose and spur only slightly broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Nemandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Scutum between parapsidal lines with numerous, extremely ﬁne, longitudinal rugulae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Gonandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Gonandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Gonandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Genal area often with strong posterior carina; scutellum shiny, unshagreened; propodeal triangle with rather coarse irregular sculpturing; clypeus with apical margin usually broad, distinctly reﬂexed or turned upward

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Leucandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur bent and broadened near base; tibial scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Leucandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Leucandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Malar area extremely short, linear, its length onesixth to one-tenth of its width; dorsolateral angle of pronotum weak; basal area of labrum simple, as long as broad or longer, strap-shaped or U-shaped with sides diverging slightly basad; propodeal triangle roughened at least mediobasally

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Psammandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Labrum below basal area with strong median crista, often lamellate, and with strong lateral crista and two shiny transverse sulci (metasomal terga tessellate, opaque)

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Thysandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Females)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Propodeum outside of triangle without punctures, smoothly tessellate or shagreened; dorsal femoral hairs with relatively short, stiff barbs or simple; galeal blade with outer apical margin gently convex, broad at base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Inner hind tibial spur slightly broadened basally by a membranous ﬂange, often strongly curved, broader than outer spur; S6 bent downward and forward apicolaterally to form two reﬂexed blunt teeth; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell near or only slightly beyond middle of cell

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Trachandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Marginal zone of T2 one-third or more of median tergal length; third ﬂagellar segment usually two-thirds as wide as long or longer, antennae in repose usually reaching beyond scutellum; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell near middle of cell, rarely beyond

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scrapteropsis) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Marginal zone of T2 less than one-third of median tergal length; third ﬂagellar segment distinctly more than two-thirds as wide as long, antennae in repose usually not reaching beyond middle of scutellum; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell two-thirds or more of length of cell from base

Author: Daniel C. Danforth

(T aeniandrena) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Clypeus ﬂattened mediobasally; metasomal terga distinctly punctate, surface and bottoms of punctures dulled by ﬁne tessellation; T2-T5 with pale apical fasciae, but these often interrupted medially

Title: Bees Of The World

Title: Bees Of The World

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. Title: Bees Of The World

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena)(in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Submarginal cells three

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Thysandrena) (in part) of Andrena of North and Central America (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1986): Galeal blade broad basally, outer margin of apical half or less gently concave; basal area of labrum usually emarginate apically

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Orandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.: Inner side of hind femur with a row of small peglike or thornlike projections

Title: Bees Of The World

In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.: Tibial scopa of simple hairs; labrum not conspicuously divided

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rufandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Females)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.: Tibial scopa of small to large plumose hairs; labrum divided conspicuously into median and lateral parts

Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key)The subgenus Oreomelissa, containing the EuropeanAndrena coitana(Kirby), is omitted from the key to males,but see the key to Japanese subgenera. Warncke (1968)placed this species in Stenomelissa but neither describedthat subgenus nor placed it in his key. It presumably hasnothing to do with the east Asian Stenomelissa Hirashimaand LaBerge. Although Carinandrena, Fuscandrena,Leimelissa, Longandrena, Osychnyukandrena, and Pla-niandrena are palearctic taxa, they not included in thiskey. Four of them are monotypic. Malayapis is included,although it is oriental. For couplet 17, see also couplet 49;the subgenus Holandrenawould seemingly run to couplet18. In Warncke’s key these couplet numbers are 17 and48, respectively.: Surface of propodeal corbicula impunctate and bare, its margin entirely densely hairy; metanotum with dense, light tuft of hairs directed forward

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Scitandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Metasoma ﬁnely and densely punctate; genitalia complex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Campylogaster) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Mesepisternum strongly and deeply punctate; head thick, with short clypeus; genitalia simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cubiandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Propodeum entirely declivous; ocelloccipital distance almost as long as four midﬂagellar segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Micrandrena)(in part) and A. (Fumandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Propodeal triangle strongly to weakly rugose, usually areolate to posterior truncation of basal area (clypeus black)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Distandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): First ﬂagellar segment at least as long as second and third taken together; clypeus usually longitudinally grooved and weakly elongated, always black; genitalia simple with elongated gonostylus, which is uniformly broad to apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Aciandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Clypeus yellow or rarely black; gonostylus slightly angled, shovel-shaped

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Graecandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Clypeus black or exceptionally yellow; gonostylus not as above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (T aeniandrena)and A. (Troandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Broad central area of clypeus ﬂattened, anterior edge truncate, punctation not strong; basal area of labrum shortened and transversely wrinkled basally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Charitandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Charitandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Clypeus yellow; mesepisternum with strongly inclined punctures having weak, downwardly elongated, raised margins

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Didonia) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cryptandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cryptandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Mesepisternum strongly rugosely areolate; metasoma strongly punctate and glossy; clypeus usually ﬂat (clypeus broader than long)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chlorandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chlorandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): T1 shagreened, with craterlike punctures (edges of punctures raised on all sides), or, if terga glossy and strongly punctate, then propodeal triangle toward metanotum at most weakly rugose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Suandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Suandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Propodeal triangle alveolarly areolate to posterior margin; mesepisternum not alveolar but punctures slightly sloped, with weakly raised margins (genitalia typically complex)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hoplandrena) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Carandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Carandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Mesepisternum and propodeal triangle strongly rugose-alveolar

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Carandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Pronotum without strong, elevated dorsolateral angle (ridge) and without well-developed dorsoventral carina below it

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Carandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Galeal blade of normal length; mesepisternum ﬁnely punctate; propodeal triangle shagreened with few short rugae near anterior margin; metasoma usually very ﬁnely punctate; gonostylar apex and penis valve scarcely broadened

Title: Bees Of The World

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Apex of S8 rarely strongly broadened, and never bearing visible spines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Galeal blade short; mesepisternum strongly punctate; propodeal triangle shagreened and weakly rugosely areolate; metasoma usually conspicuously punctate; gonostylar apex and penis valve distinctly broadened

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andrena s. str.) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Clypeus ﬂattened and broad, anterior margin usually distinctly indented; genitalia complex

Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ptilandrena) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Propodeal triangle rugosely wrinkled; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell about in middle; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment longer than second

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hoplandrena) (in part) of Andrena of the WesternPalearctic Region (Males)(Modiﬁed from A. Molino-Pardo’s translation (MS) ofWarncke’s 1968 key): Propodeal triangle smooth and shiny to shagreened, without rugae; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting second submarginal cell far beyond middle; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually very short, seldom longer than second

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Parandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Submarginal cells two

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Micrandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Submarginal cells three

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Micrandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Body length about or less than 7 mm; T1 impunctate or ﬁnely and sparsely punctate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Trachandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Submarginal cells three

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Trachandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Body length about or more than 8 mm; if occasionally smaller, then T1 closely punctate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Trachandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Propodeal triangle clearly indicated, coarsely roughened to strongly wrinkled, basal area bounded posteriorly by transverse carina or by strong wrinkles behind which surface is declivous

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Trachandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Facial fovea separated from eye by wide, shiny space; scutum and scutellum either foveolate-punctate or very strongly rugoso-punctate; inner hind tibial spur neither widened nor curved near base; trochanteral ﬂoccus incomplete, scanty; body length less than 10 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): T riangle of propodeum large, well indicated, sparsely wrinkled; propodeum outside triangle densely tessellate and densely rugose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Stenomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Submarginal cells three

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Stenomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Body length about or more than 8 mm; if occasionally smaller, then T1 closely punctate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Stenomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured, or, if coarsely sculptured, then apex of triangle not bounded by a transverse carina nor by irregular rugae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Stenomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Tibial scopa well developed, composed of long, dense, branched hairs, and femoral scopal hairs also branched

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Stenomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Head elongate; clypeus protuberant

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chlorandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Head broader than long, more or less round in front view; clypeus not protuberant

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Habromelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Third submarginal cell receiving second recurrent vein at end of cell or close to it

Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cnemidandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Middle basitarsus strongly expanded medially, subequal to or broader than hind basitarsus (the latter widened subbasally)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poecilandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Submarginal cells three

(Poecilandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Propodeal triangle ﬁnely sculptured, or, if coarsely sculptured, then apex of triangle not bounded by a transverse carina nor by irregular rugae

(Poecilandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Tibial scopa and femoral scopa largely composed of simple hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poecilandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Third submarginal cell receiving second recurrent vein well before end of cell

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poecilandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Middle basitarsus slender, not widened medially (or at most only slightly so)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poecilandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): T1 densely, ﬁnely punctate; T2 and T3 progressively more sparsely, ﬁnely punctate; metasoma sparsely hairy, without distinct hair fringes; posterior margins of metasomal terga yellowish-transparent; clypeus densely tessellate, dull, sparsely and more or less weakly punctate, with broad, median, longitudinal, impunctate space; antenna short, swollen toward apical segments, ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment one and one-half times as long as broad, about as long as second plus third segments; scutum tessellate, more or less weakly punctate, covered with rather short, pale fulvous hairs; propodeal triangle well indicated, distinctly wrinkled all over; propodeum outside triangle densely rugulose or nearly shagreened; robust species, length about or less than 8 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hoplandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Metasoma with integument densely tessellate, therefore dull, impunctate or with indications of weak, sparse punctures; posterior margins of T3 and T4 each with complete, narrow band of short, dense, appressed, white hairs, a similar hair band usually on posterior margin of T2; interior of propodeal corbicula with sparse, usually coarse, simple hairs throughout

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andrena s. str.) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Metasoma tessellate, impunctate, dull or slightly shiny; trochanteral ﬂoccus complete, well developed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): T riangle of propodeum large, well indicated, sparsely wrinkled; propodeum outside triangle densely tessellate and densely rugose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Holandrena) (in part) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Propodeal corbicula with sparse, coarse, simple hairs nearly throughout interior; dorsal fringe of corbicula rather well indicated but not well developed, rather short and not especially dense; no fringe of hairs on anterior margin of corbicula; trochanteral ﬂoccus complete, dense; metasoma smooth and shiny, weakly to very weakly punctate; interocellar distance equal to or a little longer than ocelloccipital distance

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Simandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Propodeal corbicula well developed, with dorsal fringe of long, dense, well-arranged, curled hairs, and with complete fringe of hairs anteriorly, interior of corbicula free of hairs medially; hind tibia rather short, dilated apically

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Propodeal corbicula moderately well developed, with dorsal fringe of long, dense, rather wellto well-arranged hairs, interior of corbicula with coarse, simple hairs throughout, no complete fringe of hairs anteriorly, but frequently sparse branched hairs present on dorsal portion of anterior margin; trochanteral ﬂoccus incomplete, scanty to dense; tibial scopa compact, well developed; facial fovea separated from eye by a narrow punctate space; mediumsized to large, robust species

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Holandrena) (in part) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Propodeal corbicula with sparse, coarse, simple hairs nearly throughout interior; dorsal fringe of corbicula rather well indicated but not well developed, rather short and not especially dense; no fringe of hairs on anterior margin of corbicula; trochanteral ﬂoccus complete, dense; metasoma smooth and shiny, weakly to very weakly punctate; interocellar distance equal to or a little longer than ocelloccipital distance

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (T aeniandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Metasoma short-oval, densely tessellate-punctate, nearly dull or weakly shiny, posterior margins of intermediate terga with narrow, appressed, pure-white hair bands, those of T3 and T4 complete; head broad and thin, nearly round in front view; clypeus hardly convex, tessellate, coarsely rugoso-punctate; basal area of labrum short, transverse, apex narrowly bilobed; scutum tessellate, rather densely punctate, covered with short, dull, pale, yellowish-brown hairs; propodeum roughened, triangle poorly deﬁned, rugose basally, granulate apically; trochanteral ﬂoccus nearly complete, white; tibial scopa silver-white, narrowly brownish above basally, composed of rather coarse hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Metasomal terga tessellate, sometimes weakly so, therefore nearly dull or weakly shiny, impunctate or rarely with weak punctures; metasoma more or less hairy, posterior margins of intermediate terga with loose to more or less compact hair fringes; propodeal corbicula poorly developed, with dorsal fringe of loose or more or less well-arranged, rather long hairs, interior with sparse, ﬁne hairs; trochanteral ﬂoccus incomplete, scanty; tibial scopa well developed; dorsal surface of propodeum shagreened to roughened; propodeal triangle ﬁnely to rather ﬁnely sculptured, usually less coarsely sculptured than rest of dorsal surface of propodeum; facial fovea rather narrow, upper end occupying about or less than one-half distance between eye and posterior ocellus; head and thorax with rather abundant, not especially long hairs; rather small species

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Mesopleura coarsely sculptured or at least rugose above, or with distinct punctures; dorsal surface of propodeum coarsely sculptured or at least shagreened; dorsal fringe of propodeal corbicula long, rather well to well arranged; trochanteral ﬂoccus usually complete

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Calomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Submarginal cells three

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Calomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Facial fovea very broad, with upper end occupying full space between eye and posterior ocellus; propodeal triangle large, with lateral margins convex outward; mesopleura w eakly tessellate with distinct, well-separated punctures; tibial scopa compact, with hairs well arranged, not loose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oreomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Submarginal cells three

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oreomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Females)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a; I have not indicatedhere the doubts expressed by Hirashima concerning theplacement of certain species of Notandrena, etc.): Facial fovea much narrower; propodeal triangle large, subtriangular, with sides not convex outward; mesopleura densely tessellate, impunctate or with an indication of weak punctures; tibial scopa large, composed of long, rather loose hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Stenomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Stenomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Malar area approximately as long as broad; apical segment of antenna uncinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Habromelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Habromelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Malar area linear; apical segment of antenna normal

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Habromelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Second recurrent vein at end of third submarginal cell, meeting third submarginal crossvein or nearly so

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena)(in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena)(in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Propodeal triangle rather strongly wrinkled (metasoma very shiny, feebly tessellate, with an indication of sparse ﬁne punctures; posterior margins of T2-T4 with lateral fringes of sparse white hairs; scutellum nearly smooth and shiny anteriorly; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment much longer than second, second about as long as broad)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poecilandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poecilandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Malar area linear; apical segment of antenna normal

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poecilandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Second recurrent vein much basad of third submarginal crossvein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poecilandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Clypeus not strongly convex, largely yellow or ivorywhite

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Poecilandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Length about 6 mm, or occasionally slightly larger; metasomal terga, including T1, ﬁnely and densely punctate; propodeal triangle coarsely sculptured; dorsal surface of propodeum roughened; ﬂagellum beneath yellowish brown; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment approximately one and one-half times as long as broad, second much broader than long, about one-half as long as ﬁrst, third as long as broad

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oreomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Length more than 7 mm; or, if occasionally smaller, then without combination of characters listed above

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oreomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Head and thorax with abundant brown to blackish hairs, or at least with admixture of brown hairs

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oreomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Clypeus and lateral face marks ivory-white or only slightly yellowish; vertex strongly arched in front view

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Calomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Head and thorax with abundant brown to blackish hairs, or at least with admixture of brown hairs

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Calomelissa) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Clypeus yellow, lateral face marks usually lacking; vertex not arched or only slightly convex in front view

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chlorandrena)(in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): First ﬂagellar segment slightly longer than second plus third, these broader than long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Holandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Head and thorax without admixture of brown hairs, primarily covered with yellowish hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Holandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Basal area of labrum rather large, transverse, reﬂexed and deeply emarginate at apex; propodeal triangle rugulose or wrinkled all over; body length about 10 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hoplandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Clypeus black

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hoplandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): First ﬂagellar segment at most as long as broad, about one-half as long as second; third and following segments about twice as long as broad, distinctly convex in front; malar area usually with sharp spine posteriorly in spring form (only)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andrena s. str.)(in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Mandible slender, curved, with sharp falciform apex; malar area evident, about one-third as long as broad; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment slightly longer than broad, much shorter than elongate second segment (about 3:4.2); face covered with pale yellowish hairs; paraocular area, frons, and gena near eye with black hairs; length about 9 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andrena s. str.)(in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Mandible slender, curved, with sharp falciform apex; malar area evident, about one-third as long as broad; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment slightly longer than broad, much shorter than elongate second segment (about 3:4.2); face covered with pale yellowish hairs; paraocular area, frons, and gena near eye with black hairs; length about 9 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) (in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Length about 10 mm; lower paraocular area with punctures more obscure than those on clypeus; propodeal triangle with wrinkles irregular

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Plastandrena) (in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Length about 10 mm; lower paraocular area with punctures more obscure than those on clypeus; propodeal triangle with wrinkles irregular

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Trachandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Length less than 9 mm; lower paraocular area with punctures distinct; propodeal triangle with wrinkles longitudinal

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Micrandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Length about or less than 7 mm; propodeal triangle large, weakly and rather coarsely sculptured; second submarginal crossvein ending close to stigma

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cnemidandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Basal area of labrum protuberant

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Gena well developed, carinate posteriorly

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chlorandrena)(in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): First ﬂagellar segment slightly longer than second plus third, these broader than long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Ocellocciptal distance about or more than twice as long as ocellar width

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena)(in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Notandrena)(in part) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Propodeal triangle rather strongly wrinkled (metasoma very shiny, feebly tessellate, with an indication of sparse ﬁne punctures; posterior margins of T2-T4 with lateral fringes of sparse white hairs; scutellum nearly smooth and shiny anteriorly; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment much longer than second, second about as long as broad)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Simandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Simandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Propodeal triangle large, densely, rather weakly wrinkled all over

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (T aeniandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (T aeniandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Ocelloccipital distance longer than posterior ocellar diameter; metasomal terga tessellate, with distinct, close punctures

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Clypeus and frequently lower paraocular area ivory-white or yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euandrena) of Andrena of Japan (Males)(Modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1966a): Ocelloccipital distance at most as long as posterior ocellar diameter; metasomal terga tessellate, impunctate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Erythrandrena) of Megandrena: Long hairs of fore tarsus of female curved; gonobase of male absent or completely enclosed in bases of gonocoxites

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Megandrena s. str.) of Megandrena: Long hairs of fore tarsus of female straight; gonobase of male present, a narrow ring (Fig. 51-7a, b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Calliopsini, of the Panurginae: S6 of female with curved (i.e., lateral parts oblique) marginal band of dense hairs (Fig. 59-3d), the band sometimes broken medially, elsewhere S6 with only widely scattered minute hairs; base of S6 of female with two broad membranous lobes (visible only on dissection) occupying space between apodemes (Fig. 59-3d); S5 of female with distal margin convex medially; gonostylus of male absent or reduced to small projection usually not reaching middle of penis valve, the latter enormous and complex (Fig. 59-3a, e, h); anterior tentorial pit in outer subantennal suture (Fig. 59-1) (Western Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Perditini, of the Panurginae: S6 of female with marginal hair band undeﬁned, poorly deﬁned (Figs. 53-6g, 57-1d), or transverse (not curved), S6 commonly with moderate-sized hairs basal to band (in a few Melitturgini, especially Plesiopanurgus, very like Calliopsini but the band less curved); base of S6 of female without membranous lobes between apodemes (Figs. 536g, 57-1d); S5 of female with distal margin nearly straight to concave; gonostylus of male well developed, usually nearly reaching or exceeding apex of penis valve (or directed downward in Neffapis); penis valve variable in complexity; anterior tentorial pit at intersection of epistomal and outer subantennal sutures, or below, in epistomal suture, except in Nolanomelissini and some Melitturgini, in which it is in outer subantennal suture

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Perditini, of the Panurginae: Marginal cell usually much shorter than, usually about half as long as, distance from its apex to wing tip, broadly truncate, margin on costa little if any longer than stigma (Figs. 58-1, 58-2); submarginal cells two, or, rarely, a minute, petiolate intercalary cell between ﬁrst and second; second submarginal cell (or third if there is a petiolate intercalary cell) less than two-thirds as long as ﬁrst, rarely absent; integument often metallic and often with yellow markings; upper margin of hind tibia of male usually not toothed (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Protomeliturgini, of the Panurginae: S6 of female with marginal hair band undeﬁned, poorly deﬁned (Figs. 53-6g, 57-1d), or transverse (not curved), S6 commonly with moderate-sized hairs basal to band (in a few Melitturgini, especially Plesiopanurgus, very like Calliopsini but the band less curved); base of S6 of female without membranous lobes between apodemes (Figs. 536g, 57-1d); S5 of female with distal margin nearly straight to concave; gonostylus of male well developed, usually nearly reaching or exceeding apex of penis valve (or directed downward in Neffapis); penis valve variable in complexity; anterior tentorial pit at intersection of epistomal and outer subantennal sutures, or below, in epistomal suture, except in Nolanomelissini and some Melitturgini, in which it is in outer subantennal suture

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Protomeliturgini, of the Panurginae: Marginal cell slightly shorter to longer than distance from its apex to wing tip, moderately to narrowly and often obliquely truncate, margin on costa usually longer than stigma; submarginal cells two or three, and if two, then second submarginal cell at least two-thirds as long as ﬁrst on posterior margin; integument usually nonmetallic, but if metallic, then with no yellow on metasoma; upper margin of hind tibia of male nearly always carinate or toothed (indistinctly carinate in Nolinomelissini)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Protomeliturgini, of the Panurginae: Labial palpus with ﬁrst two segments elongate (ﬁrst over twice length of second), rather ﬂattened; third segment arising preapically on second and directed laterally (as in L-T bees), third and fourth segments similar and small (Fig. 52-1c); basal vein strongly curved (uniformly curved, the curve not principally near base as in Halictinae); T7 of male strongly curled forward, with strong, blunt, apicolateral tooth (Brazil)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Panurgini, of the Panurginae: S6 of female with marginal hair band undeﬁned, poorly deﬁned (Figs. 53-6g, 57-1d), or transverse (not curved), S6 commonly with moderate-sized hairs basal to band (in a few Melitturgini, especially Plesiopanurgus, very like Calliopsini but the band less curved); base of S6 of female without membranous lobes between apodemes (Figs. 536g, 57-1d); S5 of female with distal margin nearly straight to concave; gonostylus of male well developed, usually nearly reaching or exceeding apex of penis valve (or directed downward in Neffapis); penis valve variable in complexity; anterior tentorial pit at intersection of epistomal and outer subantennal sutures, or below, in epistomal suture, except in Nolanomelissini and some Melitturgini, in which it is in outer subantennal suture

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Panurgini, of the Panurginae: Marginal cell slightly shorter to longer than distance from its apex to wing tip, moderately to narrowly and often obliquely truncate, margin on costa usually longer than stigma; submarginal cells two or three, and if two, then second submarginal cell at least two-thirds as long as ﬁrst on posterior margin; integument usually nonmetallic, but if metallic, then with no yellow on metasoma; upper margin of hind tibia of male nearly always carinate or toothed (indistinctly carinate in Nolinomelissini)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Panurgini, of the Panurginae: Labial palpus with all segments similar to one another or only ﬁrst strongly elongate (as in Fig. 52-1h), ﬁrst three elongate in Nolanomelissa and Plesiopanurgus, or ﬁrst shortest; third segment arising apically on second, last segments thus not directed laterally; basal vein straight or gently curved; T7 of male usually not strongly curled, lacking apicolateral tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Panurgini, of the Panurginae: Stigma wider, broadest at level of vein r (Figs. 53-1, 532), margin within marginal cell convex except in Liphanthus; facial fovea of both sexes present (weakly deﬁned in some males of Panurgus); valve of ﬁrst valvula of sting usually well developed; inner orbits of male parallel or converging below [except somewhat diverging below in Psaenythia, Rhophitulus (Cephalurgus),and Panurgus (Flavipanurgus)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Panurgini, of the Panurginae: Episternal groove absent, short, or curving into and joining scrobal groove; T2-T5 of male with marginal zones usually hairy; foramen of male genitalia in deep sinus between bases of gonocoxites, its two halves facing one another (Fig. 54-3a, e, k) (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Protandrenini, of the Panurginae: S6 of female with marginal hair band undeﬁned, poorly deﬁned (Figs. 53-6g, 57-1d), or transverse (not curved), S6 commonly with moderate-sized hairs basal to band (in a few Melitturgini, especially Plesiopanurgus, very like Calliopsini but the band less curved); base of S6 of female without membranous lobes between apodemes (Figs. 536g, 57-1d); S5 of female with distal margin nearly straight to concave; gonostylus of male well developed, usually nearly reaching or exceeding apex of penis valve (or directed downward in Neffapis); penis valve variable in complexity; anterior tentorial pit at intersection of epistomal and outer subantennal sutures, or below, in epistomal suture, except in Nolanomelissini and some Melitturgini, in which it is in outer subantennal suture

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Protandrenini, of the Panurginae: Marginal cell slightly shorter to longer than distance from its apex to wing tip, moderately to narrowly and often obliquely truncate, margin on costa usually longer than stigma; submarginal cells two or three, and if two, then second submarginal cell at least two-thirds as long as ﬁrst on posterior margin; integument usually nonmetallic, but if metallic, then with no yellow on metasoma; upper margin of hind tibia of male nearly always carinate or toothed (indistinctly carinate in Nolinomelissini)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Protandrenini, of the Panurginae: Labial palpus with all segments similar to one another or only ﬁrst strongly elongate (as in Fig. 52-1h), ﬁrst three elongate in Nolanomelissa and Plesiopanurgus, or ﬁrst shortest; third segment arising apically on second, last segments thus not directed laterally; basal vein straight or gently curved; T7 of male usually not strongly curled, lacking apicolateral tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Protandrenini, of the Panurginae: Stigma wider, broadest at level of vein r (Figs. 53-1, 532), margin within marginal cell convex except in Liphanthus; facial fovea of both sexes present (weakly deﬁned in some males of Panurgus); valve of ﬁrst valvula of sting usually well developed; inner orbits of male parallel or converging below [except somewhat diverging below in Psaenythia, Rhophitulus (Cephalurgus),and Panurgus (Flavipanurgus)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Protandrenini, of the Panurginae: Episternal groove usually extending below scrobal groove, not curving to join scrobal groove; T2-T5 of male with marginal zones glabrous; genital foramen of male exposed at bases of gonocoxites (Fig. 53-6a, d) (Western Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Parapsaenythia of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Forewing with three submarginal cells (Fig. 53-1)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Parapsaenythia of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Eye pilose; pronotum with strong transverse dorsal lamella; punctation on parts of thorax strong, contiguous (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Liphanthus (in part) of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 53-2)

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Liphanthus (in part) of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Glossa and labial palpus not reaching beyond base of metasoma in repose, labial palpus four-segmented; maxillary palpus six-segmented; gonostylus directed posteriorly at side of penis valve

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Liphanthus (in part) of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Stigma only slightly wider than prestigma, as measured to wing margin, sides subparallel or converging slightly basad from vein r, margin within marginal cell straight; T2 with narrow, deep postgradular depression, shallower on succeeding terga (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Psaenythia of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Forewing with three submarginal cells (Fig. 53-1)

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Psaenythia of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Eye glabrous; pronotum with rounded ridge on dorsal margin; punctation well marked, usually not contiguous, to ﬁne, weak

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Psaenythia of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Stigma clearly wider than prestigma, sides converging basad from vein r, margin within marginal cell at least slightly convex (Fig. 53-1); T2 with postgradular depression usually shallow, always similar on succeeding terga

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Psaenythia of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Metasoma usually with yellow markings; T2 with lateral fovea well developed; mandible with preapical tooth (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World

Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Neffapis of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Glossa and labial palpus reaching middle of metasoma in repose, labial palpus three-segmented, third segment longer than ﬁrst and second combined (Fig. 19-5c, d); maxillary palpus two-segmented; gonostylus directed downward at right angle to gonocoxite (Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhophitulus (Cephalurgus) of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Stigma clearly wider than prestigma, sides converging basad from vein r, the margin within marginal cell at least slightly convex (Fig. 53-2); T2 with postgradular depression usually shallow, always similar on succeeding terga

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhophitulus (Cephalurgus) of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Head wider than thorax; orbits somewhat divergent below [Some wide-headed species of Rhophitulus s. str. might run here; for additional characters, see account of the genus.] (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudopanurgus of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 53-2)
