Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudopanurgus of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Head usually narrower than thorax; orbits at least slightly convergent below

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudopanurgus of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Propodeal triangle with hairs on at least lateral third.. 12 10(9). Punctation strong, punctures usually contiguous on some areas of thorax; omaulus sharp, at least dorsally; hind tibia with upper margin a strong, untoothed carina (Fig. 52-6j) (North and Central America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chaeturginus of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Antennal ﬂagellum about as long as head; propodeal triangle polished; tentorial pit far below intersection of outer subantennal and epistomal sutures (Brazil)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protandrena (in part) of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Antennal ﬂagellum clearly longer than head; propodeal triangle striate basally; tentorial pit at intersection of outer subantennal and epistomal sutures or just below it

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhophitulus s. str. of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): First ﬂagellar segment about as long as second; genitalia with basal dorsal gonobase-like sclerotization; digitus (mesal lobe) of volsella prolonged, parallel-sided in ventral view, longer than rest of volsella (Fig. 53-3a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protandrena (Metapsaenythia) of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Yellow on lower half of face, areas of thorax, and legs; antennal ﬂagellum longer than head; glossa somewhat shorter than to longer than prementum; metasoma red or partly red (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Anthemurgus of the Protandrenini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Yellow limited to small, faded spots on face; antennal ﬂagellum shorter than head; glossa about half as long as prementum (Fig. 51-1a); metasoma black (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Parapsaenythia of the Protandrenini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Forewing with three submarginal cells (Fig. 53-1)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Parapsaenythia of the Protandrenini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Eye pilose; pronotum with dorsal margin a strong lamella (at least laterally); T2 to T5 with complete or interrupted median (not apical) hair bands (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Psaenythia of the Protandrenini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Forewing with three submarginal cells (Fig. 53-1)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Psaenythia of the Protandrenini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Eye glabrous; pronotum with dorsal margin a rounded ridge; metasomal terga without hair bands, except in some species of Protandrena s. str.

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Psaenythia of the Protandrenini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Metasomal terga usually with yellow markings; middle tibial spur with coarse teeth; hind femur on inner surface with longitudinal ridge (Fig. 53-6h); T1 to T5 densely punctate (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World

Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Anthrenoides of the Protandrenini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Face black; paraocular area concave medially and below; tentorial pit at intersection of outer antennal and epistomal sutures; propodeal triangle pilose (inner orbits subparallel) (South America)

Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudopanurgus of the Protandrenini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): S2 to S5 with normal hairs on premarginal areas

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudopanurgus of the Protandrenini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Fore coxa with well-developed, hairy, apical spine or process (Fig. 53-6k); middle tibial spur with small, ﬁne, dense teeth (North and Central America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Anthemurgus of the Protandrenini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Glossa about half as long as prementum; ﬁrst segment of labial palpus less than half length of second to fourth segments taken together (Fig. 52-1a) (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhophitulus of the Protandrenini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Lateral third of propodeal triangle with hairs (South America)

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protandrena (in part) of the Protandrenini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1986): Propodeal triangle bare

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Neoliphanthus) of Liphanthus (Males)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983): Submarginal cells two; propodeal triangle laterally less than half length of metanotum (laterally)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Melaliphanthus) of Liphanthus (Males)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983): Distance between antennal socket and inner orbit shorter than or similar to interantennal distance

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Melaliphanthus) of Liphanthus (Males)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983): First ﬂagellar segment about three times as long as broad; clypeus ﬂattened basally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leptophanthus) of Liphanthus (Males)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983): Distance between antennal socket and inner orbit shorter than or similar to interantennal distance

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leptophanthus) of Liphanthus (Males)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983): First ﬂagellar segment less than twice as long as broad; clypeus convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Tricholiphanthus) of Liphanthus (Males)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983): Distance between antennal socket and inner orbit longer than interantennal distance

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Tricholiphanthus) of Liphanthus (Males)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983): S3 and S4 with posterior margins usually clearly concave ( if only slightly concave, then with median, depressed, triangular, transparent area between apical thickenings)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Liphanthus s. str.) of Liphanthus (Males)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983): Distance between antennal socket and inner orbit longer than interantennal distance

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Liphanthus s. str.) of Liphanthus (Males)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983): S3 and S4 with posterior margins convex or straight (without thickenings)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Liphanthus s. str.) of Liphanthus (Males)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983): Pygidial plate present; head in ventral view with lateroventral area of clypeus widened mesally; frontal line in a very long and well-marked groove

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Pseudoliphanthus) of Liphanthus (Males)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983): Distance between antennal socket and inner orbit longer than interantennal distance

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Pseudoliphanthus) of Liphanthus (Males)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983): S3 and S4 with posterior margins convex or straight (without thickenings)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Pseudoliphanthus) of Liphanthus (Males)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983): Pygidial plate absent; head in ventral view with lateroventral area of clypeus widened laterally; frontal line scarcely marked, not in groove

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Neoliphanthus) of Liphanthus (Females)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983)(Females of the subgenus Tricholiphanthusare not known.): Submarginal cells two; propodeal triangle laterally about half length of metanotum (laterally)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Xenoliphanthus) of Liphanthus (Females)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983)(Females of the subgenus Tricholiphanthusare not known.): Submarginal cells three; propodeal triangle laterally slightly more than half length of metanotum (laterally) or almost same length

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Xenoliphanthus) of Liphanthus (Females)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983)(Females of the subgenus Tricholiphanthusare not known.): Hind tibial spurs with apices curved like claws, subequal in length; vertex concave or almost straight in frontal view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leptophanthus) of Liphanthus (Females)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983)(Females of the subgenus Tricholiphanthusare not known.): Submarginal cells three; propodeal triangle laterally slightly more than half length of metanotum (laterally) or almost same length

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leptophanthus) of Liphanthus (Females)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983)(Females of the subgenus Tricholiphanthusare not known.): Hind tibial spurs with apices only slightly curved, inner somewhat longer than outer; vertex convex in frontal view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Leptophanthus) of Liphanthus (Females)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983)(Females of the subgenus Tricholiphanthusare not known.): Lateral ocellus, in frontal view, above upper orbital tangent; inner orbits divergent dorsally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Melaliphanthus) of Liphanthus (Females)(Based on Ruz and T oro, 1983)(Females of the subgenus Tricholiphanthusare not known.): Lateral ocellus, in frontal view, at same level as or slightly below upper orbital tangent; inner orbits convergent dorsally or almost subparallel

Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Protandrena s. str.) of Protandrena (Males): Submarginal cells three (occasional individuals have only two) (North and Central America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Metapsaenythia) of Protandrena (Males): Submarginal cells two (Fig. 53-2b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Metapsaenythia) of Protandrena (Males): Propodeal triangle basally pilose (metasoma often red or largely so) (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Austropanurgus) of Protandrena (Males): Submarginal cells two (Fig. 53-2b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Austropanurgus) of Protandrena (Males): Propodeal triangle basally glabrous

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Austropanurgus) of Protandrena (Males): Hind tibial spurs strongly curved at apices; ﬁrst submarginal cell on posterior margin shorter than second (Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Parasarus) of Protandrena (Males): Submarginal cells two (Fig. 53-2b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Parasarus) of Protandrena (Males): Hind tibial spurs or at least one of them slightly curved or almost straight; ﬁrst submarginal cell on posterior margin about as long as or longer than second

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Parasarus) of Protandrena (Males): Gonostylus less than one-third as long as gonocoxite; S6 scarcely notched apically (face black) (South America)

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pterosarus) of Protandrena (Males): Gonostylus over one-half as long as gonocoxite; S6 with deep midapical notch or slit

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pterosarus) of Protandrena (Males): Scutum with punctures well marked, many of them separated by spaces larger than their diameters; S6 with midapical emargination narrow, deep (North and Central America)

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Heterosarus) of Protandrena (Males): Gonostylus over one-half as long as gonocoxite; S6 with deep midapical notch or slit

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Heterosarus) of Protandrena (Males): Scutum with punctures very small, homogeneous, commonly dense; S6 midapical emargination V-shaped

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Parasarus) of Protandrena (Males): First submarginal cell on posterior margin longer than second; face black (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera (R. Rhophitulus s. str.) of Rhophitulus: Entire lower face strongly convex, clypeus protuberant for full eye width in lateral view and produced apicad so that lower ocular tangent crosses face near base of clypeus; S6 of male with apical emargination V-shaped although rounded at anterior extremity; male gonocoxite with small dorsal lobe (Fig. 53-3a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Camptopoeum of the Panurgini: S7 of male with disc small, about as broad as long, almost parallel-sided, with broad apical notch (Fig. 54-2g) and sometimes [e.g., in Camptopoeum ruber(Warncke)] with lateral lobe at each side, and with long somewhat pedunculate apodemal lobes; body usually with yellow markings (episternal groove punctate, extending slightly below scrobal level) (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Panurginus of the Panurgini: S7 of male with disc rather large, usually apically with two, three, or four lobes, angles, or spines or a median process, disc much broader than long [except when drawn out as an apical process in Panurginus such as P. clavatus (Warncke)]; apodemal lobes of S7 not or little narrowed basally, relatively short (Figs. 54-2c, 54-3c, g, i); body often entirely black or only clypeus yellow, but body sometimes extensively yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Panurginus of the Panurgini: S6 of male with posterior margin slightly to strongly produced medially, this projection with truncate to broadly concave apex margined by zone of short hairs (Fig. 54-3d); episternal groove entirely absent (body entirely black except for yellow clypeus of some males; ﬁrst recurrent vein meeting or basal to ﬁrst submarginal crossvein or nearly so, Fig. 54-1c) (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Camptopoeum s. str.) of Camptopoeum: Labrum with basal area triangular, delimited by converging carinae, those in females meeting and forming longitudinal median carina that ends near apex of labrum, and in males ending together near apex of labrum; clypeus protuberant one-fourth to one-half or more of eye width in lateral view; glossa longer than prementum; ﬁrst segment of labial palpus about as long as second to fourth segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Epimethea) of Camptopoeum: Labrum with basal area delimited by transverse carina that curves basad laterally; clypeus not protuberant; glossa about one-half as long as prementum; ﬁrst segment of labial palpus shorter than second to fourth segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Panurgus s. str.) of Panurgus: Body without yellow markings; scopal hairs minutely spiraled or zigzag; galeal comb absent; glossa longer than prementum (episternal groove weak, not reaching down to scrobal level)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Simpanurgus) of Panurgus: Body with yellow at least on face and metasoma; scopal hairs simple (female unknown in Simpanurgus); galeal comb present; glossa shorter than prementum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Simpanurgus) of Panurgus: Episternal groove well marked, extending below scrobal level; inner orbits of male convex, closest to one another medially (Iberian peninsula)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Melitturga of the Tribe Melitturgini: Body with few to extensive yellow areas; submarginal cells three (Fig. 56-1); eyes of male large, inner orbits conspicuously convergent above; antennal ﬂagellum of male at least somewhat clavate (Fig. 56-2g); labrum partially pilose, the hairs short; episternal groove usually extending below scrobal level

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Melitturga of the Tribe Melitturgini: Posterior margins of submarginal cells subequal; tarsi of male with segments 2 to 4 expanded; stigma shorter than prestigma; T6 of male basally with conspicuous, broad, swollen hairy area (palearctic, Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Plesiopanurgus of the Tribe Melitturgini: Body without yellow markings; submarginal cells two; inner orbits of male not convergent above; antennal ﬂagellum not clavate; labrum fully pilose, hairs long; episternal groove reaching but not extending below scrobal level

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Plesiopanurgus of the Tribe Melitturgini: Scape of male robust; last antennal segment of male strongly tapered at apex (Fig. 56-2k); pronotum with strong dorsolateral lamella or protuberance; metasoma black; T1 (lateral view) with dorsal and anterior surfaces rounding smoothly; T2 and T3 with gradulus not strongly carinate, lateral part rather short; head slightly wider than long (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mermiglossa of the Tribe Melitturgini: Body without yellow markings; submarginal cells two; inner orbits of male not convergent above; antennal ﬂagellum not clavate; labrum fully pilose, hairs long; episternal groove reaching but not extending below scrobal level

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mermiglossa of the Tribe Melitturgini: Scape and last antennal segment unmodiﬁed; pronotum with rounded and little-developed ridge on dorsal margin; metasoma red; T1 (lateral view) with dorsal and anterior surfaces meeting at almost 90 degrees; T2 and T3 with lateral part of gradulus strongly carinate, long; head conspicuously wider than long (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Flavomeliturgula of the Tribe Melitturgini: Body with few to extensive yellow areas; submarginal cells three (Fig. 56-1); eyes of male large, inner orbits conspicuously convergent above; antennal ﬂagellum of male at least somewhat clavate (Fig. 56-2g); labrum partially pilose, the hairs short; episternal groove usually extending below scrobal level

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Flavomeliturgula of the Tribe Melitturgini: Posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell nearly as long as that of second and third taken together; tarsi of male with segments 2 to 4 unmodiﬁed; stigma almost as long as to longer than prestigma; T6 of male unmodiﬁed (Africa, southwest Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Flavomeliturgula of the Tribe Melitturgini: First three segments of labial palpus elongate, fourth shorter; body usually partly or wholly yellow (glossa longer than face, at least in some species with apex broadly truncate (Fig. 52-1 f)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Gasparinahla of the Tribe Melitturgini: Body with few to extensive yellow areas; submarginal cells three (Fig. 56-1); eyes of male large, inner orbits conspicuously convergent above; antennal ﬂagellum of male at least somewhat clavate (Fig. 56-2g); labrum partially pilose, the hairs short; episternal groove usually extending below scrobal level

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Gasparinahla of the Tribe Melitturgini: Posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell nearly as long as that of second and third taken together; tarsi of male with segments 2 to 4 unmodiﬁed; stigma almost as long as to longer than prestigma; T6 of male unmodiﬁed (Africa, southwest Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Gasparinahla of the Tribe Melitturgini: First segment of labial palpus elongate, as long as or longer than second to fourth segments together; body variable in coloration but often mostly dark, never wholly yellow; glossa pointed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Gasparinahla of the Tribe Melitturgini: Maxillary palpus “nearly absent” (Patiny, 2001); glossa longer than face; ﬁrst segment of labial palpus longer than second to fourth segments together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Borgatomelissa of the Tribe Melitturgini: Body with few to extensive yellow areas; submarginal cells three (Fig. 56-1); eyes of male large, inner orbits conspicuously convergent above; antennal ﬂagellum of male at least somewhat clavate (Fig. 56-2g); labrum partially pilose, the hairs short; episternal groove usually extending below scrobal level

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Borgatomelissa of the Tribe Melitturgini: Posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell nearly as long as that of second and third taken together; tarsi of male with segments 2 to 4 unmodiﬁed; stigma almost as long as to longer than prestigma; T6 of male unmodiﬁed (Africa, southwest Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Borgatomelissa of the Tribe Melitturgini: First segment of labial palpus elongate, as long as or longer than second to fourth segments together; body variable in coloration but often mostly dark, never wholly yellow; glossa pointed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Borgatomelissa of the Tribe Melitturgini: Maxillary palpus 6-segmented; glossa shorter than face; ﬁrst segment of labial palpus about as long as second to fourth together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Borgatomelissa of the Tribe Melitturgini: Scutum of female densely covered with short, thickened, appressed hairs among which are scattered erect hairs; male gonostylus very slender, as long as gonocoxite; volsella spiculate, extending beyond gonocoxites; T7 of male with biﬁd apex; S6 and S7 of male with deep median apical emarginations

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Meliturgula of the Tribe Melitturgini: Body with few to extensive yellow areas; submarginal cells three (Fig. 56-1); eyes of male large, inner orbits conspicuously convergent above; antennal ﬂagellum of male at least somewhat clavate (Fig. 56-2g); labrum partially pilose, the hairs short; episternal groove usually extending below scrobal level

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Meliturgula of the Tribe Melitturgini: Posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell nearly as long as that of second and third taken together; tarsi of male with segments 2 to 4 unmodiﬁed; stigma almost as long as to longer than prestigma; T6 of male unmodiﬁed (Africa, southwest Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Meliturgula of the Tribe Melitturgini: First segment of labial palpus elongate, as long as or longer than second to fourth segments together; body variable in coloration but often mostly dark, never wholly yellow; glossa pointed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Meliturgula of the Tribe Melitturgini: Maxillary palpus 6-segmented; glossa shorter than face; ﬁrst segment of labial palpus about as long as second to fourth together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Meliturgula of the Tribe Melitturgini: Scutum with scattered suberect hairs or in some species with appressed hairs, usually less dense than in Borgatomelissa; male gonostylus robust, half as long as gonocoxite or less (Fig. 56-2a); volsella not spiculate, extending little if at all beyond gonocoxites; T7 of male with apex simple; S6 and S7 with apical margins transverse or convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Perdita of the Perditini: Outer groove of mandible broadened and fading away toward mandibular base (Fig. 58-5a); episternal groove usually curving posteriorly to scrobe (Fig. 58-6a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Macrotera of the Perditini: Outer groove of mandible narrow basally (as it is apically) and bent upward, cutting diagonally across mandible to acetabulum (Fig. 58-5b); episternal groove absent or short, not curving posteriorly to scrobe (Fig. 58-6b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Perdita of the Perditini: Outer groove of mandible broadened and fading away toward mandibular base (Fig. 58-5a); episternal groove usually curving posteriorly to scrobe (Fig. 58-6a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera M. (Macrotera s. str.) of the Perditini: Glossa reaching hind coxae in repose, two to three times as long as prementum; head of male much broader than long, widened anteriorly; mandible of male inserted below eye, only posterior articulation behind posterior eye margin; metasoma of male lacking special modiﬁcations except for broad, depressed form; tibial spurs brieﬂy hooked at apices and not serrate on inner margins

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera M. (Cockerellula) of the Perditini: Glossa not over twice as long as prementum; head of male a little broader than long, only slightly widened anteriorly; mandible of male inserted partly behind posterior margin of eye; T7 and one or more metasomal sterna modiﬁed; tibial spurs strongly curved at apices and minutely serrate on inner margins

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera M. (Macroteropsis) of the Perditini: Head of male broader than long, rounded on sides and above, but truncate anteriorly, thus appearing almost semicircular in frontal view; mandible of male usually with half of base behind posterior margin of eye, either bidentate or simple at apex; stigma slender and tapering; maxillary palpus fourto six-segmented, apical segments short and more or less indistinct

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera M. (Macroterella) of the Perditini: Head of male not enlarged, ordinary in shape although more or less wider than long; mandible of male rather short, simple, tapering, and inserted largely below eye, only posterior articulation behind posterior eye margin; stigma small and usually rounded posteriorly, but varying to very small and lanceolate; maxillary palpus with six distinct segments

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Xerophasma) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Ocelli large, ocellocular distance less than half ocellar diameter; body wholly pallid; intercalary cell present between ﬁrst and second submarginal cells (Fig. 58-10)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pseudomacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Ocelli of ordinary size, ocellocular distance much greater than ocellar diameter; if body pallid, then intercalary cell absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pseudomacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Stigma small and slender, width about or not much over half maximum width of marginal cell and less than width of apical truncation of that cell; basitibial plate more or less distinct, at least in the male

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pseudomacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Metasoma broader than thorax and especially broad and depressed in male; hair of hind tibia and basitarsus of male unusually abundant, ﬁne and appressed; basitibial plate developed in both sexes (head of male often greatly enlarged, facial fovea about three times as long as wide but weakly impressed; mandible of male with a broad biangulate or bidentate expansion on inner margin)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Heteroperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Ocelli of ordinary size, ocellocular distance much greater than ocellar diameter; if body pallid, then intercalary cell absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Heteroperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Stigma small and slender, width about or not much over half maximum width of marginal cell and less than width of apical truncation of that cell; basitibial plate more or less distinct, at least in the male

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Heteroperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Metasoma not broadened in female, and at most only moderately depressed and broadened in male; hair of hind tibia and basitarsus of male more or less long, curved, erect, and not much thickened by short, densely set branches; basitibial plate little developed in female

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Heteroperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Marginal cell more or less shorter and smaller than ﬁrst submarginal cell and squarely truncate at apex; stigma small and slender, but more or less rounded on posterior margin; facial fovea small and inconspicuous (very small bees with a satiny luster and appressed white pubescence; mandible simple and tapering in both sexes)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Glossoperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Ocelli of ordinary size, ocellocular distance much greater than ocellar diameter; if body pallid, then intercalary cell absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Glossoperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Stigma small and slender, width about or not much over half maximum width of marginal cell and less than width of apical truncation of that cell; basitibial plate more or less distinct, at least in the male

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Glossoperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Metasoma not broadened in female, and at most only moderately depressed and broadened in male; hair of hind tibia and basitarsus of male more or less long, curved, erect, and not much thickened by short, densely set branches; basitibial plate little developed in female

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Glossoperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Marginal cell subequal to ﬁrst submarginal, apex a little obliquely truncate; stigma more or less narrowly lanceolate; facial fovea distinct

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Glossoperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Glossa elongate, reaching middle coxae in repose (facial fovea of female considerably widened at lower end; metasoma of male at most moderately broadened; mandible of male simple)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Hesperoperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Ocelli of ordinary size, ocellocular distance much greater than ocellar diameter; if body pallid, then intercalary cell absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Hesperoperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Stigma small and slender, width about or not much over half maximum width of marginal cell and less than width of apical truncation of that cell; basitibial plate more or less distinct, at least in the male

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Hesperoperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Metasoma not broadened in female, and at most only moderately depressed and broadened in male; hair of hind tibia and basitarsus of male more or less long, curved, erect, and not much thickened by short, densely set branches; basitibial plate little developed in female

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Hesperoperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Marginal cell subequal to ﬁrst submarginal, apex a little obliquely truncate; stigma more or less narrowly lanceolate; facial fovea distinct

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Hesperoperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Glossa ordinary, not reaching much behind front coxae in repose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Hesperoperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Stigma slender and tapering, hardly wide enough to show central pale streak; mandible of both sexes with a blunt inner tooth near apex; facial fovea of female slightly widened below; metasoma of male not broadened; front and middle femora of male subincrassate and apical segments of tarsi unusually large, with large claws

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Epimacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Ocelli of ordinary size, ocellocular distance much greater than ocellar diameter; if body pallid, then intercalary cell absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Epimacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Stigma small and slender, width about or not much over half maximum width of marginal cell and less than width of apical truncation of that cell; basitibial plate more or less distinct, at least in the male

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Epimacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Metasoma not broadened in female, and at most only moderately depressed and broadened in male; hair of hind tibia and basitarsus of male more or less long, curved, erect, and not much thickened by short, densely set branches; basitibial plate little developed in female

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Epimacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Marginal cell subequal to ﬁrst submarginal, apex a little obliquely truncate; stigma more or less narrowly lanceolate; facial fovea distinct

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Epimacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Glossa ordinary, not reaching much behind front coxae in repose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Epimacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Stigma somewhat less slender; mandible of female with a small inner tooth, that of male usually simple and tapering; facial fovea of female very narrow; metasoma of male moderately depressed and broadened; legs of male ordinary

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Allomacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Ocelli of ordinary size, ocellocular distance much greater than ocellar diameter; if body pallid, then intercalary cell absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Allomacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Stigma more or less large and broad, width ordinarily more than half width of marginal cell and as wide as apical truncation of that cell; basitibial plate usually absent or poorly developed, but sometimes well developed in both sexes, as in Pygoperdita

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Allomacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Scopa of hind tibia copious, hairs long, often more or less crinkly or minutely branched, seemingly adapted for carrying pollen at least partly dry; claws of female simple; side of pronotum of male more or less deeply furrowed (except in Allomacrotera); S8 of male with bilobate base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Allomacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Usually large species, 5 to 9 mm long; mandible of female dilated on inner margin and abruptly bent inward before apex, incurved part tapering and simple; metasoma of male no wider than thorax; claws of male hind leg simple (except in Allomacrotera where cleft)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Allomacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Claws of male hind leg cleft; side of pronotum not furrowed (maxillary palpus three-segmented)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Cockerellia) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Maxillary palpus six-segmented; stigma moderately wide, sometimes less than half as wide as marginal cell; thorax green, mesonotum and scutellum never black but sometimes yellow; mandible of male long, slender, tapering, and curved

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Procockerellia) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Maxillary palpus threeto ﬁve-segmented; stigma considerably larger and broader, more than half as wide to fully as wide as marginal cell; thorax green, disc of mesoscutum and scutellum black; mandible of male long, simple, abruptly bent inward before middle, slightly dilated beyond bend

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pentaperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Body metallic blue or green, usually with white facial marks (tibial scopa of female unusually copious; metasoma of male depressed, considerably broader than thorax and usually without light markings)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Xeromacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Body yellow with black or nearly black markings on head and thorax [head of male very large, quadrate; malar area short but evident (almost obliterated in allies); disc of clypeus small, much narrower than lateral extensions of enormous paraocular areas]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Callomacrotera) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Body large (length 6.5-9.0 mm), robust; metasoma with yellow bands and a deﬁnite pygidial plate in both sexes; mandible of female having triangular process on inner margin about one-fourth of length from base; tibial scopa copious for a Perdita and distinctly plumose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Hexaperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Body small, of ordinary form; metasoma without distinct light markings, not subpygidiform at apex; mandible of female more or less dilated within; tibial scopa moderately copious, hairs simple and curved except on dorsal margin where they are mosslike with closeset, very short branches

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Perditella) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Marginal cell extremely short and oblique behind short, broad stigma; second submarginal cell triangular, ﬁrst and second submarginal crossveins uniting at marginal cell (clypeus of male produced to sharp tooth or slender lobe on each side of base of labrum)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Alloperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): Small intercalary cell usually present between ﬁrst and second submarginal cells (as in Fig. 56-10); mandible of male with small subapical tooth on inner margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pygoperdita) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): T7 of male strongly emarginate on each side, setting off median pygidiform process or deeply bilobed process, or modiﬁcations thereof (female robust; head broader than long; margin of clypeus dentate on each side of labrum)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Perdita s. str.) of Perdita(Modiﬁed from Timberlake, 1954): T7 of male usually simple, tapering, or, if somewhat modiﬁed, then never deeply emarginate on each side nor strongly bilobed at apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Acamptopoeum of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): Inner orbits convergent below; tentorial pit clearly below middle of outer subantennal suture (Fig. 59-1)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Acamptopoeum of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): T7 with median smooth area distally, area delimited by hairs and tapered at apex (S4 and S5 with distal margins straight or nearly so, without median projections)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Calliopsis of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): Inner orbits convergent below; tentorial pit clearly below middle of outer subantennal suture (Fig. 59-1)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Calliopsis of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): T7 with pygidial plate rounded or truncate at apex, usually delimited by ridges or carinae laterally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Calliopsis of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): S4 with distal margin usually produced in middle, its surface broadly concave mesally; S5 with median projection (sometimes inconspicuous) on distal margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Litocalliopsis of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): Inner orbits convergent below; tentorial pit clearly below middle of outer subantennal suture (Fig. 59-1)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Litocalliopsis of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): T7 with pygidial plate rounded or truncate at apex, usually delimited by ridges or carinae laterally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Litocalliopsis of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): S4 and S5 unmodiﬁed, transverse, without projections or concavity

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Arhysosage of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): Inner orbits subparallel or divergent below; tentorial pit near middle of outer subantennal suture

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Arhysosage of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): Orbits strongly divergent below; lower paraocular area ﬂat; most of body yellow; hind tibial spurs strongly curved; metasoma much wider than head; body length about 10 mm or nearly so (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Spinoliella of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): Inner orbits subparallel or divergent below; tentorial pit near middle of outer subantennal suture

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Spinoliella of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): Orbits usually subparallel, but if not, then lower paraocular area very swollen mesally; body with yellow markings but usually predominantly black; inner hind tibial spur almost straight, outer spur straight or somewhat curved; metasoma as broad as head; body length 4 to 7 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Spinoliella of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): Metasoma at apex slightly curved or straight; paraocular area yellow only on lower part; clypeus (in ventral view) with projection or convexity of lateral, downwarddirected part beside lateral margin of labrum; antennal socket (lower margin) usually at lower third of face (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Callonychium of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): Inner orbits subparallel or divergent below; tentorial pit near middle of outer subantennal suture

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Callonychium of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): Orbits usually subparallel, but if not, then lower paraocular area very swollen mesally; body with yellow markings but usually predominantly black; inner hind tibial spur almost straight, outer spur straight or somewhat curved; metasoma as broad as head; body length 4 to 7 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Callonychium of the Calliopsini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Ruz, 1991): Metasoma at apex strongly curved downward and forward; paraocular area with yellow surpassing level of antennal socket, usually narrowly following orbit; clypeus (in ventral view) with inner margin of lateral area beside lateral margin of labrum usually almost straight; antennal socket (lower margin) usually at lower quarter of face (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeum) of Calliopsis (Males): Hind basitarsus with pubescence of dorsal margin at least partly about as long as basitarsus or longer; apical area of labrum clearly convex, almost glabrous except at margin; labrum with no deﬁned ridge separating basal and apical areas (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Verbenapis) of Calliopsis (Males): Hind basitarsus with pubescence of dorsal margin about half as long as basitarsus or shorter; apical area of labrum hairy, rather ﬂattened; labrum with ridge or carina separating basal and apical areas [but entire labrum ﬂat and pilose in C. (Hypomacrotera) subalpina(Cockerell)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Verbenapis) of Calliopsis (Males): T2-T5 at least laterally with marginal hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Verbenapis) of Calliopsis (Males): Subantennal area black; metanotum laterally without velvety area; propodeal triangle basally smooth, medially concave (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsis s. str.) of Calliopsis (Males): Hind basitarsus with pubescence of dorsal margin about half as long as basitarsus or shorter; apical area of labrum hairy, rather ﬂattened; labrum with ridge or carina separating basal and apical areas [but entire labrum ﬂat and pilose in C. (Hypomacrotera) subalpina(Cockerell)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsis s. str.) of Calliopsis (Males): T2-T5 at least laterally with marginal hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsis s. str.) of Calliopsis (Males): Subantennal area yellow; metanotum laterally with area (sometimes reduced to a small and narrow strip) of dense velvety hairs; propodeal triangle basally rugose or at least slightly roughened, medially ﬂat

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsis s. str.) of Calliopsis (Males): Clypeus (in lateral view) clearly protuberant; metanotum with conspicuous patch of velvet-brown hairs laterally (North and Central America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsima) —. Labrum with basal area delimited by weak ridge; mid- dle basitarsus much longer than hind; propodeal triangle basally with weak striae, not delimited posteriorly by  strong transverse ridge (nearctic) ..............C. (Perissander) of Calliopsis (Males): Hind basitarsus with pubescence of dorsal margin about half as long as basitarsus or shorter; apical area of labrum hairy, rather ﬂattened; labrum with ridge or carina separating basal and apical areas [but entire labrum ﬂat and pilose in C. (Hypomacrotera) subalpina(Cockerell)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsima) —. Labrum with basal area delimited by weak ridge; mid- dle basitarsus much longer than hind; propodeal triangle basally with weak striae, not delimited posteriorly by  strong transverse ridge (nearctic) ..............C. (Perissander) of Calliopsis (Males): T2-T5 at least laterally with marginal hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsima) —. Labrum with basal area delimited by weak ridge; mid- dle basitarsus much longer than hind; propodeal triangle basally with weak striae, not delimited posteriorly by  strong transverse ridge (nearctic) ..............C. (Perissander) of Calliopsis (Males): Subantennal area yellow; metanotum laterally with area (sometimes reduced to a small and narrow strip) of dense velvety hairs; propodeal triangle basally rugose or at least slightly roughened, medially ﬂat

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsima) —. Labrum with basal area delimited by weak ridge; mid- dle basitarsus much longer than hind; propodeal triangle basally with weak striae, not delimited posteriorly by  strong transverse ridge (nearctic) ..............C. (Perissander) of Calliopsis (Males): Clypeus (in lateral view) almost ﬂat; metanotum with small patch of velvet-white hairs laterally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsima) —. Labrum with basal area delimited by weak ridge; mid- dle basitarsus much longer than hind; propodeal triangle basally with weak striae, not delimited posteriorly by  strong transverse ridge (nearctic) ..............C. (Perissander) of Calliopsis (Males): Labrum with basal area delimited by strong carinate ridge; middle basitarsus somewhat shorter than hind; propodeal triangle basally with strong striae, striated part delimited posteriorly by strong transverse ridge (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ceroliopoeum) of Calliopsis (Males): Hind basitarsus with pubescence of dorsal margin about half as long as basitarsus or shorter; apical area of labrum hairy, rather ﬂattened; labrum with ridge or carina separating basal and apical areas [but entire labrum ﬂat and pilose in C. (Hypomacrotera) subalpina(Cockerell)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ceroliopoeum) of Calliopsis (Males): T2-T5 without marginal hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ceroliopoeum) of Calliopsis (Males): Metasoma without yellow marks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ceroliopoeum) of Calliopsis (Males): Antennal scape robust, less than three times as long as wide; stigma more than twice as broad as prestigma, as measured to wing margin, margin within marginal cell clearly convex (Argentina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Hypomacrotera) of Calliopsis (Males): Hind basitarsus with pubescence of dorsal margin about half as long as basitarsus or shorter; apical area of labrum hairy, rather ﬂattened; labrum with ridge or carina separating basal and apical areas [but entire labrum ﬂat and pilose in C. (Hypomacrotera) subalpina(Cockerell)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Hypomacrotera) of Calliopsis (Males): T2-T5 without marginal hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Hypomacrotera) of Calliopsis (Males): Metasoma without yellow marks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Hypomacrotera) of Calliopsis (Males): Antennal scape normal, over four times as long as wide; stigma less than twice as broad as prestigma, margin within marginal cell straight or nearly so (Fig. 59-5)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Hypomacrotera) of Calliopsis (Males): Inner orbits subparallel; marginal cell about twice as long as second submarginal cell or longer (Fig. 59-5); hind tarsomeres 2 to 5 unmodiﬁed (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeodes) of Calliopsis (Males): Hind basitarsus with pubescence of dorsal margin about half as long as basitarsus or shorter; apical area of labrum hairy, rather ﬂattened; labrum with ridge or carina separating basal and apical areas [but entire labrum ﬂat and pilose in C. (Hypomacrotera) subalpina(Cockerell)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeodes) of Calliopsis (Males): T2-T5 without marginal hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeodes) of Calliopsis (Males): Metasoma without yellow marks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeodes) of Calliopsis (Males): Antennal scape normal, over four times as long as wide; stigma less than twice as broad as prestigma, margin within marginal cell straight or nearly so (Fig. 59-5)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeodes) of Calliopsis (Males): Inner orbits convergent below (Fig. 59-1f); marginal cell less than twice as long as second submarginal cell; hind basitarsus and tarsomeres 2 to 4 asymmetrical, and distitarsus widened medially (Argentina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Micronomadopsis) of Calliopsis (Males): Hind basitarsus with pubescence of dorsal margin about half as long as basitarsus or shorter; apical area of labrum hairy, rather ﬂattened; labrum with ridge or carina separating basal and apical areas [but entire labrum ﬂat and pilose in C. (Hypomacrotera) subalpina(Cockerell)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Micronomadopsis) of Calliopsis (Males): T2-T5 without marginal hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Micronomadopsis) of Calliopsis (Males): Metasomal terga almost always with interrupted or complete yellow bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Micronomadopsis) of Calliopsis (Males): Front and middle tarsi slender, and tarsomeres 2 to 4 of hind tarsus often broadened laterally, asymmetrical (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Nomadopsis) of Calliopsis (Males): Hind basitarsus with pubescence of dorsal margin about half as long as basitarsus or shorter; apical area of labrum hairy, rather ﬂattened; labrum with ridge or carina separating basal and apical areas [but entire labrum ﬂat and pilose in C. (Hypomacrotera) subalpina(Cockerell)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Nomadopsis) of Calliopsis (Males): T2-T5 without marginal hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Nomadopsis) of Calliopsis (Males): Metasomal terga almost always with interrupted or complete yellow bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Nomadopsis) of Calliopsis (Males): Tarsi with tarsomeres broadened distally, symmetrical (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ceroliopoeum) of Calliopsis (Females): Stigma more than twice as broad as prestigma as measured to wing margin; stigmal margin within marginal cell clearly convex; midfemoral comb less than half length of femur (Argentina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeodes) of Calliopsis (Females): Stigma less than twice as broad as prestigma as measured to wing margin; stigmal margin within marginal cell straight or nearly so; midfemoral comb about half length of femur

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeodes) of Calliopsis (Females): T2-T4 with marginal hair bands, at least laterally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeodes) of Calliopsis (Females): Integument black (with some slight blue but no yellow); wing veins mostly dark; inner orbits subparallel; T1 and T2 polished, scarcely punctate (Argentina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeum) (in part) of Calliopsis (Females): Stigma less than twice as broad as prestigma as measured to wing margin; stigmal margin within marginal cell straight or nearly so; midfemoral comb about half length of femur

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeum) (in part) of Calliopsis (Females): T2-T4 without marginal hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeum) (in part) of Calliopsis (Females): Middle tibial spur with most teeth much longer than those of hind tibial spurs; S6 with apical marginal fringe of hairs broken medially (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Verbenapis) of Calliopsis (Females): Stigma less than twice as broad as prestigma as measured to wing margin; stigmal margin within marginal cell straight or nearly so; midfemoral comb about half length of femur

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Verbenapis) of Calliopsis (Females): T2-T4 with marginal hair bands, at least laterally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Verbenapis) of Calliopsis (Females): Integument with at least some yellow marks; wing veins mostly yellowish; inner orbits convergent below; terga with rather abundant punctation

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Verbenapis) of Calliopsis (Females): Middle tibial spur with somewhat coarse teeth, not limited to distal half; hind tibia with keirotrichia on most of inner surface or absent toward ventral border; S6 distally with hairs forming a continuous curved fringe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Verbenapis) of Calliopsis (Females): Front tarsus with hairs on inner surface sparse, mostly stiff, curved and not tapered at apices (Fig. 59-3k); metanotum laterally without patch of velvety hairs (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsis s. str.) of Calliopsis (Females): Stigma less than twice as broad as prestigma as measured to wing margin; stigmal margin within marginal cell straight or nearly so; midfemoral comb about half length of femur

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsis s. str.) of Calliopsis (Females): T2-T4 with marginal hair bands, at least laterally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsis s. str.) of Calliopsis (Females): Integument with at least some yellow marks; wing veins mostly yellowish; inner orbits convergent below; terga with rather abundant punctation

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsis s. str.) of Calliopsis (Females): Middle tibial spur with somewhat coarse teeth, not limited to distal half; hind tibia with keirotrichia on most of inner surface or absent toward ventral border; S6 distally with hairs forming a continuous curved fringe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsis s. str.) of Calliopsis (Females): Front tarsus with hairs on inner surface dense, unmodiﬁed; metanotum laterally with small (sometimes inconspicuous) patch of white, velvety hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsis s. str.) of Calliopsis (Females): Clypeus (in lateral view) protuberant, projecting forward one-third width of eye or more; paraocular area with lowest part noticeably wider than at level of antennal sockets, usually swollen on lower inner corner (North and Central America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsima) of Calliopsis (Females): Stigma less than twice as broad as prestigma as measured to wing margin; stigmal margin within marginal cell straight or nearly so; midfemoral comb about half length of femur

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsima) of Calliopsis (Females): T2-T4 with marginal hair bands, at least laterally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsima) of Calliopsis (Females): Integument with at least some yellow marks; wing veins mostly yellowish; inner orbits convergent below; terga with rather abundant punctation

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsima) of Calliopsis (Females): Middle tibial spur with somewhat coarse teeth, not limited to distal half; hind tibia with keirotrichia on most of inner surface or absent toward ventral border; S6 distally with hairs forming a continuous curved fringe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsima) of Calliopsis (Females): Front tarsus with hairs on inner surface dense, unmodiﬁed; metanotum laterally with small (sometimes inconspicuous) patch of white, velvety hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsima) of Calliopsis (Females): Clypeus (in lateral view) less protuberant, projecting forward only about one-fourth width of eye or less; paraocular area with lowest part about as wide as at level of antennal sockets, only slightly convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calliopsima) of Calliopsis (Females): Propodeum mostly punctate, base with a conspicuously rugose triangle delimited by strong ridge or carina; metanotum laterally with clearly visible patch of white, velvety hairs (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Perissander) of Calliopsis (Females): Stigma less than twice as broad as prestigma as measured to wing margin; stigmal margin within marginal cell straight or nearly so; midfemoral comb about half length of femur

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Perissander) of Calliopsis (Females): T2-T4 with marginal hair bands, at least laterally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Perissander) of Calliopsis (Females): Integument with at least some yellow marks; wing veins mostly yellowish; inner orbits convergent below; terga with rather abundant punctation

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Perissander) of Calliopsis (Females): Middle tibial spur with somewhat coarse teeth, not limited to distal half; hind tibia with keirotrichia on most of inner surface or absent toward ventral border; S6 distally with hairs forming a continuous curved fringe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Perissander) of Calliopsis (Females): Front tarsus with hairs on inner surface dense, unmodiﬁed; metanotum laterally with small (sometimes inconspicuous) patch of white, velvety hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Perissander) of Calliopsis (Females): Clypeus (in lateral view) less protuberant, projecting forward only about one-fourth width of eye or less; paraocular area with lowest part about as wide as at level of antennal sockets, only slightly convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Perissander) of Calliopsis (Females): Propodeum posteriorly with extensive impunctate area, base usually little or not very strongly rugose, triangle delimited by rather rounded ridge; metanotum laterally with inconspicuous (difﬁcult to see) patch of white, velvety hairs (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeum) (in part) of Calliopsis (Females): Stigma less than twice as broad as prestigma as measured to wing margin; stigmal margin within marginal cell straight or nearly so; midfemoral comb about half length of femur

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeum) (in part) of Calliopsis (Females): T2-T4 without marginal hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liopoeum) (in part) of Calliopsis (Females): Middle tibial spur with most teeth much longer than those of hind tibial spurs; S6 with apical marginal fringe of hairs broken medially (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Hypomacrotera) of Calliopsis (Females): Stigma less than twice as broad as prestigma as measured to wing margin; stigmal margin within marginal cell straight or nearly so; midfemoral comb about half length of femur

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Hypomacrotera) of Calliopsis (Females): T2-T4 without marginal hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Hypomacrotera) of Calliopsis (Females): Middle tibial spur with most teeth only slightly longer than those of hind tibial spurs; S6 with hairs forming a continuous curved fringe distally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Hypomacrotera) of Calliopsis (Females): Propodeal triangle polished; metasoma with no yellow markings (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Micronomadopsis) of Calliopsis (Females): Body length less than 10 mm; middle tibial spur with four teeth on distal half (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Nomadopsis) of Calliopsis (Females): Body length 10 mm or longer; middle tibial spur with more than four teeth on distal half (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Callonychium s. str.) of Callonychium: Axilla acute, yellow; S1 of male without premarginal process

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Paranychium) of Callonychium: Axilla rounded, depressed, black; S1 of male with premarginal process

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Oxaea of the Oxaeinae: Maxillary palpus absent; male gonostylus not recognizable, the apex of gonoforceps hairless (Fig. 60-3d)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Notoxaea of the Oxaeinae: Maxillary palpus present, six-segmented; male gonostylus partly differentiated from gonocoxite and hairy (Fig. 60-3a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Notoxaea of the Oxaeinae: Mandible with preapical tooth on inner margin; clypeus and mandible of male with pale maculations (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protoxaea of the Oxaeinae: Maxillary palpus present, six-segmented; male gonostylus partly differentiated from gonocoxite and hairy (Fig. 60-3a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protoxaea of the Oxaeinae: Mandible simple apically; clypeus and mandible of male without pale maculations

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protoxaea of the Oxaeinae: S8 of male with apex convex, not emarginate (Fig. 603b); T6 of male and T5 of female without conspicuous lateral tufts of long white hairs (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mesoxaea of the Oxaeinae: Maxillary palpus present, six-segmented; male gonostylus partly differentiated from gonocoxite and hairy (Fig. 60-3a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mesoxaea of the Oxaeinae: Mandible simple apically; clypeus and mandible of male without pale maculations

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mesoxaea of the Oxaeinae: S8 of male with median apical emargination (Fig. 603g); T6 of male and T5 of female each with lateral tuft of long white hairs (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Rophitinae, of the Halictidae: Antennae usually arising below midlength of eyes and antennal sockets separated from upper clypeal margin by little (if any) more than diameter of socket (Fig. 61-2); apex of labrum of female truncate or rounded (Fig. 612c), not produced to a process; hind basitarsus of female usually with apical angle or process but always without penicillus; trochanteral and femoral scopa reduced, longest hairs ordinarily shorter than those of tibial scopa

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomiinae, of the Halictidae: Antenna usually arising near midlength of eyes, or, if below that level, then separated from upper clypeal margin by much more than diameter of antennal socket; apex of labrum of female, except in some cleptoparasitic forms, produced to a process commonly bearing a strong keel; hind basitarsus of female, except in some parasitic forms, with apical process bearing penicillus; trochanteral and femoral scopa well developed except in parasitic forms, longest hairs ordinarily longer than those of tibial scopa and forming femoral corbicula [but femoral scopa poorly developed in some Lipotriches (Nomiinae) such as L. tuleareasis(Benoist)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomiinae, of the Halictidae: Episternal groove below scrobal groove absent or a weak depression, sometimes directed strongly forward; when there are three submarginal cells, third usually about as long as ﬁrst, or,i fshorter, then usually twice as long as second (apex of marginal cell rather broadly rounded, Fig. 63-1 (prepygidial ﬁmbria of female not divided medially; S7 of male a transverse plate with short apodemal arms and no midapical projection)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Halictinae, of the Halictidae: Antenna usually arising near midlength of eyes, or, if below that level, then separated from upper clypeal margin by much more than diameter of antennal socket; apex of labrum of female, except in some cleptoparasitic forms, produced to a process commonly bearing a strong keel; hind basitarsus of female, except in some parasitic forms, with apical process bearing penicillus; trochanteral and femoral scopa well developed except in parasitic forms, longest hairs ordinarily longer than those of tibial scopa and forming femoral corbicula [but femoral scopa poorly developed in some Lipotriches (Nomiinae) such as L. tuleareasis(Benoist)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Halictinae, of the Halictidae: Episternal groove distinct and directed strongly downward below scrobal groove; when there are three submarginal cells, third shorter than ﬁrst and less than twice as long as second

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Halictinae, of the Halictidae: Apex of marginal cell pointed or minutely truncate; prepygidial ﬁmbria of female divided by longitudinal median zone or triangle of very ﬁne, dense hairs and punctation or sometimes nearly bare integument, the ﬁmbria and its median zone absent in some cleptoparasitic forms; S7 of male consisting of a small discal region, long basolateral apodemes, and usually a midapical angle or process; S8 of male broader than long, variable in shape (S7 and S8 aberrant in Urohalictus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
