Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomioidinae, of the Halictidae: Antenna usually arising near midlength of eyes, or, if below that level, then separated from upper clypeal margin by much more than diameter of antennal socket; apex of labrum of female, except in some cleptoparasitic forms, produced to a process commonly bearing a strong keel; hind basitarsus of female, except in some parasitic forms, with apical process bearing penicillus; trochanteral and femoral scopa well developed except in parasitic forms, longest hairs ordinarily longer than those of tibial scopa and forming femoral corbicula [but femoral scopa poorly developed in some Lipotriches (Nomiinae) such as L. tuleareasis(Benoist)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomioidinae, of the Halictidae: Episternal groove distinct and directed strongly downward below scrobal groove; when there are three submarginal cells, third shorter than ﬁrst and less than twice as long as second

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomioidinae, of the Halictidae: Apex of marginal cell rounded or truncate; prepygidial ﬁmbria of female not divided medially; S7 of male a broad and little modiﬁed sternum; S8 of male longer than broad, with broad spiculum and often long apical process (Eastern Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dufourea of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dufourea of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: S8 of male without a spiculum but with a pair of basal lobes (Fig. 62-2b); penis valves large, elevated above bases of gonocoxites; volsella produced to a ﬁngerlike hairy process (Fig. 62-2a); distance from apex of stigma to apex of marginal cell almost always at least as great as distance from apex of marginal cell to wing tip (Fig. 62-1b) (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Micralictoides of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Micralictoides of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: S8 of male pointed to truncate at base (Fig. 62-2f, i), without pair of basal lobes; penis valves but little elevated above bases of gonocoxites; volsella relatively short, not produced to a ﬁngerlike process (Fig. 62-2e, h); distance from apex of stigma to apex of marginal cell sometimes less than distance from apex of marginal cell to wing tip (Fig. 62-1c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Micralictoides of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Dorsal surface of propodeum more than twice as long as metanotum; male with major apical lobes of S7 slender basally and strongly incurled apically; gonostylus slender and straplike (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodosoma (in part) of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodosoma (in part) of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: S8 of male pointed to truncate at base (Fig. 62-2f, i), without pair of basal lobes; penis valves but little elevated above bases of gonocoxites; volsella relatively short, not produced to a ﬁngerlike process (Fig. 62-2e, h); distance from apex of stigma to apex of marginal cell sometimes less than distance from apex of marginal cell to wing tip (Fig. 62-1c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodosoma (in part) of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Dorsal surface of propodeum not or little longer than metanotum; male with apical lobes of S7 broad throughout and downcurved; gonostylus subtriangular and not well differentiated from gonocoxite (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dufourea of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dufourea of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Flagellum of male not so modiﬁed; metasoma without abundant long hair; S8 of male with apical process slender, capitate, often projecting but not suggesting a tergal plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dufourea of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Male without pygidial plate, or sometimes with shiny bare area but this area not deﬁned by carinae and not elevated; base of S8 of male deeply bilobed (Fig. 60-2b); labial palpus with ﬁrst two segments, or at least second, slender and similar in width to third and fourth segments (metasomal hair bands absent or sparse, integument thus visible through bands of hair) (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Micralictoides of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Micralictoides of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Flagellum of male not so modiﬁed; metasoma without abundant long hair; S8 of male with apical process slender, capitate, often projecting but not suggesting a tergal plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Micralictoides of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Dorsal surface of propodeum more than twice as long as metanotum; male with major apical lobes of S7 slender basally and strongly incurled apically; gonostylus slender and straplike (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodosoma (in part) of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodosoma (in part) of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Flagellum of male not so modiﬁed; metasoma without abundant long hair; S8 of male with apical process slender, capitate, often projecting but not suggesting a tergal plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodosoma (in part) of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Dorsal surface of propodeum not or little longer than metanotum; male with apical lobes of S7 broad throughout and downcurved; gonostylus subtriangular and not well differentiated from gonocoxite (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ceblurgus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ceblurgus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Flagellum of male not so modiﬁed; metasoma without abundant long hair; S8 of male with apical process slender, capitate, often projecting but not suggesting a tergal plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ceblurgus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Male with well deﬁned, strongly elevated pygidial plate [not veriﬁed for Rophites (Flavodufourea)]; base of S8 of male rounded to weakly bilobed; labial palpus with ﬁrst two segments broad and ﬂattened in contrast to third and fourth segments (except that in Rophites s. str. third segment is on same axis as second and also rather broad basally, only fourth being freely articulated)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ceblurgus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Subantennal area sharply deﬁned, smooth, impunctate, and hairless, extending down broadly to epistomal suture; anterior tentorial pit adjacent to lower outer edge of antennal socket; labial palpus longer than prementum, at least ﬁrst three segments ﬂattened (South America).

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ceblurgus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Clypeus four or ﬁve times as broad as long; mandible of both sexes with medial or basal tooth or projection on upper margin, in addition to preapical tooth; pygidial plate of male nearly linear (Brazil)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Penapis of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Penapis of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Flagellum of male not so modiﬁed; metasoma without abundant long hair; S8 of male with apical process slender, capitate, often projecting but not suggesting a tergal plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Penapis of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Male with well deﬁned, strongly elevated pygidial plate [not veriﬁed for Rophites (Flavodufourea)]; base of S8 of male rounded to weakly bilobed; labial palpus with ﬁrst two segments broad and ﬂattened in contrast to third and fourth segments (except that in Rophites s. str. third segment is on same axis as second and also rather broad basally, only fourth being freely articulated)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Penapis of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Subantennal area sharply deﬁned, smooth, impunctate, and hairless, extending down broadly to epistomal suture; anterior tentorial pit adjacent to lower outer edge of antennal socket; labial palpus longer than prementum, at least ﬁrst three segments ﬂattened (South America).

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Penapis of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Clypeus two or three times as broad as long; mandible with usual preapical tooth only; pygidial plate of male broad or absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Penapis of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Maxillary palpus six-segmented; tibial scopal hairs simple; pygidial plate of male about as broad at base as long (Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Goeletapis of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Goeletapis of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Flagellum of male not so modiﬁed; metasoma without abundant long hair; S8 of male with apical process slender, capitate, often projecting but not suggesting a tergal plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Goeletapis of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Male with well deﬁned, strongly elevated pygidial plate [not veriﬁed for Rophites (Flavodufourea)]; base of S8 of male rounded to weakly bilobed; labial palpus with ﬁrst two segments broad and ﬂattened in contrast to third and fourth segments (except that in Rophites s. str. third segment is on same axis as second and also rather broad basally, only fourth being freely articulated)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Goeletapis of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Subantennal area sharply deﬁned, smooth, impunctate, and hairless, extending down broadly to epistomal suture; anterior tentorial pit adjacent to lower outer edge of antennal socket; labial palpus longer than prementum, at least ﬁrst three segments ﬂattened (South America).

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Goeletapis of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Clypeus two or three times as broad as long; mandible with usual preapical tooth only; pygidial plate of male broad or absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Goeletapis of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Maxillary palpus four-segmented; tibial scopal hairs plumose; pygidial plate of male absent (Peru)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeralictus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeralictus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Flagellum of male not so modiﬁed; metasoma without abundant long hair; S8 of male with apical process slender, capitate, often projecting but not suggesting a tergal plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeralictus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Male with well deﬁned, strongly elevated pygidial plate [not veriﬁed for Rophites (Flavodufourea)]; base of S8 of male rounded to weakly bilobed; labial palpus with ﬁrst two segments broad and ﬂattened in contrast to third and fourth segments (except that in Rophites s. str. third segment is on same axis as second and also rather broad basally, only fourth being freely articulated)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeralictus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Subantennal area often evident as small triangle, impunctate area below antenna, if present, not sharply deﬁned, with punctures and hairs at least marginally; anterior tentorial pit on or just above epistomal suture; labial palpus equal to or shorter than prementum, not ﬂattened (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeralictus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Outer hind tibial spur and middle tibial spur coarsely serrate, some teeth long enough to make the spurs brieﬂy pectinate (Fig. 62-4); S7 of male a broad plate without or with small apical lobe on each side, much smaller than disc of sternum; body length 8 mm or more (nearctic deserts)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protodufourea of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protodufourea of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Flagellum of male not so modiﬁed; metasoma without abundant long hair; S8 of male with apical process slender, capitate, often projecting but not suggesting a tergal plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protodufourea of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Male with well deﬁned, strongly elevated pygidial plate [not veriﬁed for Rophites (Flavodufourea)]; base of S8 of male rounded to weakly bilobed; labial palpus with ﬁrst two segments broad and ﬂattened in contrast to third and fourth segments (except that in Rophites s. str. third segment is on same axis as second and also rather broad basally, only fourth being freely articulated)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protodufourea of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Subantennal area often evident as small triangle, impunctate area below antenna, if present, not sharply deﬁned, with punctures and hairs at least marginally; anterior tentorial pit on or just above epistomal suture; labial palpus equal to or shorter than prementum, not ﬂattened (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protodufourea of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Tibial spurs minutely ciliate, appearing simple; S7 of male with small disc to which are attached two or four large apical lobes, the lobes collectively much larger than disc; body length usually less than 7.5 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protodufourea of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Dorsal surface of propodeum about two-thirds as long as scutellum and about one-half as long as posterior surface of propodeum, as seen from side (Fig. 62-3a); S7 of male with four apical lobes (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Conanthalictus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Conanthalictus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Flagellum of male not so modiﬁed; metasoma without abundant long hair; S8 of male with apical process slender, capitate, often projecting but not suggesting a tergal plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Conanthalictus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Male with well deﬁned, strongly elevated pygidial plate [not veriﬁed for Rophites (Flavodufourea)]; base of S8 of male rounded to weakly bilobed; labial palpus with ﬁrst two segments broad and ﬂattened in contrast to third and fourth segments (except that in Rophites s. str. third segment is on same axis as second and also rather broad basally, only fourth being freely articulated)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Conanthalictus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Subantennal area often evident as small triangle, impunctate area below antenna, if present, not sharply deﬁned, with punctures and hairs at least marginally; anterior tentorial pit on or just above epistomal suture; labial palpus equal to or shorter than prementum, not ﬂattened (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Conanthalictus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Tibial spurs minutely ciliate, appearing simple; S7 of male with small disc to which are attached two or four large apical lobes, the lobes collectively much larger than disc; body length usually less than 7.5 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Conanthalictus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Dorsal surface of propodeum about as long as scutellum, more than one-half as long as posterior surface of propodeum, as seen from side (Fig. 62-3b); S7 of male with two apical lobes (Fig. 62-2g, k)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Conanthalictus of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Clypeal truncation more than twice as long as length of clypeus; body surface minutely roughened and usually more or less dull; S7 of male relatively ﬂat; spiculum of S8 of male pointed (Fig. 62-2f) (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Systropha of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Systropha of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Flagellum of male with ﬁrst six segments more or less normal, remaining segments abruptly more slender than preceding segments, tightly curled, and sometimes reduced in number; metasoma of both sexes, at least laterally, with abundant, long, more or less erect hair; S8 of male with apical process very broad, projecting, thus suggesting in undissected specimens an eighth tergum (forewing with three submarginal cells)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dufourea of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dufourea of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Flagellum of male not so modiﬁed; metasoma without abundant long hair; S8 of male with apical process slender, capitate, often projecting but not suggesting a tergal plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dufourea of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Male without pygidial plate, or sometimes with shiny bare area but this area not deﬁned by carinae and not elevated; base of S8 of male deeply bilobed (Fig. 60-2b); labial palpus with ﬁrst two segments, or at least second, slender and similar in width to third and fourth segments (metasomal hair bands absent or sparse, integument thus visible through bands of hair) (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rophites of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rophites of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Flagellum of male not so modiﬁed; metasoma without abundant long hair; S8 of male with apical process slender, capitate, often projecting but not suggesting a tergal plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rophites of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Male with well deﬁned, strongly elevated pygidial plate [not veriﬁed for Rophites (Flavodufourea)]; base of S8 of male rounded to weakly bilobed; labial palpus with ﬁrst two segments broad and ﬂattened in contrast to third and fourth segments (except that in Rophites s. str. third segment is on same axis as second and also rather broad basally, only fourth being freely articulated)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rophites of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Metasomal terga with well-developed, dense, pale apical hair bands; forewing with two submarginal cells; pygidial plate of male margined by sharp carina (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Morawitzia of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 62-1b, c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Morawitzia of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Flagellum of male not so modiﬁed; metasoma without abundant long hair; S8 of male with apical process slender, capitate, often projecting but not suggesting a tergal plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Morawitzia of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Male with well deﬁned, strongly elevated pygidial plate [not veriﬁed for Rophites (Flavodufourea)]; base of S8 of male rounded to weakly bilobed; labial palpus with ﬁrst two segments broad and ﬂattened in contrast to third and fourth segments (except that in Rophites s. str. third segment is on same axis as second and also rather broad basally, only fourth being freely articulated)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Morawitzia of the Rophitinae of the WesternHemisphere: Metasomal terga without pale apical hair bands; forewing with three submarginal cells; pygidial plate of male not margined by sharp carina (T urkey)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Conanthalictus. s. str.) of Conanthalictus: Head elongate oval, longer than broad; antennal bases twice as far from ocelli as from anterior clypeal margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Phaceliapis) of Conanthalictus: Head broader than long; antennal bases scarcely 1.5 times as far from ocelli as from anterior clypeal margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera R. (Flavodufourea) of Rophites: First segment of labial palpus strongly broadened in apical half; apical lobes of S7 of male broad basally and tapering to points

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera R. (Rophites s. str.) of Rophites: First segment of labial palpus nearly parallel-sided; apical lobes of S7 of male slender basally, slightly enlarged and rounded apically

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera R. (Rophites s. str.) of Rophites: Labial palpal segments 1 to 3 ﬂattened, fourth segment not ﬂattened and sometimes divergent from axis of other segments; labial palpus longer than maxillary palpus; frons of female with several coarse bristles, these hooked or curved at tips (but bristles absent in Rophites gusenleitneri Schwammberger)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera R. (Rhophitoides) of Rophites: First segment of labial palpus nearly parallel-sided; apical lobes of S7 of male slender basally, slightly enlarged and rounded apically

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera R. (Rhophitoides) of Rophites: Labial palpus with at least segment 3 (as well as 4) not ﬂattened, commonly diverging from axis of 1 and 2; labial palpus shorter than maxillary palpus; frons of female without coarse bristles

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Michenerula) of Sphecodosoma: Fore wing with two submarginal cells; dorsal surface of propodeum not or little longer than metanotum; body length about 6 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Sphecodosoma s. str.) of Sphecodosoma: Fore wing usually with three submarginal cells; dorsal surface of propodeum much longer than metanotum; body length 4.5 mm or less

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mellitidia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Malar space at least half as long as wide (apical tergal hair bands absent except sometimes at sides of T1 and T2; head only slightly, if any, wider than long)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mellitidia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Metanotum with median tubercle or projection (weak in Mellitidia simplicinotum Michener); mandible of female three-toothed; inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with two large, broad teeth (Fig. 63-2k) (New Guinea region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ptilonomia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Malar space at least half as long as wide (apical tergal hair bands absent except sometimes at sides of T1 and T2; head only slightly, if any, wider than long)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ptilonomia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Metanotum strongly convex, slightly depressed medially, without median tubercle; mandible of female twotoothed; inner hind tibial spur of female minutely ciliateserrate (as in Fig. 63-2f) (New Guinea)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Reepenia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Malar space nearly absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Reepenia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Ocelli enlarged, ocellocular distance equal to or less than ocellar diameter; hind wing with dark area (due to dense minute hairs) along costal margin between hamuli and wing tip (body partly brown or testaceous; scutellum of male bituberculate) (New Guinea region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Nomia (in part) of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Malar space nearly absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Nomia (in part) of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Ocelli not or only slightly enlarged, ocellocular distance greater than ocellar diameter; hind wing without dark area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Nomia (in part) of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Marginal zones of T2 to T4 (or, in males, to T5), and often also T1, except near bases, hairless, impunctate, usually opaque white, yellow, green, or blue, although sometimes concolorous with rest of metasoma, the frequently opalescent bands sometimes broken medially (basal area of propodeum subhorizontal to vertical, sometimes incompletely distinguished from rest of propodeal triangle; anterior end of scutum not or only medially bent sharply down to meet pronotum; pronotum not lamellate)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudapis of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Malar space nearly absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudapis of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Ocelli not or only slightly enlarged, ocellocular distance greater than ocellar diameter; hind wing without dark area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudapis of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Marginal zones of T1 to T4 variable, often hairy or punctate, and if impunctate, then often translucent, sometimes only that of T4 hairy or punctate, the zones never white, yellow, green, or blue

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudapis of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: T egula enormous, extending well behind level of scutoscutellar suture (Fig. 63-4o) and preoccipital carina present; anterior end of scutum medially bent sharply downward, the angle sharp and commonly carinate (pronotum with strong, translucent lamella from posterior lobe mesad)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Steganomus of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Malar space nearly absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Steganomus of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Ocelli not or only slightly enlarged, ocellocular distance greater than ocellar diameter; hind wing without dark area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Steganomus of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Marginal zones of T1 to T4 variable, often hairy or punctate, and if impunctate, then often translucent, sometimes only that of T4 hairy or punctate, the zones never white, yellow, green, or blue

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Steganomus of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: T egula not reaching level of scutoscutellar suture, or, if enlarged as above, then preoccipital carina absent; anterior end of scutum, if bent sharply downward, without sharp angle or carina along bend

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Steganomus of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Submarginal cells two; males and some females with translucent lamella on dorsolateral angle of pronotum, the lamella extending continuously mesad as carina all across pronotum; tegula large as in Pseudapis (Fig. 634o); mesepisternum of male, mesal to middle coxa, with tubercle or spine; antenna of male with last two segments enlarged and ﬂattened, not pedunculate (African, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mellitidia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Malar space at least half as long as wide (apical tergal hair bands absent except sometimes at sides of T1 and T2; head only slightly, if any, wider than long)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mellitidia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Metanotum with median tubercle or projection (weak in Mellitidia simplicinotum Michener); mandible of female three-toothed; inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with two large, broad teeth (Fig. 63-2k) (New Guinea region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ptilonomia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Malar space at least half as long as wide (apical tergal hair bands absent except sometimes at sides of T1 and T2; head only slightly, if any, wider than long)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ptilonomia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Metanotum strongly convex, slightly depressed medially, without median tubercle; mandible of female twotoothed; inner hind tibial spur of female minutely ciliateserrate (as in Fig. 63-2f) (New Guinea)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Reepenia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Malar space nearly absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Reepenia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Ocelli enlarged, ocellocular distance equal to or less than ocellar diameter; hind wing with dark area (due to dense minute hairs) along costal margin between hamuli and wing tip (body partly brown or testaceous; scutellum of male bituberculate) (New Guinea region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Nomia (in part) of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: T2 to T4 completely without apical bands of hair or tomentum, depressed marginal zones largely impunctate; pronotum without continuous transverse carina; male upper gonostylus directed apically and consisting of a broad, ﬂat plate with ornate or incised margins (metanotum sometimes with broad lamelliform projections)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudapis of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Malar space nearly absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudapis of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Ocelli not or only slightly enlarged, ocellocular distance greater than ocellar diameter; hind wing without dark area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudapis of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Marginal zones of T1 to T4 variable, often hairy or punctate, and if impunctate, then often translucent, sometimes only that of T4 hairy or punctate, the zones never white, yellow, green, or blue

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudapis of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: T egula enormous, extending well behind level of scutoscutellar suture (Fig. 63-4o) and preoccipital carina present; anterior end of scutum medially bent sharply downward, the angle sharp and commonly carinate (pronotum with strong, translucent lamella from posterior lobe mesad)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Steganomus of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Malar space nearly absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Steganomus of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Ocelli not or only slightly enlarged, ocellocular distance greater than ocellar diameter; hind wing without dark area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Steganomus of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Marginal zones of T1 to T4 variable, often hairy or punctate, and if impunctate, then often translucent, sometimes only that of T4 hairy or punctate, the zones never white, yellow, green, or blue

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Steganomus of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: T egula not reaching level of scutoscutellar suture, or, if enlarged as above, then preoccipital carina absent; anterior end of scutum, if bent sharply downward, without sharp angle or carina along bend

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Steganomus of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Submarginal cells two; males and some females with translucent lamella on dorsolateral angle of pronotum, the lamella extending continuously mesad as carina all across pronotum; tegula large as in Pseudapis (Fig. 634o); mesepisternum of male, mesal to middle coxa, with tubercle or spine; antenna of male with last two segments enlarged and ﬂattened, not pedunculate (African, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphegocephala of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Malar space nearly absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphegocephala of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Ocelli not or only slightly enlarged, ocellocular distance greater than ocellar diameter; hind wing without dark area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphegocephala of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Marginal zones of T1 to T4 variable, often hairy or punctate, and if impunctate, then often translucent, sometimes only that of T4 hairy or punctate, the zones never white, yellow, green, or blue

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphegocephala of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: T egula not reaching level of scutoscutellar suture, or, if enlarged as above, then preoccipital carina absent; anterior end of scutum, if bent sharply downward, without sharp angle or carina along bend

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphegocephala of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Submarginal cells three; pronotum frequently without lamella, although often with carina that may or may not extend across pronotum, and in some Lipotriches s. str. [e.g., notabilis (Schletterer)] that do have a lamella there is a break or angular notch between lamella of posterior pronotal lobe and that of dorsolateral angle of pronotum; tegula only rarely enlarged as in Pseudapis; mesepisternum of male without ventral tubercle or spine; antenna of male usually not enlarged and ﬂattened at apex [except inSpatunomia and Lipotriches (Clavinomia)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphegocephala of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Propodeal triangle sloping, curving down onto posterior surface of propodeum; basal area of propodeum neither sculptured distinctively nor deﬁned by strong line or carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphegocephala of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Basitibial plate of female delimited by carina only along posterior side; lateral carina of T1 strong, reaching posterior margin of tergum; pronotum with strong transverse carina at and usually extending mesad from dorsolateral angle, but the carina depressed and weak or absent medially; T6 of male with median, ﬂat, apical projection resembling a pygidial plate (Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictonomia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Malar space nearly absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictonomia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Ocelli not or only slightly enlarged, ocellocular distance greater than ocellar diameter; hind wing without dark area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictonomia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Marginal zones of T1 to T4 variable, often hairy or punctate, and if impunctate, then often translucent, sometimes only that of T4 hairy or punctate, the zones never white, yellow, green, or blue

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictonomia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: T egula not reaching level of scutoscutellar suture, or, if enlarged as above, then preoccipital carina absent; anterior end of scutum, if bent sharply downward, without sharp angle or carina along bend

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictonomia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Submarginal cells three; pronotum frequently without lamella, although often with carina that may or may not extend across pronotum, and in some Lipotriches s. str. [e.g., notabilis (Schletterer)] that do have a lamella there is a break or angular notch between lamella of posterior pronotal lobe and that of dorsolateral angle of pronotum; tegula only rarely enlarged as in Pseudapis; mesepisternum of male without ventral tubercle or spine; antenna of male usually not enlarged and ﬂattened at apex [except inSpatunomia and Lipotriches (Clavinomia)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictonomia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Propodeal triangle sloping, curving down onto posterior surface of propodeum; basal area of propodeum neither sculptured distinctively nor deﬁned by strong line or carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictonomia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Basitibial plate of female delimited by carina on both sides; lateral carina of T1 absent; pronotum without or with weak carina; T6 of male without apical projection (Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Lipotriches (in part) of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: T2 to T4 with apical bands of hair or tomentum, at least on T4 and at least laterally, or if posterior marginal zones hairless as in some Lipotriches s. str., then pronotum with continuous transverse carina in front of posterior pronotal margin; male upper gonostylus directed mesoapically, not a broad plate (Fig. 63-3a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Nomia (in part) of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: T2 to T4 completely without apical bands of hair or tomentum, depressed marginal zones largely impunctate; pronotum without continuous transverse carina; male upper gonostylus directed apically and consisting of a broad, ﬂat plate with ornate or incised margins (metanotum sometimes with broad lamelliform projections)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dieunomia of the Nomiinae of the EasternHemisphere: Marginal zones of T2 to T4 with hair bands (sometimes of dark hairs) and punctate except for margins, zones concolorous with adjacent areas; S2 to S5 and sides of T2 to T5 with well-developed scopa of long, straight hairs, those of medial region simple or nearly so, of lateral areas with branches; male gonostylus slender, directed apicad, with only a few simple hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera D. (Dieunomia s. str.) of Dieunomia: Labial palpus with ﬁrst segment as long as or longer than segments 2 to 4 taken together; last antennal segment of male broader than preceding segments; tegula large, posterior end subtrunctate and attaining level of scutoscutellar suture, lateral margin sinuate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera D. (Epinomia) of Dieunomia: Labial palpus with ﬁrst segment shorter than remaining segments taken together; last antennal segment of male unmodiﬁed; tegula as above or shorter, its lateral and posterior margins then convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Nubenomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female tridentate, of male usually bidentate; basal area of propodeum reduced to transverse line or ﬁne groove

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lipotriches s. str.) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female bidentate, or simple in Clavinomia, of male simple (except bidentate in a few species of Lipotrichess. str.); basal area of propodeum larger, sometimes not deﬁned medially or (rarely) entirely unrecognizable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lipotriches s. str.) of Lipotriches: Pronotum with continuous or medially or laterally notched transverse carina or lamella anterior to the scutum, at about level of scutum, the latter thus not bending down anteriorly (inner hind tibial spur of female commonly untoothed, margin a simple lamella, broadest near middle of spur, sometimes with a few teeth, Fig. 63-2i)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Clavinomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female bidentate, or simple in Clavinomia, of male simple (except bidentate in a few species of Lipotrichess. str.); basal area of propodeum larger, sometimes not deﬁned medially or (rarely) entirely unrecognizable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Clavinomia) of Lipotriches: Pronotum with transverse carina either absent or broadly interrupted medially, the anterior part of the scutum thus bending down medially to depressed pronotal margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Clavinomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female simple; inner hind tibial spur of female with simple, smooth-margined lamella; male with last two antennal segments curled to one side, the last segment much expanded, broader than long (Iran)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Maynenomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female bidentate, or simple in Clavinomia, of male simple (except bidentate in a few species of Lipotrichess. str.); basal area of propodeum larger, sometimes not deﬁned medially or (rarely) entirely unrecognizable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Maynenomia) of Lipotriches: Pronotum with transverse carina either absent or broadly interrupted medially, the anterior part of the scutum thus bending down medially to depressed pronotal margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Maynenomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female with preapical tooth, thus bidentate; inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate, dentate, or minutely serrate (ciliate); male with apical antennal segments usually unmodiﬁed, but if modiﬁed, then not as above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Maynenomia) of Lipotriches: Ocellocular distance less than twice ocellar diameter; glossa very slender, as long as face; basitibial plate of female delimited on both sides but apex open; scape of female short, not reaching median ocellus (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Melanomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female bidentate, or simple in Clavinomia, of male simple (except bidentate in a few species of Lipotrichess. str.); basal area of propodeum larger, sometimes not deﬁned medially or (rarely) entirely unrecognizable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Melanomia) of Lipotriches: Pronotum with transverse carina either absent or broadly interrupted medially, the anterior part of the scutum thus bending down medially to depressed pronotal margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Melanomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female with preapical tooth, thus bidentate; inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate, dentate, or minutely serrate (ciliate); male with apical antennal segments usually unmodiﬁed, but if modiﬁed, then not as above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Melanomia) of Lipotriches: Ocellocular distance usually twice ocellar diameter or more; glossa shorter than face; basitibial plate of female, if carinate on both sides, with apex almost always closed; scape of female reaching to or beyond median ocellus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Melanomia) of Lipotriches: Head about as long as broad; clypeus with well-developed lip below row of large apical hairs (Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Macronomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female bidentate, or simple in Clavinomia, of male simple (except bidentate in a few species of Lipotrichess. str.); basal area of propodeum larger, sometimes not deﬁned medially or (rarely) entirely unrecognizable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Macronomia) of Lipotriches: Pronotum with transverse carina either absent or broadly interrupted medially, the anterior part of the scutum thus bending down medially to depressed pronotal margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Macronomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female with preapical tooth, thus bidentate; inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate, dentate, or minutely serrate (ciliate); male with apical antennal segments usually unmodiﬁed, but if modiﬁed, then not as above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Macronomia) of Lipotriches: Ocellocular distance usually twice ocellar diameter or more; glossa shorter than face; basitibial plate of female, if carinate on both sides, with apex almost always closed; scape of female reaching to or beyond median ocellus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Macronomia) of Lipotriches: Head distinctly broader than long; clypeus with row of large apical hairs very near lower margin except in a few Austronomiaand Macronomia species in which lip extends below hair bases

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Macronomia) of Lipotriches: Basitibial plate of female margined by carina only on posterior side (Africa, oriental region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Austronomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female bidentate, or simple in Clavinomia, of male simple (except bidentate in a few species of Lipotrichess. str.); basal area of propodeum larger, sometimes not deﬁned medially or (rarely) entirely unrecognizable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Austronomia) of Lipotriches: Pronotum with transverse carina either absent or broadly interrupted medially, the anterior part of the scutum thus bending down medially to depressed pronotal margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Austronomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female with preapical tooth, thus bidentate; inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate, dentate, or minutely serrate (ciliate); male with apical antennal segments usually unmodiﬁed, but if modiﬁed, then not as above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Austronomia) of Lipotriches: Ocellocular distance usually twice ocellar diameter or more; glossa shorter than face; basitibial plate of female, if carinate on both sides, with apex almost always closed; scape of female reaching to or beyond median ocellus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Austronomia) of Lipotriches: Head distinctly broader than long; clypeus with row of large apical hairs very near lower margin except in a few Austronomiaand Macronomia species in which lip extends below hair bases

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Austronomia) of Lipotriches: Basitibial plate of female with marginal carina complete except for base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Austronomia) of Lipotriches: Propodeal basal area more or less horizontal, only posterior part of propodeal triangle declivous (Australia, oriental region, Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Trinomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female bidentate, or simple in Clavinomia, of male simple (except bidentate in a few species of Lipotrichess. str.); basal area of propodeum larger, sometimes not deﬁned medially or (rarely) entirely unrecognizable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Trinomia) of Lipotriches: Pronotum with transverse carina either absent or broadly interrupted medially, the anterior part of the scutum thus bending down medially to depressed pronotal margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Trinomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female with preapical tooth, thus bidentate; inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate, dentate, or minutely serrate (ciliate); male with apical antennal segments usually unmodiﬁed, but if modiﬁed, then not as above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Trinomia) of Lipotriches: Ocellocular distance usually twice ocellar diameter or more; glossa shorter than face; basitibial plate of female, if carinate on both sides, with apex almost always closed; scape of female reaching to or beyond median ocellus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Trinomia) of Lipotriches: Head distinctly broader than long; clypeus with row of large apical hairs very near lower margin except in a few Austronomiaand Macronomia species in which lip extends below hair bases

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Trinomia) of Lipotriches: Basitibial plate of female with marginal carina complete except for base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Trinomia) of Lipotriches: Propodeal basal area more or less vertical, at least medially, so that whole propodeal triangle, or most of it, is vertical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Trinomia) of Lipotriches: T erga, at least most of T1, minutely tessellate, dull, with only ﬁne, sparse punctation; hind femur of male with three strong teeth on undersurface (Africa, Arabia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Afronomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female bidentate, or simple in Clavinomia, of male simple (except bidentate in a few species of Lipotrichess. str.); basal area of propodeum larger, sometimes not deﬁned medially or (rarely) entirely unrecognizable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Afronomia) of Lipotriches: Pronotum with transverse carina either absent or broadly interrupted medially, the anterior part of the scutum thus bending down medially to depressed pronotal margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Afronomia) of Lipotriches: Mandible of female with preapical tooth, thus bidentate; inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate, dentate, or minutely serrate (ciliate); male with apical antennal segments usually unmodiﬁed, but if modiﬁed, then not as above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Afronomia) of Lipotriches: Ocellocular distance usually twice ocellar diameter or more; glossa shorter than face; basitibial plate of female, if carinate on both sides, with apex almost always closed; scape of female reaching to or beyond median ocellus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Afronomia) of Lipotriches: Head distinctly broader than long; clypeus with row of large apical hairs very near lower margin except in a few Austronomiaand Macronomia species in which lip extends below hair bases

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Afronomia) of Lipotriches: Basitibial plate of female with marginal carina complete except for base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Afronomia) of Lipotriches: Propodeal basal area more or less vertical, at least medially, so that whole propodeal triangle, or most of it, is vertical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Afronomia) of Lipotriches: T erga more shiny, often shagreened but not tessellate, usually more coarsely punctate; hind femur of male without or with one or two strong teeth (Africa, oriental region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Crocisaspidia) of Nomia: Metanotum with two broad, lamelliform projections, the two often united to one another

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Crocisaspidia) of Nomia: Lateral extremity of scutellum with lamelliform projection (Africa, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Hoplonomia) of Nomia: Metanotum with two broad, lamelliform projections, the two often united to one another

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Hoplonomia) of Nomia: Lateral extremity of scutellum not produced (oriental, Australia, Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Acunomia) of Nomia: Metanotum without projections

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Acunomia) of Nomia: Outer hind tibial spur of female and some males bent near apex, usually with projection at the bend continuing direction of main shaft (Fig. 63-2l); middle tibial spur usually with a few coarse preapical teeth (basitibial plate of female completely margined by carinae except at base; posterior femur of male without tooth)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Acunomia) of Nomia: S8 of male a small, compact sclerite with midapical peglike projection (as in Fig. 63-3g); S7 of male transverse, with two hirsute apical projections (as in Fig. 633h); male gonostylus ﬂattened, commonly expanded, sometimes curved basad (as in Fig. 63-3f); S6 of male with apical margin emarginate, surface without oblique rows of setae; S5 of male with apex variously thickened, lobate, with hair tufts (as in Fig. 63-3j) (holarctic, Africa, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Paulynomia) of Nomia: Metanotum without projections

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Paulynomia) of Nomia: Outer hind tibial spur of female and some males bent near apex, usually with projection at the bend continuing direction of main shaft (Fig. 63-2l); middle tibial spur usually with a few coarse preapical teeth (basitibial plate of female completely margined by carinae except at base; posterior femur of male without tooth)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Paulynomia) of Nomia: S8 of male relatively large, broadened basally and preapically, lateral margins thus concave, apical peglike projection absent (Fig. 63-3l); S7 of male relatively large, basolateral apodemal lobes long, length of sclerite thus much more than half its width (Fig. 63-3m); male gonostylus rather slender, not ﬂattened, much exceeding penis valves, directed posteriorly, and arising from distal end of elongated gonocoxite (Fig. 63-3k); S6 of male with apex rounded, surface with oblique rows of ﬂattened setae (Fig. 63-3n); S5 of male unmodiﬁed (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Leuconomia) of Nomia: Metanotum without projections

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Leuconomia) of Nomia: Outer hind tibial spur of female and most males tapering to unmodiﬁed apex (Fig. 63-2h); middle tibial spur with all teeth minute

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Leuconomia) of Nomia: Male, in species with slender legs, with basitibial plate; T1 frequently without colored band and usually with pale hair band laterally; hind femur of male without tooth or with tooth near base on underside; body length 10 mm or less; colored bands white or nearly so (Africa, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Nomia s. str.) of Nomia: Metanotum without projections

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Nomia s. str.) of Nomia: Outer hind tibial spur of female and most males tapering to unmodiﬁed apex (Fig. 63-2h); middle tibial spur with all teeth minute

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Nomia s. str.) of Nomia: Male without basitibial plate; T1 with colored band, without hair band; hind leg enlarged, femur with one or two preapical teeth on underside; body length 9 mm or more; bands more brightly colored (Africa, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pachynomia) of Pseudapis: Basitibial plate of female delimited by a carina only on posterior margin; hind leg of male not enlarged, tibia without apical process but bearing two apical spurs; male upper gonostylus broadly fused to gonocoxite, directed apicad, with mosslike hair covering dorsal surface (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pseudapis s. str.) of Pseudapis: Basitibial plate of female fully delimited, i.e., with a carina on both anterior and posterior margins; hind leg of male somewhat, often greatly, swollen, at least tibia with apical process, but without spurs or with only one spur; male upper gonostylus differentiated from gonocoxite, directed mesad across apex of genital capsule, and without mosslike hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Nomioides of the Nomioidinae: S8 of male with long apical process (Fig. 64-2e), the process much longer than broad, thus sternum over 2.5 times as long as wide; posterior depressed marginal zone of T2 and frequently other terga translucent yellowish, so that yellow base of T3 shows through

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Cellariella of the Nomioidinae: S8 of male without or with short apical process (Fig. 642b), the process not or scarcely longer than broad, sternum thus less than 2.5 times as long as broad; posterior depressed marginal zone of T2 and frequently other terga brown or dusky, at least basally (margin often narrowly pallid translucent) so that base of T3 does not show through conspicuously

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Cellariella of the Nomioidinae: Second submarginal cell petiolate from costal side (Fig. 64-3d); median ﬂagellar segments of male little longer than broad; inner hind tibial spur of female with one large tooth (Fig. 64-3e); S8 of male with apical process short, broader than long or about as broad as long depending on how it is measured (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ceylalictus of the Nomioidinae: S8 of male without or with short apical process (Fig. 642b), the process not or scarcely longer than broad, sternum thus less than 2.5 times as long as broad; posterior depressed marginal zone of T2 and frequently other terga brown or dusky, at least basally (margin often narrowly pallid translucent) so that base of T3 does not show through conspicuously

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ceylalictus of the Nomioidinae: Second submarginal cell not petiolate (as in Fig. 64-1a), although sometimes pointed on marginal cell; median ﬂagellar segments of male about 1.5 times as long as broad; inner hind tibial spur of female with two large teeth; S8 of male completely without apical process, apex Yshaped with membrane between arms of Y (Fig. 642b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ceylalictus s. str.) of Ceylalictus (Males): Gonostylus of male slender, eight or more times as long as wide (Fig. 64-2a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Meganomioides) of Ceylalictus (Males): Gonostylus of male broad, not over about four times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Meganomioides) of Ceylalictus (Males): Gonostylus of male three or four times as long as wide, the apex narrowly rounded; penis valve rather straight

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Atronomioides) of Ceylalictus (Males): Gonostylus of male broad, not over about four times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Atronomioides) of Ceylalictus (Males): Gonostylus of male about twice as long as broad, the apex broadly truncate; penis valve with strong bend near base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Halictini, of the Halictinae: Longitudinal median specialized area of T5 of female of nonparasitic forms not divided by a notch or cleft (Fig. 65-1j); parasitic forms (recognized by loss or reduction of scopa and other pollen-carrying and -manipulating structures) nonmetallic or with dull greenish coloration; T7 of male with a transverse ridge, usually carinate, forming a false apex beneath which the tergum is strongly reﬂexed to the morphological apical margin, surface above the transverse ridge usually with a recognizable hairless pygidial plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Augochlorini, of the Halictinae: Longitudinal median specialized area of T5 of female of nonparasitic forms divided by a notch or cleft in tergal margin (Fig. 65-1k); parasitic forms mostly brilliant metallic green; T7 of male without pygidial plate and without transverse premarginal ridge or carina forming a false apex (Western Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Lasioglossum (Dialictus) (in part) of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Scopa weak (Figs. 8-5a, 8-6) or absent; T5 with longitudinal median zone of ﬁne punctation and short hairs weakly developed or absent; apical labral process without keel (as in Fig. 65-1i) or keel reduced to weak carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Lasioglossum (Dialictus) (in part) of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Second and third submarginal crossvein and ﬁrst recurrent vein (as in Fig. 66-6c); head and thorax largely dull greenish; inner hind tibial spur pectinate with two to four teeth (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ptilocleptis of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Scopa weak (Figs. 8-5a, 8-6) or absent; T5 with longitudinal median zone of ﬁne punctation and short hairs weakly developed or absent; apical labral process without keel (as in Fig. 65-1i) or keel reduced to weak carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ptilocleptis of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Distal veins of forewing as strong as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (as in Fig. 66-6b); body black, metasoma often red; inner hind tibial spur ciliate or minutely serrate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ptilocleptis of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Inner orbits of eyes strongly converging below (Fig. 66-3c); head little wider than long; clypeus about twice as broad as long (Fig. 66-3c); carina across pronotum between dorsolateral angles continuous; surface of S2 conspicuously convex in proﬁle, its base strongly depressed, suggesting strong constriction between S1 and S2 (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Microsphecodes of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Scopa weak (Figs. 8-5a, 8-6) or absent; T5 with longitudinal median zone of ﬁne punctation and short hairs weakly developed or absent; apical labral process without keel (as in Fig. 65-1i) or keel reduced to weak carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Microsphecodes of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Distal veins of forewing as strong as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (as in Fig. 66-6b); body black, metasoma often red; inner hind tibial spur ciliate or minutely serrate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Microsphecodes of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Inner orbits of eyes usually not strongly converging; head distinctly wider than long, as seen from front (Fig. 66-3d); clypeus three or more times as wide as long, rarely only twice as broad as long (Fig. 66-3d); carina between dorsolateral pronotal angles incomplete; surface of S2 usually not strongly convex in proﬁle, apparent constriction between S1 and S2 being weak

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Microsphecodes of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Free part of marginal cell about or more than three times as long as part subtended by submarginal cells (Fig. 66-5a); T1 slightly longer than broad; T5 with apical margin bare, like that of preceding terga (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Lasioglossum (in part) of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Scopa present from hind trochanter to tibia (Fig. 8-5b), forming corbicula on underside of femur; T5 with welldeveloped longitudinal median zone of ﬁne punctation and commonly short, dense hairs, this zone dividing prepygidial ﬁmbria (Fig. 65-1j); apical labral process with strong longitudinal keel on anterior surface (Fig. 651a, b, e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Lasioglossum (in part) of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Third and often second submarginal crossvein and second recurrent vein weaker than ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (Fig. 66-6a, b) in females and some males; body not brilliantly metallic except in a few, mostly Antillean, species; metasomal terga without apical hair bands (Fig. 66-4a), basal hair bands present or absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Scopa present from hind trochanter to tibia (Fig. 8-5b), forming corbicula on underside of femur; T5 with welldeveloped longitudinal median zone of ﬁne punctation and commonly short, dense hairs, this zone dividing prepygidial ﬁmbria (Fig. 65-1j); apical labral process with strong longitudinal keel on anterior surface (Fig. 651a, b, e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Distal veins of forewing strong (Fig. 66-6b); coloration and hair bands variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): T1 to T4 with apical bands of posteriorly directed, plumose, tomental, pale hairs (Fig. 66-4b), sometimes limited to extreme sides of terga or to T5, terga sometimes also with basal bands; body not or weakly metallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Epistomal suture, at or lateral to tentorial pit, obtusely angulate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudagapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Scopa present from hind trochanter to tibia (Fig. 8-5b), forming corbicula on underside of femur; T5 with welldeveloped longitudinal median zone of ﬁne punctation and commonly short, dense hairs, this zone dividing prepygidial ﬁmbria (Fig. 65-1j); apical labral process with strong longitudinal keel on anterior surface (Fig. 651a, b, e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudagapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Distal veins of forewing strong (Fig. 66-6b); coloration and hair bands variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudagapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): T1 to T4 with apical bands of posteriorly directed, plumose, tomental, pale hairs (Fig. 66-4b), sometimes limited to extreme sides of terga or to T5, terga sometimes also with basal bands; body not or weakly metallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudagapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Epistomal suture, at or near tentorial pit, forming acute paraocular lobe protruding down into clypeus (as in Fig 67-6d) (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Agapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Scopa present from hind trochanter to tibia (Fig. 8-5b), forming corbicula on underside of femur; T5 with welldeveloped longitudinal median zone of ﬁne punctation and commonly short, dense hairs, this zone dividing prepygidial ﬁmbria (Fig. 65-1j); apical labral process with strong longitudinal keel on anterior surface (Fig. 651a, b, e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Agapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Distal veins of forewing strong (Fig. 66-6b); coloration and hair bands variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Agapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): T1 to T4 without bands (Fig. 66-7) or with basal bands of hairs (Fig. 66-4a), and without apical bands (but bands sometimes suggested by the density of laterally directed hairs, as in Mexalictus); body coloration variable, sometimes bright metallic green or blue

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Agapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Posterior surface of propodeum enclosed by strong carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ruizantheda of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Inner hind tibial spur with two or three teeth; hind tibia about as long as tarsal segments 1 to 4 taken together (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dinagapostemon (in part) of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Body not uniformly bright metallic; T2 and T3 and often T4 without lateral gradular carinae (Fig. 66-8b); epistomal suture obtusely angulate laterally (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mexalictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Inner hind tibial spur coarsely to minutely serrate; epistomal suture near tentorial pit forming paraocular lobe protruding into clypeus (as in Fig. 67-6d) and body nonmetallic or weakly metallic greenish blue (Mesoamerica to Arizona)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
