Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhinetula of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Propodeal proﬁle almost wholly steeply declivous, with only narrow sloping portion above, next to metanotum; T2 to T4 with lateral gradular carinae (Fig. 66-8a) andmetasoma nonmetallic (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habralictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Eye bare or with scattered minute hairs; metasoma nonmetallic black or brown, rarely honey-colored, commonly with yellow markings (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Caenohalictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Inner hind tibial spur usually with three teeth; subhorizontal basal zone of propodeum over 1.5 times as long as metanotum (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paragapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Body uniformly bright metallic green or blue; T2 to T4 with lateral gradular carinae (as in Fig. 66-8a); epistomal suture laterally forming prominent paraocular lobe protruding down into clypeus (Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dinagapostemon (in part) of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Body not uniformly bright metallic; T2 and T3 and often T4 without lateral gradular carinae (Fig. 66-8b); epistomal suture obtusely angulate laterally (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T1 to T4 with apical bands of posteriorly directed, plumose, tomental, pale hairs (Fig. 66-4b), these sometimes limited to extreme sides of terga; terga sometimes also with basal bands; body not or weakly metallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Epistomal suture, at or lateral to tentorial pit, obtusely angulate (North America, rarely south to central Brazil)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudagapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T1 to T4 with apical bands of posteriorly directed, plumose, tomental, pale hairs (Fig. 66-4b), these sometimes limited to extreme sides of terga; terga sometimes also with basal bands; body not or weakly metallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudagapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Epistomal suture, at or near tentorial pit, forming acute paraocular lobe protruding down into clypeus (as in Fig. 67-6d) (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paragapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T1 to T4 without bands or with basal bands of hairs (Fig. 66-4a), but without apical bands (these sometimes suggested by the density of laterally directed hairs, as in Mexalictus); body coloration variable, sometimes bright metallic green or blue

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paragapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T2 to T4 with lateral gradular carinae (Fig. 66-8a) (eye with abundant hair as long as ocellar diameter)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paragapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Paraocular lobe projecting down into clypeus prominent and narrowly rounded or acutely angulate (as in Fig. 67-6d); propodeal proﬁle with basal subhorizontal portion about as long as metanotum; body bright green or blue (Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhinetula of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T1 to T4 without bands or with basal bands of hairs (Fig. 66-4a), but without apical bands (these sometimes suggested by the density of laterally directed hairs, as in Mexalictus); body coloration variable, sometimes bright metallic green or blue

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhinetula of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T2 to T4 with lateral gradular carinae (Fig. 66-8a) (eye with abundant hair as long as ocellar diameter)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhinetula of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Paraocular lobe absent or obtuse, because epistomal suture not or obtusely angulate laterally; propodeal proﬁle almost entirely declivous; head and thorax weakly metallic and metasoma not metallic (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Agapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T1 to T4 without bands or with basal bands of hairs (Fig. 66-4a), but without apical bands (these sometimes suggested by the density of laterally directed hairs, as in Mexalictus); body coloration variable, sometimes bright metallic green or blue

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Agapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T2 to T4 without lateral gradular carinae (Fig. 66-8b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Agapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Gonostylus (not including ventral gonostylus, which is often a large retrorse lobe) usually small and simple, less than half as long as and less than half as wide as gonocoxite (Fig. 66-16a), but if more than half as long as or as wide as gonocoxite or both; distal veins of forewing as strong as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Agapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Posterior surface of propodeum enclosed by strong carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mexalictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T1 to T4 without bands or with basal bands of hairs (Fig. 66-4a), but without apical bands (these sometimes suggested by the density of laterally directed hairs, as in Mexalictus); body coloration variable, sometimes bright metallic green or blue

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mexalictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T2 to T4 without lateral gradular carinae (Fig. 66-8b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mexalictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Gonostylus (not including ventral gonostylus, which is often a large retrorse lobe) usually small and simple, less than half as long as and less than half as wide as gonocoxite (Fig. 66-16a), but if more than half as long as or as wide as gonocoxite or both; distal veins of forewing as strong as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mexalictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Posterior surface of propodeum not or only partially surrounded by strong carina, at least upper transverse part of carina absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mexalictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Epistomal suture near tentorial pit forming a paraocular lobe protruding down into clypeus (as in Fig. 67-6d); S7 with four basal apodemes (body weakly metallic or nonmetallic, eyes bare) (Mesoamerica)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habralictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T1 to T4 without bands or with basal bands of hairs (Fig. 66-4a), but without apical bands (these sometimes suggested by the density of laterally directed hairs, as in Mexalictus); body coloration variable, sometimes bright metallic green or blue

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habralictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T2 to T4 without lateral gradular carinae (Fig. 66-8b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habralictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Gonostylus (not including ventral gonostylus, which is often a large retrorse lobe) usually small and simple, less than half as long as and less than half as wide as gonocoxite (Fig. 66-16a), but if more than half as long as or as wide as gonocoxite or both; distal veins of forewing as strong as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habralictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Posterior surface of propodeum not or only partially surrounded by strong carina, at least upper transverse part of carina absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habralictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Epistomal suture near tentorial pit nearly straight to obtusely angulate (or about right-angular in some Caenohalictus, which are bright green with long hairs on eyes); S7 with two basal apodemes, one at each lateral extremity

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habralictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Metasoma very slender, almost petiolate, T1 over 1.5 times as long as wide; eyes bare or nearly so (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Microsphecodes of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Free part of marginal cell about or more than three times as long as part subtended by submarginal cells (Fig. 66-5a); T1 slightly longer than broad (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dinagapostemon of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Hind femur swollen, with angle or tooth on underside; upper sloping part of propodeal proﬁle about as long as metanotum (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ruizantheda of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Legs with yellow areas or largely yellow (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Caenohalictus of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Body usually metallic blue or green or with metallic areas, although sometimes nonmetallic; scutum and most of body entirely minutely granular and dull because of extremely ﬁne, dense punctation (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ptilocleptis of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Body nonmetallic; scutum and most of body distinctly and in some areas rather coarsely punctate (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodes of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Anterior margin of mesoscutum abruptly declivous, well differentiated from dorsal surface; head and thorax coarsely pitted, dorsum of propodeum with coarse irregular rugae; free part of marginal cell less than twice as long as part subtended by submarginal cells (Fig. 66-5b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Nesosphecodes of the Halictini of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Anterior margin of mesoscutum in proﬁle gently convex, not sharply differentiated from dorsal surface; head and thorax ﬁnely punctate, dorsum of propodeum with ﬁne radiating ridges; free part of marginal cell about twice as long as part subtended by submarginal cells. (Greater Antilles)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Parathrincostoma of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Distal crossveins of forewing as strong as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (Fig. 66-6b); gonostylus of male broader or longer than indicated below, sometimes branched or otherwise complex (Fig. 66-11)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Parathrincostoma of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Scopa absent (Fig. 8-5a); median ﬁnely punctate and ﬁnely haired area on T5 of female absent, prepygidial ﬁmbria, if present, thus not divided; S8 of male quadrate, somewhat longer than broad, with basolateral apodeme or arm [this unknown for Halictus (Paraseladonia)] [inner hind tibial spur of female ciliate or minutely serrate, or, in Halictus (Paraseladelina),coarsely serrate]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Parathrincostoma of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Face fully as long as broad, clypeus produced and protuberant; paraocular lobe extending into clypeus strong, right-angular; labrum of both sexes with apical process (margined by bristles) with longitudinal carina, that of female high and keel-like apically (Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictus (Paraseladonia) of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Distal crossveins of forewing as strong as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (Fig. 66-6b); gonostylus of male broader or longer than indicated below, sometimes branched or otherwise complex (Fig. 66-11)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictus (Paraseladonia) of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Scopa absent (Fig. 8-5a); median ﬁnely punctate and ﬁnely haired area on T5 of female absent, prepygidial ﬁmbria, if present, thus not divided; S8 of male quadrate, somewhat longer than broad, with basolateral apodeme or arm [this unknown for Halictus (Paraseladonia)] [inner hind tibial spur of female ciliate or minutely serrate, or, in Halictus (Paraseladelina),coarsely serrate]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictus (Paraseladonia) of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Face much wider than long, clypeus neither produced nor protuberant; paraocular lobe absent, i.e., lateral segment of epistomal suture nearly straight; labrum of both sexes with apical part truncate or broadly rounded, without longitudinal carina or keel (Fig. 65-1i), or [in Halictus (Paraseladonia)] with keel scarcely evident

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictus (Paraseladonia) of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Inner hind tibial spur of female serrate with about eight teeth; metasomal terga with sparse, pale, apical hair bands, at least in male (body metallic blue-green; basal area of propodeum minutely reticulate) (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eupetersia of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Distal crossveins of forewing as strong as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (Fig. 66-6b); gonostylus of male broader or longer than indicated below, sometimes branched or otherwise complex (Fig. 66-11)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eupetersia of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Scopa absent (Fig. 8-5a); median ﬁnely punctate and ﬁnely haired area on T5 of female absent, prepygidial ﬁmbria, if present, thus not divided; S8 of male quadrate, somewhat longer than broad, with basolateral apodeme or arm [this unknown for Halictus (Paraseladonia)] [inner hind tibial spur of female ciliate or minutely serrate, or, in Halictus (Paraseladelina),coarsely serrate]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eupetersia of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Face much wider than long, clypeus neither produced nor protuberant; paraocular lobe absent, i.e., lateral segment of epistomal suture nearly straight; labrum of both sexes with apical part truncate or broadly rounded, without longitudinal carina or keel (Fig. 65-1i), or [in Halictus (Paraseladonia)] with keel scarcely evident

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eupetersia of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Inner hind tibial spur of female ciliate or minutely serrate, like other spurs of hind and middle legs; metasomal terga without apical hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eupetersia of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: First two ﬂagellar segments of male both distinctly broader than long; gonocoxite of male not striate, with dorsolateral depression margined by and usually traversed by ﬂanges or ridges; body with moderate to ﬁne punctation, rarely involving coarse pitting as is usual in Sphecodes;mandible of female simple (Africa, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodes of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Distal crossveins of forewing as strong as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (Fig. 66-6b); gonostylus of male broader or longer than indicated below, sometimes branched or otherwise complex (Fig. 66-11)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodes of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Scopa absent (Fig. 8-5a); median ﬁnely punctate and ﬁnely haired area on T5 of female absent, prepygidial ﬁmbria, if present, thus not divided; S8 of male quadrate, somewhat longer than broad, with basolateral apodeme or arm [this unknown for Halictus (Paraseladonia)] [inner hind tibial spur of female ciliate or minutely serrate, or, in Halictus (Paraseladelina),coarsely serrate]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodes of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Face much wider than long, clypeus neither produced nor protuberant; paraocular lobe absent, i.e., lateral segment of epistomal suture nearly straight; labrum of both sexes with apical part truncate or broadly rounded, without longitudinal carina or keel (Fig. 65-1i), or [in Halictus (Paraseladonia)] with keel scarcely evident

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodes of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Inner hind tibial spur of female ciliate or minutely serrate, like other spurs of hind and middle legs; metasomal terga without apical hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodes of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Second ﬂagellar segment of male usually longer than broad, unlike ﬁrst; gonocoxite of male usually striate, without depression; body and especially propodeum usually coarsely pitted; mandible of female nearly always with preapical tooth (except in neotropical Austrosphecodes group)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Distal crossveins of forewing as strong as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (Fig. 66-6b); gonostylus of male broader or longer than indicated below, sometimes branched or otherwise complex (Fig. 66-11)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Scopa present (Fig. 8-5b); T5 of female with longitudinal median ﬁnely punctate and haired or sometimes smooth area dividing prepygidial ﬁmbria (Fig. 65-1j); S8 of male variable but not as above, disc usually much broader than long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Female with margin of clypeal truncation, distal to preapical ﬁmbria, extended downward at each side of labrum as a small, rather sharp, impunctate projection (except in some minute Asiatic species of the subgenus Vestitohalictusthat lack such projections); S4 of male unmodiﬁed or at least without coarse apical setae; ventral gonostylus of male absent or directed apically, not retrorse (holarctic, Africa, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thrinchostoma of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Distal crossveins of forewing as strong as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (Fig. 66-6b); gonostylus of male broader or longer than indicated below, sometimes branched or otherwise complex (Fig. 66-11)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thrinchostoma of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Scopa present (Fig. 8-5b); T5 of female with longitudinal median ﬁnely punctate and haired or sometimes smooth area dividing prepygidial ﬁmbria (Fig. 65-1j); S8 of male variable but not as above, disc usually much broader than long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thrinchostoma of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Female with margin of clypeal truncation, distal to preapical ﬁmbria, extending but little downward at each side of labrum, forming only a low, rounded projection (except in some species of Thrinchostoma in which there is a strong projection); S4 of male usually shortened, commonly hidden by S3, frequently with several coarse apical or subapical setae; ventral gonostylus of male usually present, directed ventrally or basally, forming a retrorse lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thrinchostoma of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Apical marginal zones of terga with simple, laterally directed hairs usually forming apical bands that are conspicuous only in certain lights; proﬁle of anterior part of scutum gently convex, rising but little above level of pronotum; pronotum with carina or lamella separating dorsal from declivous anterior surface (recurrent veins both entering third submarginal cell, or ﬁrst recurrent entering extreme apex of second cell) (Africa, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thrincohalictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Distal crossveins of forewing as strong as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (Fig. 66-6b); gonostylus of male broader or longer than indicated below, sometimes branched or otherwise complex (Fig. 66-11)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thrincohalictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Scopa present (Fig. 8-5b); T5 of female with longitudinal median ﬁnely punctate and haired or sometimes smooth area dividing prepygidial ﬁmbria (Fig. 65-1j); S8 of male variable but not as above, disc usually much broader than long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thrincohalictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Female with margin of clypeal truncation, distal to preapical ﬁmbria, extending but little downward at each side of labrum, forming only a low, rounded projection (except in some species of Thrinchostoma in which there is a strong projection); S4 of male usually shortened, commonly hidden by S3, frequently with several coarse apical or subapical setae; ventral gonostylus of male usually present, directed ventrally or basally, forming a retrorse lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thrincohalictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Apical marginal zones of terga variable, but without simple, laterally directed hairs; proﬁle of anterior part of scutum strongly convex, subvertical surface thus rising well above level of pronotum and then curving strongly or angularly onto dorsum of scutum; pronotum medially without carina separating dorsal from anterior surface

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thrincohalictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Malar area about as long (female) to twice as long (male) as diameter of ﬂagellum; pygidial plate of male not deﬁned (dorsal gonostylus of male not bifurcate) (Asia Minor)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Glossodialictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Distal crossveins of forewing as strong as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (Fig. 66-6b); gonostylus of male broader or longer than indicated below, sometimes branched or otherwise complex (Fig. 66-11)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Glossodialictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Scopa present (Fig. 8-5b); T5 of female with longitudinal median ﬁnely punctate and haired or sometimes smooth area dividing prepygidial ﬁmbria (Fig. 65-1j); S8 of male variable but not as above, disc usually much broader than long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Glossodialictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Female with margin of clypeal truncation, distal to preapical ﬁmbria, extending but little downward at each side of labrum, forming only a low, rounded projection (except in some species of Thrinchostoma in which there is a strong projection); S4 of male usually shortened, commonly hidden by S3, frequently with several coarse apical or subapical setae; ventral gonostylus of male usually present, directed ventrally or basally, forming a retrorse lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Glossodialictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Apical marginal zones of terga variable, but without simple, laterally directed hairs; proﬁle of anterior part of scutum strongly convex, subvertical surface thus rising well above level of pronotum and then curving strongly or angularly onto dorsum of scutum; pronotum medially without carina separating dorsal from anterior surface

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Glossodialictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Malar area usually linear, rarely about half as long as diameter of ﬂagellum; pygidial plate of male deﬁned at least posteriorly and posterolaterally by a carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Glossodialictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Glossa extremely long and slender, about twice as long as head; dorsal gonostylus of male broad, simple (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Patellapis of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Distal crossveins of forewing as strong as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (Fig. 66-6b); gonostylus of male broader or longer than indicated below, sometimes branched or otherwise complex (Fig. 66-11)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Patellapis of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Scopa present (Fig. 8-5b); T5 of female with longitudinal median ﬁnely punctate and haired or sometimes smooth area dividing prepygidial ﬁmbria (Fig. 65-1j); S8 of male variable but not as above, disc usually much broader than long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Patellapis of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Female with margin of clypeal truncation, distal to preapical ﬁmbria, extending but little downward at each side of labrum, forming only a low, rounded projection (except in some species of Thrinchostoma in which there is a strong projection); S4 of male usually shortened, commonly hidden by S3, frequently with several coarse apical or subapical setae; ventral gonostylus of male usually present, directed ventrally or basally, forming a retrorse lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Patellapis of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Apical marginal zones of terga variable, but without simple, laterally directed hairs; proﬁle of anterior part of scutum strongly convex, subvertical surface thus rising well above level of pronotum and then curving strongly or angularly onto dorsum of scutum; pronotum medially without carina separating dorsal from anterior surface

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Patellapis of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Malar area usually linear, rarely about half as long as diameter of ﬂagellum; pygidial plate of male deﬁned at least posteriorly and posterolaterally by a carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Patellapis of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Glossa shorter than head or rarely about as long as head [somewhat longer in Patellapis (Zonalictus) concinnula (Cockerell)]; dorsal gonostylus of male deeply biﬁd, one branch sometimes slender and inconspicuous [or, in P. (Madagalictus) suarezensis (Benoist), small and simple] (Africa, oriental, Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Urohalictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: S7 and S8 of male, taken together, longer than broad, as long as genital capsule, heavily sclerotized, with large lobes curved up into and around genitalia (Fig. 66-22bd); pronotum and metanotum with middorsal yellow areas (female unknown) (New Guinea)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Echthralictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Femoral scopa reduced to few simple hairs less than two-thirds as long as diameter of femur; dorsolateral angle of pronotum produced to spine; mandible of female simple, acute; inner hind tibial spur of male coarsely pectinate (Samoa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Homalictus of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Metasomal terga of female, especially T1 to T3, usually sharply folded laterally, forming angle at margin between dorsal and ventrolateral parts of terga; scopal hairs plumelike with numerous lateral branches, those on sterna and ventrolateral parts of terga large, those of hind femur arising ventrally and especially at ends of femur forming femoral corbicula; gonobase of male genitalia, as seen from above, usually continuing contours of gonocoxites (Australia, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Lasioglossum of Halictini of the Eastern Hemi-sphere: Metasomal terga rounded from dorsal to ventrolateral parts; scopal hairs with relatively few, longer branches, less developed on metasomal venter, those of hind femur arising subdorsally and curling around femur to form femoral corbicula; gonobase of male genitalia, as seen from above, relatively broad, usually not at all continuing contours of gonocoxites

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Agapostemonoides) of Agapostemon: Eyes with hairs about as long as ocellar radius (Fig. 6610a, b); epistomal suture very obtusely angulate laterally (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Agapostemon s. str.) of Agapostemon: Eyes bare or nearly so; epistomal suture, near tentorial pit, forming paraocular lobe protruding down into clypeus, basal margins of this lobe at right or acute angle to each other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Eupetersia s. str.) of Eupetersia: Scutum rather densely punctate; scutellum bigibbous, the two convexities not or scarcely punctate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Nesoeupetersia) of Eupetersia: Scutum with widely separated punctures; scutellum gently convex, with punctation similar to that of scutum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Habralictus s. str.) of Habralictus (Males)(T wo subgenera are tentatively recognized. One of them,Zikaniella, is known only in the male; subgeneric charac-ters for females are unknown.): Head not or scarcely wider than thorax; genal area much narrower than eye, as seen from side; clypeal surface not concave or with small median concavity; inner hind tibial spur simple, ciliate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Zikaniella) of Habralictus (Males)(T wo subgenera are tentatively recognized. One of them,Zikaniella, is known only in the male; subgeneric charac-ters for females are unknown.): Head much broader than thorax; genal area wider than eye, strongly angulate posteriorly; middle half of clypeal surface broadly concave; inner hind tibial spur pectinate with four teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Halictus s. str.) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Body length over 16 mm; scutum of female sparsely punctate; antennal ﬂagellum of male ﬂattened with long fringe on lower side, last segment ﬂattened, curved; hind basitarsus of male curved (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Nealictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Body length less than 14 mm; scutum of female densely punctate; antennal ﬂagellum of male not ﬂattened, not fringed except rarely with short hairs, last segment unmodiﬁed; hind basitarsus of male nearly always straight.

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Nealictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Upper gonostylus of male broad with clump of very coarse bristles on inner surface; lower gonostylus a slender process, much reduced in H. (Protohalictus) rubicundus (Christ) and hedini Blüthgen

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Nealictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Propedeal triangle densely and ﬁnely granulate; hind tibia of female black; male antenna reaching scutellum; S4 of male of normal length, posterior margin nearly straight (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Lampralicutus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Body length less than 14 mm; scutum of female densely punctate; antennal ﬂagellum of male not ﬂattened, not fringed except rarely with short hairs, last segment unmodiﬁed; hind basitarsus of male nearly always straight.

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Lampralicutus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Upper gonostylus of male broad with clump of very coarse bristles on inner surface; lower gonostylus a slender process, much reduced in H. (Protohalictus) rubicundus (Christ) and hedini Blüthgen

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Lampralicutus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Propedeal triangle rugose or rugulose; hind tibia of female usually red or reddish yellow, rarely black; male antenna reaching propodeum; S4 of male short, broadly emarginate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Lampralicutus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Sides and posterior surface of propedeum nearly smooth, polished; antennal ﬂagellum of male with dense, short pubescence in proximal and distal bands on each segment; head of female as long as wide in frontal view, gena with large tooth (Central Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Protohalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Body length less than 14 mm; scutum of female densely punctate; antennal ﬂagellum of male not ﬂattened, not fringed except rarely with short hairs, last segment unmodiﬁed; hind basitarsus of male nearly always straight.

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Protohalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Upper gonostylus of male broad with clump of very coarse bristles on inner surface; lower gonostylus a slender process, much reduced in H. (Protohalictus) rubicundus (Christ) and hedini Blüthgen

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Protohalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Propedeal triangle rugose or rugulose; hind tibia of female usually red or reddish yellow, rarely black; male antenna reaching propodeum; S4 of male short, broadly emarginate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Protohalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Sides and posterior surface of propodeum granulate or rugose, dull; antennal ﬂagellum with pubescence inconspicuous; head of female shorter than wide in frontal view, genal area without tooth (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Monilapis) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Body length less than 14 mm; scutum of female densely punctate; antennal ﬂagellum of male not ﬂattened, not fringed except rarely with short hairs, last segment unmodiﬁed; hind basitarsus of male nearly always straight.

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Monilapis) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Upper gonostylus of male elongate, proximal half narrowed, without clump of coarse bristles on inner surface; lower gonostylus absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Monilapis) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Hypostomal and lower genal areas of male, at least in ventral view, slightly concave to deeply excavated; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment of male broader than long, following segments often convex ventrally and thus moniliform and each with glabrous, shiny area or band mesally; S4 of male with posterior margin broadly and deeply emarginate with extreme lateral angle distinct

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Monilapis) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Propedeal triangle with distinct wrinkles, shiny; malar areas of male more than one third as long as broad; hypostomal and genal areas deeply and sharply excavated (palearctic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Platyhalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Body length less than 14 mm; scutum of female densely punctate; antennal ﬂagellum of male not ﬂattened, not fringed except rarely with short hairs, last segment unmodiﬁed; hind basitarsus of male nearly always straight.

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Platyhalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Upper gonostylus of male elongate, proximal half narrowed, without clump of coarse bristles on inner surface; lower gonostylus absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Platyhalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Hypostomal and lower genal areas of male, at least in ventral view, slightly concave to deeply excavated; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment of male broader than long, following segments often convex ventrally and thus moniliform and each with glabrous, shiny area or band mesally; S4 of male with posterior margin broadly and deeply emarginate with extreme lateral angle distinct

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Platyhalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Propedeal triangle obscurely rugulose, silk-shiny; malar area of male less than one ﬁfth as long as broad; hypostomal and genal areas of male only slightly concave (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Odontalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Body length less than 14 mm; scutum of female densely punctate; antennal ﬂagellum of male not ﬂattened, not fringed except rarely with short hairs, last segment unmodiﬁed; hind basitarsus of male nearly always straight.

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Odontalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Upper gonostylus of male elongate, proximal half narrowed, without clump of coarse bristles on inner surface; lower gonostylus absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Odontalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Hypostomal and genal areas of male convex or ﬂat in lateral view; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment of male as long as or longer than broad, following segments usually not convex, without glabrous areas; S4 of male with posterior margin straight or shallowly incised medially, without strong angle at side

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Odontalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Male antenna at most reaching scutellum; S7 of male transverse without posterior median process; lower genal area of female with large tooth; inner hind tibial spur of female with one large basal tooth (North America to northern South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hexataenites) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Propodeum with carina bordering its posterior surface; last antennal segment of male usually hook-shaped; S4 of male trapezoidal, narrowed, and emarginate posteriorly (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Tytthalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Propodeum and metasomal terga distinctly punctate; metasomal hair bands broadly interrupted medially, consisting of ﬁne hairs; S8 of male with median, apical prominence (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Argalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Propodeum and metasomal terga obscurely punctate; metasomal hair bands unbroken, consisting of coarser hairs; S8 of male without median, apical prominence

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Paraseladonia) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Scopa almost absent; mandible of female simple; T5 without median specialized areas of minute hairs characteristic of most female Halictini [Cleptoparsitic, male unknown] (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Vestitohalictus) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Basitibial plate of female slender, pointed, its anterior margin incompletely deﬁned; hairless propodeal triangle small, often not as long as metanotum, area lateral to triangle, and metasomal terga, largely covered with pale tomenum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Seladonia) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Male antenna usually reaching only to scutellum, second ﬂagellar segment 1.2 to 1.4 times as long as wide; S6 of male ﬂat or with slight longitudinal median depression

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Pachyceble) of Halictus(From Pesenko, 2004b): Male antenna usually reaching metasoma, second ﬂagellar segment 1.7 to 2.0 times as long as wide; S6 of male with deep triangular depression behind gradulus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Homalictus s. str.) of Homalictus (Females)(For males, see comments on the subgenera): Hairs of lower distal part of outer surface of hind tibia short, uniform, erect, branched; undersurface of tibia concave

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Papualictus) of Homalictus (Females)(For males, see comments on the subgenera): Hairs of lower distal part of outer surface of hind tibia not differentiated from those on rest of surface, and the hairs not erect; undersurface of tibia not or scarcely concave

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Papualictus) of Homalictus (Females)(For males, see comments on the subgenera): T2 to T4 without bands of tomentum; hair on outer surface of hind tibia simple, sparse, almost bristle-like (New Guinea)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Quasilictus) of Homalictus (Females)(For males, see comments on the subgenera): Hairs of lower distal part of outer surface of hind tibia not differentiated from those on rest of surface, and the hairs not erect; undersurface of tibia not or scarcely concave

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Quasilictus) of Homalictus (Females)(For males, see comments on the subgenera): T2 to T4 with bands of tomentum, broken medially; hair on outer surface of hind tibia short, minutely plumose, appressed (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lasioglossum s. str.) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein as strong as ﬁrst (Figs. 661a, 66-6a) [usually rather large and robust, body length 6.8-12.0 mm, usually nonmetallic, although Lasioglossum pavonotum (Cockerell) of the Paciﬁc Coast of USA is strongly green] (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Posterior surface of propodeum margined at side by vertical carina that extends upward to summit and then mesad at least partway across upper margin, so that there is a sometimes interrupted carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces; body nearly always nonmetallic (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sphecodogastra) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sphecodogastra) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sphecodogastra) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Scopa sparse, consisting of a row of simple bristles on hind trochanter and lower edge of femur, shorter bristles on upper part of femur, and some long, nearly simple hairs on inner side of tibia (nonmetallic) (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Hemihalictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Hemihalictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Hemihalictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Scopa normal, largely plumose (as in Fig. 8-5b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Hemihalictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Nonmetallic and with two submarginal cells; inner hind tibial spur of female serrate (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Eickwortia) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Eickwortia) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Eickwortia) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Scopa normal, largely plumose (as in Fig. 8-5b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Eickwortia) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Nonmetallic or metallic, with three submarginal cells or, in a few metallic species, with two; inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with a few large teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Eickwortia) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Mandible of female strongly bidentate at apex; middorsal length of male gonobase less than one-fourth as long as gonocoxite (Mesoamerica)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Dialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Dialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Dialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Scopa normal, largely plumose (as in Fig. 8-5b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Dialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Nonmetallic or metallic, with three submarginal cells or, in a few metallic species, with two; inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with a few large teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Dialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Mandible of female with small, dorsal preapical tooth; middorsal length of male gonobase usually over onethird as long as gonocoxite

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lasioglossum s. str.) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Lasioglossum s. str.) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Inner hind tibial spur of female serrate or rarely pectinate with ﬁve or more teeth (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Mandible of female with one preapical tooth; body smaller; S6 of male not as described above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Basitibial plate of female distinct; scopa of female well developed, forming corbicula on underside of femur, evident but less well developed in parasitic species of Dialictus (Fig. 8-6a); propodeum with carina or rounded angle separating lateral from posterior surfaces

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: T2 of male without basal band of white hairs, or,i f present, then hairs more or less prostrate as on other terga; disc of labrum of female with elevated area or tubercles, not uniformly convex; inner hind tibial spur of female usually pectinate with less than ﬁve long teeth, but sometimes serrate or brieﬂy pectinate with more teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Subpleural signum of female inconspicuous or absent, not elevated as tubercle; inner hind tibial spur of male usually ciliate or minutely dentate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Posterior surface of propodeum margined at side by vertical carina that extends upward to summit and then mesad at least partway across upper margin, so that there is a sometimes interrupted, transverse carina between basal area and posterior surface, i.e., across posterior margin of basal area; rarely transverse carina present but vertical carina reduced or absent; usually rather large, nonmetallic except for some Asian species (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sphecodogastra) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ctenonomia) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ctenonomia) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with few large teeth, or with one large tooth followed by undulate margin (Africa, Oriental, Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Acanthalictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Acanthalictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Mandible of female with two preapical teeth on upper margin; body length 11 to 13 mm; S6 of male ending in thick, shining, uniformly curved and elevated margin (inner hind tibial spur of female serrate) (Siberia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Paradialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Paradialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Basitibial plate of female absent (Fig. 66-17d); scopa of female represented by only a few hairs; propodeum with vertical lunate ﬂange separating lateral from posterior surfaces (male unknown) (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sellalictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sellalictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: T2 of male with broad, basal band of erect white hairs; disc of labrum of female rather uniformly convex; inner hind tibial spur of female serrate or,i fpectinate, then with ﬁve or more teeth, all longer than broad (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Sudila) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Subpleural signum of female usually elevated as distinct tubercle in front of middle coxa; inner hind tibial spur of male brieﬂy pectinate (Oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Mandible of female with one preapical tooth; body smaller; S6 of male not as described above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Basitibial plate of female distinct; scopa of female well developed, forming corbicula on underside of femur, evident but less well developed in parasitic species of Dialictus (Fig. 8-6a); propodeum with carina or rounded angle separating lateral from posterior surfaces

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: T2 of male without basal band of white hairs, or,i f present, then hairs more or less prostrate as on other terga; disc of labrum of female with elevated area or tubercles, not uniformly convex; inner hind tibial spur of female usually pectinate with less than ﬁve long teeth, but sometimes serrate or brieﬂy pectinate with more teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Subpleural signum of female inconspicuous or absent, not elevated as tubercle; inner hind tibial spur of male usually ciliate or minutely dentate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Evylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Posterior surface of propodeum margined at side by vertical carina that extends upward to summit and then mesad at least partway across upper margin, so that there is a sometimes interrupted, transverse carina between basal area and posterior surface, i.e., across posterior margin of basal area; rarely transverse carina present but vertical carina reduced or absent; usually rather large, nonmetallic except for some Asian species (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Dialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Second submarginal crossvein, at least in female, weaker than ﬁrst, although not always as weak as third or as second recurrent vein (Fig. 66-6c) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Dialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Posterior surface of propodeum in nonmetallic species usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or, if attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between dorsal and posterior surfaces, but in metallic species, with or without propodeal carinae, sometimes even more strongly carinate than in L. (Evylaeus); body black or metallic greenish or bluish, rarely bright metallic green

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Dialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Mandible of female with one preapical tooth; body smaller; S6 of male not as described above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Dialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Basitibial plate of female distinct; scopa of female well developed, forming corbicula on underside of femur, evident but less well developed in parasitic species of Dialictus (Fig. 8-6a); propodeum with carina or rounded angle separating lateral from posterior surfaces

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Dialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: T2 of male without basal band of white hairs, or,i f present, then hairs more or less prostrate as on other terga; disc of labrum of female with elevated area or tubercles, not uniformly convex; inner hind tibial spur of female usually pectinate with less than ﬁve long teeth, but sometimes serrate or brieﬂy pectinate with more teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Dialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Subpleural signum of female inconspicuous or absent, not elevated as tubercle; inner hind tibial spur of male usually ciliate or minutely dentate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Dialictus) of Lasioglossum of the WesternHemisphere: Posterior surface of propodeum usually with lateral vertical carina extending only partway to summit, or,i f attaining summit, then usually not extending mesad across upper margin, so that there is usually no carina between basal area and posterior surface, i.e., so that basal area is usually not enclosed; body commonly smaller, sometimes metallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Austrevylaeus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Second submarginal crossvein in both sexes narrower than ﬁrst (as in Fig. 66-6c); small (less than 7 mm long); inner hind tibial spur of female ciliate, essentially simple, or in some cases bearing a few large oblique teeth (body dull, nonmetallic) (Hemihalictus series)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Pseudochilalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Second submarginal crossvein as strong as ﬁrst (as in Fig. 66-6a); if body less than 7 mm long, then inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with one to several large teeth, teeth usually not so sloping or oblique as in the above (Lasioglossumseries)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Pseudochilalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Females

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Pseudochilalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Apical labral process triangular (Fig. 66-13a, b), widest at base, tapering to pointed apex, apex usually simple except for being keeled (two keels in a few Parasphecodes, process broadened preapically in a few Ctenonomia) (basitibial plates usually rather elongate and pointed apically)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Pseudochilalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Inner hind tibial spur ﬁnely serrate, ciliate, or essentially simple (Fig. 66-13a, b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Pseudochilalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Metasomal terga black with broad basal bands of tomentum; teeth of inner margin of inner hind tibial spur about half as long as diameter of spur

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Parasphecodes) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Propodeal triangle roughened, basal area usually deﬁned; thorax black

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Callalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Propodeal triangle smooth, basal area not margined; thorax partly or wholly red or testaceous

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ctenonomia) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Second submarginal crossvein as strong as ﬁrst (as in Fig. 66-6a); if body less than 7 mm long, then inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with one to several large teeth, teeth usually not so sloping or oblique as in the above (Lasioglossumseries)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ctenonomia) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Females

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ctenonomia) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Apical labral process triangular (Fig. 66-13a, b), widest at base, tapering to pointed apex, apex usually simple except for being keeled (two keels in a few Parasphecodes, process broadened preapically in a few Ctenonomia) (basitibial plates usually rather elongate and pointed apically)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ctenonomia) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Inner hind tibial spur pectinate with a few coarse teeth (coarsely serrate in a few species)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ctenonomia) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Propodeum with triangle variously roughened, basal area often margined by a carina; thorax black; metasomal terga usually with tomentum basally or basolaterally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Glossalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Glossa about two-thirds as long as face, which is broader than long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Chilalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Second submarginal crossvein as strong as ﬁrst (as in Fig. 66-6a); if body less than 7 mm long, then inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with one to several large teeth, teeth usually not so sloping or oblique as in the above (Lasioglossumseries)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Chilalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Females

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Chilalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Apical labral process broadened so that it does not taper uniformly to a pointed apex (Fig. 66-13c-f ), lateral margins often pectinate, toothed, elevated, or otherwise modiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Chilalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Inner hind tibial spur of female not pectinate; glossa little more than one-half as long as face; margin of labral process of female variously modiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Chilalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Inner hind tibial spur with a large tooth followed by a wavy margin (Figs. 66-13d, e), tooth in some cases reduced so that margin is almost simple, rarely a second tooth developed sufﬁciently that spur is almost pectinate; eyes usually bare, but in some cases with rather long hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Australictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Gonostylus almost absent or at most short and triangular

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Glossalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Glossa about two-thirds as long as face, which is broader than long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Ctenonomia) (in part) —. Gonostylus more than half as long as gonocoxite (except in L. idoneum Cockerell), in some cases as long as gono- coxite ........................................................L. (Chilalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Glossa longer than face, which is longer than broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Australictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Gonostylus almost absent or at most short and triangular

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Callalictus) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Propodeal triangle smooth, basal area not margined; thorax partly or wholly red or testaceous

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera L. (Parasphecodes) of Lasioglossum of the Australian Region: Propodeal triangle roughened, basal area usually deﬁned; thorax black

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Lomatalictus) of Patellapis: Posterior tibia of female with fringe of long, pectinate to palmate hairs along basal two-thirds of lower margin, these hairs not curved strongly posteriorly toward apex of tibia or upward across outer surface of tibia, but if pectinate, then branches close together (thus approaching palmate) and tending to be at right angles to rachis; intermediates between large hairs of lower tibial margin and hairs of outer tibial surface very few; metasomal terga frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum, without strong apical hair bands (except in Lomatalictus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Lomatalictus) of Patellapis: Metasomal terga with apical hair bands, without basal bands or lateral areas of tomentum; claws of female simple or with inner tooth very small, those of male with teeth close together (S4 of male unmodiﬁed) (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Zonalictus) of Patellapis: Posterior tibia of female with fringe of long, pectinate to palmate hairs along basal two-thirds of lower margin, these hairs not curved strongly posteriorly toward apex of tibia or upward across outer surface of tibia, but if pectinate, then branches close together (thus approaching palmate) and tending to be at right angles to rachis; intermediates between large hairs of lower tibial margin and hairs of outer tibial surface very few; metasomal terga frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum, without strong apical hair bands (except in Lomatalictus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Zonalictus) of Patellapis: Metasomal terga without strong apical hair bands, frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum; claws of both sexes toothed, as usual in halictines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Zonalictus) of Patellapis: Posterior margins of terga, especially T1 to T3, bare, nearly always contrastingly white, yellow, greenish, or bluish (Africa, Arabia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Archihalictus) of Patellapis: Posterior tibia of female with fringe of long, pectinate to palmate hairs along basal two-thirds of lower margin, these hairs not curved strongly posteriorly toward apex of tibia or upward across outer surface of tibia, but if pectinate, then branches close together (thus approaching palmate) and tending to be at right angles to rachis; intermediates between large hairs of lower tibial margin and hairs of outer tibial surface very few; metasomal terga frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum, without strong apical hair bands (except in Lomatalictus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Archihalictus) of Patellapis: Metasomal terga without strong apical hair bands, frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum; claws of both sexes toothed, as usual in halictines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Archihalictus) of Patellapis: Posterior margins of terga brownish or translucent, commonly with weak or very weak apical hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Archihalictus) of Patellapis: Scutum and scutellum smooth or minutely roughened to coarsely striate, with punctures well separated at least in some areas; metasomal terga without areas of pale tomentum (ignoring pale hairs arising from graduli); S4 of male similar in size and shape to S3 and S5, without very large bristles (Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pachyhalictus) of Patellapis: Posterior tibia of female with fringe of long, pectinate to palmate hairs along basal two-thirds of lower margin, these hairs not curved strongly posteriorly toward apex of tibia or upward across outer surface of tibia, but if pectinate, then branches close together (thus approaching palmate) and tending to be at right angles to rachis; intermediates between large hairs of lower tibial margin and hairs of outer tibial surface very few; metasomal terga frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum, without strong apical hair bands (except in Lomatalictus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pachyhalictus) of Patellapis: Metasomal terga without strong apical hair bands, frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum; claws of both sexes toothed, as usual in halictines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
