Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pachyhalictus) of Patellapis: Posterior margins of terga brownish or translucent, commonly with weak or very weak apical hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pachyhalictus) of Patellapis: Scutum and scutellum coarsely and closely punctate or punctures usually so large that surface is coarsely reticulate, rarely, as in Pachyhalictus (Pachyhalictus) binghami (Kirby), with partly smooth areas; metasomal terga (at least T2 and T3) with basal areas of pale tomentum, sometimes expanded to cover whole terga; S4 of male short, largely hidden, with a few large apical or preapical bristles

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pachyhalictus) of Patellapis: Inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with three to six long teeth; basitibial plate of male absent or indicated only at apex; S4 of male not produced posteriorly at side but with an enormous and complex lateral bristle, usually hidden by T4 (Fig. 66-20c); ﬁrst two hind tarsal segments of male fused (Oriental to Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Dictyohalictus) of Patellapis: Posterior tibia of female with fringe of long, pectinate to palmate hairs along basal two-thirds of lower margin, these hairs not curved strongly posteriorly toward apex of tibia or upward across outer surface of tibia, but if pectinate, then branches close together (thus approaching palmate) and tending to be at right angles to rachis; intermediates between large hairs of lower tibial margin and hairs of outer tibial surface very few; metasomal terga frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum, without strong apical hair bands (except in Lomatalictus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Dictyohalictus) of Patellapis: Metasomal terga without strong apical hair bands, frequently with basal areas of pale tomentum; claws of both sexes toothed, as usual in halictines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Dictyohalictus) of Patellapis: Posterior margins of terga brownish or translucent, commonly with weak or very weak apical hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Dictyohalictus) of Patellapis: Scutum and scutellum coarsely and closely punctate or punctures usually so large that surface is coarsely reticulate, rarely, as in Pachyhalictus (Pachyhalictus) binghami (Kirby), with partly smooth areas; metasomal terga (at least T2 and T3) with basal areas of pale tomentum, sometimes expanded to cover whole terga; S4 of male short, largely hidden, with a few large apical or preapical bristles

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Dictyohalictus) of Patellapis: Inner hind tibial spur of female serrate or pectinate with ten or more teeth; basitibial plate of male present; S4 of male produced posteriorly at side with several large bristles usually hidden by T4; ﬁrst two hind tarsal segments of male apparently articulated, but articulation broader than that between subsequent tarsomeres (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Patellapis s. str.) of Patellapis: Posterior tibia of female with long hairs of lower margin strongly curved posteriorly toward apex of tibia, or distal parts usually curved upward across outer surface of tibia, with well-separated long branches directed in same general direction as rachis, or usually branched in such a way that the rachis is not identiﬁable except basally; distal parts of long marginal hairs overlapping hairs of outer tibial surface, and intermediate hair types seemingly present, thus there is no striking superﬁcial contrast between long hairs of lower margin and hairs of outer surface (this is as in Lasioglossumand Halictus); metasomal terga without basal bands or lateral areas of tomentum, frequently with apical bands of pale hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Patellapis s. str.) of Patellapis: T erga with conspicuous apical hair bands; basitibial plate margined both in front and behind, its apex in female usually rounded (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Chaetalictus) of Patellapis: Posterior tibia of female with long hairs of lower margin strongly curved posteriorly toward apex of tibia, or distal parts usually curved upward across outer surface of tibia, with well-separated long branches directed in same general direction as rachis, or usually branched in such a way that the rachis is not identiﬁable except basally; distal parts of long marginal hairs overlapping hairs of outer tibial surface, and intermediate hair types seemingly present, thus there is no striking superﬁcial contrast between long hairs of lower margin and hairs of outer surface (this is as in Lasioglossumand Halictus); metasomal terga without basal bands or lateral areas of tomentum, frequently with apical bands of pale hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Chaetalictus) of Patellapis: T erga without or with weak apical hair bands; basitibial plate not or incompletely deﬁned on anterior margin, its apex in female angulate or pointed (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Brasilagapostemon) of Pseudagapostemon: Eyes conspicuously hairy; malar area of male about onethird as long as second ﬂagellar segment (Brazil)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Neagapostemon) of Pseudagapostemon: Eyes nearly bare; malar area of male usually one-ﬁfth as long as second ﬂagellar segment or less

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Neagapostemon) of Pseudagapostemon: Clypeus usually with longitudinal median elevation or carina, and, in males, ﬁne striae lacking or not converging on midline

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pseudagapostemon s. str.) of Pseudagapostemon: Eyes nearly bare; malar area of male usually one-ﬁfth as long as second ﬂagellar segment or less

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pseudagapostemon s. str.) of Pseudagapostemon: Clypeus without longitudinal median ridge or carina except sometimes at uppermost end of clypeus, and, in males, with ﬁne oblique striae converging downward to midline of clypeus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Eothrincostoma) of Thrinchostoma(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1978a): Forewing without an area of dense hairs along second submarginal crossvein, this vein simple and straight; ﬁrst submarginal crossvein arising far from base of vein r and margin of stigma; S4 of male with a series of enormous simple bristles arising from margin both medially under S3 and laterally, under the lateral extremity of T4, where the setae are largest (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Diagonozus) of Thrinchostoma(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1978a): Forewing with an area of dense hairs near median part of second submarginal crossvein, these hairs forming, in males, a conspicuous dark spot, this crossvein usually angulate or thickened medially, sometimes incomplete (not reaching marginal cell); ﬁrst submarginal crossvein arising very near margin of stigma; S4 of male without coarse, specialized setae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Diagonozus) of Thrinchostoma(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1978a): Head extraordinarily produced below eyes, malar area nearly as long as or longer than eye, several times as long as wide (Fig 66-22b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Thrinchostoma s. str.) of Thrinchostoma(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1978a): Forewing with an area of dense hairs near median part of second submarginal crossvein, these hairs forming, in males, a conspicuous dark spot, this crossvein usually angulate or thickened medially, sometimes incomplete (not reaching marginal cell); ﬁrst submarginal crossvein arising very near margin of stigma; S4 of male without coarse, specialized setae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Thrinchostoma s. str.) of Thrinchostoma(Modiﬁed from Michener, 1978a): Head only moderately produced below eyes, malar area much shorter than eye, three times as long as wide or less

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ariphanarthra of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ariphanarthra of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Maxillary palpus much longer than stipes plus galea, reaching metasoma when mouthparts are in repose (basitibial plate moderately developed, much exceeding apex of femur, as in Fig. 67-5c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megaloptidia of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megaloptidia of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Maxillary palpus not greatly lengthened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megaloptidia of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Eye greatly enlarged, projecting above vertex (Fig. 677b), separated from lateral ocellus and from vertical part of epistomal suture above tentorial pit by one-fourth of ocellar diameter or less (basitibial plate not short, much surpassing apex of femur; ocelli much enlarged)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogelloides of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogelloides of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Maxillary palpus not greatly lengthened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogelloides of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Eyes not projecting above vertex, widely separated from lateral ocellus and from epistomal suture above tentorial pit (Fig. 67-6, 67-13g)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogelloides of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Pronotal dorsal surface swollen, dorsolateral angle and vertical ridge below angle absent; paraocular lobe long, lower end acute (Fig. 67-13a, b); head elongated, owing to greatly lengthened clypeus; inner hind tibial spur serrate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megommation of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megommation of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Maxillary palpus not greatly lengthened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megommation of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Eyes not projecting above vertex, widely separated from lateral ocellus and from epistomal suture above tentorial pit (Fig. 67-6, 67-13g)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megommation of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Pronotal dorsal surface normal, not swollen; paraocular lobe approximately right-angular (Fig. 67-7a); head not greatly elongated; inner hind tibial spur pectinate or serrate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megommation of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Basitibial plate very short, scarcely surpassing apex of femur

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Micrommation of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Micrommation of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Maxillary palpus not greatly lengthened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Micrommation of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Eyes not projecting above vertex, widely separated from lateral ocellus and from epistomal suture above tentorial pit (Fig. 67-6, 67-13g)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Micrommation of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Pronotal dorsal surface normal, not swollen; paraocular lobe approximately right-angular (Fig. 67-7a); head not greatly elongated; inner hind tibial spur pectinate or serrate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Micrommation of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Basitibial plate moderately developed (ocelli small; inner hind tibial spur serrate) (placed here on the basis of the description; I have seen no specimens)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera T emnosoma of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis not so slender (Fig. 67-4a, c-e), prementum four to eight times as long as broad; proboscidial fossa much wider than mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera T emnosoma of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Inner hind tibial spur serrate, teeth shorter than wide, pointed or rounded, or margin of spur undulate or ciliate (Fig. 67-5f, g, k-m)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera T emnosoma of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Scopa and median specialized area of T5 absent; integument coarsely punctate (Fig. 67-15); labral process truncate, without keel (Fig. 65-1i)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Augochlora of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Epistomal suture forming acute paraocular lobe protruding into clypeus (Fig. 67-6d); clypeus relatively ﬂat, green almost to apex; anterior angle of hypostomal carina usually a sharp right angle or produced into spine; apex of marginal cell narrowly truncate and usually appendiculate (Fig. 67-1a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Augochlorella of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Epistomal suture forming obtuse or right angle laterally (Fig. 67-6c); clypeus beveled, area below angle not green; anterior angle of hypostomal carina rounded; apex of marginal cell acute or very narrowly truncate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Corynura (Corynura) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Basal area of propodeum completely smooth or granular, without striae; eyes deeply emarginate (Fig. 67-6a) (preoccipital ridge gradually rounded)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paroxystoglossa —. Preoccipital ridge rounded; mesoscutum very slightly narrowed anteriorly, lip low and rounded; labral basal el- evation transverse ..........................................Megaloptilla of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Preoccipital ridge sharply angled; mesoscutum strongly narrowed anteriorly, lip high and sharply angled; labral basal elevation suborbiculate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Caenaugochlora (Ctenaugochlora) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Preoccipital carina strong, even almost lamella-like; apex of marginal cell minutely truncate; basal area of propodeum about as long as scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogella (Ischnomelissa) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Preoccipital ridge rounded; apex of marginal cell pointed; basal area of propodeum about as long as scutellum and metanotum taken together (head at least as long as broad)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogella (Chlerogella) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Pronotum convex dorsally, dorsolateral angle and vertical ridge below angle absent; paraocular lobe acute (Fig. 67-7e); scutellum normal; ﬂagellum ten-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogas of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Pronotum normal in form; paraocular lobe right-angular (Fig. 67-7f, g); scutellum produced into two convexities; ﬂagellum nine-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megalopta of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Eyes and ocelli enlarged, ocellocular distance thus equal to or less than ocellar diameter (Fig. 67-7d, 6713d); hamuli in a closely packed series (Fig. 67-1b); hind tibia covered with amber setae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xenochlora of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Eyes and ocelli not enlarged, ocellocular distance twice ocellar diameter or more; hamuli in series broken by gaps (as in most other Augochlorini), some hooks thus isolated; hind tibia and basitarsus largely covered with black setae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Augochloropsis of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): T egula with inner posterior angle produced mesally, forming an emargination in the posterior part of the mesal tegular margin (Fig. 67-5t); basitibial plate very short, poorly deﬁned, extending barely past apex of femur (Fig. 67-8a); labrum with distal process expanded and rounded, as broad as body of labrum (Fig. 65-1g), distal keel projecting beyond apex (pronotal dorsal ridge between lateral angle and pronotal lobe lamellate, forming ﬂange from lateral angle to lobe)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhinocorynura of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhinocorynura of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Vertex swollen behind ocelli; clypeus usually armed with spines or median tubercle (Fig. 67-7h); basal area of propodeum smooth, usually depressed transversely; base of T1 normal

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thectochlora of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thectochlora of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Vertex not swollen; clypeus not armed; basal area of propodeum short, striate, completely covered with short, dense pile; T1 with basal enclosure formed by dense plumose hairs near petiole, usually containing large mites

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhectomia of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhectomia of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Pronotal dorsolateral angle produced, strongly carinate anteriorly and laterally behind angle, dorsal ridge not carinate behind dorsolateral angle, but vertical ridge below angle carinate (mesoscutum slightly produced over pronotum, low and sharply angled; preoccipital ridge rounded)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Andinaugochlora (Andinaugochlora) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Andinaugochlora (Andinaugochlora) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Basitibial plate well-deﬁned posteriorly, obsolescent anteriorly (Fig. 67-5q); pronotal dorsolateral angle not produced, obtuse; eye hairs short

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Neocorynura of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Neocorynura of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Preoccipital ridge carinate or lamellate; mesoscutum usually narrowed anteriorly and anterior mesoscutal lip usually narrow, high, projecting forward and sharply angled; pronotal dorsolateral angle usually strongly produced, lateral ridge carinate or lamellate; propodeum usuallynarrowed posteriorly

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Corynura (Callistochlora) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Corynura (Callistochlora) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Eyes with long hair; basitibial plate deﬁned only posteriorly, very short (Fig. 67-5p)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Augochlorodes of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Augochlorodes of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Pronotal dorsal ridge strongly carinate; marginal cell with apex acute; body length approximately 7 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudaugochlora of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudaugochlora of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Vertex produced to rounded ridge behind ocelli (Fig. 67-14a); preoccipital ridge rounded; galea of maxilla with apex pointed, well sclerotized; basal elevation of labrum with apical surface ﬂattened, rimmed (Fig. 651b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Caenaugochlora (Caenaugochlora) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Caenaugochlora (Caenaugochlora) of Augochlorini (Females)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b): Vertex not produced; preoccipital ridge usually sharply angled or carinate; galea normal, with apical lobe; basal elevation of labrum without ﬂattened distal surface

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ariphanarthra of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ariphanarthra of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Maxillary palpus much longer than stipes plus galea, reaching metasoma when mouthparts are in repose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megaloptidia of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megaloptidia of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Maxillary palpus not greatly lengthened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megaloptidia of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Eyes greatly enlarged, projecting above vertex, separated from lateral ocellus and from vertical part of epistomal suture above tentorial pit by one-fourth of ocellar diameter or less (Fig. 67-7b); S4 bilobed with deep median notch, the lobes strongly pilose (ocelli much enlarged)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogelloides of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogelloides of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Maxillary palpus not greatly lengthened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogelloides of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Eyes not projecting above vertex, widely separated from lateral ocellus and epistomal suture above tentorial pit (Fig. 67-6); S4 not bilobed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogelloides of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Pronotal dorsal surface swollen; paraocular lobe long, acute; head elongate owing to greatly lengthened clypeus; middle femur sometimes greatly swollen and ﬂattened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogella (in part) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Pronotum convex dorsally, lateral angle a mere convexity and vertical ridge below angle absent; epistomal suture forming acute paraocular lobe laterally; scutellum normal; ﬂagellum 11-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogas of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Pronotum normal; epistomal suture forming right angle laterally (Fig. 67-7f, g); scutellum produced into two large tubercles; ﬂagellum 10-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Augochloropsis of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): T egula with inner posterior angle produced mesally (Fig. 67-5t); posterior margins of T1 and T2 frequently each with a row of strong simple setae (pronotal dorsal ridge lamellate, forming ﬂange from lateral angle to lobe; S4 usually with posterolateral appendage (Fig. 67-9c, f, but see also b), the appendage usually hidden or partly projecting from beneath T4; S4 posteriorly emarginate with median point; marginal cell truncate)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megalopta of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Eyes and ocelli enlarged, ocellocular distance usually less than ocellar diameter (Fig. 67-7d); S3 bilobed; S4 with posterior margin notched laterally, bilobed medially, and with median ﬂap; pronotal dorsal ridge rounded and narrow, anterior edge of dorsolateral angle and vertical ridge below dorsolateral angle both carinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thectochlora (in part) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Vertex not swollen; basal area of propodeum striate; S4 produced into caudally directed lateral process bearing strong setae (usually hidden), posterior margin medially depressed and truncate, disc of S4 with a median patch of short, erect, stout setae; S5 emarginate, with long plumose pubescence; scape less than 1.5 times as long as second ﬂagellar segment

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paroxystoglossa of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paroxystoglossa of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): S4 and S5 depressed medially and shiny, posterior margin of S4 broadly emarginate (as in Fig. 67-9a); venter of head and mesosoma and lower surfaces of legs clothed with long plumose pubescence; metasoma not petiolate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera T emnosoma of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Body very coarsely punctate; T1 to T3 strongly depressed basally (Fig. 67-15); T7 prolonged apically and bilobed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhinocorynura of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Vertex swollen above ocelli; basal area of propodeum smooth; S4 and S5 unmodiﬁed; scape more than twice length of second ﬂagellar segment

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thectochlora (in part) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Vertex not swollen; basal area of propodeum striate; S4 produced into caudally directed lateral process bearing strong setae (usually hidden), posterior margin medially depressed and truncate, disc of S4 with a median patch of short, erect, stout setae; S5 emarginate, with long plumose pubescence; scape less than 1.5 times as long as second ﬂagellar segment

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chlerogella (Ischnomelissa) (in part) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Basal area of propodeum about as long as scutellum and metanotum combined; propodeal pit narrow, not enclosed by V-shaped depression; paraocular lobe about right-angular; pronotal dorsal ridge not carinate; gonostylus not divided into dorsal and ventral gonostylar processes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Halictillus of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Metasoma elongate, not petiolate, dull metallic blue-green; body about 5 to 6 mm long; bridge of penis valves shifted apicad to level of apices of gonocoxites

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Corynura of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Metasoma petiolate, ﬁrst two segments long and narrow, or, if not, then body usually bright green or orangegreen; body length usually over 6 mm; bridge of penis valves in usual position near level of middles of gonocoxites

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megaloptilla of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Megaloptilla of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Mesoscutum weakly narrowed anteriorly; dorsal pronotal ridge between lateral angle and lobe carinate, vertical ridge below angle not carinate; apical margin of S5 unmodiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhectomia of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhectomia of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Mesoscutum broadly rounded anteriorly; dorsal pronotal ridge between lateral angle and lobe not carinate, vertical ridge below angle carinate; apical margin of S5 with weak median notch

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Augochlorodes of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Augochlorodes of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Basal area of propodeum smooth; S5 with dense clump of setae medially; S6 shallowly notched along apical margin; dorsal lobes of gonobase weakly deﬁned; venter of penis valve without prong

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Andinaugochlora (Neocorynurella) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Andinaugochlora (Neocorynurella) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Basal area of propodeum striate; S5 with scattered setae; S6 deeply notched along apical margin; dorsal lobes of gonobase strong; penis valve with ventral prong

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Augochlorella (Ceratalictus) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Augochlorella (Ceratalictus) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Antenna reaching about to scutellum, scape more than 2.5 times length of second ﬂagellar segment, which is subequal to ﬁrst; scutum not narrowed and not produced over pronotum (integument bright green; tibiae and tarsi orange)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paroxystoglossa of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paroxystoglossa of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): S4 and S5 depressed medially and shiny, posterior margin of S4 broadly emarginate (as in Fig. 67-9a); venter of head and mesosoma and lower surfaces of legs clothed with long plumose pubescence; metasoma not petiolate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Neocorynura of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Neocorynura of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): S4 and S5 not modiﬁed; ventral surfaces without long plumose pubescence; metasoma frequently petiolate, S1 and S2 usually very long and narrow (compare with Andinaugochlora)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Andinaugochlora (Andinaugochlora) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Andinaugochlora (Andinaugochlora) of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Antenna very long, surpassing propodeum; scape twice length of second ﬂagellar segment or less; ﬂagellum with plate areas containing only sensory plate-organs, these areas without setae; S6 strongly notched with deep concavities on either side of median notch

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Augochlora of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Augochlora of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Epistomal suture forming acute lateral angle or paraocular lobe protruding into clypeus (Fig. 67-6d); marginal cell truncate, usually appendiculate (Fig. 671a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Augochlorella of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Augochlorella of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Epistomal suture forming right angle laterally (Fig. 676c); marginal cell acute, rarely very narrowly truncate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudaugochlora of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudaugochlora of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Apical ﬂagellar segment tapering, hooked (Fig. 6714c); preoccipital ridge rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Caenaugochlora of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Proboscis extraordinarily slender, prementum 10 to over 20 times as long as broad (Fig. 67-4b); proboscidial fossa about as wide as mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Caenaugochlora of Augochlorini (Males)(Modiﬁed from Eickwort, 1969b; males unknown forXenochlora.): Apical ﬂagellar segment rounded; preoccipital ridge sharply angled or carinate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Andinaugochlora s. str.) of Andinaugochlora: Preoccipital carina present although weak behind vertex; anterior margin of basitibial plate of female absent; paraocular lobe near right-angular (about 100 /H11034); penis valve without ventral prong

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Neocorynurella) of Andinaugochlora: Preoccipital carina absent; anterior margin of basitibial plate of female a distinct carina; paraocular lobe strongly obtuse (about 135/H11034); penis valve with ventral prong

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oxystoglossella) of Augochlora: Female: Mandible normal, preapical tooth not produced, far from apex of mandible; median area of T5 with long setae, not scale-like; S1 usually normal, rarely with slight median ridge or tooth; basitibial plate usually narrowly rounded, occasionally broadly rounded; basal elevation of labrum suborbicular. Male: Ventral gonostylus with long setae, greatly surpassing gonostylus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Augochlora s. str.) of Augochlora: Female: Mandible bidentate, preapical tooth and occasionally outer ridge produced; median area of T5 with scale-like setae; S1 frequently with tooth or median ridge, sometimes unarmed; basitibial plate broadly rounded (Fig. 67-8b); basal elevation of labrum transverse. Male: Ventral gonostylus with short setae (Fig. 67-10d)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ceratalictus) of Augochlorella (Females): Epistomal suture forming obtuse paraocular lobe (as in Fig. 67-6b); inner hind tibial spur broadest near middle (Fig. 67-5l); basitibial plate poorly deﬁned on anterior edge (preoccipital ridge carinate)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pereirapis) of Augochlorella (Females): Epistomal suture forming right-angular or slightly obtuse paraocular lobe (Fig. 67-6c); inner hind tibial spur broadest at basal one-third to one-ﬁfth; basitibial plate well deﬁned on all edges

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pereirapis) of Augochlorella (Females): Inner hind tibial spur with few short, rounded teeth, basal tooth largest, forming broadest part of spur (Fig. 67-5m); basal area of propodeum strongly granular, striate basally; body length about 5 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Augochlorella s. str.) of Augochlorella (Females): Epistomal suture forming right-angular or slightly obtuse paraocular lobe (Fig. 67-6c); inner hind tibial spur broadest at basal one-third to one-ﬁfth; basitibial plate well deﬁned on all edges

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Augochlorella s. str.) of Augochlorella (Females): Inner hind tibial spur with rounded serrations, basal part broadened and serrate, i.e., not formed from a single tooth; basal area of propodeum not strongly granular; body length usually over 5 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ceratalictus) of Augochlorella (Males): Epistomal suture forming obtuse paraocular lobe; dorsal gonostylus with long, narrow, hairless basal process extending mesad to midline

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pereirapis) of Augochlorella (Males): Epistomal suture forming right-angular paraocular lobe; dorsal gonostylus without such a mesal process

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pereirapis) of Augochlorella (Males): S4 broadly emarginate posteriorly, laterally bearing long, modiﬁed setae that are usually hidden; body length about 5 mm; inner lobe of ventral gonostylus without row of coarse setae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Augochlorella s. str.) of Augochlorella (Males): Epistomal suture forming right-angular paraocular lobe; dorsal gonostylus without such a mesal process

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Augochlorella s. str.) of Augochlorella (Males): S4 not broadly emarginate, without long lateral setae; body length usually over 5 mm; inner lobe of ventral gonostylus bearing marginal row of coarse, ﬂattened setae (Fig. 67-10f)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Augochloropsis s. str.) of Augochloropsis: Basal area of propodeum deeply and regularly pitted or strongly striate basally, smooth apically; S5 of male with apical margin notched, and with long, curved setae centrally; S6 of male with wide apical ﬂange (broken medially) projecting beyond posterior border; distal process of male labrum truncate or notched apically; ventral gonostylus of male bearing row of strong, ﬂattened, modiﬁed setae at apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Paraugochloropsis) of Augochloropsis: Basal area of propodeum smooth, irregularly roughened, or with light plicae; S5 of male with apical margin entire, setae not modiﬁed; S6 of male with apical ﬂange little developed; distal process of male labrum rounded; ventral gonostylus of male bearing dense unmodiﬁed setae at apex (Fig. 67-12b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Caenaugochlora s. str.) of Caenaugochlora: Basitibial plate of female well deﬁned on all edges; inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with well separated teeth (as in Fig. 67-5i); eye hair frequently long; S4 of male bearing distinctive setal clumps on raised tubercles on either side of apical median depression (Fig. 67-9d)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ctenaugochlora) of Caenaugochlora: Basitibial plate of female obsolescent anteriorly; inner hind tibial spur of female closely pectinate, with over ten teeth (Fig. 67-5n); eye hair short; S4 of male with Vshaped patch of setae bordering slight median depression

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ischnomelissa) of Chlerogella: Inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with over ten close teeth (as in Fig. 67-5n); paraocular lobe slightly acute; male gonostylus undivided

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Chlerogella s. str.) of Chlerogella: Inner hind tibial spur of female with fewer, well-separated teeth (as in Fig. 67-5i); paraocular lobe strongly acute; male gonostylus divided into dorsal and ventral processes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ischnomelissa) of Chlerogella: Inner hind tibial spur of female pectinate with over ten close teeth (as in Fig. 67-5n); paraocular lobe slightly acute; male gonostylus undivided

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Megalopta s. str.) of Megalopta: Female with scopa and poorly developed basitibial plate (Fig. 67-5s); mandible of female stout, bidentate, with supplementary teeth on inner surface (Fig. 67-5o); S5 of male narrowly emarginate; clypeus and scape of male partly white

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Noctoraptor) of Megalopta: Female without either scopa or basitibial plate (Fig. 6713e); mandible of female simple, long and slender, without supplementary teeth (Fig. 67-13d); S5 of male broadly notched; clypeus and scape of male black

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Megommation s. str.) of Megommation: Ocelli much enlarged, ocellocular distance equal to or less than ocellar diameter (Fig. 67-7a); body length 12 mm or more (inner hind tibial spur of female serrate)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Meganomiinae, of the Melittidae: Yellow or cream markings on head, thorax, and metasoma; body length over 10 mm; mandible of female simple; apex of marginal cell rounded, bent away from wing margin (Africa, Arabia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Dasypodainae, of the Melittidae: Yellow or cream markings, if present, limited to male face and rarely areas on legs [except for Eremaphanta (Central Asia; length 6.5 mm or less) which often has abundant yellow markings, and Macropis hedini Popov, which has yellow on supraclypeal area of female]; mandible of female with preapical tooth on upper margin, sometimes two teeth; apex of marginal cell pointed, on or very near wing margin (Fig. 68-1)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Dasypodainae, of the Melittidae: Paraglossa largely bare, usually markedly shorter than suspensorium, its hairs largely limited to apex, or paraglossa absent (Fig. 72-1b); forewing with two submarginal cells, second usually shorter than ﬁrst; ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (/H11005base of second submarginal cell) usually more or less at right angles to longitudinal veins (Fig. 68-1c, d) and usually close to ﬁrst recurrent vein; known larvae do not spin cocoons

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Melittinae, of the Melittidae: Yellow or cream markings, if present, limited to male face and rarely areas on legs [except for Eremaphanta (Central Asia; length 6.5 mm or less) which often has abundant yellow markings, and Macropis hedini Popov, which has yellow on supraclypeal area of female]; mandible of female with preapical tooth on upper margin, sometimes two teeth; apex of marginal cell pointed, on or very near wing margin (Fig. 68-1)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Melittinae, of the Melittidae: Paraglossa densely hairy; forewing with two or three submarginal cells, second (if only two) or second plus third as long as or longer than ﬁrst; ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (/H11005base of second submarginal cell) slanting (Fig. 68-1a, b), usually well separated from ﬁrst recurrent vein; larvae spin cocoons

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Dasypodaini, of the Dasypodainae: Vertex, as seen from front (except in Eremaphanta s. str.), elevated well above summits of eyes, usually convex; gonostylus of male (except in Dasypoda) robust, fused to gonocoxite; S7 of male without or (in some Dasypoda) with only one pair of straplike lateroapical lobes (Fig. 701f); paraglossa small, slender, more or less cylindrical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Promelittini, of the Dasypodainae: Vertex, as seen from front, little elevated above summits of eyes, gently convex to concave; gonostylus of male long, ﬂexibly joined or articulated to gonocoxite; S7 of male with one or two pairs of broad lateroapical lobes (Fig 72-1f, g); paraglossa tapering distally or absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Promelittini, of the Dasypodainae: Clypeus of male largely yellow; metasomal terga with basal zones of pale hair; paraglossa nearly as long as its suspensorium; vertex weakly, uniformly convex, as seen from front (Egypt)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Sambini, of the Dasypodainae: Vertex, as seen from front, little elevated above summits of eyes, gently convex to concave; gonostylus of male long, ﬂexibly joined or articulated to gonocoxite; S7 of male with one or two pairs of broad lateroapical lobes (Fig 72-1f, g); paraglossa tapering distally or absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Sambini, of the Dasypodainae: Clypeus of male concolorous with rest of head; metasomal terga usually without basal hair bands, but if bands present, then apical; paraglossa much shorter than its suspensorium or usually not recognizable (Fig. 72-1b); vertex straight or concave, as seen from front (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eremaphanta of the Dasypodaini: Yellow integumental markings present, at least on face and legs; stigma large, slightly shorter to slightly longer than costal margin of marginal cell; prepygidial and pygidial ﬁmbriae of female absent (Central Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dasypoda of the Dasypodaini: Yellow integumental markings absent (except rarely on part of clypeus of male); stigma not enlarged, about half as long as costal margin of marginal cell (Fig. 68-1c, d); prepygidial and pygidial ﬁmbriae of female well developed, or the former represented by a mere hair band similar to that of T4

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Dasypoda of the Dasypodaini: Basitibial plate absent in both sexes; proﬁle of propodeum all more or less in one plane; galeal comb absent or nearly so; male gonostylus well differentiated, nearly always deeply biﬁd (Fig. 70-1d) (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Eremaphanta s. str.) ofEremaphanta: T erga without apical hair bands; head broader than long; vertex gently convex, scarcely above level of summits of eyes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Popovapis) ofEremaphanta: T erga with apical hair bands; head longer than broad; vertex extending far above summits of eyes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Capicoloides) of Hesperapis: Pygidial plate of female with longitudinal median elevated area, or at least ridges representing edges of such an area; male gonostylus without inner lobe (Fig. 70-1a) (southern Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Capicoloides) of Hesperapis: Outer surface of hind tibia of female with large, blunt, spinelike hairs among scopal hairs; S7 of male with disc narrowed, with diverging, densely hairy, lateroapical lobes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Capicola) of Hesperapis: Pygidial plate of female with longitudinal median elevated area, or at least ridges representing edges of such an area; male gonostylus without inner lobe (Fig. 70-1a) (southern Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Capicola) of Hesperapis: Outer surface of hind tibia of female without spinelike hairs interspersed among scopal hairs; S7 of male with disc broad, without diverging lateroapical lobes (Fig. 701c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Xeralictoides) of Hesperapis: Pygidial plate of female without longitudinal median elevated or differentiated area (sometimes with triangular basal area); male gonostylus with inner lobe, usually bearing long, coarse, branched bristles or hairs (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Xeralictoides) of Hesperapis: Mesoscutum as long as or longer than minimum intertegular distance; front tibia with series of ﬁve or more robust, amber apical and posteroapical spines on outer surface

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Panurgomia) of Hesperapis: Pygidial plate of female without longitudinal median elevated or differentiated area (sometimes with triangular basal area); male gonostylus with inner lobe, usually bearing long, coarse, branched bristles or hairs (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Panurgomia) of Hesperapis: Mesoscutum considerably shorter than minimum intertegular distance; front tibia without such spines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Panurgomia) of Hesperapis: Propodeal triangle contiguously punctured throughout and dull, in contrast to sparsely punctured and shining posterior and lateral propodeal surfaces; pygidial plate of female more or less ﬂat, with mesal area bearing patch of appressed plumose hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Carinapis) of Hesperapis: Pygidial plate of female without longitudinal median elevated or differentiated area (sometimes with triangular basal area); male gonostylus with inner lobe, usually bearing long, coarse, branched bristles or hairs (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Carinapis) of Hesperapis: Mesoscutum considerably shorter than minimum intertegular distance; front tibia without such spines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Carinapis) of Hesperapis: Propodeal triangle smooth and shiny, at most anteriorly rugose or irregularly punctured, or, if dull and closely punctured, then posterior and lateral propodeal surfaces similar; pygidial plate of female often strongly convex with elevated basal triangle, always without mesal hair patch

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Carinapis) of Hesperapis: Females

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Carinapis) of Hesperapis: Hairs along upper (i.e., posterior) margin of hind basitarsus parted, margin being narrowly hairless and exposed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Carinapis) of Hesperapis: Pygidial plate with elevated, triangular basal area margined by carinae that meet posteromedially [except in H. oliviae (Cockerell), which lacks these carinae]; body length 7-16 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hesperapis s. str.) of Hesperapis: Pygidial plate of female without longitudinal median elevated or differentiated area (sometimes with triangular basal area); male gonostylus with inner lobe, usually bearing long, coarse, branched bristles or hairs (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hesperapis s. str.) of Hesperapis: Mesoscutum considerably shorter than minimum intertegular distance; front tibia without such spines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hesperapis s. str.) of Hesperapis: Propodeal triangle smooth and shiny, at most anteriorly rugose or irregularly punctured, or, if dull and closely punctured, then posterior and lateral propodeal surfaces similar; pygidial plate of female often strongly convex with elevated basal triangle, always without mesal hair patch

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hesperapis s. str.) of Hesperapis: Females

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hesperapis s. str.) of Hesperapis: Hairs along upper (i.e., posterior) margin of hind basitarsus parted, margin being narrowly hairless and exposed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hesperapis s. str.) of Hesperapis: Pygidial plate ﬂat with shallow longitudinal sulcus near apex, without elevated area; body length 4-7 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Zacesta) of Hesperapis: Labial palpus with second segment much longer than ﬁrst; head about as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Disparapis) —. First ﬂagellar segment equal to or shorter than second ................................................................ H. (Amblyapis) of Hesperapis: Pygidial plate of female without longitudinal median elevated or differentiated area (sometimes with triangular basal area); male gonostylus with inner lobe, usually bearing long, coarse, branched bristles or hairs (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Disparapis) —. First ﬂagellar segment equal to or shorter than second ................................................................ H. (Amblyapis) of Hesperapis: Mesoscutum considerably shorter than minimum intertegular distance; front tibia without such spines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Disparapis) —. First ﬂagellar segment equal to or shorter than second ................................................................ H. (Amblyapis) of Hesperapis: Propodeal triangle smooth and shiny, at most anteriorly rugose or irregularly punctured, or, if dull and closely punctured, then posterior and lateral propodeal surfaces similar; pygidial plate of female often strongly convex with elevated basal triangle, always without mesal hair patch

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Disparapis) —. First ﬂagellar segment equal to or shorter than second ................................................................ H. (Amblyapis) of Hesperapis: Females

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Disparapis) —. First ﬂagellar segment equal to or shorter than second ................................................................ H. (Amblyapis) of Hesperapis: Hairs along upper (i.e., posterior) margin of hind basitarsus not parted, arising on, as well as on both sides of, the margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Disparapis) —. First ﬂagellar segment equal to or shorter than second ................................................................ H. (Amblyapis) of Hesperapis: Head length much less than width; labial palpus with second segment little if any longer than ﬁrst

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Disparapis) —. First ﬂagellar segment equal to or shorter than second ................................................................ H. (Amblyapis) of Hesperapis: First ﬂagellar segment at least 1.6 times length of second

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Zacesta) of Hesperapis: Labial palpus with second segment much longer than ﬁrst; head about as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hesperapis s. str.) of Certain Male Hesperapisfrom North AmericaGood subgeneric characters are difﬁcult to ﬁnd amongmany males. Because the following key, to certain malesthat run to the second alternative of couplet 10 in theabove key, utilizes species-group characters, some sub-genera come out in two or more places.: Body length 6 mm or less and metasomal terga with distinct, white, apical hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Carinapis) (in part) of Certain Male Hesperapisfrom North AmericaGood subgeneric characters are difﬁcult to ﬁnd amongmany males. Because the following key, to certain malesthat run to the second alternative of couplet 10 in theabove key, utilizes species-group characters, some sub-genera come out in two or more places.: Body length greater than 6 mm or metasomal terga without white apical hair bands, sometimes with pale brown hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Carinapis) (in part) of Certain Male Hesperapisfrom North AmericaGood subgeneric characters are difﬁcult to ﬁnd amongmany males. Because the following key, to certain malesthat run to the second alternative of couplet 10 in theabove key, utilizes species-group characters, some sub-genera come out in two or more places.: Pygidial plate absent, T7 covered with pubescence 3 3(2). Posterior lobe of pronotum produced into stout, weakly recurved spine; galea dark, sparsely punctured, glabrous

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Carinapis) (in part) of Certain Male Hesperapisfrom North AmericaGood subgeneric characters are difﬁcult to ﬁnd amongmany males. Because the following key, to certain malesthat run to the second alternative of couplet 10 in theabove key, utilizes species-group characters, some sub-genera come out in two or more places.: Body length greater than 6 mm or metasomal terga without white apical hair bands, sometimes with pale brown hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Carinapis) (in part) of Certain Male Hesperapisfrom North AmericaGood subgeneric characters are difﬁcult to ﬁnd amongmany males. Because the following key, to certain malesthat run to the second alternative of couplet 10 in theabove key, utilizes species-group characters, some sub-genera come out in two or more places.: Pygidial plate absent, T7 covered with pubescence 3 3(2). Posterior lobe of pronotum produced into stout, weakly recurved spine; galea dark, sparsely punctured, glabrous

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Disparapis) of Certain Male Hesperapisfrom North AmericaGood subgeneric characters are difﬁcult to ﬁnd amongmany males. Because the following key, to certain malesthat run to the second alternative of couplet 10 in theabove key, utilizes species-group characters, some sub-genera come out in two or more places.: S6 with apical lobes rounded, shiny and relatively free of hair except for apically directed marginal fringe; terga always with distinct pale apical hair bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Amblyapis) (in part) of Certain Male Hesperapisfrom North AmericaGood subgeneric characters are difﬁcult to ﬁnd amongmany males. Because the following key, to certain malesthat run to the second alternative of couplet 10 in theabove key, utilizes species-group characters, some sub-genera come out in two or more places.: S6 with apical lobes acute, dull, and bearing inner, subapical brush of suberect hair; terga with pale apical hair bands occasionally very weakly developed or absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Amblyapis) (in part) of Certain Male Hesperapisfrom North AmericaGood subgeneric characters are difﬁcult to ﬁnd amongmany males. Because the following key, to certain malesthat run to the second alternative of couplet 10 in theabove key, utilizes species-group characters, some sub-genera come out in two or more places.: T erga dull with irregular-sized continuous punctures

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Samba of the Sambini: Female with only one hind tibial spur that is large and curved (Fig. 72-2d); vertex strongly concave, as seen from front; hind basitarsus of male with hairy pocket near base of outer surface (Fig. 72-2c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Haplomelitta of the Sambini: Female with two hind tibial spurs; vertex not or scarcely concave; hind basitarsus of male without hairy pocket (Fig. 72-2a, b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Samba of the Sambini: Female with only one hind tibial spur that is large and curved (Fig. 72-2d); vertex strongly concave, as seen from front; hind basitarsus of male with hairy pocket near base of outer surface (Fig. 72-2c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera H. (Haplosamba) of the Sambini: Mandible of female tridentate (male unknown)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera H. (Haplomelitta s. str.) of the Sambini: Mandible of female bidentate (inner tooth sometimes reduced to a shoulder)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera H. (Haplomelitta s. str.) of the Sambini: Propodeal triangle strongly differentiated, basal zone (and laterally entire length of triangle) with short longitudinal rugae; hind basitarsus of male strongly inﬂated (Fig. 72-2b), as broad as tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera H. (Atrosamba) of the Sambini: Mandible of female bidentate (inner tooth sometimes reduced to a shoulder)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera H. (Atrosamba) of the Sambini: Propodeal triangle differentiated only by weak lines, without rugae on basal zone; hind basitarsus of male slender, much narrower than tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera H. (Atrosamba) of the Sambini: Second submarginal cell about as long as ﬁrst; ﬁrst recurrent and ﬁrst submarginal crossvein usually well separated; basal vein meeting cu-v or nearly so; S7 of male with two pairs of pedunculate membranous lobes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera H. (Prosamba) of the Sambini: Mandible of female bidentate (inner tooth sometimes reduced to a shoulder)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera H. (Prosamba) of the Sambini: Propodeal triangle differentiated only by weak lines, without rugae on basal zone; hind basitarsus of male slender, much narrower than tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera H. (Prosamba) of the Sambini: Second submarginal cell distinctly shorter than ﬁrst; ﬁrst recurrent and ﬁrst submarginal crossvein close together, meeting one another or the former on either side of the latter; basal vein much basad of cu-v; S7 of male with one pair of pedunculate membranous lobes and one pair of hairy areas

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Meganomia of the Meganomiinae: Arolia absent (although long, hairy, yellow plantae project between the claws); ﬂagellum of male with apical segment or several segments curled and attenuate (Fig. 733c); hind basitarsus of male bent or contorted, or at least with curved carina on outer side

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudophilanthus of the Meganomiinae: Arolia present, conspicuously black among associated pale interungual structures; ﬂagellum of male with apex simple or expanded as a plate; hind basitarsus of male simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudophilanthus of the Meganomiinae: Ocelli much in front of posterior edge of vertex, posterior ocellus separated from that edge by more than two ocellar diameters; upper part of head gently convex, as seen from front; front edge of median ocellus little if any nearer to posterior edge of vertex than to antennal bases; glossa as long as prementum or nearly so (Fig. 73-1b).

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Uromonia of the Meganomiinae: Arolia present, conspicuously black among associated pale interungual structures; ﬂagellum of male with apex simple or expanded as a plate; hind basitarsus of male simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Uromonia of the Meganomiinae: Posterior ocellus separated from posterior edge of vertex by an ocellar diameter or a little more; upper part of head, as seen from front, feebly convex or ﬂat or with ocellar region slightly elevated; front edge of median ocellus much nearer to posterior edge of vertex than to antennal bases; glossa three-ﬁfths as long as prementum or shorter (Fig. 73-1a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Uromonia of the Meganomiinae: Flagellum of male not expanded at apex (Fig. 73-3a); T4 and T5 (both sexes) without sublateral stridulating areas; basitibial plate of female not deﬁned (female un known in subgenus Nesomonia); glossa one-half to threeﬁfths as long as prementum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ceratomonia of the Meganomiinae: Arolia present, conspicuously black among associated pale interungual structures; ﬂagellum of male with apex simple or expanded as a plate; hind basitarsus of male simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ceratomonia of the Meganomiinae: Posterior ocellus separated from posterior edge of vertex by an ocellar diameter or a little more; upper part of head, as seen from front, feebly convex or ﬂat or with ocellar region slightly elevated; front edge of median ocellus much nearer to posterior edge of vertex than to antennal bases; glossa three-ﬁfths as long as prementum or shorter (Fig. 73-1a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ceratomonia of the Meganomiinae: Flagellum of male with apical segment expanded, platelike, black (Fig. 73-3d); T4 and T5 (both sexes) with sublateral stridulating areas hidden under preceding tergal margins; glossa less than one-third as long as prementum (Fig. 73-1a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Dicromonia) of Pseudophilanthus: T7 of male biﬁd, without pygidial plate; galeal blade broad, shorter than stipes (Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pseudophilanthus s. str.) of Pseudophilanthus: T7 of male simple, with pygidial plate; galeal blade tapering, about as long as stipes (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera U. (Nesomonia) of Uromonia: Flagellum of male crenulate, 11-segmented; S8 of male with apical process narrower than disc of sternum (Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera U. (Uromonia s. str.) of Uromonia: Flagellum of male not crenulate, 12-segmented (Fig. 73-3a); S8 of male tapering toward subtruncate apex, without recognizable apical process (Africa)
