Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Macropis of the Melittinae: T wo submarginal cells (Fig. 68-1b); pygidial plate of male strongly developed; male with yellow face marks; gonostylus of male long, slender at least at base, articulated to gonocoxite; S8 of male not ending in beveled area suggestive of a pygidial plate (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Melitta of the Melittinae: Three submarginal cells (Fig. 68-1a); pygidial plate of male absent or weakly evident; male lacking yellow face marks; gonostylus of male broadly fused to gonocoxite (Fig. 74-2a, d); S8 of male ending in a beveled area suggestive of a pygidial plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Melitta of the Melittinae: Propodeal triangle dull (ﬁnely granular), large (width at upper margin usually at least nearly equal to distance between transmetanotal sutures); second submarginal cell usually wider than long or about as long as wide (Fig. 68-1a); S7 of male a large plate, truncate or emarginate apically, the lobes or processes reduced to small sclerotic structures and sometimes hair patches at posterior lateral angles of sternum (Fig. 74-2f) (holarctic, Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Redivivoides of the Melittinae: Three submarginal cells (Fig. 68-1a); pygidial plate of male absent or weakly evident; male lacking yellow face marks; gonostylus of male broadly fused to gonocoxite (Fig. 74-2a, d); S8 of male ending in a beveled area suggestive of a pygidial plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Redivivoides of the Melittinae: Propodeal triangle shiny (usually smooth), often ill-deﬁned, small (width at upper margin not over half distance between transmetanotal sutures and often much less); second submarginal cell usually longer than wide; S7 of male with a small disc, apex biﬁd or with membranous lobes or both (Fig. 74-2c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Redivivoides of the Melittinae: Scopa of female consisting of simple bristles; hind tibia and basitarsus of female slender, the latter three or more times as long as wide; anterior tarsus ordinary, with ordinary vestiture; S7 of male with apex weakly emarginate, bearing, at each side, a large, ﬂat, vertically expanded process with long erect hairs on outer surface (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rediviva of the Melittinae: Three submarginal cells (Fig. 68-1a); pygidial plate of male absent or weakly evident; male lacking yellow face marks; gonostylus of male broadly fused to gonocoxite (Fig. 74-2a, d); S8 of male ending in a beveled area suggestive of a pygidial plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rediviva of the Melittinae: Propodeal triangle shiny (usually smooth), often ill-deﬁned, small (width at upper margin not over half distance between transmetanotal sutures and often much less); second submarginal cell usually longer than wide; S7 of male with a small disc, apex biﬁd or with membranous lobes or both (Fig. 74-2c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rediviva of the Melittinae: Scopa of female consisting of densely plumose understory beneath long simple bristles; hind tibia and basitarsus of female broad, the latter about twice as long as broad; anterior tarsus thickened or elongate, with dense, short vestiture; S7 of male with apex deeply biﬁd or with two long, slender apical processes, lobes at each side (if present) hairless (although spiculate), not ﬂattened, but coarsely striate or ribbed (Fig. 74-2c) (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Paramacropis) of Macropis: Vertex broad behind ocelli, ending in a sharp preoccipital carina; gonostylus of male slender, simple; S6 of male with broadly truncate apical process, S7 with apical process broader than body of sternum, process densely hairy (eastern palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Sinomacropis) of Macropis: Vertex declivous posteriorly, no carina separating it from concave occiput; gonostylus of male apically expanded and bilobed or biﬁd; S6 of male with attenuate apex, S7 with apical process narrow, pointed, bearing relatively sparse hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Sinomacropis) of Macropis: Propodeal triangle punctate, hairy except for small median area (China)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Macropis s. str.) of Macropis: Vertex declivous posteriorly, no carina separating it from concave occiput; gonostylus of male apically expanded and bilobed or biﬁd; S6 of male with attenuate apex, S7 with apical process narrow, pointed, bearing relatively sparse hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Macropis s. str.) of Macropis: Propodeal triangle impunctate and hairless, smooth or rugose (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Paramacropis) of Macropis: Vertex broad behind ocelli, ending in a sharp preoccipital carina; gonostylus of male slender, simple; S6 of male with broadly truncate apical process, S7 with apical process broader than body of sternum, process densely hairy (eastern palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Sinomacropis) of Macropis: Vertex declivous posteriorly, no carina separating it from concave occiput; gonostylus of male apically expanded and bilobed or biﬁd; S6 of male with attenuate apex, S7 with apical process narrow, pointed, bearing relatively sparse hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Sinomacropis) of Macropis: Propodeal triangle punctate, hairy except for small median area (China)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Fideliinae, of the Megachilidae: Submarginal cells three (two in Pararhophites); mandible of female with preapical tooth (sometimes sufﬁciently enlarged that mandible is bilobed or biﬁd) or simple; dorsum of T6 of female hairless at least posteriorly, minutely roughened, often with a lateral ridge or carina suggesting that pygidial plate, if present, occupies most of exposed tergal surface; subantennal suture directed toward middle of lower margin of antennal socket, or usually so short that its direction cannot easily be determined

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Megachilinae, of the Megachilidae: Submarginal cells two; mandible of female with three or more teeth (except in Dioxyini and in a few Megachile that have a much elongated, bidentate mandible); dorsum of T6 of female usually with hairs, pygidial plate usually absent but, if present, then represented only by a narrow midapical process (Fig. 80-2); subantennal suture directed toward outer margin of antennal socket (Fig. 753)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Fideliini, of the Fideliinae: Submarginal cells three; stigma slender, parallel-sided, less than twice as long as prestigma, margin within marginal cell straight or concave (Fig. 76-1b); T7 of male strongly sclerotized with distinct pygidial plate, or with the plate drawn out into a long and sometimes deeply biﬁd process; episternal groove present above level of scrobal groove and curving posteriorly to form scrobal groove; body densely hairy, without yellow markings except sometimes on T6 of the female and on clypeus of both sexes (Africa, Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Pararhophitini, of the Fideliinae: Submarginal cells two; stigma broad, about twice as long as prestigma, margin within marginal cell convex (Fig. 76-1a); T7 of male weakly sclerotized without distinct pygidial plate; episternal groove absent; body sparsely hairy, yellow or with yellow markings (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Neoﬁdelia of the Fideliini: Hind basitarsus of female slender, parallel-sided; hind legs of male enlarged, basitarsus forming two enormous curved talons; clypeus separated from antennal bases by much more than diameter of antennal socket (Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Fidelia of the Fideliini: Hind basitarsus of female broadest near base, tapering to narrow apex; hind legs of male not enlarged or modiﬁed; clypeus separated from antennal bases by less than diameter of socket, subantennal suture thus difﬁcult to observe (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Fideliopsis) of Fidelia (modiﬁed from En-gel, 2002b): Mandible strongly bidentate, teeth long, slender, and diverging from one another; pygidial plate of male present; midapical process of male T7 with apex emarginate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Fidelia s. str.) of Fidelia (modiﬁed from En-gel, 2002b): Mandible broadly bilobed (teeth broad and ﬂat), or with short, subapical tooth, or simple; male pygidial plate absent; midapical process of male T7 deeply bilobed (essentially forming two processes) or simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Fidelia s. str.) of Fidelia (modiﬁed from En-gel, 2002b): Marginal cell not extending beyond apex of submarginal cells, shorter than combined lengths of second and third submarginal cells; claws of female simple; front basitarsus of male ﬂattened and extended laterally as lamella (only a weak lamella in F. kobrowiBrauns)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Fideliana) of Fidelia (modiﬁed from En-gel, 2002b): Mandible broadly bilobed (teeth broad and ﬂat), or with short, subapical tooth, or simple; male pygidial plate absent; midapical process of male T7 deeply bilobed (essentially forming two processes) or simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Fideliana) of Fidelia (modiﬁed from En-gel, 2002b): Marginal cell extending beyond apex of submarginal cells, as long as or longer than combined lengths of second and third submarginal cells; claws of female biﬁd or cleft; male front tarsus unmodiﬁed, segments cylindrical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Fideliana) of Fidelia (modiﬁed from En-gel, 2002b): Marginal cell about as long as combined lengths of second and third submarginal cells; apical ﬂagellar segment of male antenna hooked, preceding segments ventrally crenulate; female T6 off-white; male T7 deeply emarginate (essentially forming two apical processes)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Paraﬁdelia) of Fidelia (modiﬁed from En-gel, 2002b): Mandible broadly bilobed (teeth broad and ﬂat), or with short, subapical tooth, or simple; male pygidial plate absent; midapical process of male T7 deeply bilobed (essentially forming two processes) or simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Paraﬁdelia) of Fidelia (modiﬁed from En-gel, 2002b): Marginal cell extending beyond apex of submarginal cells, as long as or longer than combined lengths of second and third submarginal cells; claws of female biﬁd or cleft; male front tarsus unmodiﬁed, segments cylindrical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Paraﬁdelia) of Fidelia (modiﬁed from En-gel, 2002b): Marginal cell longer than combined lengths of second and third submarginal cells; male antenna simple, unmodiﬁed; female T6 black; male T7 with single midapical process, apex undivided

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Lithurgini, of the Megachilinae: Pygidial plate of male present (Fig. 80-4a, b), that of female represented by an apical process or spine (Fig. 802); metapleuron with lower half narrow (less than half as wide as upper end and ﬁve to six times as long as wide) to linear; outer surfaces of tibiae, except hind tibiae of some males, with coarse tubercles that do not end in bristles (Fig. 80-3b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Dioxyini, of the Megachilinae: Metanotum with median spine or tubercle (except in Allodioxys and Ensliniana); mandible of female slender apically, bidentate, similar to that of male; pronotum (except in Prodioxys) with prominent obtuse or right-angular dorsolateral angle, below which a vertical ridge extends downward; sting and associated structures greatly reduced (scopa absent)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Tribe Megachilini (Sec. 84) — Arolia present; preaxilla, below posterolateral angle of scutum, vertical, smooth and shining or with some hairs, these much shorter than those of adjacent sclerites; body sometimes metallic green, blue, or brassy ...................... ............................................................ Osmiini, of the Megachilinae: Arolia absent, at least on hind legs, usually on all legs; preaxilla, below posterolateral angle of scutum, sloping and with small patch of hairs, these as long as those of adjacent sclerites; body nonmetallic or nearly so

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Trichothurgus of the Lithurgini(From Michener, 1983a): Labrum longer than clypeus, often much longer; hind tibia of female rather uniformly hairy on outer, anterior, and posterior surfaces, spicules relatively inconspicuous among the hairs; lower mandibular tooth longer than middle tooth, or, in some females, lower and middle teeth equal (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Microthurge of the Lithurgini(From Michener, 1983a): Labrum about as long as clypeus; hind tibia of female with hairs of broad, longitudinal outer zone shorter and sparser than those of anterior and posterior surfaces, spicules large and conspicuous in outer zone (Fig. 80-3b); lower mandibular tooth conspicuously shorter than middle tooth, which is the longest mandibular tooth (Fig. 803a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Microthurge of the Lithurgini(From Michener, 1983a): Body small, slender, hoplitiform; claws of female biﬁd (Fig. 80-3c); stigma of moderate size, broadest at base of vein r, sides converging toward base; maxillary palpi twosegmented (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Trichothurgus of the Lithurgini(From Michener, 1983a): Labrum longer than clypeus, often much longer; hind tibia of female rather uniformly hairy on outer, anterior, and posterior surfaces, spicules relatively inconspicuous among the hairs; lower mandibular tooth longer than middle tooth, or, in some females, lower and middle teeth equal (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Microthurge of the Lithurgini(From Michener, 1983a): Labrum about as long as clypeus; hind tibia of female with hairs of broad, longitudinal outer zone shorter and sparser than those of anterior and posterior surfaces, spicules large and conspicuous in outer zone (Fig. 80-3b); lower mandibular tooth conspicuously shorter than middle tooth, which is the longest mandibular tooth (Fig. 803a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Microthurge of the Lithurgini(From Michener, 1983a): Body small, slender, hoplitiform; claws of female biﬁd (Fig. 80-3c); stigma of moderate size, broadest at base of vein r, sides converging toward base; maxillary palpi twosegmented (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Noteriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): T7 weakly sclerotized, not exposed, hidden by large T6

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Noteriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Scutellum with transverse preapical carina, behind which it is vertical or overhanging metanotum; clypeus with longitudinal carina continued dorsally between antennal sockets (Africa, southern Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Wainia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): T7 weakly sclerotized, not exposed, hidden by large T6

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Wainia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Scutellum not carinate, without such a posterior marginal zone; clypeus without longitudinal carina, or carina not continued dorsally between antennal sockets

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Wainia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Scutellum curved down posteriorly, posterior part of its surface thus steeply sloping, vertical, or overhanging; metanotum well below level of most of scutellum; posterior lateral angle of scutum frequently acutely produced posteriorly (Africa and Israel to the Philippines)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Heriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): T7 weakly sclerotized, not exposed, hidden by large T6

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Heriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Scutellum not carinate, without such a posterior marginal zone; clypeus without longitudinal carina, or carina not continued dorsally between antennal sockets

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Heriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Scutellum ﬂat or scarcely convex, not curved down posteriorly and not overhanging metanotum; metanotum medially about on the level of most of scutellum; posterior lateral angle of scutum obtuse

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Heriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Posterior margins of S2 and S3 notched or stepped laterally; pronotal lobe without carinules in addition to carina (holarctic, Oriental, Africa, Central America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protosmia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): T7 weakly sclerotized, not exposed, hidden by large T6

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protosmia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Scutellum not carinate, without such a posterior marginal zone; clypeus without longitudinal carina, or carina not continued dorsally between antennal sockets

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protosmia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Scutellum ﬂat or scarcely convex, not curved down posteriorly and not overhanging metanotum; metanotum medially about on the level of most of scutellum; posterior lateral angle of scutum obtuse

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protosmia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Posterior margins of S2 and S3 not notched or stepped laterally; pronotal lobe with several minute carinules behind and parallel to carina, carina rarely absent but carinules present (except carinules absent in subgenus Dolichosmiafrom Burma) (holarctic, Burma)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Osmia (in part) of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): T7 strongly sclerotized, exposed though sometimes small

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Osmia (in part) of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Males)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Parapsidal line punctiform or rarely short-linear, oneﬁfth as long as tegula or usually less (Fig. 81-2a); S3 of male commonly emarginate with fringe in emargination, the middle of S3 being largely or wholly covered by an enlarged S2, and S4 neither emarginate nor fringed like S3 (but some have S2 and S3 transverse and similar to one another); body commonly with some greenish or bluish metallic color (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Afroheriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Posterolateral corner of scutum with marginal ridge not carinate, a dense patch of long pubescence on lateral surface (T6 with translucent apical lip extending beyond hairs and projecting at strong angle to surface of tergum) (South Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ochreriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Posterolateral corner of scutum with strong marginal carina, pubescence absent lateral to carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ochreriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Apical part of labrum without long, erect hairs; body slender, elongate (Fig. 81-6), scutal length at least equal to intertegular distance

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ochreriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Pronotum elevated, scutum thus lacking anterior surface; body (at least metasoma) with yellow or ivory markings (Near East, Namibia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hofferia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Posterolateral corner of scutum with strong marginal carina, pubescence absent lateral to carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hofferia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Apical part of labrum without long, erect hairs; body slender, elongate (Fig. 81-6), scutal length at least equal to intertegular distance

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hofferia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Pronotum medially not attaining level of dorsal scutal surface, anterior end of scutum thus bent down, forming anterior scutal surface; body without yellow or ivory markings

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hofferia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Preoccipital carina complete, reaching hypostomal carina, where it is produced into strong tooth; S6 with acute median apical spine (Mediterranean region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Noteriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Mesopleuron elongate ventrally, as long as scutum or nearly so; mesopleural signum narrowly linear; stigma relatively large, margin within marginal cell convex (as in Fig. 81-1c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Noteriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Posterior edge of scutellum with premarginal carina, surface behind carina a narrow vertical or overhanging zone; clypeus with strong longitudinal carina (Africa, southern Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudoheriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Mesopleuron elongate ventrally, as long as scutum or nearly so; mesopleural signum narrowly linear; stigma relatively large, margin within marginal cell convex (as in Fig. 81-1c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudoheriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Posterior margin of scutellum not carinate, usually without vertical or overhanging marginal zone; clypeus without longitudinal carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudoheriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Hypostomal area margined laterally by carina and fringe of long curled hair; acetabular interspace of mandible with short, oblique secondary ridge (Africa, India, Mediterranean region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stenoheriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Mesopleuron elongate ventrally, as long as scutum or nearly so; mesopleural signum narrowly linear; stigma relatively large, margin within marginal cell convex (as in Fig. 81-1c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stenoheriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Posterior margin of scutellum not carinate, usually without vertical or overhanging marginal zone; clypeus without longitudinal carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stenoheriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Hypostomal area not carinate or fringed laterally; acetabular interspace of mandible without secondary ridge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stenoheriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Mouthparts long, in repose well exceeding proboscidial fossa [except in palearctic Stenoheriades asiaticus (Friese) and coelostoma (Benoist), which have medially emarginate clypeus and bidentate mandibles] (Africa, Mediterranean region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Heriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Mesopleuron elongate ventrally, as long as scutum or nearly so; mesopleural signum narrowly linear; stigma relatively large, margin within marginal cell convex (as in Fig. 81-1c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Heriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Posterior margin of scutellum not carinate, usually without vertical or overhanging marginal zone; clypeus without longitudinal carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Heriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Hypostomal area not carinate or fringed laterally; acetabular interspace of mandible without secondary ridge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Heriades of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Mouthparts short, in repose not or scarcely exceeding proboscidial fossa [palearctic species with clypeus not emarginate medially and mandible with at least three teeth] (holarctic, oriental, Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protosmia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Pronotal lobe carinate (holarctic, Burma)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Othinosmia (in part) of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Pronotal lobe usually not carinate (South Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Othinosmia (Afrosmia) of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Metapleuron with round dorsal projection; S1 with apical spine (East Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hoplosmia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Metapleuron planar, without round dorsal projection; S1 without apical spine (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Wainia(in part) of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Posterior lateral angle of scutum acute or right-angular, and produced posteriorly or in Wainia algoensis (Brauns) upward as strong lamella [except South African W. elizabethae(Friese), in which entire propodeum is densely shagreened] (Africa to Israel and east to the Philippines)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Osmia (Allosmia, some Erythrosmia) of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Metanotum with medial, dorsal spine, or clypeus rugose (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hoplitis (most subgenera) of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Metanotum not spined medially; clypeus not rugose (holarctic, Africa, India)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Haetosmia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): T6 with preapical carina visible through dense pubescence; mouthparts with hooked hairs; clypeus without longitudinal carina (Mediterranean region, East Africa to central Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Wainia (Wainiella) of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): T6 without preapical carina; mouthparts without hooked hairs; clypeus with longitudinal carina, carina sometimes obscured by dense pubescence (southern Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stenosmia of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Omaulus strongly carinate below nearly to midventral line; clypeus and mandibles obscured by dense plumose hair (Egypt to China)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hoplitis (Kumobia) of the Osmiini of the EasternHemisphere (Females)(Based on Griswold and Michener, 1998): Omaulus not carinate below; clypeus and mandibles with hair sparse, not obscuring surfaces (Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Heriades of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Propodeum with narrow horizontal basal zone, set off from declivous posterior surface by a carina, and divided by carinae into a series of large pits (Fig. 81-3); anterior surface of T1 broadly concave and delimited by strong carina; lines delimiting propodeal triangle absent or feeble (holarctic, Mesoamerica)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Osmia of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Propodeum without such a horizontal basal zone (but if pits and a zone set off by a carina are evident, then zone is usually sloping, and anterior surface of T1 is neither broadly concave nor delimited by strong carina); lines delimiting propodeal triangle distinct, at least as sharp changes in sculpturing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Osmia of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Parapsidal lines punctiform (Fig. 81-2a) or at most three times as long as wide; body usually metallic (holarctic, Mesoamerica)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chelostoma of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Propodeum without such a horizontal basal zone (but if pits and a zone set off by a carina are evident, then zone is usually sloping, and anterior surface of T1 is neither broadly concave nor delimited by strong carina); lines delimiting propodeal triangle distinct, at least as sharp changes in sculpturing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chelostoma of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Parapsidal lines linear (Fig. 81-2b); body rarely metallic although sometimes strongly so

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Chelostoma of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Thorax elongate (Fig. 81-6), a line tangent to anterior ends of tegulae is thus near middle of scutum, and ventral proﬁle of mesepisternum, in front of middle coxa, is as long as dorsoventral thickness of thorax (seen in lateral view); apex of marginal cell curving away from wing margin only at extreme apex (Fig. 81-1c); S6 of male fully exposed; labrum of female with few and inconspicuous erect setae, thus often appearing hairless (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protosmia of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Propodeum without such a horizontal basal zone (but if pits and a zone set off by a carina are evident, then zone is usually sloping, and anterior surface of T1 is neither broadly concave nor delimited by strong carina); lines delimiting propodeal triangle distinct, at least as sharp changes in sculpturing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protosmia of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Parapsidal lines linear (Fig. 81-2b); body rarely metallic although sometimes strongly so

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protosmia of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Thorax less elongate (Figs. 81-8, 81-10), a line tangent to anterior ends of tegulae is thus considerably anterior to middle of scutum, and ventral proﬁle of mesepisternum, in front of middle coxa, is much shorter than dorsoventral thickness of thorax; apex of marginal cell usually curving away from wing margin in apical oneeighth or more of cell; S6 of male usually concealed or only its apical margin exposed; labrum of female with numerous erect setae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protosmia of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Posterior lobe of pronotum with several small vertical carinulae parallel to posterior margin; clypeus of female with apical, somewhat spatulate, slender horn (Fig. 8113); T6 of male with median apical rounded ﬂange and broad produced angle laterally (T7 of male not exposed) (palearctic; western North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeroheriades of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Propodeum without such a horizontal basal zone (but if pits and a zone set off by a carina are evident, then zone is usually sloping, and anterior surface of T1 is neither broadly concave nor delimited by strong carina); lines delimiting propodeal triangle distinct, at least as sharp changes in sculpturing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeroheriades of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Parapsidal lines linear (Fig. 81-2b); body rarely metallic although sometimes strongly so

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeroheriades of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Thorax less elongate (Figs. 81-8, 81-10), a line tangent to anterior ends of tegulae is thus considerably anterior to middle of scutum, and ventral proﬁle of mesepisternum, in front of middle coxa, is much shorter than dorsoventral thickness of thorax; apex of marginal cell usually curving away from wing margin in apical oneeighth or more of cell; S6 of male usually concealed or only its apical margin exposed; labrum of female with numerous erect setae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeroheriades of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Posterior lobe of pronotum usually without carinulae [but with carinulae in Hoplitis (Alcidamea) pilosifrons (Cresson) and others]; clypeus of female without apical horn; T6 of male not as described above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeroheriades of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: S1 of female with strong preapical bilobed process; S6 of female with median and apical spikes; posterior margins of T1 to T3 gently concave middorsally; S5 of male with deep midapical notch, its margin distally bearing a few capitate hairs (S6 of male without ﬂaps such as are found in Hoplitis, broadly exposed; S1 convex in proﬁle, its anterior surface not deﬁned) (California)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ashmeadiella of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Propodeum without such a horizontal basal zone (but if pits and a zone set off by a carina are evident, then zone is usually sloping, and anterior surface of T1 is neither broadly concave nor delimited by strong carina); lines delimiting propodeal triangle distinct, at least as sharp changes in sculpturing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ashmeadiella of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Parapsidal lines linear (Fig. 81-2b); body rarely metallic although sometimes strongly so

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ashmeadiella of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Thorax less elongate (Figs. 81-8, 81-10), a line tangent to anterior ends of tegulae is thus considerably anterior to middle of scutum, and ventral proﬁle of mesepisternum, in front of middle coxa, is much shorter than dorsoventral thickness of thorax; apex of marginal cell usually curving away from wing margin in apical oneeighth or more of cell; S6 of male usually concealed or only its apical margin exposed; labrum of female with numerous erect setae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ashmeadiella of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: Posterior lobe of pronotum usually without carinulae [but with carinulae in Hoplitis (Alcidamea) pilosifrons (Cresson) and others]; clypeus of female without apical horn; T6 of male not as described above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ashmeadiella of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: S1 of female without strong preapical process; S6 of female without spikes or rarely with midapical spike; posterior margins of T1 to T3 straight middorsally; S5 of male not deeply notched, without capitate hairs on margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ashmeadiella of the Osmiini of the WesternHemisphere: S2 and S3 of male similar to one another; S5 and S6 of male hidden, largely membranous, only transverse apical marginal areas and lateral margins somewhat sclerotized, these sterna with large, basal, minutely hairy areas invaginated anteriorly into metasoma; distance from ﬁrst submarginal crossvein to ﬁrst recurrent usually twice distance from second recurrent vein to second submarginal crossvein (Fig. 81-1a); anterior surface of mesepisternum in front of omaulus smooth, shining, lower part usually sharply divided at omaulus from outer surface, lower part of omaulus carinate (except in subgenus Isosmia); male T6 with four strong teeth (Fig. 81-4) (except in subgenus Isosmia) (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Isosmia) of Ashmeadiella: Omaulus not carinate; T6 of male not toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chilosima) of Ashmeadiella: Omaulus carinate below; T6 of male with four teeth (Fig. 81-4)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chilosima) of Ashmeadiella: Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chilosima) of Ashmeadiella: Mandible tridentate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cubitognatha, Arogochila) of Ashmeadiella: Omaulus carinate below; T6 of male with four teeth (Fig. 81-4)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cubitognatha, Arogochila) of Ashmeadiella: Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cubitognatha, Arogochila) of Ashmeadiella: Mandible bidentate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cubitognatha, Arogochila) of Ashmeadiella: Lateral margin of T6 distinctly and rather evenly convex, ending at nearly right-angular apex of lateral tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ashmeadiella s. str.) of Ashmeadiella: Omaulus carinate below; T6 of male with four teeth (Fig. 81-4)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ashmeadiella s. str.) of Ashmeadiella: Females

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ashmeadiella s. str.) of Ashmeadiella: Outer side of mandible, as measured along lower carina, at most twice as long as scape [except in the group of A. (A.) cubiceps(Cresson)]; clypeus produced over base of labrum, clypeal apex usually truncate; well-developed pair of orange brushes beneath clypeal margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ashmeadiella s. str.) of Ashmeadiella: Omaulus carinate below; T6 of male with four teeth (Fig. 81-4)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ashmeadiella s. str.) of Ashmeadiella: Females

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ashmeadiella s. str.) of Ashmeadiella: Outer side of mandible, as measured along lower carina, at most twice as long as scape [except in the group of A. (A.) cubiceps(Cresson)]; clypeus produced over base of labrum, clypeal apex usually truncate; well-developed pair of orange brushes beneath clypeal margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cubitognatha) of Ashmeadiella: Omaulus carinate below; T6 of male with four teeth (Fig. 81-4)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cubitognatha) of Ashmeadiella: Females

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cubitognatha) of Ashmeadiella: Outer side of mandible, as measured along lower carina, more than twice as long as scape; clypeus produced or not over base of labrum, but if produced, then not simply truncate; orange brushes beneath clypeal margin reduced or absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Cubitognatha) of Ashmeadiella: Mandible bidentate, parallel-sided, elbowed; clypeal margin impunctate, upper margin protuberant

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Atoposmia s. str.) of Atoposmia: Proboscis in repose extending behind fore coxa; ﬁrst segment of labial palpus less than one-fourth as long as second

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hexosmia) of Atoposmia: Proboscis in repose hardly reaching fore coxa; ﬁrst segment of labial palpus over one-half as long as second

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Hexosmia) of Atoposmia: Body with weak greenish tints; T6 of the male without lateral tooth or angle, or rarely with obtuse angle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Eremosmia) of Atoposmia: Proboscis in repose hardly reaching fore coxa; ﬁrst segment of labial palpus over one-half as long as second

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Eremosmia) of Atoposmia: Body without greenish tints; T6 of male with lateral tooth or strong rounded angle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Gyrodromella) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Third segment of labial palpus ﬂattened, its axis a continuation of that of second; T7 of male with dorsal pit

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Gyrodromella) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Preoccipital carina present; propodeum with sloping basal zone little more than one-half as long as metanotum; T1 shallowly concave anteriorly (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Foveosmia) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Third segment of labial palpus ﬂattened, its axis a continuation of that of second; T7 of male with dorsal pit

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Foveosmia) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Preoccipital carina absent; propodeum with horizontal basal zone at least two-thirds as long as metanotum; T1 with anterior surface convex except for longitudinal groove

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Foveosmia) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Parapsidal line half as long as tegula or more; S2 of male without sloping platform, or, if present, then not carinate; labrum of female less than twice as long as broad (longer in C. isabellinum Warncke) (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Chelostoma s. str.) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Third segment of labial palpus ﬂattened, its axis a continuation of that of second; T7 of male with dorsal pit

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Chelostoma s. str.) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Preoccipital carina absent; propodeum with horizontal basal zone at least two-thirds as long as metanotum; T1 with anterior surface convex except for longitudinal groove

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Chelostoma s. str.) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Parapsidal line less than half as long as tegula; S2 of male with median prominence, its posterior surface a ﬂat sloping platform margined by carina; labrum of female elongate, nearly three times as long as broad or more (shorter inC. nasutum Pérez) (palearctic, introduced in nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Prochelostoma) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Third segment of labial palpus not ﬂattened, its axis directed laterally as in most megachilid bees; T7 of male without dorsal pit (male unknown in Ceraheriades)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Prochelostoma) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Hind coxa not carinate (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ceraheriades) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Third segment of labial palpus not ﬂattened, its axis directed laterally as in most megachilid bees; T7 of male without dorsal pit (male unknown in Ceraheriades)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ceraheriades) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Hind coxa with longitudinal carina along inner ventral margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ceraheriades) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): T1 not concave on anterior surface; female mandible elongate, two-toothed; labrum apically thickened (central Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Eochelostoma) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Third segment of labial palpus not ﬂattened, its axis directed laterally as in most megachilid bees; T7 of male without dorsal pit (male unknown in Ceraheriades)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Eochelostoma) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Hind coxa with longitudinal carina along inner ventral margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Eochelostoma) of Chelostoma(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): T1 shallowly concave on anterior surface; female mandible not elongate, three-toothed; labrum not apically thickened (Himalayas to Thailand)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Rhopaloheriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): S1 produced apically, with a brush of ﬁne hair under margin (except in Pachyheriades); S2 depressed basomedially, with a hump or ridge apicolaterally; lateral line of T1 reaching spiracle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Rhopaloheriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): T6 with strong midapical projection below strong rounded carina; S1 produced posteriorly as keeled projection completely covering median part of S2; last antennal segment expanded, wider than preceding segments (central Asia to Israel)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Neotrypetes) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): S1 produced apically, with a brush of ﬁne hair under margin (except in Pachyheriades); S2 depressed basomedially, with a hump or ridge apicolaterally; lateral line of T1 reaching spiracle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Neotrypetes) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): T6 truncate or emarginate, transverse ridge, if present, apical; S1 produced as unkeeled projection not reaching apex of S2; last antennal segment not wider than other segments

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Neotrypetes) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): Mandible with two teeth, though upper one may be broad and truncate; gradulus of S4 procurved medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Neotrypetes) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): Apex of S6 acutely angled; S2 at most angulate laterally, not notched (North and Central America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Michenerella) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): S1 produced apically, with a brush of ﬁne hair under margin (except in Pachyheriades); S2 depressed basomedially, with a hump or ridge apicolaterally; lateral line of T1 reaching spiracle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Michenerella) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): T6 truncate or emarginate, transverse ridge, if present, apical; S1 produced as unkeeled projection not reaching apex of S2; last antennal segment not wider than other segments

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Michenerella) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): Mandible with two teeth, though upper one may be broad and truncate; gradulus of S4 procurved medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Michenerella) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): Apex of S6 bilobate, truncate, or rounded; S2 distinctly notched laterally (Africa, oriental, palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Pachyheriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): S1 produced apically, with a brush of ﬁne hair under margin (except in Pachyheriades); S2 depressed basomedially, with a hump or ridge apicolaterally; lateral line of T1 reaching spiracle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Pachyheriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): T6 truncate or emarginate, transverse ridge, if present, apical; S1 produced as unkeeled projection not reaching apex of S2; last antennal segment not wider than other segments

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Pachyheriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): Mandible with three teeth; gradulus of S4 straight, not procurved medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Pachyheriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): S2 without distinct fringe, at most with scattered hairs much shorter than hind basitarsal width; apical area of S2 transversely depressed below level of disc; basal zone of propodeum bounded posteriorly by a distinct carina that extends laterally behind spiracle; metanotum shallowly notched medially (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (T oxeriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): S1 produced apically, with a brush of ﬁne hair under margin (except in Pachyheriades); S2 depressed basomedially, with a hump or ridge apicolaterally; lateral line of T1 reaching spiracle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (T oxeriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): T6 truncate or emarginate, transverse ridge, if present, apical; S1 produced as unkeeled projection not reaching apex of S2; last antennal segment not wider than other segments

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (T oxeriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): Mandible with three teeth; gradulus of S4 straight, not procurved medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (T oxeriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): S2 with strong fringe of hair at least as long as width of hind basitarsus; apical area of S2 not depressed below level of disc; basal zone of propodeum not bounded posteriorly by a carina, or carina extremely weak, no carina posterior to spiracle; metanotum not notched medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (T oxeriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): T6 with strong longitudinal crest abruptly terminated by a V-shaped, ﬂattened apical area; mandible and hypostoma clothed in dense pubescence obscuring integument (southern Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Tyttheriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): S1 produced apically, with a brush of ﬁne hair under margin (except in Pachyheriades); S2 depressed basomedially, with a hump or ridge apicolaterally; lateral line of T1 reaching spiracle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Tyttheriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): T6 truncate or emarginate, transverse ridge, if present, apical; S1 produced as unkeeled projection not reaching apex of S2; last antennal segment not wider than other segments

Title: Bees Of The World

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Tyttheriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): Mandible with three teeth; gradulus of S4 straight, not procurved medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Tyttheriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): S2 with strong fringe of hair at least as long as width of hind basitarsus; apical area of S2 not depressed below level of disc; basal zone of propodeum not bounded posteriorly by a carina, or carina extremely weak, no carina posterior to spiracle; metanotum not notched medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Tyttheriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): T6 without longitudinal crest, contour not abruptly changed or ﬂattened near margin; mandible with sparse hair not concealing surface, but hypostoma with narrow longitudinal strip of short plumose hair obscuring integument, surface otherwise visible (southern Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Amboheriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): S1 not produced apically, without a brush of hair under margin; S2 not depressed basomedially, without hump or ridge apicolaterally; lateral line of T1 not reaching spiracle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Amboheriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): Frons and interantennal area with pair of juxtantennal carinae; T6 emarginate medially; T6 with Uor V-shaped raised area medially, without parallel-sided crest; S2 not notched laterally (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Heriades s. str.) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): S1 not produced apically, without a brush of hair under margin; S2 not depressed basomedially, without hump or ridge apicolaterally; lateral line of T1 not reaching spiracle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Heriades s. str.) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): Frons and interantennal area without juxtantennal carinae; T6 not emarginate medially and/or T6 medially with parallel-sided longitudinal crest (palearctic, Africa, India)

Title: Bees Of The World

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Tyttheriades) of Heriades (Males)(Modiﬁed from Griswold, 1985): T6 without longitudinal crest, contour not abruptly changed or ﬂattened near margin; mandible with sparse hair not concealing surface, but hypostoma with narrow longitudinal strip of short plumose hair obscuring integument, surface otherwise visible (southern Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Annosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Thorax steeply declivous behind posterior part of scutellum; apical spines of fore and middle tibiae each simple (palearctic to Sudan)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Coloplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Labial palpus two-segmented, with abundant long, curled, capitate hair (Iran, Baluchistan)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Eurypariella) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Thorax slanting posteriorly to posterior part of basal area of propodeum, behind which propodeum is steeply declivous; apical spines of fore and middle tibiae robust, each biﬁd or with preapical shoulder (eastern palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplitis s. str.) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): S6 with submarginal carina, sometimes extremely weak and visible only laterally, so that females may not differ appreciably from those of H. (Annosmia) (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Bytinskia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Bytinskia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Females

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Bytinskia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Mandible four-toothed; either clypeus thickened and modiﬁed or scopa reduced, longest hairs shorter than exposed parts of sterna

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Bytinskia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Clypeus neither thickened nor modiﬁed; scopa reduced, sternal hairs appressed, shorter than exposed parts of sterna (eastern Mediterranean; cleptoparasitic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Kumobia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Kumobia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Females

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Kumobia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Mandible four-toothed; either clypeus thickened and modiﬁed or scopa reduced, longest hairs shorter than exposed parts of sterna

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Kumobia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Clypeus thickened, modiﬁed; scopa not reduced, sternal hairs erect (central Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H.
