Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Kumobia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Clypeus thickened, modiﬁed; scopa not reduced, sternal hairs erect (central Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Bytinskia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Bytinskia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Females

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Bytinskia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Mandible four-toothed; either clypeus thickened and modiﬁed or scopa reduced, longest hairs shorter than exposed parts of sterna

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Bytinskia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Clypeus neither thickened nor modiﬁed; scopa reduced, sternal hairs appressed, shorter than exposed parts of sterna (eastern Mediterranean; cleptoparasitic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplitis s. str.) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): S6 with submarginal carina, sometimes extremely weak and visible only laterally, so that females may not differ appreciably from those of H. (Annosmia) (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Coloplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Labial palpus two-segmented, with abundant long, curled, capitate hair (Iran, Baluchistan)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Annosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Thorax steeply declivous behind posterior part of scutellum; apical spines of fore and middle tibiae each simple (palearctic to Sudan)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Eurypariella) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Thorax slanting posteriorly to posterior part of basal area of propodeum, behind which propodeum is steeply declivous; apical spines of fore and middle tibiae robust, each biﬁd or with preapical shoulder (eastern palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Megahoplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Megahoplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Megahoplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Apex of front basitarsus and second tarsal segment with strong, upcurved, capitate setae on outer surface; upper mandibular tooth truncate (Mediterranean region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Formicapis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Formicapis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Formicapis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Mandible three-toothed (long, straight or undulate edge between middle and upper tooth); propodeum and anterior surface of T1 shagreened (northern holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Anthocopa) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Anthocopa) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Anthocopa) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Clypeal margin without notch, rarely with wide, angled emargination; hind tibial spurs slender, straight; fore basitarsus with plumose hair [but hair absent in H. (A.) furcula (Morawitz) and H. (A.) picicornis (Morawitz) and sparse and not evident in worn specimens of H. (A.) matheranensis (Michener)]; outer apex of middle tibia with narrow to broadly rounded lobe (palearctic, Africa, India)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Platosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Platosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Platosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Proboscis in repose not or scarcely extending beyond fossa; clypeus quite ﬂat, not convex above, somewhat ﬂared outward to broad truncation; suture between clypeus and supraclypeal area weak; body form robust, suggesting subgenus Anthocopa (northern Africa to T urkey)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Chlidoplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Chlidoplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Chlidoplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Clypeal margin with narrow, parallel-sided median notch; hind tibial spurs stout, strongly hooked apically; fore basitarsus with simple hair; outer apex of middle tibia with acute spine (T urkey)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Jaxartinula) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Jaxartinula) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Jaxartinula) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Mandible with long, slightly convex margin between second and uppermost teeth, thus possibly fourtoothed; median part of metanotum elevated and strongly convex, attaining level of scutellar convexity, so that line tangent to scutal and scutellar convexities is also tangent to metanotum, as seen in proﬁle (Central and northeastern Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Exanthocopa) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Exanthocopa) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): T7 with shallow middorsal depression or pit; S6 without lateral ﬂaps; anterior surface of T1 with broad concave basin delimited above by transverse line and containing longitudinal median groove (northern Africa).

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Nasutosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Nasutosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Nasutosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Mandible four-toothed; propodeum and anterior surface of T1 shiny (Mediterranean region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Microhoplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Microhoplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Hypostoma shiny, with sparse punctures and hairs, but without differentiated area behind mandibular base and without fringe demarcating this area; fore basitarsus without plumose hairs (Canary Islands)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Prionohoplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Prionohoplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Preoccipital ridge carinate or sharply angled (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Megalosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Megalosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): S2 bearing strong transverse ridge with rather sharp crest; wings with dark papillae beyond closed cells; body with abundant yellow hair forming broad, distinct metasomal tergal bands (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Monumetha) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Monumetha) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Monumetha) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Wings with weak papillae beyond closed cells, papillae not dark; metasoma with weak white hair bands interrupted medially (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Alcidamea) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Alcidamea) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Alcidamea) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Proboscis in repose extending at least a little beyond fossa; clypeus usually somewhat convex above, usually not ﬂared toward truncation [except in H. tridentata (Dufour and Perris), mitis (Nylander), etc.]; suture between clypeus and supraclypeal area usually distinct; body form slender (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Prionohoplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Preoccipital ridge carinate or sharply angled (palearctic)

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Megalosmia) (in part) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Megalosmia) (in part) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Wings strongly stained, especially darkened in marginal cell; pubescence yellow; frons below anterior ocellus impunctate and polished (palearctic)

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Monumetha) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Monumetha) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Wings with weak papillae beyond closed cells, papillae not dark; metasoma with weak white hair bands interrupted medially (holarctic)

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Pentadentosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Pentadentosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Pentadentosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Wings clear or only lightly stained; pubescence white or off-white; frons below anterior ocellus without impunctate polished area (palearctic south to Sudan)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Megalosmia) (in part) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Megalosmia) (in part) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Wings strongly stained, especially darkened in marginal cell; pubescence yellow; frons below anterior ocellus impunctate and polished (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Megahoplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Megahoplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Megahoplitis) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Apex of front basitarsus and second tarsal segment with strong, upcurved, capitate setae on outer surface; upper mandibular tooth truncate (Mediterranean region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Platosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Platosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Platosmia) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Proboscis in repose not or scarcely extending beyond fossa; clypeus quite ﬂat, not convex above, somewhat ﬂared outward to broad truncation; suture between clypeus and supraclypeal area weak; body form robust, suggesting subgenus Anthocopa (northern Africa to T urkey)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Alcidamea) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Base of labrum exposed between closed mandibles and lower margin of clypeus; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to lateral clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (mandible of female rather slender, distinctly narrower at or before middle than at base)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Alcidamea) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Alcidamea) of Hoplitis of the EasternHemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1998): Proboscis in repose extending at least a little beyond fossa; clypeus usually somewhat convex above, usually not ﬂared toward truncation [except in H. tridentata (Dufour and Perris), mitis (Nylander), etc.]; suture between clypeus and supraclypeal area usually distinct; body form slender (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Proteriades) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): S6 with longitudinal median hairy ridge, sometimes extending as median process beyond rest of sternum or consisting primarily of a midapical hairy process; T7 bilobed, sometimes only weakly so [except tridentate with lateral spine longer than median spine in H. (Proteriades) xerophila (Cockerell)]; metasoma commonly partly or wholly red, never metallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Proteriades) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Galeal blade and ﬁrst two segments of labial palpus with numerous strong hairs that are hooked or wavy apically (western nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Acrosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): S6 with longitudinal median hairy ridge, sometimes extending as median process beyond rest of sternum or consisting primarily of a midapical hairy process; T7 bilobed, sometimes only weakly so [except tridentate with lateral spine longer than median spine in H. (Proteriades) xerophila (Cockerell)]; metasoma commonly partly or wholly red, never metallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Acrosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Galeal blade and labial palpus without hooked or wavy hairs (or, in Penteriades, with very few)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Acrosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Basal half of ﬂagellum with some hairs as long as ﬂagellar diameter; apex of last antennal segment produced laterally (western nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Penteriades) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): S6 with longitudinal median hairy ridge, sometimes extending as median process beyond rest of sternum or consisting primarily of a midapical hairy process; T7 bilobed, sometimes only weakly so [except tridentate with lateral spine longer than median spine in H. (Proteriades) xerophila (Cockerell)]; metasoma commonly partly or wholly red, never metallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Penteriades) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Galeal blade and labial palpus without hooked or wavy hairs (or, in Penteriades, with very few)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Penteriades) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Flagellum with all hairs short; apex of last antennal segment unmodiﬁed or rarely tapering to a curved point

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Penteriades) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Proboscis scarcely extending beyond proboscidial fossa in repose; hind coxa with longitudinal carina on inner ventral angle (western nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplitina) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): S6 with longitudinal median hairy ridge, sometimes extending as median process beyond rest of sternum or consisting primarily of a midapical hairy process; T7 bilobed, sometimes only weakly so [except tridentate with lateral spine longer than median spine in H. (Proteriades) xerophila (Cockerell)]; metasoma commonly partly or wholly red, never metallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplitina) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Galeal blade and labial palpus without hooked or wavy hairs (or, in Penteriades, with very few)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplitina) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Flagellum with all hairs short; apex of last antennal segment unmodiﬁed or rarely tapering to a curved point

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplitina) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Proboscis extending well beyond proboscidial fossa in repose; hind coxa without longitudinal carina (western nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Cyrtosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): S6 without longitudinal median hairy ridge or midapical process (but with a tuft of hairs in Monumetha); T7 ending in a truncation, convexity, or point [tridentate with median spine longer than lateral spine in Cyrtosmia and H. (Dasyosmia) biscutellae (Cockerell)]; metasoma black or brownish black, sometimes metallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Cyrtosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Mandible tridentate; T6 with median apical as well as lateral tooth; T7 tapering with three small adjacent teeth (western nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Formicapis) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): S6 without longitudinal median hairy ridge or midapical process (but with a tuft of hairs in Monumetha); T7 ending in a truncation, convexity, or point [tridentate with median spine longer than lateral spine in Cyrtosmia and H. (Dasyosmia) biscutellae (Cockerell)]; metasoma black or brownish black, sometimes metallic

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Formicapis) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Mandible bidentate; T6 without median apical tooth except in Dasyosmia; T7 pointed, rounded, or truncate or, if tridentate (one species of Dasyosmia), then not tapering, teeth widely separated

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Formicapis) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Metanotum approximately on same level as scutellum, a line tangent to scutum and scutellum in proﬁle thus nearly touching metanotum; stigma distinctly broader than prestigma, as measured to wing margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Formicapis) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): First recurrent vein nearly meeting ﬁrst submarginal crossvein; T7 four-lobed (northern holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplitis s. str.) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base; S1 to S5 not modiﬁed (introduced, New York State)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Monumetha) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): S8 elongate, distal process downcurved, ligulate, undersurface with short, modiﬁed hairs; S6 with midapical tuft of spreading hairs; antennal pedicel exposed [partly hidden in H. (M.) spoliata(Provancher)] (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Alcidamea) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Males): S8 without long, downcurved distal process, its hairs simple; S6 without tuft of spreading hairs; antennal pedicel largely hidden by invagination into apex of scape (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Penteriades) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Galeal blade and ﬁrst two segments of labial palpus with numerous strong hairs, these hooked or wavy apically; proboscis short, in repose scarcely extending out of proboscidial fossa (T6 not strongly concave in proﬁle; posterior coxa with longitudinal carina on inner ventral angle; metasoma usually partly or wholly red)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Penteriades) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Maxillary palpus ﬁve-segmented; clypeus with upper two-thirds strongly swollen and shining, nearly impunctate medially (western nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Proteriades) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Galeal blade and ﬁrst two segments of labial palpus with numerous strong hairs, these hooked or wavy apically; proboscis short, in repose scarcely extending out of proboscidial fossa (T6 not strongly concave in proﬁle; posterior coxa with longitudinal carina on inner ventral angle; metasoma usually partly or wholly red)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Proteriades) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Maxillary palpus twoto four-segmented; clypeus uniformly convex, punctures moderately dense to crowded (western nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Robertsonella) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Galeal blade and labial palpus without hooked hairs; proboscis longer, in repose extending well beyond limit of proboscidial fossa (except in Acrosmia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Robertsonella) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Metanotum approximately on same level as scutellum, a line tangent to scutum and scutellum in proﬁle thus nearly touching metanotum; stigma distinctly broader than prestigma, as measured to wing margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Robertsonella) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Mandibular apical width nearly half of mandibular length; mandible tridentate; lower margin of clypeus entire; ﬁrst recurrent vein considerably distal to ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (eastern nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Formicapis) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Galeal blade and labial palpus without hooked hairs; proboscis longer, in repose extending well beyond limit of proboscidial fossa (except in Acrosmia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Formicapis) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Metanotum approximately on same level as scutellum, a line tangent to scutum and scutellum in proﬁle thus nearly touching metanotum; stigma distinctly broader than prestigma, as measured to wing margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Formicapis) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Mandibular apical margin more than half of mandibular length; mandible with two lower apical teeth followed by long undulate margin; lower margin of clypeus with median snoutlike projection; ﬁrst recurrent vein nearly meeting ﬁrst submarginal crossvein (northern holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Monumetha) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Galeal blade and labial palpus without hooked hairs; proboscis longer, in repose extending well beyond limit of proboscidial fossa (except in Acrosmia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Monumetha) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Metanotum depressed below level of scutellum, which curves down posteriorly to meet metanotum, a line tangent to scutum and scutellum in proﬁle thus well above metanotum; stigma smaller, about as broad as prestigma, as measured to wing margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Monumetha) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Mandible clearly four-toothed (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Cyrtosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Galeal blade and labial palpus without hooked hairs; proboscis longer, in repose extending well beyond limit of proboscidial fossa (except in Acrosmia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Cyrtosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Metanotum depressed below level of scutellum, which curves down posteriorly to meet metanotum, a line tangent to scutum and scutellum in proﬁle thus well above metanotum; stigma smaller, about as broad as prestigma, as measured to wing margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Cyrtosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Mandible three-toothed, sometimes with a weak convexity between second and third teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Cyrtosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Median mandibular tooth almost twice as far from upper tooth as from lower tooth, with a weak convexity between median and upper teeth, the convexity sometimes worn so as to yield a long undulating margin above median tooth; S6 with longitudinal median ridge ending in apical tooth (western nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Acrosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Galeal blade and labial palpus without hooked hairs; proboscis longer, in repose extending well beyond limit of proboscidial fossa (except in Acrosmia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Acrosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Metanotum depressed below level of scutellum, which curves down posteriorly to meet metanotum, a line tangent to scutum and scutellum in proﬁle thus well above metanotum; stigma smaller, about as broad as prestigma, as measured to wing margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Acrosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Mandible three-toothed, sometimes with a weak convexity between second and third teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Acrosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Median mandibular tooth more nearly midway between upper and lower teeth; S6 without median longitudinal ridge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Acrosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Proboscis short, in repose not extending beyond proboscidial fossa (western nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplitina) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Galeal blade and labial palpus without hooked hairs; proboscis longer, in repose extending well beyond limit of proboscidial fossa (except in Acrosmia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplitina) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Metanotum depressed below level of scutellum, which curves down posteriorly to meet metanotum, a line tangent to scutum and scutellum in proﬁle thus well above metanotum; stigma smaller, about as broad as prestigma, as measured to wing margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplitina) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Mandible three-toothed, sometimes with a weak convexity between second and third teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplitina) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Median mandibular tooth more nearly midway between upper and lower teeth; S6 without median longitudinal ridge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplitina) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Proboscis longer, in repose extending well beyond proboscidial fossa

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplitina) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): T6 nearly straight in proﬁle; metasoma partly red (western nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Dasyosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Galeal blade and labial palpus without hooked hairs; proboscis longer, in repose extending well beyond limit of proboscidial fossa (except in Acrosmia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Dasyosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Metanotum depressed below level of scutellum, which curves down posteriorly to meet metanotum, a line tangent to scutum and scutellum in proﬁle thus well above metanotum; stigma smaller, about as broad as prestigma, as measured to wing margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Dasyosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Mandible three-toothed, sometimes with a weak convexity between second and third teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Dasyosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Median mandibular tooth more nearly midway between upper and lower teeth; S6 without median longitudinal ridge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Dasyosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Proboscis longer, in repose extending well beyond proboscidial fossa

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Dasyosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): T6 distinctly concave in proﬁle; metasoma without red

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Dasyosmia) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Apex of mandible nearly as broad as eye; distal part of fore wing with minute papillae, median part with very few hairs (western nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplitis s. str.) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Base of labrum exposed when mandibles are closed; lateral basal extremity of labrum connected to clypeal margin by yellowish membrane extending downward beside labral base (introduced, New York State)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Alcidamea) of Hoplitis of the WesternHemisphere (Females): Base of labrum hidden when mandibles are closed; lateral basal angles of labrum without yellowish membrane (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplosmia s. str.) of Hoplosmia (Males): Carina of T6 with numerous spines (Fig. 81-9b); T6 with distinct lateral tooth; T7 produced to median spine (Fig. 81-9b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Paranthocopa) of Hoplosmia (Males): Carina of T6 simple, irregularly crenulate or nodulose (Fig. 81-9c); lateral tooth of T6 absent or very blunt; T7 not produced to spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Paranthocopa) of Hoplosmia (Males): T7 broad, subtruncate, much exserted, exposed part thus as long as T6

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Odontanthocopa) of Hoplosmia (Males): Carina of T6 simple, irregularly crenulate or nodulose (Fig. 81-9c); lateral tooth of T6 absent or very blunt; T7 not produced to spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Odontanthocopa) of Hoplosmia (Males): T7 bidentate or bilobed with median apical emargination (Fig. 81-9c), or rounded, exposed part much shorter than T6

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplosmia s. str.) of Hoplosmia (Males): Carina of T6 simple, irregularly crenulate or nodulose (Fig. 81-9c); lateral tooth of T6 absent or very blunt; T7 not produced to spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplosmia s. str.) of Hoplosmia (Males): Body clothed with off-white hair that does not obscure frons and scutum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplosmia s. str.) of Hoplosmia (Males): Preoccipital margin carinate dorsally; scopal hairs slender, crinkly, not blunted apically; hind basitarsus at least four times as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Paranthocopa) of Hoplosmia (Males): Carina of T6 simple, irregularly crenulate or nodulose (Fig. 81-9c); lateral tooth of T6 absent or very blunt; T7 not produced to spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Paranthocopa) of Hoplosmia (Males): Body clothed with reddish hair that obscures frons and scutum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Paranthocopa) of Hoplosmia (Males): Carina of T6 simple, irregularly crenulate or nodulose (Fig. 81-9c); lateral tooth of T6 absent or very blunt; T7 not produced to spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Paranthocopa) of Hoplosmia (Males): Body clothed with reddish hair that obscures frons and scutum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplosmia s. str.) of Hoplosmia (Males): Carina of T6 simple, irregularly crenulate or nodulose (Fig. 81-9c); lateral tooth of T6 absent or very blunt; T7 not produced to spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplosmia s. str.) of Hoplosmia (Males): Body clothed with off-white hair that does not obscure frons and scutum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Hoplosmia s. str.) of Hoplosmia (Males): Preoccipital margin carinate dorsally; scopal hairs slender, crinkly, not blunted apically; hind basitarsus at least four times as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Odontanthocopa) (in part) of Hoplosmia (Males): Carina of T6 simple, irregularly crenulate or nodulose (Fig. 81-9c); lateral tooth of T6 absent or very blunt; T7 not produced to spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Odontanthocopa) (in part) of Hoplosmia (Males): Body clothed with off-white hair that does not obscure frons and scutum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera H. (Odontanthocopa) (in part) of Hoplosmia (Males): Preoccipital margin not carinate dorsally though rather abruptly angled; scopal hairs stout, smooth, blunted apically; hind basitarsus three times as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Osmia s. str.) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Malar space with minimum length over half basal width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; middle femur somewhat broadened basal to middle by rounded angle on undersurface; penis valves attaining apices of gonoforceps, which are slender and parallel-sided medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Osmia s. str.) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Proboscis of ordinary length, usually not reaching beyond middle of thorax in repose; anterior surface of T1 shagreened; antenna usually reaching propodeum and middle ﬂagellar segments usually over twice as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Monosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Malar space with minimum length over half basal width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; middle femur somewhat broadened basal to middle by rounded angle on undersurface; penis valves attaining apices of gonoforceps, which are slender and parallel-sided medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Monosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Proboscis extremely long, reaching metasoma in repose; anterior surface of T1 shiny; antenna not reaching propodeum, middle ﬂagellar segments less than twice as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Monosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Front tibia with two apical spines, a shorter one posterior to usual single spine; metasomal terga with diffuse pale hairs but no fasciae; S2 large, nearly completely hiding S3, which is emarginate and fringed; T6 entire, T7 with feeble apical emargination

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Orientosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Malar space with minimum length over half basal width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; middle femur somewhat broadened basal to middle by rounded angle on undersurface; penis valves attaining apices of gonoforceps, which are slender and parallel-sided medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Orientosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Proboscis extremely long, reaching metasoma in repose; anterior surface of T1 shiny; antenna not reaching propodeum, middle ﬂagellar segments less than twice as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Orientosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Front tibia with usual single apical spine; metasomal terga with broad apical bands of dense white plumose hairs; S2 not enlarged, S3 fully exposed, not emarginate, with small, dense midapical fringe; T6 with small apical emargination, T7 entire

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Ozbekosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Malar space absent or linear, its minimum length half basal width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment or less; middle femur without rounded premedian angle on undersurface; penis valves not attaining apices of gonoforceps, or, if so, then gonoforceps usually robust and tapering throughout

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Ozbekosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): S4 with posterior margin not thin, with two apical carinae, at least laterally (the distal one being the sternal margin) and intervening narrow hairless groove along margin [often visible only in posterior view, and absent although margin rather thick in a few species such as O. (Pyrosmia) versicolor Latreille and ferruginea Latreille]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Ozbekosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): T7 ending in long, slender, heavily sclerotized, blunttipped process; S2 and S3 similar to one another, both exposed, transverse, each with transverse shining gibbosity, that on S3 broken medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Helicosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Malar space absent or linear, its minimum length half basal width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment or less; middle femur without rounded premedian angle on undersurface; penis valves not attaining apices of gonoforceps, or, if so, then gonoforceps usually robust and tapering throughout

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Helicosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): S4 with posterior margin not thin, with two apical carinae, at least laterally (the distal one being the sternal margin) and intervening narrow hairless groove along margin [often visible only in posterior view, and absent although margin rather thick in a few species such as O. (Pyrosmia) versicolor Latreille and ferruginea Latreille]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Helicosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): T7 relatively short, margin medially emarginate, two-, three-, or rarely four-toothed, rarely entire and rounded; S2 large, covering much of S3, which has fringed emargination, these sterna without gibbosities

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Helicosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Margin of T6 medially projecting posteriorly or with median notch or crenulate; S5 simple, without velvety hair on disc or basal or lateral ridges; S6 without longitudinal groove, margin without projecting lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Pyrosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Malar space absent or linear, its minimum length half basal width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment or less; middle femur without rounded premedian angle on undersurface; penis valves not attaining apices of gonoforceps, or, if so, then gonoforceps usually robust and tapering throughout

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Pyrosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): S4 with posterior margin not thin, with two apical carinae, at least laterally (the distal one being the sternal margin) and intervening narrow hairless groove along margin [often visible only in posterior view, and absent although margin rather thick in a few species such as O. (Pyrosmia) versicolor Latreille and ferruginea Latreille]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Pyrosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): T7 relatively short, margin medially emarginate, two-, three-, or rarely four-toothed, rarely entire and rounded; S2 large, covering much of S3, which has fringed emargination, these sterna without gibbosities

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Pyrosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Margin of T6 medially gently convex, not crenulate or notched; S5 with velvety hair on disc or ridges; S6 with longitudinal groove, margin with projecting lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Hemiosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Malar space absent or linear, its minimum length half basal width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment or less; middle femur without rounded premedian angle on undersurface; penis valves not attaining apices of gonoforceps, or, if so, then gonoforceps usually robust and tapering throughout

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Hemiosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): S4 with posterior margin thin, without double carinae and groove

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Hemiosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Mandible three-toothed, middle tooth well separated from upper tooth by deep notch, upper tooth sometimes broad, truncate or even concave, so that mandible could be considered four-toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Hemiosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): T6 with strong posterolateral tooth; T7 not visible in dorsal view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Neosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Malar space absent or linear, its minimum length half basal width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment or less; middle femur without rounded premedian angle on undersurface; penis valves not attaining apices of gonoforceps, or, if so, then gonoforceps usually robust and tapering throughout

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Neosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): S4 with posterior margin thin, without double carinae and groove

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Neosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Mandible three-toothed, middle tooth well separated from upper tooth by deep notch, upper tooth sometimes broad, truncate or even concave, so that mandible could be considered four-toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Neosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): T6 without posterolateral tooth; T7 visible in dorsal view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Neosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): First ﬂagellar segment at least three times as long as broad; apical margin of S3 with hair-ﬁlled notch

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (T ergosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Malar space absent or linear, its minimum length half basal width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment or less; middle femur without rounded premedian angle on undersurface; penis valves not attaining apices of gonoforceps, or, if so, then gonoforceps usually robust and tapering throughout

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (T ergosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): S4 with posterior margin thin, without double carinae and groove

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (T ergosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Mandible three-toothed, middle tooth well separated from upper tooth by deep notch, upper tooth sometimes broad, truncate or even concave, so that mandible could be considered four-toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (T ergosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): T6 without posterolateral tooth; T7 visible in dorsal view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (T ergosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): First ﬂagellar segment at most two times as long as broad; apical margin of S3, like S2 and S4, transverse, without hair-ﬁlled notch

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Allosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): T7 apically a simple process, much thickened and heavily sclerotized, ﬂattened on dorsal surface and margined almost like a pygidial plate; S2 with ﬂat-topped, bare longitudinal ridge apically almost to margin; maxillary palpus ﬁve-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Erythrosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): T7 biﬁd or bilobed, thin, not particularly heavily sclerotized, not ﬂattened on dorsal surface; S2 apically thin, rounded or feebly emarginate medially, hairy; maxillary palpus four-segmented or with minute apical ﬁfth segment

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Metallinella) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Anterior margin of metanotum sharp, elevated approximately to level of scutellar surface and with space between metanotal crest and posterior margin of scutellum; S2 with posterior margin transverse

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Melanosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Males): Anterior margin of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, which is curved down to metanotal margin; S2 with posterior margin broadly convex, sometimes with small median emargination

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Metallinella) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws cleft, inner ramus shorter than outer; anterior edge of metanotum sharp, elevated approximately to level of scutellar surface; space present between crest of metanotum and scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Osmia s. str.) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Osmia s. str.) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Head with small, usually bare and shiny depression immediately behind lower end of eye, i.e., below posterior margin of eye (body commonly covered with long, loose hairs rarely forming metasomal fasciae)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Helicosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Helicosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Head without small depression immediately behind lower end of eye, although depression directly below or in front of lower end of eye, or occupying much of malar area, sometimes present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Helicosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Depression across mandibular base deep and abruptly set off almost vertically from adjacent ﬂat mandibular surface (Fig. 81-12d); orange hairs beneath clypeal margin arranged in four tufts, except when clypeus is highly modiﬁed, in which case there may be two broad tufts, or no orange hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Monosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Monosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Head without small depression immediately behind lower end of eye, although depression directly below or in front of lower end of eye, or occupying much of malar area, sometimes present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Monosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Depression across mandibular base absent or shallower, rarely completely separated from adjacent mandibular surface by vertical wall [some Melanosmia, e.g., O. nigriventris (Zetterstedt), approach the condition of Helicosmia]; orange hairs under clypeal margin in two tufts or brushes, or absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Monosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Malar space, where shortest, as long as width of pedicel; proboscis extremely long, reaching metasoma in repose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Monosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Front tibia with two apical spines, a short one posterior to usual single spine; metasomal terga with diffuse pale hairs not forming fasciae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Orientosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Orientosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Head without small depression immediately behind lower end of eye, although depression directly below or in front of lower end of eye, or occupying much of malar area, sometimes present

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Orientosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Malar space, where shortest, as long as width of pedicel; proboscis extremely long, reaching metasoma in repose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Orientosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Front tibia with single apical spine; metasomal terga with broad apical fasciae of dense, white plumose hairs.

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Allosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Allosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Malar space, where shortest, much shorter than width of pedicel; proboscis not reaching beyond middle of thorax in repose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Allosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Hind coxa with strong longitudinal carina along inner margin and body nonmetallic, metasoma sometimes red; parapsidal lines usually short-linear, sometimes punctiform; erect tergal hair (middorsally on T2-T3, as seen in proﬁle, ignoring apical tergal margins) sometimes no longer than minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Allosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Maxillary palpus distinctly ﬁve-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Erythrosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Erythrosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Maxillary palpus four-segmented or with minute apical ﬁfth segment

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Neosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Neosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Hind coxa not or weakly carinate, or, if carinate, then body metallic, if with ridge in location of coxal carina (as in some Hemiosmia, Pyrosmia, T ergosmia,etc.), then ridge usually punctate, not raised and shining as in above; parapsidal lines punctiform or sometimes short-linear in T ergosmia;erect tergal hair much longer than minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Neosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): First ﬂagellar segment nearly three to more than three times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Hemiosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum
