Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Hemiosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Hind coxa not or weakly carinate, or, if carinate, then body metallic, if with ridge in location of coxal carina (as in some Hemiosmia, Pyrosmia, T ergosmia,etc.), then ridge usually punctate, not raised and shining as in above; parapsidal lines punctiform or sometimes short-linear in T ergosmia;erect tergal hair much longer than minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Hemiosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): First ﬂagellar segment not over 2.5 times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Hemiosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Anterior trochanter with longitudinal ventral carina or sharp ridge that is most prominent medially so that lower edge of trochanter, in side view, is convex; mandible in ventrolateral view with strong submedian tooth on inner margin of lower edge (mandible four-toothed or approaching that condition because of distinct cutting edge forming tooth in upper interspace)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Pyrosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Hind coxa with longitudinal carina on inner ventral margin; clypeal margin usually with median impression (mandible usually three-toothed without cutting edge in upper interspace)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Melanosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Body frequently slightly to strongly metallic; pubescence often including black or fuscous hairs; mandible commonly four-toothed, usually because of cutting edge in upper interspace

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Ozbekosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Anterior margin of clypeus produced and rounded; impunctate hairless area behind mandibular base overhung by long, curved hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (T ergosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Anterior margin of clypeus produced and truncate; impunctate area behind mandibular base limited and not extensively overhung by long hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Metallinella) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws cleft, inner ramus shorter than outer; anterior edge of metanotum sharp, elevated approximately to level of scutellar surface; space present between crest of metanotum and scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Osmia s. str.) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Osmia s. str.) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Malar space as long as width of scape; small shining depression in genal area below and behind lowermost point of eye margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Helicosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Helicosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Malar area shorter than width of scape, except in forms with anterior clypeal margin greatly swollen; no small shiny depression below eye

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Helicosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Depression across mandibular base deep and abruptly set off almost vertically from adjacent ﬂat mandibular surface (Fig. 81-12d); orange hairs beneath clypeal margin arranged in four tufts, except when clypeus is highly modiﬁed, in which case there may be two broad tufts, or no orange hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Monosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Monosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Malar area shorter than width of scape, except in forms with anterior clypeal margin greatly swollen; no small shiny depression below eye

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Monosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Monosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): S2 transverse, posterior margin feebly concave, straight, to slightly convex; S3 not or weakly emarginate medially, exposed from side to side, posterior margin not or gently concave

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Monosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Front tibia with two apical spines, a short one posterior to usual single spine; metasomal terga with diffuse pale hairs not forming fasciae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Orientosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Orientosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Malar area shorter than width of scape, except in forms with anterior clypeal margin greatly swollen; no small shiny depression below eye

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Orientosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Orientosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): S2 transverse, posterior margin feebly concave, straight, to slightly convex; S3 not or weakly emarginate medially, exposed from side to side, posterior margin not or gently concave

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Orientosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Front tibia with single apical spine; metasomal terga with broad apical fasciae of dense, white plumose hairs.

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Allosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Allosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Malar area shorter than width of scape, except in forms with anterior clypeal margin greatly swollen; no small shiny depression below eye

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Allosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Allosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): S2 large, posterior margin strongly convex; S3 medially hidden by S2, posterior margin broadly emarginate with fringe of long hairs in emargination

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Allosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Maxillary palpus distinctly ﬁve-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Erythrosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Erythrosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Malar area shorter than width of scape, except in forms with anterior clypeal margin greatly swollen; no small shiny depression below eye

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Erythrosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Erythrosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): S2 large, posterior margin strongly convex; S3 medially hidden by S2, posterior margin broadly emarginate with fringe of long hairs in emargination

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Erythrosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Maxillary palpus four-segmented or with minute apical ﬁfth segment

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Neosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Neosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Malar area shorter than width of scape, except in forms with anterior clypeal margin greatly swollen; no small shiny depression below eye

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Neosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Neosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Malar space, where shortest, much shorter than width of pedicel; proboscis not reaching beyond middle of thorax in repose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Neosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Hind coxa not or weakly carinate, or, if carinate, then body metallic, if with ridge in location of coxal carina (as in some Hemiosmia, Pyrosmia, T ergosmia,etc.), then ridge usually punctate, not raised and shining as in above; parapsidal lines punctiform or sometimes short-linear in T ergosmia;erect tergal hair much longer than minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Neosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): First ﬂagellar segment nearly three to more than three times as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Hemiosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O.(Mystacosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Claws simple; anterior edge of metanotum below level of most of scutellum, i.e., scutellar surface curved down to margin of metanotum [except in long-bodied species ofPyrosmia (e.g., O. cephalotes Morawitz) in which metanotum is horizontal, on level with scutellum]; ordinarily no space between edge of metanotum and scutellum

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O.(Mystacosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Malar area shorter than width of scape, except in forms with anterior clypeal margin greatly swollen; no small shiny depression below eye

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O.(Mystacosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Males

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O.(Mystacosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Malar space, where shortest, much shorter than width of pedicel; proboscis not reaching beyond middle of thorax in repose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O.(Mystacosmia) of Osmia of the Eastern Hemi-sphere (Females): Median ﬂagellar segments 1.5 times as long as broad; T6 prolonged medially over T7

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Othinosmia s. str.) of Othinosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): Front tibia with apical spine long, curved posteriorly; S2 not depressed medially, without dense covering of hair; hypostomal area with polished, impunctate area (southern Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Afrosmia) of Othinosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): Front tibia with apical spine short, straight; S2 depressed medially, densely covered with velvety hair; hypostomal area without polished, impunctate area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Afrosmia) of Othinosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): Metapleuron with large dorsal projection; axilla produced to acute angle (Kenya)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Megaloheriades) of Othinosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): Front tibia with apical spine short, straight; S2 depressed medially, densely covered with velvety hair; hypostomal area without polished, impunctate area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Megaloheriades) of Othinosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): Metapleuron without dorsal projection; axilla rounded (southern Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Othinosmia s. str.) of Othinosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): Front tibia with apical spine long, curved posteriorly; S2 not depressed medially, without dense covering of hair; hypostomal area with polished, impunctate area (southern Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Megaloheriades) of Othinosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): Metapleuron without dorsal projection; axilla rounded (southern Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Protosmia s. str.) of Protosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): S1 with large ventral projection; margin of T6 acutely angled laterally; ﬂagellum modiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Protosmia s. str.) of Protosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): Gena with elongate lateroventral fovea or crease; distal ﬂagellar segments stout (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Dolichosmia) of Protosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): S1 with large ventral projection; margin of T6 acutely angled laterally; ﬂagellum modiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Dolichosmia) of Protosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): Gena without lateroventral fovea; distal ﬂagellar segments, except the last, threadlike (Burma)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Chelostomopsis) of Protosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): S1 without ventral projection; margin of T6 not acutely angled laterally; ﬂagellum not modiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Chelostomopsis) of Protosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): T6 in dorsal view with strongly projecting median lobe; pronotal lobe not carinate; S2 with median longitudinal line of short, appressed hairs, these quite different from long, erect hairs of adjacent areas (Mediterranean region, western nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Nanosmia) of Protosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): S1 without ventral projection; margin of T6 not acutely angled laterally; ﬂagellum not modiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Nanosmia) of Protosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): T6 in dorsal view with weakly projecting median lobe; pronotal lobe carinate; S2 without median longitudinal line of short hairs (Mediterranean region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Protosmia s. str.) of Protosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): S1 with large ventral projection; margin of T6 acutely angled laterally; ﬂagellum modiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Chelostomopsis) of Protosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): S1 without ventral projection; margin of T6 not acutely angled laterally; ﬂagellum not modiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Chelostomopsis) of Protosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): T6 in dorsal view with strongly projecting median lobe; pronotal lobe not carinate; S2 with median longitudinal line of short, appressed hairs, these quite different from long, erect hairs of adjacent areas (Mediterranean region, western nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Nanosmia of Protosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): S1 without ventral projection; margin of T6 not acutely angled laterally; ﬂagellum not modiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Nanosmia of Protosmia (Males)(By T erry L. Griswold): T6 in dorsal view with weakly projecting median lobe; pronotal lobe carinate; S2 without median longitudinal line of short hairs (Mediterranean region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera W . (Wainia s. str.) of Wainia: Metasomal pale hair bands of T2 to T4, except laterally on basal terga, immediately behind graduli, not on posterior marginal zones of terga; mandible of male threetoothed (Africa to southern India and the Philippines)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera W . (Wainiella) of Wainia: Metasomal pale hair bands on posterior marginal zones of terga; mandible of male two-toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera W . (Wainiella) of Wainia: Body heriadiform, 6-8 mm long; omaular carina distinct; female clypeus with longitudinal median carina; tibial spurs strongly hooked; labrum of female without well-formed fringe (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera Caposmia of Wainia: Metasomal pale hair bands on posterior marginal zones of terga; mandible of male two-toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera Caposmia of Wainia: Body robust hoplitiform, 8.0-10.5 mm long; omaular carina absent; female without clypeal carina; tibial spurs weakly curved at apices; labrum of female with distinct fringe (southern Africa and Israel)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Anthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Anthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): T5 with posterior marginal zone depressed (except sometimes medially), more ﬁnely punctate than rest of tergum and usually densely so, not over half as wide laterally as medially, this zone ending in very narrow, smooth posterior margin, the anterior margin of depressed zone often obtusely angulate medially, whole zone thus very broadly triangular

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Anthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): T6 of female with margin usually not denticulate, sometimes with lateral tooth, with median apical notch or emargination accommodating sting [margin rarely denticulate, e.g., A. (Proanthidium) oblongatum Latreille]; T5 of female with basal edge of depressed marginal zone commonly obtusely angulate medially, zone thus broadly triangular; penis valves of male widely separated basally, united by long, narrow bridge; volsella projecting as lobe at apex of gonocoxite

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Afranthidium (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Afranthidium (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): T5 with posterior marginal zone either not depressed or weakly to strongly depressed, but if recognizable, then punctate like rest of tergum to impunctate, often over half as wide laterally as medially, this zone often ending in broad, smooth posterior margin, the anterior margin of depressed zone straight or curved, not angulate, or with small basal median angular projection

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Afranthidium (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): First recurrent vein entering second submarginal cell; axillar margin rounded or straight; face without longitudinal median ridge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Afranthidium (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Basal area of propodeum with hairs, sometimes very short; pale markings usually present, but if not [as in Gnathanthidium and Afranthidium (Immanthidium), etc.], then scutellum usually angulate laterally and terga with impunctate marginal zones

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Afranthidium (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Preoccipital ridge and omaulus rounded or at most carinate (except preoccipital ridge lamellate inGnathanthidium)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Afranthidium (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Subantennal suture straight or weakly arcuate; S4 and S5 of male not strongly concave, rather simple, S3 to S5 without combs or areas of specialized bristles, posterior margins straight or weakly concave (with lateral projections in Neanthidium and on S5 in Gnathanthidium)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Afranthidium (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): T6 of male simple, T7 short, bidentate, bilobed, or tridentate; S4 and S5 without lateral projections or (in Gnathanthidium) S5 with such projections; T6 of female without or with very weak lateral spine and median emargination

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Afranthidium (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with eight teeth or less; scutellum rounded as seen from above, sometimes weakly emarginate medially, not or incompletely carinate; tibiae tuberculate or not (Africa, palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Serapista of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Serapista of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): First recurrent vein joining ﬁrst submarginal cell; axilla acutely pointed; face with shiny longitudinal median ridge from frons to clypeus (Africa)

Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Anthidioma of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Basal area of propodeum hairless except laterally; pale markings absent; scutellum not angulate laterally; terga without impunctate margins (male unknown) (Africa)

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Neanthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): T6 and T7 of male each with four large equidistant teeth; S4 and S5 of male with lateral projections; T6 of female with lateral spine and median emargination (length 9-13 mm) (Mediterranean)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Gnathanthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): T6 of male simple, T7 short, bidentate, bilobed, or tridentate; S4 and S5 without lateral projections or (in Gnathanthidium) S5 with such projections; T6 of female without or with very weak lateral spine and median emargination

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Gnathanthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 13 or 14 teeth, apex broad, lower two teeth and upper one large, others small and subequal; scutellum transverse, truncate, carinate; tibiae coarsely tuberculate (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Afranthidium (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Afranthidium (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): T6 of male simple, T7 short, bidentate, bilobed, or tridentate; S4 and S5 without lateral projections or (in Gnathanthidium) S5 with such projections; T6 of female without or with very weak lateral spine and median emargination

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Afranthidium (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with eight teeth or less; scutellum rounded as seen from above, sometimes weakly emarginate medially, not or incompletely carinate; tibiae tuberculate or not (Africa, palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Indanthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): T7 of male nearly as wide as T6, multidentate; subantennal suture arising at upper end of tentorial pit (S3 of male without wavy bristles; S5 with margin strongly concave but no lateral projections) (India)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudoanthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): T7 of male markedly narrower than T6, twoor threetoothed or lobed; subantennal suture arising from epistomal suture well above tentorial pit [except in P. (Royanthidium) reticulatum Mocsáry]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Aspidosmia of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Hind tibia of female with scopa-like hairs, some of them at least as long as tibial width; basal vein of forewing curved (as in Halictus but less strongly) and meeting vein Cu at a right angle; jugal lobe of hind wing about half as long as vannal lobe (y ellow markings absent except on clypeus of male) (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Icteranthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Lower part of preoccipital carina sloping forward and continuing directly to lower mandibular articulation; axilla frequently pointed posteriorly (anterior coxa with lamella in most species; hind trochanter of male with preapical ridge, carina, lamella or tooth on inner surface; arolia absent) (palearctic, Sahel)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Euaspis of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Face with three longitudinal ridges or carinae, two of them juxtantennal carinae and the third—a median longitudinal one on frons and supraclypeal area—often only a shiny ridge (body without yellow markings)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Trachusoides of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Claws of female simple (male unknown) (India)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Trachusa of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): T7 of male curled under, dorsal surface thus facing downward; mandible of female dull, minutely roughened and bearing very short hairs, carinae absent on basal half of mandible; middle tibia with anterior margin strongly convex, at lowermost extremity usually at right angle to line across distal end of tibia (Fig. 82-4c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Apianthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): T7 of male directed posteriorly although small, short, and transverse; mandible of female slightly shining, carinae strongly shining; middle tibia with anterior margin less strongly convex, at acute angle to line across distal end of tibia (Borneo)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Acedanthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Anterior part of axilla produced to a point or lobe directed laterally, behind which margin is concave; margin of T7 of male with median point and two lobes on each side, thus with ﬁve apical projections (India)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Larinostelis of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Larinostelis of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Axilla positioned and produced laterally, thus almost abutting posterior end of tegula; arolia absent; scopa absent (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eoanthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eoanthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Juxtantennal carinae present although sometimes weak; interantennal distance usually less than, rarely equal to, antennocular distance; S6 of female (except in subgenusClistanthidium) with spine or premarginal ridge, sometimes weak and lateral only, sternal margin thus appearing thick, sometimes elevated to lateral tooth (T7 of male over half as wide as T6) (palearctic, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Cyphanthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Cyphanthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): T6 of male with median apical tooth or small projection; body length 8.5 mm or less and metasoma with continuous yellow bands [form and coloration as in Afranthidium (Oranthidium)] (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Plesianthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Plesianthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Yellow or cream markings absent or limited to face of male; T3 and other terga with depressed premarginal zone sublaterally nearly one-half length of exposed part of tergum; T6 of male with median lobe (often subtruncate and elevated) and lateral tooth, thus triﬁd or (in subgenusSpinanthidiellum) truncate with a longitudinal median ridge at apex (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Benanthis of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Benanthis of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Apex of T7 of male strongly bilobed; S4 and S5 of male simple, without combs or lateral teeth, margin of S6 with lateral lobe resembling a tooth in side view; ocelloccipital distance about equal to ocellar diameter (Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhodanthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhodanthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Apex of T7 of male with a median projection, thus with three projections (or ﬁve in subgenus Meganthidium); S4 or S5 of male frequently with marginal comb, S5 often with lateral tooth, S6 without lateral projection; ocelloccipital distance two or more ocellar diameters (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Bathanthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Bathanthidium of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Omaular carina absent or extending down only to middle of mesepisternum; T7 of male, if trilobed, then with median lobe much longer than lateral lobe or spine; subantennal suture straight (eastern Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Anthidiellum (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Anthidiellum (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Omaular carina strong, sometimes lamellate, and extending onto ventral surface of thorax, sometimes across venter (except in subgenus Clypanthidium, in which omaular carina does not reach lower part of mesepisternum); T7 of male, if trilobed, then with median lobe small, either not separated from lateral lobe by emargination or not longer than lateral lobe; subantennal suture usually arcuate outward (Fig. 82-5c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stelis (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Stelis (in part) of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): T egula of ordinary size and shape, widest medially and longer than wide (scutum wider than long, only moderately so in subgenus Stelidomorpha)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Afrostelis of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Afrostelis of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Scutum longer than wide; body without yellow markings (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xenostelis of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Mandible of female with 5 to 18, usually sharp teeth separated by acute notches (Fig. 82-3a) or (in one species of Pachyanthidium) minutely denticulate; maxillary palpus minute [relatively long in Afranthidium (Zosteranthidium)], two-segmented (arolia absent; base of propodeal triangle punctate or ﬁnely roughened, nearly always hairy; propodeum without basal series of pits and without fovea behind spiracle; juxtantennal carina absent) (Series B)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xenostelis of the Anthidiini of the EasternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Michener and Griswold, 1994a)(See also the Supplementary Characteristics to Males, below.): Scutum slightly broader than long; metasoma with yellow markings (Yeman)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Males of the Anthidiine Gen-era of the Eastern Hemisphere(From Griswold and Michener, 1994a)The preceding key will be frustrating for various reasons,chief among which will likely be that couplet 1 is basedlargely on a character of females; supplementary charac-ters will help, but as indicated within the couplet, they arenot always decisive. The following supplementary key formales leads either to certain genera or to numbered cou-plets in the main key, thus bypassing couplet 1. In reality,its main function is to help identify males of taxa thatshould run to 11 in the main key and that lack arolia, asdo all taxa that run to 2. A. Arolia absent.................................................................. B—. Arolia present .................................................... go to11B(A). Paleotropical species ................................................ C—. Palearctic species .................................................. go to2C(B). Vein cu-v of hind wing more than half as long as second abscissa of M /H11001Cu, oblique (as in Fig. 82-1a); middle tibia as broad as hind tibia or nearly so .............. D—. Vein cu-v of hind wing less than half as long as secondabscissa of M/H11001Cu (as in Fig. 82-1b, c), oblique or trans-verse; middle tibia narrower than hind tibia.................... ED(C). T7 curled under, dorsal surface thus facing down-ward; middle tibia with anterior margin stronglycurved, at lowermost extremity thus usually at right an-gle to line across distal end of tibia (Fig. 82-4c) ..........................................................................Trachusa(in part)—. T7 directed posteriorly although small, short, and trans-verse; middle tibia with anterior margin less strongly con-vex, thus at acute angle to line across distal end of tibia(as in Fig. 82-4d, e) ....................................ApianthidiumE(C). Axilla almost entirely lateral to lateral margin of scu-tum; outer, apical margins of fore and middle tibiae eachwith two minute spines (placed on basis of female char-acters; male unknown) ....................................Larinostelis—. Axilla at most extending slightly lateral to lateral mar-gin of scutum; outer, apical margins of fore and middletibiae each with at most one spine .................................. FF(E). Omaulus carinate for at least three-fourths of distance from upper end to midventral line ................................ G—. Omaulus not carinate, or carinate for no more than one-half of distance from upper end to midventral line ............................................................................ go to 2G(F). Preoccipital carina present dorsally, behind vertex .... H—. Preoccipital carina absent dorsally, behind vertex .......... IH(G). Hind tibia tuberculate on outer surface; scutellumvery short, width greater than four times length, onlyslightly overhanging metanotum (for one-third itslength) ..................................................Gnathanthidium—. Hind tibia not tuberculate; scutellum moderately long,width equal to or less than three times length, greatlyoverhanging metanotum (for one-half its length) ............................................................ Pachyanthidium (in part)I(G). Juxtantennal carinae present (as in Fig. 82-5a); T7broadly truncate with small median projection.................................................................... Eoanthidium (in part)—. Juxtantennal carinae absent (as in Fig. 82-5c); T7 withthree apical spines .............................................. SerapistaCharacteristics to the Genera B of the Anthidiini of the WesternHemisphere: In reality, its main function is to help identify males of taxa that should run to 11 in the main key and that lack arolia, as do all taxa that run to 2. A. Arolia absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Immanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Marginal zones of T2 to T5 broadly impunctate, median lengths of impunctate zones usually one-sixth length of exposed parts of terga or more, these zones transparent, pale brown or cream-colored; male gonostylus enormous, broad, ﬂat, and almost membranous; pronotal lobe not carinate, sometimes with small punctate and hairy ridge in position of carina (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Zosteranthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Marginal zones of T2 to T5 punctate or narrowly impunctate, median lengths of impunctate zones about one-seventh lengths of exposed parts of terga or less, these zones dark or translucent brownish; male gonostylus neither broad nor ﬂat nor almost membranous although sometimes broadly paddle-shaped; pronotal lobe usually with transverse carina or low lamella that is hairless even when it extends only partway across lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Zosteranthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Scutellum and axilla laterally not much overhanging as seen obliquely so as to show proﬁles; scutellum rounded in proﬁle, not or scarcely overhanging metanotum; outer surfaces of tibiae not more coarsely punctate than mesepisternum, not tuberculate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Zosteranthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): T2 to T5 with apical bands, broken medially, of white plumose hair; propodeal triangle with punctures (and hairs) widely separated from one another, surface between punctures strongly shagreened, dull; body and legs black, without pale markings (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Nigranthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Marginal zones of T2 to T5 punctate or narrowly impunctate, median lengths of impunctate zones about one-seventh lengths of exposed parts of terga or less, these zones dark or translucent brownish; male gonostylus neither broad nor ﬂat nor almost membranous although sometimes broadly paddle-shaped; pronotal lobe usually with transverse carina or low lamella that is hairless even when it extends only partway across lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Nigranthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Scutellum and axilla laterally not much overhanging as seen obliquely so as to show proﬁles; scutellum rounded in proﬁle, not or scarcely overhanging metanotum; outer surfaces of tibiae not more coarsely punctate than mesepisternum, not tuberculate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Nigranthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): T2 to T5 without apical hair bands; propodeal triangle rather densely punctate and hairy, surface between punctures shining; body and legs usually with yellow or white markings, but if not, then at least anterior surfaces of front and middle tibiae brownish yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Nigranthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Hind basitarsus of female with apical projection over base of second tarsal segment; hind trochanter of male with apicoventral denticle; sterna of male with distinct basal hair fasciae arising at graduli; body black, with yellow or cream color usually limited to minute streak along inner margin of eye of both sexes (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Domanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Marginal zones of T2 to T5 punctate or narrowly impunctate, median lengths of impunctate zones about one-seventh lengths of exposed parts of terga or less, these zones dark or translucent brownish; male gonostylus neither broad nor ﬂat nor almost membranous although sometimes broadly paddle-shaped; pronotal lobe usually with transverse carina or low lamella that is hairless even when it extends only partway across lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Domanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Scutellum and axilla laterally not much overhanging as seen obliquely so as to show proﬁles; scutellum rounded in proﬁle, not or scarcely overhanging metanotum; outer surfaces of tibiae not more coarsely punctate than mesepisternum, not tuberculate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Domanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): T2 to T5 without apical hair bands; propodeal triangle rather densely punctate and hairy, surface between punctures shining; body and legs usually with yellow or white markings, but if not, then at least anterior surfaces of front and middle tibiae brownish yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Domanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Hind basitarsus of female with apex truncate, without apical projection; hind trochanter of male without apicoventral denticle; sterna of male without basal hair fasciae; body brown or black with yellow or cream-colored areas at least on face of male and metasomal terga of both sexes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Domanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): T5 of female without lateral spine; T1 of female with carina separating anterior from dorsal surfaces abruptly strengthened laterally and thence extended lateroposteriorly; apex of T7 of male with two lobes, each lobe two or three times as broad as long, emargination between them with small median spine; S6 of male with small, pointed midapical process at base of which are two spines directed forward (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oranthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Marginal zones of T2 to T5 punctate or narrowly impunctate, median lengths of impunctate zones about one-seventh lengths of exposed parts of terga or less, these zones dark or translucent brownish; male gonostylus neither broad nor ﬂat nor almost membranous although sometimes broadly paddle-shaped; pronotal lobe usually with transverse carina or low lamella that is hairless even when it extends only partway across lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oranthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Scutellum and axilla laterally not much overhanging as seen obliquely so as to show proﬁles; scutellum rounded in proﬁle, not or scarcely overhanging metanotum; outer surfaces of tibiae not more coarsely punctate than mesepisternum, not tuberculate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oranthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): T2 to T5 without apical hair bands; propodeal triangle rather densely punctate and hairy, surface between punctures shining; body and legs usually with yellow or white markings, but if not, then at least anterior surfaces of front and middle tibiae brownish yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oranthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Hind basitarsus of female with apex truncate, without apical projection; hind trochanter of male without apicoventral denticle; sterna of male without basal hair fasciae; body brown or black with yellow or cream-colored areas at least on face of male and metasomal terga of both sexes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oranthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): T5 of female with lateral spine; T1 carina of female unmodiﬁed; apex of T7 of male two-lobed, usually with median angle or tooth, or three-lobed, each lateral lobe about as long as broad or longer; S6 of male without small apical process and spines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Oranthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Gonostylus of male tapering, not or scarcely longer than gonocoxite, not attaining middle of penis valve; ventral surface of mesepisternum of female covered with strong, backward-directed, golden to black bristles that appear ﬂattened, minutely barbed, and blunt or abruptly tapered at apices (S6 of male elongate, produced to narrowly rounded or bidentate apex) (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Afranthidium s. str.) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Marginal zones of T2 to T5 punctate or narrowly impunctate, median lengths of impunctate zones about one-seventh lengths of exposed parts of terga or less, these zones dark or translucent brownish; male gonostylus neither broad nor ﬂat nor almost membranous although sometimes broadly paddle-shaped; pronotal lobe usually with transverse carina or low lamella that is hairless even when it extends only partway across lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Afranthidium s. str.) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Scutellum and axilla laterally not much overhanging as seen obliquely so as to show proﬁles; scutellum rounded in proﬁle, not or scarcely overhanging metanotum; outer surfaces of tibiae not more coarsely punctate than mesepisternum, not tuberculate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Afranthidium s. str.) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): T2 to T5 without apical hair bands; propodeal triangle rather densely punctate and hairy, surface between punctures shining; body and legs usually with yellow or white markings, but if not, then at least anterior surfaces of front and middle tibiae brownish yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Afranthidium s. str.) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Hind basitarsus of female with apex truncate, without apical projection; hind trochanter of male without apicoventral denticle; sterna of male without basal hair fasciae; body brown or black with yellow or cream-colored areas at least on face of male and metasomal terga of both sexes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Afranthidium s. str.) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): T5 of female with lateral spine; T1 carina of female unmodiﬁed; apex of T7 of male two-lobed, usually with median angle or tooth, or three-lobed, each lateral lobe about as long as broad or longer; S6 of male without small apical process and spines

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Afranthidium s. str.) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Gonostylus of male expanded apically, about twice as long as gonocoxite, attaining apex of penis valve or nearly so; ventral surface of mesepisternum of female with pale, gradually tapering hairs similar to hairs of adjacent areas (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Mesanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Marginal zones of T2 to T5 punctate or narrowly impunctate, median lengths of impunctate zones about one-seventh lengths of exposed parts of terga or less, these zones dark or translucent brownish; male gonostylus neither broad nor ﬂat nor almost membranous although sometimes broadly paddle-shaped; pronotal lobe usually with transverse carina or low lamella that is hairless even when it extends only partway across lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Mesanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Scutellum laterally and usually axilla overhanging large fossa and usually acute or narrowly rounded, as seen obliquely so as to show proﬁle of lateral part of scutellum and of axilla; scutellum acute, right-angular, or sometimes rounded in proﬁle, medially often strongly overhanging metanotum; outer surfaces of tibiae, especially of female, coarsely, irregularly punctate, sometimes with extensive smooth areas between punctures, the punctures commonly coarser than those of mesepisternum, surfaces usually tuberculate (but not or weakly so in Capanthidium and Mesanthidium)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Mesanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Posterior margins of metasomal terga not curved upward, lying near surfaces of following terga; axilla extending laterally beyond scutal margin; male gonostylus greatly reduced, attaining about middle of penis valves, which are completely fused to one another (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Xenanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Marginal zones of T2 to T5 punctate or narrowly impunctate, median lengths of impunctate zones about one-seventh lengths of exposed parts of terga or less, these zones dark or translucent brownish; male gonostylus neither broad nor ﬂat nor almost membranous although sometimes broadly paddle-shaped; pronotal lobe usually with transverse carina or low lamella that is hairless even when it extends only partway across lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Xenanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Scutellum laterally and usually axilla overhanging large fossa and usually acute or narrowly rounded, as seen obliquely so as to show proﬁle of lateral part of scutellum and of axilla; scutellum acute, right-angular, or sometimes rounded in proﬁle, medially often strongly overhanging metanotum; outer surfaces of tibiae, especially of female, coarsely, irregularly punctate, sometimes with extensive smooth areas between punctures, the punctures commonly coarser than those of mesepisternum, surfaces usually tuberculate (but not or weakly so in Capanthidium and Mesanthidium)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Xenanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Posterior margins of at least some metasomal terga, as seen in proﬁle, curved upward away from following terga; axilla not extending laterally beyond scutum (except in someBranthidium); male gonostylus reaching to or beyond level of apical one-fourth of penis valves

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Xenanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): T6 of female with preapical denticulate ridge parallel to denticulate apical margin (scutellum distinctly carinate except for small midapical emargination) (male unknown) (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Capanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Marginal zones of T2 to T5 punctate or narrowly impunctate, median lengths of impunctate zones about one-seventh lengths of exposed parts of terga or less, these zones dark or translucent brownish; male gonostylus neither broad nor ﬂat nor almost membranous although sometimes broadly paddle-shaped; pronotal lobe usually with transverse carina or low lamella that is hairless even when it extends only partway across lobe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Capanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Scutellum laterally and usually axilla overhanging large fossa and usually acute or narrowly rounded, as seen obliquely so as to show proﬁle of lateral part of scutellum and of axilla; scutellum acute, right-angular, or sometimes rounded in proﬁle, medially often strongly overhanging metanotum; outer surfaces of tibiae, especially of female, coarsely, irregularly punctate, sometimes with extensive smooth areas between punctures, the punctures commonly coarser than those of mesepisternum, surfaces usually tuberculate (but not or weakly so in Capanthidium and Mesanthidium)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Capanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Posterior margins of at least some metasomal terga, as seen in proﬁle, curved upward away from following terga; axilla not extending laterally beyond scutum (except in someBranthidium); male gonostylus reaching to or beyond level of apical one-fourth of penis valves

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Capanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): T6 of female without preapical denticulate ridge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Capanthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): T6 of male with preapical, usually denticulate transverse ridge at least laterally; tibiae coarsely punctate but not or weakly tuberculate on outer surfaces (Africa, palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Mesanthidiellum) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Preoccipital carina present laterally; male S3 with trapezoidal apical projection; T5 and T6 of male with lobate lateral carinae, T5 and T6 of female with lateral longitudinal carinae (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Branthidium) of Afranthidium(From Michener and Griswold, 1994a): Preoccipital carina absent; male S3 margin not produced; T5 (usually) and T6 without lateral carinae in either sex (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ananthidiellum) of Anthidiellum: T erga not swollen laterally; S5 of male with margin broadly concave and armed with comb of black teeth, at least laterally (male unknown in Ananthidiellum); mandible of female without preapical shoulder on lower margin (Eastern Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ananthidiellum) of Anthidiellum: Mandible of female minutely sculptured, dull, almost without carinae, its apex expanded, 1.5 times as wide as basal width; subantennal suture straight; T1 to T4 without pale markings (oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chloranthidiellum) of Anthidiellum: T erga not swollen laterally; S5 of male with margin broadly concave and armed with comb of black teeth, at least laterally (male unknown in Ananthidiellum); mandible of female without preapical shoulder on lower margin (Eastern Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chloranthidiellum) of Anthidiellum: Mandible of female somewhat shining, often coarsely punctate (somewhat dull distally in Ranthidiellum and Clypanthidium), with carinae, its apex but little wider than base (except in Ranthidiellum); subantennal suture arcuate [not clearly recognizable and perhaps not arcuate inA. (Clypanthidium) bimaculatum (Friese)]; T1 to T4 with yellow, cream, or reddish bands (except in subgenus Clypanthidiumand some Ranthidiellum)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Chloranthidiellum) of Anthidiellum: Preoccipital carina present at sides, behind eyes, but absent behind vertex; lamella on pronotal lobe tapering but extending nearly as far mesad from lateral margin of scutum as laterad; axilla extending laterally beyond margin of scutum (basal zone of propodeum laterally horizontal with well-developed pits) (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Clypanthidium) of Anthidiellum: T erga not swollen laterally; S5 of male with margin broadly concave and armed with comb of black teeth, at least laterally (male unknown in Ananthidiellum); mandible of female without preapical shoulder on lower margin (Eastern Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Clypanthidium) of Anthidiellum: Mandible of female somewhat shining, often coarsely punctate (somewhat dull distally in Ranthidiellum and Clypanthidium), with carinae, its apex but little wider than base (except in Ranthidiellum); subantennal suture arcuate [not clearly recognizable and perhaps not arcuate inA. (Clypanthidium) bimaculatum (Friese)]; T1 to T4 with yellow, cream, or reddish bands (except in subgenus Clypanthidiumand some Ranthidiellum)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Clypanthidium) of Anthidiellum: Preoccipital carina complete, or present only behind vertex, or absent; lamella or carina on pronotal lobe usually extending little mesad from lateral margin of scutum; axilla not extending laterally beyond lateral margin of scutum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Clypanthidium) of Anthidiellum: T egula narrowly rounded posteriorly; omaular carina reaching about halfway down omaulus (oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pycnanthidium) of Anthidiellum: T erga not swollen laterally; S5 of male with margin broadly concave and armed with comb of black teeth, at least laterally (male unknown in Ananthidiellum); mandible of female without preapical shoulder on lower margin (Eastern Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pycnanthidium) of Anthidiellum: Mandible of female somewhat shining, often coarsely punctate (somewhat dull distally in Ranthidiellum and Clypanthidium), with carinae, its apex but little wider than base (except in Ranthidiellum); subantennal suture arcuate [not clearly recognizable and perhaps not arcuate inA. (Clypanthidium) bimaculatum (Friese)]; T1 to T4 with yellow, cream, or reddish bands (except in subgenus Clypanthidiumand some Ranthidiellum)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pycnanthidium) of Anthidiellum: Preoccipital carina complete, or present only behind vertex, or absent; lamella or carina on pronotal lobe usually extending little mesad from lateral margin of scutum; axilla not extending laterally beyond lateral margin of scutum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pycnanthidium) of Anthidiellum: T egula broadly rounded or almost transverse posteriorly; omaular carina extending to venter (in some Pycnanthidium very weak or perhaps absent on lower half of mesepisternum)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pycnanthidium) of Anthidiellum: T1 with carina separating anterior and dorsal surfaces; apex of mandible but little wider than base; body black with yellow or cream markings on all tagmata (Africa, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ranthidiellum) of Anthidiellum: T erga not swollen laterally; S5 of male with margin broadly concave and armed with comb of black teeth, at least laterally (male unknown in Ananthidiellum); mandible of female without preapical shoulder on lower margin (Eastern Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ranthidiellum) of Anthidiellum: Mandible of female somewhat shining, often coarsely punctate (somewhat dull distally in Ranthidiellum and Clypanthidium), with carinae, its apex but little wider than base (except in Ranthidiellum); subantennal suture arcuate [not clearly recognizable and perhaps not arcuate inA. (Clypanthidium) bimaculatum (Friese)]; T1 to T4 with yellow, cream, or reddish bands (except in subgenus Clypanthidiumand some Ranthidiellum)

Title: Bees Of The World
