(Haplocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the WesternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Mitchell, 1973): Subocellar area of frons usually closely punctate and quite ﬂat, but if with smooth swollen area, then usually with a few punctures or divided medially by punctate zone

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Haplocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the WesternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Mitchell, 1973): Scutellum usually well punctured, hind margin not carinate and not overlying metanotum except sometimes for a median angle or tubercle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Haplocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the WesternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Mitchell, 1973): Concavity of T1 with dorsal marginal carina; T1 usually with more or less conspicuous pale basal fascia of hairs (i.e., on dorsum immediately behind basal concavity)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Haplocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the WesternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Mitchell, 1973): S6 of female with small, lateral subapical notch; gena of male much narrowed below, hypostomal area lacking usual concavity (clypeus of female ﬂattened, its apical margin straight and simple)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Cyrtocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the WesternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Mitchell, 1973): Scutellum subtriangular, or, if broadly rounded posteriorly, then dorsal and posterior surfaces usually only indeﬁnitely separated (S6 of female usually fringed with setae)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Platycoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the WesternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Mitchell, 1973): S5 of female greatly expanded, hiding all but tip of S6; postgradular grooves of T3 to T5 in male not or only slightly fasciate; body length 6.5-7.2 mm (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Rhinocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the WesternHemisphere(Modiﬁed from Mitchell, 1973): S5 of female normal, S6 very narrow and elongate; postgradular grooves of T3 to T5 in male usually conspicuously fasciate; body usually much larger (clypeus in female variously modiﬁed) (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (T orridapis) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: Eyes bare

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (T orridapis) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: S5 of female greatly elongated, forming part of apical metasomal elongation, exposed part far longer than exposed parts of S4 and S6 (Fig. 84-6c); S6 of female narrow, without long hairs, not fringed; T6 of female with out keel, without long erect hairs; T6 of male without lateral tooth (Fig. 84-6g) (Africa, oriental, Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liothyrapis) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: Eyes bare

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Liothyrapis) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: S5 of female not attenuate, exposed part not much if any longer than exposed parts of S4 and S6; S6 of female broad, its apex bluntly pointed or rounded, fringed; T6 of female with keel ending in bare apical spine, with long erect hairs lateral to keel (Fig. 84-6b); T6 of male with lateral basal tooth (Fig. 84-6f)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Allocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: Eyes hairy

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Allocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: T ransverse subocular carina (extending posteriorly from posterior mandibular articulation) joining preoccipital carina; subgenal fossa absent; T6 of male with eight teeth, two lateral, six apical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Mesocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: Eyes hairy

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Mesocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: T ransverse subocular carina (extending posteriorly from posterior mandibular articulation) absent or ending free, without approaching preoccipital carina, except in some males in which subocular carina is extended as margin of subgenal fossa, the margin continuing upward as preoccipital carina; T6 of male with six teeth or projections, two lateral, four apical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Mesocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: Front and middle femora each with two strong but irregular longitudinal carinae on undersurfaces, one of the carinae of front femur elevated and keel-like, spaces between carinae densely covered with white, scale-like hairs; white areas or fasciae of body formed by white scales; T6 and S6 of female produced and slender but apices truncate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C.(Boreocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: Eyes hairy

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C.(Boreocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: T ransverse subocular carina (extending posteriorly from posterior mandibular articulation) absent or ending free, without approaching preoccipital carina, except in some males in which subocular carina is extended as margin of subgenal fossa, the margin continuing upward as preoccipital carina; T6 of male with six teeth or projections, two lateral, four apical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C.(Boreocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: Front and middle femora unmodiﬁed; white areas of body formed by patches or fasciae of dense hairs or scalelike hairs; T6 and S6 of female usually pointed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C.(Boreocoelioxys) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: T2 of male with sublateral pit or fovea on each side behind postgradular groove (Fig. 84-7); S6 of female with lateral subapical notch

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Coelioxys s. str.) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: Eyes hairy

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Coelioxys s. str.) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: T ransverse subocular carina (extending posteriorly from posterior mandibular articulation) absent or ending free, without approaching preoccipital carina, except in some males in which subocular carina is extended as margin of subgenal fossa, the margin continuing upward as preoccipital carina; T6 of male with six teeth or projections, two lateral, four apical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Coelioxys s. str.) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: Front and middle femora unmodiﬁed; white areas of body formed by patches or fasciae of dense hairs or scalelike hairs; T6 and S6 of female usually pointed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Coelioxys s. str.) of Coelioxys of the EasternHemisphere: T2 of male without foveae behind postgradular groove; S6 of female without lateral notch

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melanosarus) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible ﬁve-toothed, a long cutting edge in second interspace, none elsewhere

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Moureapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible four-toothed, a well-formed cutting edge in third interspace

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Moureapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Second interspace distinct, with cutting edge usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Moureapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Inner angle of mandible truncate, or apical margin of clypeus impressed medially (S6 rather narrowly truncate) (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Pseudocentron) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible four-toothed, a well-formed cutting edge in third interspace

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Pseudocentron) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Second interspace distinct, with cutting edge usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Pseudocentron) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Inner angle of mandible acute or rounded; clypeal margin straight and entire

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Acentron) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible four-toothed, a well-formed cutting edge in third interspace

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Acentron) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Second interspace lacking or small, without cutting edge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Acentron) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible more robust, apical tooth more protuberant, much broader than other teeth; gena usually broader than eye in lateral view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Leptorachis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible four-toothed, a well-formed cutting edge in third interspace

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Leptorachis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Second interspace lacking or small, without cutting edge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Leptorachis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible less robust, apical tooth not much broader than second or third; gena usually narrow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Grosapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): S6 with well-dispersed scopal hairs, or, if partly bare, then without bare apical rim behind transverse fringe of short hairs, or (in Argyropile) rim directed upward, or rim narrow and barely recognizable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Grosapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible without cutting edges between teeth (Fig. 84-12e, f), or with incomplete cutting edge in second interspace only (Fig. 84-12c); mandible with less than ﬁve teeth,or, if ﬁve-toothed, then upper two teeth (4 and 5) usually closer together than teeth 3 and 4

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Grosapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible with incomplete cutting edge in second interspace, and no cutting edges elsewhere (Fig. 84-12c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Grosapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Body very large and robust (20 X 10 mm); vestiture entirely rufous; proﬁle of T6 straight (Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Sayapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): S6 with well-dispersed scopal hairs, or, if partly bare, then without bare apical rim behind transverse fringe of short hairs, or (in Argyropile) rim directed upward, or rim narrow and barely recognizable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Sayapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible without cutting edges between teeth (Fig. 84-12e, f), or with incomplete cutting edge in second interspace only (Fig. 84-12c); mandible with less than ﬁve teeth,or, if ﬁve-toothed, then upper two teeth (4 and 5) usually closer together than teeth 3 and 4

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Sayapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible with incomplete cutting edge in second interspace, and no cutting edges elsewhere (Fig. 84-12c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Sayapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Body not so large and robust; vestiture not entirely rufous, that of metasomal terga dark with pale apical bands; proﬁle of T6 strongly concave distally because of projecting apical margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Megachile s. str.)(in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible clearly ﬁve-toothed, distance between upper two teeth not or only slightly less than distance between other pairs of teeth (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Chrysosarus) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): T6 nearly straight in proﬁle, with abundant erect pubescence (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Schrottkyapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Pronotal lobe with transverse hairless lamella hidden among hairs; mandible with third interspace narrowly Ushaped and much deeper than others (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Chelostomoides) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Pubescence largely white, not fulvous, forming narrow white apical bands on metasomal terga and sometimes narrow bands on postgradular grooves

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Stelodides) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible ﬁve-toothed; pubescence of thorax and metasoma black except for broad white band on T3 (Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Gronoceras) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Apex of front tibia with three distinct sharp spines or teeth on outer surface; clypeus with longitudinal elevation, highest at lower clypeal margin (?Jamaica)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandibular carinae minutely roughened, sometimes dull

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandibular carinae shining and smooth (at 40 /H11003)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Argyropile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): S6 with apical rim dir ected upward beyond fringe of hairs, this rim conspicuous if tergum and sternum are spread apart (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Ptilosarus) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Thoracic venter, including leg bases and S2, with dense covering of ﬁne, plumose hairs, sharply differentiated from other scopal hairs (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Eutricharaea) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible four-toothed, no cutting edge in second interspace (introduced, North America, Antilles, Chile, Argentina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Trichurochile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible with fourth tooth emarginate, thus ﬁvetoothed, second interspace with conspicuous but incomplete cutting edge (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Tylomegachile)(in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Metasomal sterna not at all fasciate; segments 1 and 2 of hind tarsus not or little produced apically (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Megachiloides) (in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): T6 straight in proﬁle; mandible with second tooth often rounded or obtuse (Fig. 84-12a), usually no cutting edge in second interspace (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Dasymegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Scopa black; body usually covered with long, dense hairs (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Litomegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Scopa white except on S6; body not densely covered with long hairs (nearctic) [The female of Megachile (Xanthosarus) addenda Cresson (couplet 24 of the ﬁrst key) runs to Litomegachile,from which, usually, it is immediately distinguishable by its large size, 12-17 mm in body length]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Megachile s. str.)(in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible clearly ﬁve-toothed, distance between upper two teeth not or only slightly less than distance between other pairs of teeth (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Austromegachile) (in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Median area of clypeus somewhat elevated and strongly ﬂattened, sloping away on each side (apical margin of clypeus medially emarginate) (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Tylomegachile)(in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Metasomal sterna not at all fasciate; segments 1 and 2 of hind tarsus not or little produced apically (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Austromegachile) (in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Median area of clypeus somewhat elevated and strongly ﬂattened, sloping away on each side (apical margin of clypeus medially emarginate) (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Cressoniella) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible four-toothed, a well-formed cutting edge in third interspace

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Cressoniella) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Lateral ocellus considerably nearer to posterior margin of vertex than to eye

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Xanthosarus) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible four-toothed, a well-formed cutting edge in third interspace

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Xanthosarus) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Lateral ocellus usually as near as or nearer to eye than to posterior margin of vertex (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Rhyssomegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible four-toothed, a well-formed cutting edge in third interspace

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Rhyssomegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Preoccipital carina distinct behind gena; cutting edges of mandible obsolescent (lateral ocellus widely removed from occipital margin) (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Ptilosaroides) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible four-toothed, a well-formed cutting edge in third interspace

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Ptilosaroides) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Thorax and metasoma above densely and minutely punctate throughout, largely cov ered with appressed or suberect tomentum (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Neochelynia) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Mandible four-toothed, a well-formed cutting edge in third interspace

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Neochelynia) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Females)(Partly from Mitchell, 1943, 1980): Punctures of thorax and metasoma distinctly separated, surface not tomentose to any considerable degree

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Leptorachis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Leptorachis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur present, articulated, but small

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Pseudocentron) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Pseudocentron) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or represented by prong immovably fused to tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Pseudocentron) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibia with a spurlike apical prong (spur presumably fused to tibia), prong sometimes reduced to large, acute tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Moureapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Moureapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or represented by prong immovably fused to tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Moureapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibia without such a process

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Moureapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Front and middle tibia and tarsus simple and unmodiﬁed; front tarsus slender, usually black (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Acentron) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Acentron) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or represented by prong immovably fused to tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Acentron) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibia without such a process

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Acentron) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Front and middle tibia and tarsus modiﬁed, middle tibia broadened apically or angulate on lower margin; basitarsus usually excavated along anterior margin; front tarsus dilated and brightly colored

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Acentron) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Scutum ﬁnely and densely rugoso-punctate, punctures not individually distinguishable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melanosarus) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melanosarus) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or represented by prong immovably fused to tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melanosarus) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibia without such a process

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melanosarus) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Front and middle tibia and tarsus modiﬁed, middle tibia broadened apically or angulate on lower margin; basitarsus usually excavated along anterior margin; front tarsus dilated and brightly colored

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melanosarus) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Punctures of scutum usually well separated, but, if close, then individually distinguishable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Chelostomoides) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Mandible three-toothed, toothed margin much shorter than distance from upper tooth to base of mandible; body not covered with rufous hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Grosapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Mandible four-toothed, elongate, toothed margin as long as distance from upper tooth to base of mandible; body covered with long, rufous hairs (Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Schrottkyapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Pronotal lobe with erect, hairless transverse lamella (clypeus protuberant medially; mandible as described for Grosapisin couplet 7) (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Gronoceras) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T6 with preapical brush of long hairs and two long, slender spines representing preapical carina (Fig. 84-18)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T6 without brush of long hairs and without long spines..11 11(10). T6 with carina short, low, not or shallowly emarginate, not denticulate (Fig. 84-14c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Neochelynia) (in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Neochelynia) (in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T6 more nearly horizontal, carina either deeply emarginate, with dorsal surface markedly concave, or surface convex, carina low, with only a small median notch

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Tylomegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Carina of T6 without emargination but with small median apical point (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Rhyssomegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Preoccipital carina strong behind genal area (front tarsus slender, dark) (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Zonomegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Anterior end of hypostomal area, immediately behind mandible, with strong, angular projection (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Ptilosaroides) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Front tarsus slender, black; carina of T6 represented principally by two spines, one on each side of emargination; mandible four-toothed (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Chrysosarus) (in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Chrysosarus) (in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or represented by prong immovably fused to tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Chrysosarus) (in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Mandible with low median or preapical inferior angle in place of usual tooth (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Dasymegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): First and second segments of ﬂagellum subequal (mandible three-toothed, middle tooth sometimes notched, suggesting a four-toothed condition) (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Trichurochile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Trichurochile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Large emargination between teeth of carina of T6 ﬁlled by dense fringes of long, plumose hairs largely arising from the teeth (mandible three-toothed) (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Cressoniella) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Cressoniella) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Mandible four-toothed; body length often 12 mm or more; pubescence erect and rather long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Ptilosarus) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Ptilosarus) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Mandible three-toothed; body smaller, length about 7 mm; pubescence short, appressed (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Neochelynia) (in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Neochelynia) (in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T6 more nearly horizontal, carina either deeply emarginate, with dorsal surface markedly concave, or surface convex, carina low, with only a small median notch

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Austromegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Austromegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): T6 vertical, completely hidden in dorsal view of metasoma, carina low and entire or with small median emargination (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Stelodides) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Stelodides) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Pubescence of thorax and metasoma black except for broad white band on T3; mandible with small preapical inferior angle (Chile)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Sayapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Sayapis) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Pubescence not forming above color pattern; mandible with large basal inferior projection

Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Argyropile) (in part) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Front coxa hairy, without red bristles; front tarsus simple, dark-colored (nearctic)

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Megachiloides) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): S4 without median apical tubercle, apical margin usually broadly membranous (nearctic)

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Megachile s. str.) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or represented by prong immovably fused to tibia

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Megachile s. str.) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Front coxal spine reduced to inconspicuous tubercle or absent (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Eutricharaea) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Eutricharaea) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or represented by prong immovably fused to tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Eutricharaea) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Morphological apical margin (not carina) of T6 without evident teeth (introduced)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Litomegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or much shorter than apical width of tibia, sometimes immovably fused to tibia, and middle basitarsus not or little modiﬁed (body megachiliform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Litomegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Middle tibial spur absent or represented by prong immovably fused to tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Litomegachile) of Megachile of the WesternHemisphere (Males): Morphological apical margin of T6 with four small but distinct teeth (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Creightonella) of Megachile (Females): Mandible ﬁveor six-toothed, teeth (except the ﬁrst) similar and with similarly shaped incomplete cutting edges in second and third (and sometimes fourth) interspaces (Fig. 84-17d); apices of mandibular teeth roughly equidistant from nearest neighbors; preapical transverse mandibular groove distinct and ﬁlled with short, ﬁne, pale hairs (these not found in other subgenera with cutting edges)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Parachalicodoma) of Megachile (Females): Mandible threeto ﬁve-toothed, without cutting edges, or, if with cutting edges, then teeth above ﬁrst of different shapes and cutting edges often of different shapes, or only one cutting edge present; apices of mandibular teeth commonly separated from nearest neighbors by different distances; preapical transverse mandibular groove, in forms with cutting edges, absent, or, if present, then not ﬁlled with short, pale hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Parachalicodoma) of Megachile (Females): Mandible without cutting edges (Fig. 84-12d-f) (body chalicodomiform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Parachalicodoma) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with ﬁve fully distinct teeth, about equidistant (northern Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Chalicodoma) of Megachile (Females): Mandible threeto ﬁve-toothed, without cutting edges, or, if with cutting edges, then teeth above ﬁrst of different shapes and cutting edges often of different shapes, or only one cutting edge present; apices of mandibular teeth commonly separated from nearest neighbors by different distances; preapical transverse mandibular groove, in forms with cutting edges, absent, or, if present, then not ﬁlled with short, pale hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Chalicodoma) of Megachile (Females): Mandible without cutting edges (Fig. 84-12d-f) (body chalicodomiform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Chalicodoma) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with three or four teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Chalicodoma) of Megachile (Females): Anterior margin of clypeus rounded (rarely weakly emarginate medially), strongly crenulate, produced well over base of labrum, not thickened; head little developed posteriorly, ocelloccipital distance thus not greater than interocellar distance (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Largella) of Megachile (Females): Mandible threeto ﬁve-toothed, without cutting edges, or, if with cutting edges, then teeth above ﬁrst of different shapes and cutting edges often of different shapes, or only one cutting edge present; apices of mandibular teeth commonly separated from nearest neighbors by different distances; preapical transverse mandibular groove, in forms with cutting edges, absent, or, if present, then not ﬁlled with short, pale hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Largella) of Megachile (Females): Mandible without cutting edges (Fig. 84-12d-f) (body chalicodomiform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Largella) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with three or four teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Largella) of Megachile (Females): Anterior margin of clypeus truncate or highly modiﬁed, usually not crenulate, often not much produced over base of labrum, but if rounded and somewhat crenulate (as in some Pseudomegachile), then margin thickened and impunctate; head usually much developed posteriorly, ocelloccipital distance thus greater than interocellar distance

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Largella) of Megachile (Females): Apex of front tibia with three spines, posterior one less acute and hidden by dense, short hairs; mandible strongly expanded apically, outer margin thus concave in basal half, narrowest part little more than half as wide as apical margin (oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Maximegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible threeto ﬁve-toothed, without cutting edges, or, if with cutting edges, then teeth above ﬁrst of different shapes and cutting edges often of different shapes, or only one cutting edge present; apices of mandibular teeth commonly separated from nearest neighbors by different distances; preapical transverse mandibular groove, in forms with cutting edges, absent, or, if present, then not ﬁlled with short, pale hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Maximegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible without cutting edges (Fig. 84-12d-f) (body chalicodomiform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Maximegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with three or four teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Maximegachile) of Megachile (Females): Anterior margin of clypeus truncate or highly modiﬁed, usually not crenulate, often not much produced over base of labrum, but if rounded and somewhat crenulate (as in some Pseudomegachile), then margin thickened and impunctate; head usually much developed posteriorly, ocelloccipital distance thus greater than interocellar distance

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Maximegachile) of Megachile (Females): Apex of front tibia with one or usually two spines, posterior one absent; mandible not so expanded apically, outer margin not or weakly concave, narrowest part more than half as wide as apical margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Maximegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible elongate, more or less parallel-sided or narrowest preapically, with teeth across apex and mandibular ridges smooth and shining (at 40X) (southwestern Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible threeto ﬁve-toothed, without cutting edges, or, if with cutting edges, then teeth above ﬁrst of different shapes and cutting edges often of different shapes, or only one cutting edge present; apices of mandibular teeth commonly separated from nearest neighbors by different distances; preapical transverse mandibular groove, in forms with cutting edges, absent, or, if present, then not ﬁlled with short, pale hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible without cutting edges (Fig. 84-12d-f) (body chalicodomiform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible of ordinary shape or if elongated as above (as in some Callomegachile), then ridges minutely roughened and dull

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with ridges largely shiny, not dulled by microsculpturing (at 40X)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible threeto ﬁve-toothed, without cutting edges, or, if with cutting edges, then teeth above ﬁrst of different shapes and cutting edges often of different shapes, or only one cutting edge present; apices of mandibular teeth commonly separated from nearest neighbors by different distances; preapical transverse mandibular groove, in forms with cutting edges, absent, or, if present, then not ﬁlled with short, pale hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with ridges dulled by microsculpturing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): Mandible threeto ﬁve-toothed, without cutting edges, or, if with cutting edges, then teeth above ﬁrst of different shapes and cutting edges often of different shapes, or only one cutting edge present; apices of mandibular teeth commonly separated from nearest neighbors by different distances; preapical transverse mandibular groove, in forms with cutting edges, absent, or, if present, then not ﬁlled with short, pale hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with cutting edge in at least one interspace, sometimes hidden behind margin of interspace (Fig. 8411)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with cutting edge only in second interspace (as in Fig. 84-12c); body heriadiform, hoplitiform (as in Fig. 84-9), or chalicodomiform

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): Metasomal sterna at least laterally with apical fasciae of white hair under scopa; mandible of ordinary shape, ﬁve-toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Eumegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible threeto ﬁve-toothed, without cutting edges, or, if with cutting edges, then teeth above ﬁrst of different shapes and cutting edges often of different shapes, or only one cutting edge present; apices of mandibular teeth commonly separated from nearest neighbors by different distances; preapical transverse mandibular groove, in forms with cutting edges, absent, or, if present, then not ﬁlled with short, pale hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Eumegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with cutting edge in at least one interspace, sometimes hidden behind margin of interspace (Fig. 8411)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Eumegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with cutting edge only in second interspace (as in Fig. 84-12c); body heriadiform, hoplitiform (as in Fig. 84-9), or chalicodomiform

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Eumegachile) of Megachile (Females): Metasomal sterna without apical fasciae; mandible over twice as long as basal width, four-toothed (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Megachile s. str.) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with ﬁve teeth, distance between fourth and ﬁfth little less than distance between other teeth (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Megella) of Megachile (Females): Metasoma over twice as long as broad; body over 20 mm long (cutting edge in third interspace, behind interspace margin and not or only slightly exposed in frontal view; Fig. 84-11h) (oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Xanthosarus) of Megachile (Females): Upper mandibular tooth broad (convex or truncate) or emarginate so that the mandible is ﬁve-toothed (Fig. 84-11a); sterna without apical hair bands beneath scopa; third interspace of mandible frequently deeper than others (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Eutricharaea) of Megachile (Females): Mandible without or with only hidden or very small cutting edge in second interspace but with cutting edge in third interspace (rarely hidden behind interspace margin) (Fig. 84-11g)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Neocressoniella) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with upper interspace as long as or longer than rest of apical margin, cutting edge in upper interspace complete, occupying full length of interspace and over twice as long as incomplete cutting edge in second interspace (oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Paracella) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with upper interspace shorter than rest of apical margin, cutting edge in upper interspace complete or incomplete, sometimes hidden, less than twice as long as incomplete cutting edge in second interspace (oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Creightonella) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): S5 (sometimes also S6) exposed and generally similar to preceding sterna (sometimes S5 largely hidden but S6 exposed); lateral extremity of carina of T6 directed basad, away from apical margin of tergum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): S5 and S6 retracted, variously modiﬁed, less sclerotized, less punctate, and less hairy than S1 to S4; lateral extremity of carina of T6 absent or directed toward lateral extremity of apical margin of tergum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible without cutting edges between teeth (Fig. 84-12e, f); S6 usually with apical hairs like scopal hairs of nearby surface of sternum, sometimes with bare rim; body chalicodomiform, metasoma strongly convex, more or less parallel-sided, and commonly two or more times as wide as long (as in Fig. 84-9)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): S4 largely or wholly retracted (as in Fig. 84-13a), less sclerotized, less punctate, and less hairy than S2 and S3 (body heriadiform or hoplitiform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Parachalicodoma) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): S5 and S6 retracted, variously modiﬁed, less sclerotized, less punctate, and less hairy than S1 to S4; lateral extremity of carina of T6 absent or directed toward lateral extremity of apical margin of tergum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Parachalicodoma) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Apex of front tibia with one or two spines, or,if (rarely) with three spines, then posterior spine a mere tubercle or covered by a patch of short hairs, or if distinct and pointed, then spaces between spines with punctures and hairs, not noticeably shining

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Parachalicodoma) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Arolia absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Parachalicodoma) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): T7 with narrow, median, apically truncate projection extending well beyond teeth of T6 carina (northern Africa)

Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Chalicodoma) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Anterior margin of clypeus rounded (rarely weakly emarginate medially), strongly crenulate, produced well over base of labrum, not thickened; head little developed posteriorly, ocelloccipital distance thus not greater than interocellar distance

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) (in part) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Front tibia without apical posterior angle, or, if weakly evident, then angle not covered with short hair

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth

(Maximegachile) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Apex of front tibia with one or usually two spines, posterior spine as found in Largella being absent; mandible not so expanded apically, outer margin not or weakly concave, narrowest part more than half as wide as apical margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Maximegachile) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible elongate, approximately parallel-sided or narrowest preapically, and mandibular ridges smooth and shining (at 40 /H11003); posterior hypostomal area with strong tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Maximegachile) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible three-toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Largella) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Apex of front tibia with three spines, posterior spine less acute than others and hidden by dense, short hairs; mandible strongly expanded apically, outer margin thus concave in basal half and narrowest part little over half as wide as apical margin (Zanzibar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) (in part) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Front tibia without apical posterior angle, or, if weakly evident, then angle not covered with short hair

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Eumegachile) (in part) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): T7 with large, exposed, biconvex, punctate surface; body chalcidomiform (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible threeto seven-toothed, without especially deep emargination and with no teeth displaced basad; clypeus truncate to highly modiﬁed, but not as above.

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Eumegachile) (in part) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): T7 with large, exposed, biconvex, punctate surface; body chalcidomiform (palearctic)

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): S4 largely or wholly retracted (as in Fig. 84-13a), less sclerotized, less punctate, and less hairy than S2 and S3 (body heriadiform or hoplitiform)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Parachalicodoma) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): S5 and S6 retracted, variously modiﬁed, less sclerotized, less punctate, and less hairy than S1 to S4; lateral extremity of carina of T6 absent or directed toward lateral extremity of apical margin of tergum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Parachalicodoma) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible without cutting edges between teeth (Fig. 84-12e, f); S6 usually with apical hairs like scopal hairs of nearby surface of sternum, sometimes with bare rim; body chalicodomiform, metasoma strongly convex, more or less parallel-sided, and commonly two or more times as wide as long (as in Fig. 84-9)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Parachalicodoma) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Apex of front tibia with one or two spines, or,if (rarely) with three spines, then posterior spine a mere tubercle or covered by a patch of short hairs, or if distinct and pointed, then spaces between spines with punctures and hairs, not noticeably shining

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Parachalicodoma) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Arolia absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Parachalicodoma) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): T7 with narrow, median, apically truncate projection extending well beyond teeth of T6 carina (northern Africa)

Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile)(in part) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Front coxa with erect spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Chalicodoma) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Anterior margin of clypeus rounded (rarely weakly emarginate medially), strongly crenulate, produced well over base of labrum, not thickened; head little developed posteriorly, ocelloccipital distance thus not greater than interocellar distance

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) (in part) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Front tibia without apical posterior angle, or, if weakly evident, then angle not covered with short hair

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Maximegachile) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Apex of front tibia with one or usually two spines, posterior spine as found in Largella being absent; mandible not so expanded apically, outer margin not or weakly concave, narrowest part more than half as wide as apical margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Maximegachile) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible elongate, approximately parallel-sided or narrowest preapically, and mandibular ridges smooth and shining (at 40 /H11003); posterior hypostomal area with strong tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Maximegachile) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible three-toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Largella) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Apex of front tibia with three spines, posterior spine less acute than others and hidden by dense, short hairs; mandible strongly expanded apically, outer margin thus concave in basal half and narrowest part little over half as wide as apical margin (Zanzibar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) (in part) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Front tibia without apical posterior angle, or, if weakly evident, then angle not covered with short hair

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Eumegachile) (in part) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): T7 with large, exposed, biconvex, punctate surface; body chalcidomiform (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible threeto seven-toothed, without especially deep emargination and with no teeth displaced basad; clypeus truncate to highly modiﬁed, but not as above.

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Eumegachile) (in part) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): T7 with large, exposed, biconvex, punctate surface; body chalcidomiform (palearctic)
