Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Stenomegachile) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Apex of front tibia with one or usually two spines, posterior spine as found in Largella being absent; mandible not so expanded apically, outer margin not or weakly concave, narrowest part more than half as wide as apical margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Stenomegachile) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible elongate, approximately parallel-sided or narrowest preapically, and mandibular ridges smooth and shining (at 40 /H11003); posterior hypostomal area with strong tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Stenomegachile) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible four-toothed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Cuspidella) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Apical margin of clypeus broadly and deeply emarginate, lower part of clypeus strongly depressed, separated from upper part by curved ridge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Clypeus not or little modiﬁed, truncate, margin sometimes crenulate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Cestella) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible ﬁve-toothed, with deep, rounded emargination between third and fourth teeth, fourth and ﬁfth teeth (interpretable jointly as angularly truncate fourth tooth) connected by straight margin basal to level of ﬁrst three teeth; clypeus with large, deep, triangular, shining, hairless area in middle of which, arising from impunctate surface, is a large tubercle (Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible threeto seven-toothed, without especially deep emargination and with no teeth displaced basad; clypeus truncate to highly modiﬁed, but not as above.

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Platysta) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible ﬁve-toothed, upper two teeth close together (interpretable jointly as emarginate fourth tooth) but with small cutting edge between them, i.e., in fourth interspace, in addition to large but rather incomplete cutting edge in third interspace

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Megella) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible much broadened apically, outer margin thus strongly concave; body length 18 mm or more; metasoma more than twice as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Eutricharaea) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible of ordinary shape, outer margin not strongly concave; body length much less than 18 mm; metasoma less than twice as long as wide

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Palearctic and Oriental Subgenera M. (Amegachile) —. Mandible with third tooth pointed or rounded, fourth tooth usually rather broad, rounded or truncate, rarely acute, rarely emarginate so that mandible ﬁve-toothed;  cutting edges not crenulate ........................M. (Paracella) of Megachile (Males)(Megella is omitted because the male of the orientalspecies is unknown to me.): Mandible with third tooth truncate because fused to cutting edge of second interspace, fourth tooth acute; cutting edges usually crenulate (Fig. 84-11e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Creightonella) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): S5 (sometimes also S6) exposed and generally similar to preceding sterna (sometimes S5 largely hidden but S6 exposed); lateral extremity of carina of T6 directed basad, away from apical margin of tergum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Gronoceras) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): S5 and S6 retracted, variously modiﬁed (less sclerotized, less punctate, and less hairy than S2 to S4); lateral extremity of carina of T6 absent or directed toward lateral extremity of posterior margin of tergum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Gronoceras) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): S8 with lateral marginal hairs (Fig. 84-10j, n); metasoma commonly strongly convex and twice as long as wide or more, chalicodomiform

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Gronoceras) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Front tibia on outer surface ending distally in three bare spines or teeth, the posteriormost extended as carina along much of outer posterior margin of tibia; T6 with carina represented by long spines or long lobes, partly hidden by extremely long hairs arising before carina (Fig. 84-18)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Cuspidella) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): S5 and S6 retracted, variously modiﬁed (less sclerotized, less punctate, and less hairy than S2 to S4); lateral extremity of carina of T6 absent or directed toward lateral extremity of posterior margin of tergum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Cuspidella) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): S8 with lateral marginal hairs (Fig. 84-10j, n); metasoma commonly strongly convex and twice as long as wide or more, chalicodomiform

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Cuspidella) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Front tibia on outer surface ending in two spines or teeth (posterior tooth of Gronoceras sometimes represented by angle, which if strong is covered by short hair, see Largella); tibia usually without carina along outer posterior margin; T6 with carina variable, not represented by long spines, but if bilobed, then lobes much broader than long, surface of T6 usually without extremely long hairs, butif present, then such hairs sparse enough that carina almost always easily seen

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Cuspidella) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Carina of T6 strongly produced medially to truncate, untoothed process with longitudinal median carina (T6 with strong lateral tooth)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) (in part) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): S5 and S6 retracted, variously modiﬁed (less sclerotized, less punctate, and less hairy than S2 to S4); lateral extremity of carina of T6 absent or directed toward lateral extremity of posterior margin of tergum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) (in part) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): S8 with lateral marginal hairs (Fig. 84-10j, n); metasoma commonly strongly convex and twice as long as wide or more, chalicodomiform

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) (in part) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Front tibia on outer surface ending in two spines or teeth (posterior tooth of Gronoceras sometimes represented by angle, which if strong is covered by short hair, see Largella); tibia usually without carina along outer posterior margin; T6 with carina variable, not represented by long spines, but if bilobed, then lobes much broader than long, surface of T6 usually without extremely long hairs, butif present, then such hairs sparse enough that carina almost always easily seen

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) (in part) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Carina of T6 dentate or medially emarginate, not produced medially, without longitudinal median carina but sometimes with broad ridge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) (in part) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): T6 with carina dentate or denticulate, sometimes with median emargination but denticulate lateral to it, sometimes bilobed but margin with at least a few irregularities (Fig. 84-14a, b), rarely with median emargination forming two large teeth and an additional large lateral tooth (T6 thus four-toothed); surface of T6 above carina commonly without median depression

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) (in part) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Front coxa without spine or with tubercle or short spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) (in part) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): T oothed margin of mandible (three-toothed) less oblique, much shorter than distance from upper tooth to mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Pseudomegachile) (in part) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Eyes of ordinary size, ocellocular distance about equal to interocellar distance; T6 with strong lateral spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Chalicodoma) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): S5 and S6 retracted, variously modiﬁed (less sclerotized, less punctate, and less hairy than S2 to S4); lateral extremity of carina of T6 absent or directed toward lateral extremity of posterior margin of tergum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Chalicodoma) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): S8 with lateral marginal hairs (Fig. 84-10j, n); metasoma commonly strongly convex and twice as long as wide or more, chalicodomiform

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Chalicodoma) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Front tibia on outer surface ending in two spines or teeth (posterior tooth of Gronoceras sometimes represented by angle, which if strong is covered by short hair, see Largella); tibia usually without carina along outer posterior margin; T6 with carina variable, not represented by long spines, but if bilobed, then lobes much broader than long, surface of T6 usually without extremely long hairs, butif present, then such hairs sparse enough that carina almost always easily seen

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Chalicodoma) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Carina of T6 dentate or medially emarginate, not produced medially, without longitudinal median carina but sometimes with broad ridge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Chalicodoma) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Front coxa without spine or with tubercle or short spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Chalicodoma) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): T oothed margin of mandible (threeto four-toothed) strongly oblique, nearly as long as distance from upper tooth to mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Cestella) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): S5 and S6 retracted, variously modiﬁed (less sclerotized, less punctate, and less hairy than S2 to S4); lateral extremity of carina of T6 absent or directed toward lateral extremity of posterior margin of tergum

Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Cestella) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): T oothed margin of mandible (three-toothed) less oblique, much shorter than distance from upper tooth to mandibular base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Cestella) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Eyes unusually large, ocellocular distance thus much less than interocellar distance; T6 without lateral spine (Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World

(Pseudomegachile) (in part) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): S5 and S6 retracted, variously modiﬁed (less sclerotized, less punctate, and less hairy than S2 to S4); lateral extremity of carina of T6 absent or directed toward lateral extremity of posterior margin of tergum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Heriadopsis) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): S5 and S6 retracted, variously modiﬁed (less sclerotized, less punctate, and less hairy than S2 to S4); lateral extremity of carina of T6 absent or directed toward lateral extremity of posterior margin of tergum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Heriadopsis) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): S8 with lateral marginal hairs (Fig. 84-10j, n); metasoma commonly strongly convex and twice as long as wide or more, chalicodomiform

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Heriadopsis) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Front tibia on outer surface ending in two spines or teeth (posterior tooth of Gronoceras sometimes represented by angle, which if strong is covered by short hair, see Largella); tibia usually without carina along outer posterior margin; T6 with carina variable, not represented by long spines, but if bilobed, then lobes much broader than long, surface of T6 usually without extremely long hairs, butif present, then such hairs sparse enough that carina almost always easily seen

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Heriadopsis) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Carina of T6 dentate or medially emarginate, not produced medially, without longitudinal median carina but sometimes with broad ridge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Heriadopsis) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): T6 with carina bilobed (Fig. 84-14c) or sometimes simple, not at all toothed, or sometimes with small lateral tooth; surface of T6 above carina usually with median depression

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Heriadopsis) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Arolia present on front and middle legs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Sub-Saharan Subgenera M. (Platysta) of Megachile(Males)(See the long note following this key.): Hairs of T6 above middle of carina not very long, not extending far beyond carina, although laterally dorsum of T6 may have very long hairs; carina of T6 commonly lower, not or weakly bilobed [in M. (Megella 15(2). Carina of T6 short, occupying little over one-ﬁfth width of tergum, high, rounded-truncate, slightly crenulate, not emarginate medially

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Creightonella) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with six teeth, incomplete cutting edges of similar shape (Fig. 84-17d) in second, third, and fourth interspaces, the last small and often inconspicuous (metasoma parallel-sided)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Austrochile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Austrochile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible without cutting edges between teeth (Fig. 84-12d-f); metasoma parallel-sided, body thus heriadiform or chalicodomiform (as in Fig. 84-9)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Austrochile) of Megachile (Females): S1 with large midapical spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Schizomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Schizomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible without cutting edges between teeth (Fig. 84-12d-f); metasoma parallel-sided, body thus heriadiform or chalicodomiform (as in Fig. 84-9)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Schizomegachile) of Megachile (Females): S1 without apical spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Schizomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Claws each with two teeth on underside; proboscidial fossa closed posteriorly by process from lower side of each genal area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Rhodomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Rhodomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible without cutting edges between teeth (Fig. 84-12d-f); metasoma parallel-sided, body thus heriadiform or chalicodomiform (as in Fig. 84-9)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Rhodomegachile) of Megachile (Females): S1 without apical spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Rhodomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Claws without or with but one ventral tooth each; proboscidial fossa open posteriorly

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Rhodomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Metasomal integument red, and T2 and T3 without deep transverse postgradular grooves; glossa broad, ligulate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Thaumatosoma) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Thaumatosoma) of Megachile (Females): Mandible without cutting edges between teeth (Fig. 84-12d-f); metasoma parallel-sided, body thus heriadiform or chalicodomiform (as in Fig. 84-9)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Thaumatosoma) of Megachile (Females): S1 without apical spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Thaumatosoma) of Megachile (Females): Claws without or with but one ventral tooth each; proboscidial fossa open posteriorly

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Thaumatosoma) of Megachile (Females): Metasomal integument black, or, if red, then with deep postgradular grooves; glossa linear or only slightly broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Thaumatosoma) of Megachile (Females): Mandible bidentate; T6, as seen from above, with strong, rounded, basolateral shoulders, lateral margins thus strongly concave immediately posterior to shoulders

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Hackeriapis) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Hackeriapis) of Megachile (Females): Mandible without cutting edges between teeth (Fig. 84-12d-f); metasoma parallel-sided, body thus heriadiform or chalicodomiform (as in Fig. 84-9)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Hackeriapis) of Megachile (Females): S1 without apical spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Hackeriapis) of Megachile (Females): Claws without or with but one ventral tooth each; proboscidial fossa open posteriorly

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Hackeriapis) of Megachile (Females): Metasomal integument black, or, if red, then with deep postgradular grooves; glossa linear or only slightly broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Hackeriapis) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with three or more teeth; T6 without shoulders, lateral margins gently convex to gently and rather uniformly concave

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Hackeriapis) of Megachile (Females): T2 and T3 usually with deep, transverse postgradular grooves, these absent from some middle-sized and large species in which claws have strong basal tooth (except in M. semiluctuosaSmith); pubescence usually giving a gray aspect, often forming apical white tergal fasciae; fulvous pubescence often present but conﬁned to apical part of metasoma, rarely (M. ustulataSmith) metasoma with extensive fulvous pubescence

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): Mandible without cutting edges between teeth (Fig. 84-12d-f); metasoma parallel-sided, body thus heriadiform or chalicodomiform (as in Fig. 84-9)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): S1 without apical spine

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): Claws without or with but one ventral tooth each; proboscidial fossa open posteriorly

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): Metasomal integument black, or, if red, then with deep postgradular grooves; glossa linear or only slightly broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with three or more teeth; T6 without shoulders, lateral margins gently convex to gently and rather uniformly concave

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): Metasomal terga without deep, transverse postgradular grooves [except in C. (Callomegachile) mcnameraeCockerell and others from New Guinea northwestward]; claws without basal teeth; pubescence black, fulvous, or with white patches, not grayish in aspect and not forming tergal fasciae; fulvous pubescence, if present, not conﬁned to apical part of metasoma

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): Mandible shining (although reticulate), apical margin very oblique, as long as distance from basal tooth to base of mandible; sharp hypostomal tooth behind base of mandible

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible without cutting edges between teeth (Fig. 84-12d-f); metasoma parallel-sided, body thus heriadiform or chalicodomiform (as in Fig. 84-9)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Females): S1 without apical spine

Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Claws without or with but one ventral tooth each; proboscidial fossa open posteriorly

Title: Bees Of The World

Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Metasomal integument black, or, if red, then with deep postgradular grooves; glossa linear or only slightly broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with three or more teeth; T6 without shoulders, lateral margins gently convex to gently and rather uniformly concave

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Metasomal terga without deep, transverse postgradular grooves [except in C. (Callomegachile) mcnameraeCockerell and others from New Guinea northwestward]; claws without basal teeth; pubescence black, fulvous, or with white patches, not grayish in aspect and not forming tergal fasciae; fulvous pubescence, if present, not conﬁned to apical part of metasoma

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible dull with minute roughening, apical margin shorter; no tooth behind base of mandible

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Mitchellapis) of Megachile (Females): S6 with large smooth hairless area before apical fringe; T6 with many long hairs visible in proﬁle, its apex produced and shallowly emarginate; pronotal lobe with rounded transverse ridge

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): S6 uniformly punctate and hairy; T6 with only very short hairs visible in proﬁle, its apex rounded; pronotal lobe with strong transverse carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Amegachile) of Megachile (Females): Species with fulvous and black coloration suggestive of Callomegachile; third mandibular tooth broad and irregularly truncate because of fusion with cutting edge of second interspace (Fig. 84-11e), second (in Australian area) truncate (sometimes obliquely) or sinuate at apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Eutricharaea) of Megachile (Females): Species usually dull-colored, gray, often with pale metasomal bands of hair; third mandibular tooth as well as second angulate, cutting edge in second interspace usually present although incomplete and not indistinguishably fused to third tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Creightonella) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with six teeth, incomplete cutting edges of similar shape (Fig. 84-17d) in second, third, and fourth interspaces, the last small and often inconspicuous (metasoma parallel-sided)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Austrochile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Austrochile) of Megachile (Females): S8 with lateral hairs (Fig. 84-10j, n); body heriadiform or chalicodomiform, metasoma ordinarily twice as long as wide (Fig. 84-9)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Austrochile) of Megachile (Females): S1 with large midapical spine; carina of T6 very high and weakly crenulate to serrate medially, usually not emarginate, abruptly disappearing laterally so that general aspect is a large, truncate projection (Fig. 84-14d)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Schizomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Schizomegachile) of Megachile (Females): S8 with lateral hairs (Fig. 84-10j, n); body heriadiform or chalicodomiform, metasoma ordinarily twice as long as wide (Fig. 84-9)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Schizomegachile) of Megachile (Females): S1 at most apically tuberculate; carina of T6 low (rarely even absent), not crenulate or serrate, medially slightly emarginate (except in Mitchellapis, Rhodomegachile, and a few others)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Schizomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Hind tibial spurs absent; S6 divided into two lateral sclerites by broad, median, membranous region

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Rhodomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Rhodomegachile) of Megachile (Females): S8 with lateral hairs (Fig. 84-10j, n); body heriadiform or chalicodomiform, metasoma ordinarily twice as long as wide (Fig. 84-9)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Rhodomegachile) of Megachile (Females): S1 at most apically tuberculate; carina of T6 low (rarely even absent), not crenulate or serrate, medially slightly emarginate (except in Mitchellapis, Rhodomegachile, and a few others)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Rhodomegachile) of Megachile (Females): T wo hind tibial spurs present (only one in Thaumatosoma); S6 continuous, not divided into lateral hemisternites

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Rhodomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Carina of T6 variable, without median tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Rhodomegachile) of Megachile (Females): S4 retracted, or rear margin in some cases exposed (Fig. 84-13a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Rhodomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Carina of T6 reduced to short, non-emarginate ridge or absent; metasomal integument red, without strong postgradular grooves on T2 and T3; glossa broad, ligulate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Thaumatosoma) of Megachile (Females): Only one hind tibial spur; clypeus with group of coarse, quill-like bristles arising near middle; ﬂagellum exceedingly attenuate, ﬁrst segment longer than others, last two segments expanded (Fig. 84-10q)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Hackeriapis) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): Carina of T6 evident, in almost every case medially emarginate [merely an emarginate swelling, not carinate, inM. (Hackeriapis) cliffordi Rayment; a scarcely emarginate ridge in M. (H.) appositaRayment]; metasomal integument usually black, but if red, then with strong transverse postgradular grooves on T2 and T3; glossa linear, rarely somewhat broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): Distance between apices of ﬁrst and third mandibular teeth nearly equal to distance from third tooth to base of mandible; apex of S1 produced as a broad, nearly hairless, median, suberect ﬂap; large, robust species; metasoma without indications of pale tergal bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Females): T2 and T3 usually without deep transverse postgradular grooves; pubescence all black or with pale or ocher areas not forming metasomal bands; posterior margin of T6 without teeth

Title: Bees Of The World

Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Mitchellapis) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Mitchellapis) of Megachile (Females): Carina of T6, near the untoothed tergal margin, broadly rounded except for median tooth at apex of low, longitudinal median ridge

(Hackeriapis) cliffordi Rayment; a scarcely emarginate ridge in M. (H.) appositaRayment]; metasomal integument usually black, but if red, then with strong transverse postgradular grooves on T2 and T3; glossa linear, rarely somewhat broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): Distance between ﬁrst and third (or second if mandible only bidentate) mandibular teeth much less than distance from uppermost tooth to base of mandible; apex of S1 not as above; usually smaller and more slender species; metasoma usually with indications of pale tergal bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): Region of carina of T6 swollen except at median emargination (northern Australia and northward)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Amegachile) of Megachile (Females): Body with fulvous-and-black pubescence suggestive of Callomegachile; apical margin of T6 with four widely separated small teeth

Title: Bees Of The World

Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Austrochile) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Rhodomegachile) of Megachile (Females): Carina of T6 reduced to short, non-emarginate ridge or absent; metasomal integument red, without strong postgradular grooves on T2 and T3; glossa broad, ligulate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): S8 with lateral hairs (Fig. 84-10j, n); body heriadiform or chalicodomiform, metasoma ordinarily twice as long as wide (Fig. 84-9)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): S1 at most apically tuberculate; carina of T6 low (rarely even absent), not crenulate or serrate, medially slightly emarginate (except in Mitchellapis, Rhodomegachile, and a few others)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): T wo hind tibial spurs present (only one in Thaumatosoma); S6 continuous, not divided into lateral hemisternites

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): Carina of T6 variable, without median tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): S4 retracted, or rear margin in some cases exposed (Fig. 84-13a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): Carina of T6 evident, in almost every case medially emarginate [merely an emarginate swelling, not carinate, inM. (Hackeriapis) cliffordi Rayment; a scarcely emarginate ridge in M. (H.) appositaRayment]; metasomal integument usually black, but if red, then with strong transverse postgradular grooves on T2 and T3; glossa linear, rarely somewhat broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chalicodomoides) of Megachile (Females): Distance between apices of ﬁrst and third mandibular teeth nearly equal to distance from third tooth to base of mandible; apex of S1 produced as a broad, nearly hairless, median, suberect ﬂap; large, robust species; metasoma without indications of pale tergal bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): Mandible with two to ﬁve teeth, cutting edges absent or in second and third interspaces only, usually of quite different shapes in the two interspaces or absent in one or the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): S8 with lateral hairs (Fig. 84-10j, n); body heriadiform or chalicodomiform, metasoma ordinarily twice as long as wide (Fig. 84-9)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): S1 at most apically tuberculate; carina of T6 low (rarely even absent), not crenulate or serrate, medially slightly emarginate (except in Mitchellapis, Rhodomegachile, and a few others)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): T wo hind tibial spurs present (only one in Thaumatosoma); S6 continuous, not divided into lateral hemisternites

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): Carina of T6 variable, without median tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): S4 retracted, or rear margin in some cases exposed (Fig. 84-13a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): Carina of T6 evident, in almost every case medially emarginate [merely an emarginate swelling, not carinate, inM. (Hackeriapis) cliffordi Rayment; a scarcely emarginate ridge in M. (H.) appositaRayment]; metasomal integument usually black, but if red, then with strong transverse postgradular grooves on T2 and T3; glossa linear, rarely somewhat broadened

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): Distance between ﬁrst and third (or second if mandible only bidentate) mandibular teeth much less than distance from uppermost tooth to base of mandible; apex of S1 not as above; usually smaller and more slender species; metasoma usually with indications of pale tergal bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Chelostomoda) of Megachile (Females): Region of carina of T6 swollen except at median emargination (northern Australia and northward)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Hackeriapis) (in part) of Megachile (Females): T erga usually with deep postgradular grooves; pubescence usually giving a gray appearance, in some cases fulvous on metasoma, usually forming metasomal bands; posterior margin of T6 usually with four teeth, median teeth absent in some cases

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Thaumatosoma) of Megachile (Females): Only one hind tibial spur; clypeus with group of coarse, quill-like bristles arising near middle; ﬂagellum exceedingly attenuate, ﬁrst segment longer than others, last two segments expanded (Fig. 84-10q)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Callomegachile) of Megachile (Females): T2 and T3 usually without deep transverse postgradular grooves; pubescence all black or with pale or ocher areas not forming metasomal bands; posterior margin of T6 without teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Hackeriapis) (in part) of Megachile (Females): T erga usually with deep postgradular grooves; pubescence usually giving a gray appearance, in some cases fulvous on metasoma, usually forming metasomal bands; posterior margin of T6 usually with four teeth, median teeth absent in some cases

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Amegachile) of Megachile (Females): Body with fulvous-and-black pubescence suggestive of Callomegachile; apical margin of T6 with four widely separated small teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Australian and Papuan Subgenera M. (Eutricharaea) of Megachile (Females): Body usually appearing dull-colored, gray, often with pale metasomal tergal hair bands; apical margin of T6 with small lateral tooth only, or sometimes with weak indication of two submedian teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Meliponini, of the Apidae: Submarginal crossveins and second recurrent vein weak compared with other veins, commonly absent (Fig. 1201); marginal cell open at apex or closed by weakened vein (hind tibial spurs absent)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Apini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Apini, of the Apidae: Scopa of female, when present, forming a corbicula on posterior tibia (Figs. 10-11, 102-2a, 118-3, 121-1a); inner apical margin of posterior tibia of nonparasitic females (except in queens of Apini) with row of stiff bristles (the rastellum, Fig. 102-2); pygidial and basitibial plates absent; eyes hairy or jugal lobe of hind wing absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Apini, of the Apidae: Eye hairy; jugal lobe of hind wing present although notch delimiting it shallow; hind tibial spurs absent; arolia present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Euglossini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Euglossini, of the Apidae: Scopa of female, when present, forming a corbicula on posterior tibia (Figs. 10-11, 102-2a, 118-3, 121-1a); inner apical margin of posterior tibia of nonparasitic females (except in queens of Apini) with row of stiff bristles (the rastellum, Fig. 102-2); pygidial and basitibial plates absent; eyes hairy or jugal lobe of hind wing absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Euglossini, of the Apidae: Eye bare; jugal lobe of hind wing absent; hind tibial spurs present; arolia absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Euglossini, of the Apidae: Proboscis in repose reaching beyond base of metasoma; body usually at least partly metallic; hind tibia of male with deep, hairy groove on upper surface (Fig. 1184a-c); comb or group of bristles in position of jugal lobe of hind wing (Fig. 118-5) (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Bombini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Bombini, of the Apidae: Scopa of female, when present, forming a corbicula on posterior tibia (Figs. 10-11, 102-2a, 118-3, 121-1a); inner apical margin of posterior tibia of nonparasitic females (except in queens of Apini) with row of stiff bristles (the rastellum, Fig. 102-2); pygidial and basitibial plates absent; eyes hairy or jugal lobe of hind wing absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Bombini, of the Apidae: Eye bare; jugal lobe of hind wing absent; hind tibial spurs present; arolia absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Bombini, of the Apidae: Proboscis in repose not reaching base of metasoma; body not metallic; hind tibia of male not grooved; no comb of bristles on base of hind wing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae, Xylocopini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae, Xylocopini, of the Apidae: Scopa of female not forming a tibial corbicula [except in Canephorula and Hamatothrix (Eucerini) from Argentina], and scopa sometimes absent; inner apical margins of posterior tibiae bare or hairy, without comb; pygidial and basitibial plates frequently present; eyes very rarely hairy and jugal lobe of hind wing almost always present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae, Xylocopini, of the Apidae: Stigma absent (Fig. 88-2a); middle and hind basitarsi usually longer than tibiae; clypeus nearly ﬂat, lower lateral areas not curved backward (Figs. 21-3c, g, 88-5b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae, Allodapini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae, Allodapini, of the Apidae: Scopa of female not forming a tibial corbicula [except in Canephorula and Hamatothrix (Eucerini) from Argentina], and scopa sometimes absent; inner apical margins of posterior tibiae bare or hairy, without comb; pygidial and basitibial plates frequently present; eyes very rarely hairy and jugal lobe of hind wing almost always present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae, Allodapini, of the Apidae: Stigma present, although sometimes (e.g., in Anthophora, Centris;Figs. 113-1, 114-1) very small; middle and hind basitarsi usually shorter than tibiae; clypeus variable but usually more convex with lower lateral parts bent backward (Fig. 21-3d, h)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae, Allodapini, of the Apidae: Pygidial plate absent, sometimes represented by spine in pygidial ﬁmbria of female; scopa present (but reduced in parasitic Allodapini); epistomal suture between lateral extremity and subantennal suture usually bent mesad such that upper part of clypeus is almost parallel-sided; clypeus not or weakly protuberant

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae, Allodapini, of the Apidae: Submarginal cells two (Fig. 90-11); clypeus typically slightly constricted at level of tentorial pits (Fig. 90-2), this level near middle of clypeus (Eastern Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae,  Manueliini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae,  Manueliini, of the Apidae: Scopa of female not forming a tibial corbicula [except in Canephorula and Hamatothrix (Eucerini) from Argentina], and scopa sometimes absent; inner apical margins of posterior tibiae bare or hairy, without comb; pygidial and basitibial plates frequently present; eyes very rarely hairy and jugal lobe of hind wing almost always present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae,  Manueliini, of the Apidae: Stigma present, although sometimes (e.g., in Anthophora, Centris;Figs. 113-1, 114-1) very small; middle and hind basitarsi usually shorter than tibiae; clypeus variable but usually more convex with lower lateral parts bent backward (Fig. 21-3d, h)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae,  Manueliini, of the Apidae: Pygidial plate absent, sometimes represented by spine in pygidial ﬁmbria of female; scopa present (but reduced in parasitic Allodapini); epistomal suture between lateral extremity and subantennal suture usually bent mesad such that upper part of clypeus is almost parallel-sided; clypeus not or weakly protuberant

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae,  Manueliini, of the Apidae: Submarginal cells three (Fig. 89-4); clypeus not constricted at level of tentorial pits, this level above middle of clypeus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae,  Manueliini, of the Apidae: Jugal lobe of hind wing less than one-ﬁfth as long as vannal lobe; female with spinelike pygidial plate arising from pygidial ﬁmbria (Chile, Argentina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae, Ceratinini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae, Ceratinini, of the Apidae: Scopa of female not forming a tibial corbicula [except in Canephorula and Hamatothrix (Eucerini) from Argentina], and scopa sometimes absent; inner apical margins of posterior tibiae bare or hairy, without comb; pygidial and basitibial plates frequently present; eyes very rarely hairy and jugal lobe of hind wing almost always present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae, Ceratinini, of the Apidae: Stigma present, although sometimes (e.g., in Anthophora, Centris;Figs. 113-1, 114-1) very small; middle and hind basitarsi usually shorter than tibiae; clypeus variable but usually more convex with lower lateral parts bent backward (Fig. 21-3d, h)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae, Ceratinini, of the Apidae: Pygidial plate absent, sometimes represented by spine in pygidial ﬁmbria of female; scopa present (but reduced in parasitic Allodapini); epistomal suture between lateral extremity and subantennal suture usually bent mesad such that upper part of clypeus is almost parallel-sided; clypeus not or weakly protuberant

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae, Ceratinini, of the Apidae: Submarginal cells three (Fig. 89-4); clypeus not constricted at level of tentorial pits, this level above middle of clypeus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Xylocopinae, Ceratinini, of the Apidae: Jugal lobe over one-third as long as vannal lobe; pygidial plate and pygidial ﬁmbria absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Melectini (in part), of the Apidae: Middle tibial spur unmodiﬁed; male gonostyli elongate; T6 of female with well-deﬁned pygidial plate; marginal cell in common genera not or scarcely exceeding last submarginal cell, but in certain rare Eastern Hemisphere genera much exceeding last submarginal cell

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, T etrapediini, Coelioxoides, of the Apidae: Arolia absent; preoccipital carina strong behind eye, upper end curved forward to summit of eye; mandible with large tooth near middle of inner margin, projecting almost at right angle to mandibular axis (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Caenoprosopidini, of the Apidae: Episternal groove extending well below scrobal groove; scutellum and axilla lamellate or produced laterally; T5 of female without longitudinal ridge; preoccipital carina present (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Ammobatoidini (in part), of the Apidae: Pygidial plate of female well deﬁned; S6 of female broadly emarginate apically, lateral lobes with many blunt, spinelike bristles (as in Fig. 91-2a); eyes of male converging above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Ammobatini, of the Apidae: Pygidial plate of female absent or feebly deﬁned; S6 of female produced to simple or biﬁd apex, without spinelike bristles (Fig. 91-2i); eyes of male not convergent above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Ammobatoidini, Ammobatoides, of the Apidae: Pygidial plate of female well deﬁned; S6 of female broadly emarginate apically, lateral lobes with many blunt, spinelike bristles (as in Fig. 91-2a); eyes of male converging above

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Neolarrini, of the Apidae: Marginal cell at most but little larger than stigma (Fig. 99-1), truncate apically; one or two submarginal cells, the second, when present, much wider than long (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Rhathymini (part), of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Rhathymini (part), of the Apidae: Maxillary palpus absent and axilla small, not at all produced; epistomal suture absent below anterior tentorial pit so that clypeus and lower paraocular areas are fused

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Ericrocidini, of the Apidae: Middle tibial spur large, biﬁd or multidentate apically (Fig. 116-3); male gonostyli short, broad, often with slender projections (Fig. 116-5a, d, g); T6 of female with pygidial plate deﬁned only at apex; marginal cell considerably exceeding last submarginal cell (Western Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Melectini (in part), of the Apidae: Middle tibial spur unmodiﬁed; male gonostyli elongate; T6 of female with well-deﬁned pygidial plate; marginal cell in common genera not or scarcely exceeding last submarginal cell, but in certain rare Eastern Hemisphere genera much exceeding last submarginal cell

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Rhathymini (part), of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Rhathymini (part), of the Apidae: Maxillary palpus absent and axilla small, not at all produced; epistomal suture absent below anterior tentorial pit so that clypeus and lower paraocular areas are fused

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Biastini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Biastini, of the Apidae: Scape, excluding basal bulb, less than twice as long as broad; T6 of female with apical margin broadly concave, without pygidial plate (except plate present in Rhopalolemma); sting sheath (third valvula) thickened (usually two submarginal cells) (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, T ownsendiellini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, T ownsendiellini, of the Apidae: Submarginal cells two, second much shorter than ﬁrst and receiving only second recurrent vein (Fig. 973a), or sometimes also ﬁrst recurrent very near its base; S6 of female broadly emarginate, lobes at either side of emargination armed with a series of large, spinelike bristles (Fig. 91-2c) (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Epeolini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Epeolini, of the Apidae: Front coxae quadrate, trochanters arising from outer distal angles of coxae, trochanters thus far apart; axilla nearly always produced to acute angle or spine (Fig. 93-1c); S6 of female largely invaginated, disc reduced and lateral distal portions produced to form a pair of long, dentate or spinose processes (Fig. 95-3c, d)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Osirini (in part), of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Osirini (in part), of the Apidae: Scopa of female, when present, forming a corbicula on posterior tibia (Figs. 10-11, 102-2a, 118-3, 121-1a); inner apical margin of posterior tibia of nonparasitic females (except in queens of Apini) with row of stiff bristles (the rastellum, Fig. 102-2); pygidial and basitibial plates absent; eyes hairy or jugal lobe of hind wing absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Osirini (in part), of the Apidae: Arolia much shorter than claws, scarcely capitate; pygidial plate present in both sexes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Brachynomadini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Brachynomadini, of the Apidae: S6 of female with apex elongate, bifurcate (Fig. 912f); maxillary palpus usually less than half as long as maxillary blade (body without yellow markings) (Western Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Nomadini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Nomadini, of the Apidae: Apex of marginal cell sharply pointed (Fig. 94-2); metasomal terga without distinct apical hair bands (Fig. 94-1); S6 of female subtruncate or feebly emarginate (Fig. 91-2e); body frequently with white or yellow markings

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Hexepeolini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Nomadinae, Hexepeolini, of the Apidae: Apex of marginal cell rounded; metasomal terga with strong apical hair bands (Fig. 92-1); S6 of female emarginate (Fig. 91-2d); body without pale markings

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Ctenoplectrini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Ctenoplectrini, of the Apidae: First two segments of labial palpus somewhat ﬂattened but neither long nor sheathlike (Fig. 110-1c, d), thus as in S-T bees; S2 to S5 of female with oblique areas of long, sigmoid, oil-collecting hairs (Fig. 110-3) (rudiments on S3 to S5 even in parasitic species); inner hind tibial spur of female a ﬁne comb of long teeth, in nonparasitic species with base greatly broadened across tibia (Fig. 110-2a, c, d) (Africa, oriental, eastern palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Eucerini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Eucerini, of the Apidae: Scopa of female, when present, forming a corbicula on posterior tibia (Figs. 10-11, 102-2a, 118-3, 121-1a); inner apical margin of posterior tibia of nonparasitic females (except in queens of Apini) with row of stiff bristles (the rastellum, Fig. 102-2); pygidial and basitibial plates absent; eyes hairy or jugal lobe of hind wing absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Eucerini, of the Apidae: Paraglossa as long as ﬁrst two segments of labial palpus taken together (except in Eucerinoda from Chile); jugal lobe of hind wing about half as long as vannal lobe or sometimes more; antenna of males commonly elongate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Anthophorini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Anthophorini, of the Apidae: Scopa of female, when present, forming a corbicula on posterior tibia (Figs. 10-11, 102-2a, 118-3, 121-1a); inner apical margin of posterior tibia of nonparasitic females (except in queens of Apini) with row of stiff bristles (the rastellum, Fig. 102-2); pygidial and basitibial plates absent; eyes hairy or jugal lobe of hind wing absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Anthophorini, of the Apidae: First submarginal cell larger than second, posterior margin longer than that of second (Fig. 113-1); scopal hairs of female largely simple, sometimes plumose along upper margin of tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Centridini, of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Centridini, of the Apidae: Scopa of female, when present, forming a corbicula on posterior tibia (Figs. 10-11, 102-2a, 118-3, 121-1a); inner apical margin of posterior tibia of nonparasitic females (except in queens of Apini) with row of stiff bristles (the rastellum, Fig. 102-2); pygidial and basitibial plates absent; eyes hairy or jugal lobe of hind wing absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Centridini, of the Apidae: First submarginal cell usually smaller than second, posterior margin shorter than that of second (Fig. 114-1); scopal hairs of female mostly plumose, often intermixed with simple hairs or with projecting simple apices (Western Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Emphorini (in part), of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Emphorini (in part), of the Apidae: Scopa of female, when present, forming a corbicula on posterior tibia (Figs. 10-11, 102-2a, 118-3, 121-1a); inner apical margin of posterior tibia of nonparasitic females (except in queens of Apini) with row of stiff bristles (the rastellum, Fig. 102-2); pygidial and basitibial plates absent; eyes hairy or jugal lobe of hind wing absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily Apinae, Emphorini (in part), of the Apidae: Vertex seen in facial view depressed between eye and ocelli, the ocellar area a little elevated (as in Fig. 111-2b); second abscissa of vein M/H11001Cu of hind wing much longer than vein cu-v and usually more than half as long as vein M (Figs. 106-2a, 107-1, 108-2b, 108-3); ﬁrst submarginal cell on posterior margin often not conspicuously longest when there are three submarginal cells, usually shorter than or subequal to third (Figs. 108-2, 108-3)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics of the Subfamily 35 35(34). Clypeus strongly protuberant, in side view pro- truding in front of eye by about width of eye; vertex gen- tly convex as seen from front; hind leg of male (femur to basitarsus) enlarged (Fig. 111-2c) (Western Hemisphere) ...................... Apinae, Emphorini (Ancyloscelis), of the Apidae: All veins well developed, conspicuous; marginal cell closed by strong vein
