(Ceratina s. str.) of Ceratina of the EasternHemisphere(In part modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1971a): Maxillary palpus ﬁveor six-segmented; S5 of female with gradulus; T6 of male without gradulus; T7 of male truncate or rounded or pointed posteriorly; S2 of male without tubercle; gonostylus of male without down-curved projection (palearctic, Africa, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Neoceratina) of Ceratina of the EasternHemisphere(In part modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1971a): Maxillary palpus ﬁve-segmented; S5 of female without gradulus; T6 of male usually with gradulus; T7 of male usually extending posteriorly as long projection that is simple or bidentate at apex; S2 of male usually with tubercle in middle; gonostylus of male with down-curved projection (palearctic, oriental, Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Euceratina) of Ceratina of the EasternHemisphere(In part modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1971a): Palearctic. Male gonostylus several times as long as broad, simple, hairy, well separated from gonocoxite; T6 with median longitudinal keel; T7 of male strongly extending posteriorly, simple or bidentate at apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Malgatina) of Ceratina of the EasternHemisphere(In part modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1971a): Body dark metallic blue; posterior femur of male without tooth or comb of hairs (Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Copoceratina) of Ceratina of the EasternHemisphere(In part modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1971a): Posterior femur of male with ventrobasal tooth, without median ventral comb of hairs; T6 of male without median convexity; terga without apical plumose hairs (Africa, Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Hirashima) of Ceratina of the EasternHemisphere(In part modiﬁed from Hirashima, 1971a): Posterior femur of male without tooth, with median ventral (sometimes interrupted) comb of hairs; T6 of male with large median convexity with punctuation much ﬁner than on nearby areas; T1 to T4 (or at least T1 and T2) with apical bands of white plumose hairs laterally (Africa, Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calloceratina) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Pronotum with distinct transverse carina sometimes interrupted medially, in front of posterior margin of pronotum, curving strongly downward at each side to front coxa

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Calloceratina) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Female without yellow or white on paraocular area; posterior tibia of female and some males on outer side basally usually with oblique carina representing posterior margin of basitibial plate; body usually brilliantly metallic, at least in some areas; maxillary palpus ﬁveor six-segmented (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Crewella) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Pronotum with distinct transverse carina sometimes interrupted medially, in front of posterior margin of pronotum, curving strongly downward at each side to front coxa

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Crewella) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Female with yellow or white on paraocular area; posterior tibia of both sexes without oblique carina, usually with protuberant angle or tooth representing apex of basitibial plate; body dark metallic; maxillary palpus sixsegmented (South and Central America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ceratinula) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Pronotum without transverse carina (or such carina almost coincident with posterior margin of pronotum), and carina usually not extending downward to front coxa

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ceratinula) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Extensive impunctate regions on genal and frontal areas; maxillary palpus ﬁveor six-segmented (preoccipital carina present or absent; paraocular area with pale marks in males and some females)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Euceratina) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Pronotum without transverse carina (or such carina almost coincident with posterior margin of pronotum), and carina usually not extending downward to front coxa

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Euceratina) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Genal and frontal areas with punctures; maxillary palpus six-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Euceratina) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Preoccipital carina absent or weak; male gonostylus several times as long as broad, hairy (California; introduced)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Rhysoceratina) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Pronotum without transverse carina (or such carina almost coincident with posterior margin of pronotum), and carina usually not extending downward to front coxa

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Rhysoceratina) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Genal and frontal areas with punctures; maxillary palpus six-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Rhysoceratina) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Preoccipital carina strong; male gonostylus little longer than broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Rhysoceratina) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Paraocular area with pale marking in both sexes; T5 without gradulus; frons punctate throughout; T6 of female with strong carina extending from apex anterolaterally, separating dorsal from lateroventral surface of tergum (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Zadontomerus) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Pronotum without transverse carina (or such carina almost coincident with posterior margin of pronotum), and carina usually not extending downward to front coxa

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Zadontomerus) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Genal and frontal areas with punctures; maxillary palpus six-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Zadontomerus) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Preoccipital carina strong; male gonostylus little longer than broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Zadontomerus) of Ceratina of the WesternHemisphere: Paraocular area dark in females and nearly all males; T5 with gradulus; frons with smooth convexity on each side of midline; T6 of female without carina (North and Central America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Macrogalea of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Body rather robust, head and thorax hairy, female with transverse fasciae of short, appressed plumose hairs on T2 to T5; stigma slender (Fig. 90-12b), basal part parallelsided; prestigma about as long as distance from base of stigma to base of vein r; jugal lobe of hind wing enormous (Fig. 90-12b), almost as long as vannal lobe (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eucondylops of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Second recurrent vein absent (Figs. 90-10b, 90-13d); facial projection on frons, bilobed or paired (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Nasutapis of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Second recurrent vein present (Fig. 90-13c); facial projection on apex of clypeus, snoutlike, not bilobed or paired (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneuridia of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Body slender, inconspicuously hairy and lacking metasomal fasciae of plumose hairs; stigma broad, not parallel-sided (Figs. 28-4, 90-11a-c, 90-13); prestigma usually half as long as distance from base of stigma to base of vein r; jugal lobe of hind wing of ordinary size, extending little if any beyond vein cu-v [except in Braunsapis trochanterata (Gerstaecker)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneuridia of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Labial palpus with apical segments small and in ordinary position sharply divergent from axis of ﬁrst two segments; maxillary palpus ﬁveto six-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneuridia of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Second recurrent vein absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneuridia of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Malar space nearly as long as broad; T5 and T6 of female each with sharp, lateral lamella or strong carina (southwestern Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Compsomelissa (in part) of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Body slender, inconspicuously hairy and lacking metasomal fasciae of plumose hairs; stigma broad, not parallel-sided (Figs. 28-4, 90-11a-c, 90-13); prestigma usually half as long as distance from base of stigma to base of vein r; jugal lobe of hind wing of ordinary size, extending little if any beyond vein cu-v [except in Braunsapis trochanterata (Gerstaecker)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Compsomelissa (in part) of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Labial palpus with apical segments small and in ordinary position sharply divergent from axis of ﬁrst two segments; maxillary palpus ﬁveto six-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Compsomelissa (in part) of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Second recurrent vein absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Compsomelissa (in part) of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Malar space much wider than long; T5 and T6 without lateral lamellate carinae, at most T5 with lateral part of gradulus as on preceding terga

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Compsomelissa (in part) of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Maxillary palpus six-segmented; thorax and metasoma with yellow or white markings (Africa, Arabia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneurella of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Body slender, inconspicuously hairy and lacking metasomal fasciae of plumose hairs; stigma broad, not parallel-sided (Figs. 28-4, 90-11a-c, 90-13); prestigma usually half as long as distance from base of stigma to base of vein r; jugal lobe of hind wing of ordinary size, extending little if any beyond vein cu-v [except in Braunsapis trochanterata (Gerstaecker)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneurella of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Labial palpus with apical segments small and in ordinary position sharply divergent from axis of ﬁrst two segments; maxillary palpus ﬁveto six-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneurella of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Second recurrent vein absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneurella of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Malar space much wider than long; T5 and T6 without lateral lamellate carinae, at most T5 with lateral part of gradulus as on preceding terga

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneurella of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Maxillary palpus ﬁve-segmented; thorax and metasoma without yellow or white markings except sometimes on pronotum, tegula, and axillary sclerites, and rarely bands on metasomal terga

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneurella of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Costal margin of second submarginal cell short, often less than half as long as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein [except almost as long as that crossvein in E. tridentata (Houston)]; basitibial plate not indicated; T6 of female with apex strongly produced, upturned, bidentate or tridentate, not at all hidden by pubescence (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneura of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Body slender, inconspicuously hairy and lacking metasomal fasciae of plumose hairs; stigma broad, not parallel-sided (Figs. 28-4, 90-11a-c, 90-13); prestigma usually half as long as distance from base of stigma to base of vein r; jugal lobe of hind wing of ordinary size, extending little if any beyond vein cu-v [except in Braunsapis trochanterata (Gerstaecker)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneura of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Labial palpus with apical segments small and in ordinary position sharply divergent from axis of ﬁrst two segments; maxillary palpus ﬁveto six-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneura of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Second recurrent vein absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneura of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Malar space much wider than long; T5 and T6 without lateral lamellate carinae, at most T5 with lateral part of gradulus as on preceding terga

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneura of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Maxillary palpus ﬁve-segmented; thorax and metasoma without yellow or white markings except sometimes on pronotum, tegula, and axillary sclerites, and rarely bands on metasomal terga

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exoneura of the Allodapini Based on Adults: Costal margin of second submarginal cell usually almost as long as ﬁrst submarginal crossvein; basitibial plate of female usually indicated by carina strongly raised across apex of plate; T6 of female with apex little produced, not or weakly upturned, not or minutely bidentate, not tridentate, and usually hidden by pubescence denser at apex of tergum than elsewhere (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Exoneurella of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Antenna tapering to attenuate, acute point; ventrolateral area of head swollen, tending to hang down on either side of mouthparts, bearing large curved hairs; body sharply bent in middle rather than uniformly curved (Australia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Braunsapis, Nasutapis of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Antenna blunt or almost absent; lateral area of head, if enlarged and with large hairs, then dorsolateral, not lobed down on either side of mouthparts; body uniformly curved or rather straight

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Braunsapis, Nasutapis of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Head or lateral protuberances of ﬁrst body segment with enormous curved hairs; antenna represented by feeble convexity

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Braunsapis, Nasutapis of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Large, curved hairs on upper and lateral parts of head 10 to 18 or more; ﬁrst ventrolateral projection of body without such hairs [except that Braunsapis trochanterata (Gerstaecker) has three to ﬁve]; ventral or ventrolateral parts of body with hairs (limited to ﬁrst and last two segments in B. simplicipesMichener)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Allodape of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Antenna blunt or almost absent; lateral area of head, if enlarged and with large hairs, then dorsolateral, not lobed down on either side of mouthparts; body uniformly curved or rather straight

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Allodape of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Head or lateral protuberances of ﬁrst body segment with enormous curved hairs; antenna represented by feeble convexity

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Allodape of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Large, curved hairs on head eight or less, on vertex; ﬁrst ventrolateral projection of body with seven to about 20 much larger hairs; ventral and ventrolateral parts of body hairless except for ﬁrst ventrolateral projections (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Macrogalea of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Antenna blunt or almost absent; lateral area of head, if enlarged and with large hairs, then dorsolateral, not lobed down on either side of mouthparts; body uniformly curved or rather straight

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Macrogalea of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Anterior end of body without large hairs; head hairs, if present, usually not much if any longer than those found elsewhere on body; antenna strongly projecting

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Macrogalea of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Body curled, covered all over with short hairs, some of those of dorsum hooked (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Compsomelissa of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Antenna blunt or almost absent; lateral area of head, if enlarged and with large hairs, then dorsolateral, not lobed down on either side of mouthparts; body uniformly curved or rather straight

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Compsomelissa of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Anterior end of body without large hairs; head hairs, if present, usually not much if any longer than those found elsewhere on body; antenna strongly projecting

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Compsomelissa of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Body naked or nearly so, or, if hairy, then nearly straight and without hooked hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Compsomelissa of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Body curled, hairless or nearly so, with lateral projections corresponding to second and third body segments but otherwise without tubercles; maxilla and labium without projecting sensory areas (Africa, Arabia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Exoneura of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Antenna blunt or almost absent; lateral area of head, if enlarged and with large hairs, then dorsolateral, not lobed down on either side of mouthparts; body uniformly curved or rather straight

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Exoneura of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Anterior end of body without large hairs; head hairs, if present, usually not much if any longer than those found elsewhere on body; antenna strongly projecting

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Exoneura of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Body naked or nearly so, or, if hairy, then nearly straight and without hooked hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Exoneura of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Body rather straight, hairy or multituberculate; maxilla and labium with projecting sensory areas representing palpi

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Exoneura of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Australian

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Allodapula, Eucondylops of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Antenna blunt or almost absent; lateral area of head, if enlarged and with large hairs, then dorsolateral, not lobed down on either side of mouthparts; body uniformly curved or rather straight

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Allodapula, Eucondylops of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Anterior end of body without large hairs; head hairs, if present, usually not much if any longer than those found elsewhere on body; antenna strongly projecting

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Allodapula, Eucondylops of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Body naked or nearly so, or, if hairy, then nearly straight and without hooked hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Allodapula, Eucondylops of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): Body rather straight, hairy or multituberculate; maxilla and labium with projecting sensory areas representing palpi

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to Genera Allodapula, Eucondylops of Allodapini Based on Mature Larvae(Illustrated in Figure 90-6; larvae of Effractapis and Ex-oneuridia are unknown): African

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dalloapula) of Allodapula Based on AdultMales: Gonostylus of male minute, stylus-shaped (Fig. 90-8a), with short, slender hairs; penis valve and ventroapical plate much exceeding gonostylus; roof of genital chamber weakly convex, not or scarcely folded, each half over twice as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Allodapula s. str.) of Allodapula Based on AdultMales: Gonostylus variously shaped, not styluslike, with hairs as long as width of gonostylus and often robust (Fig. 908d); penis valve and projections from gonocoxite not exceeding gonostylus; convexities of roof of genital chamber strong, about as in Braunsapis,each half broad, folded or not

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Allodapula s. str.) of Allodapula Based on AdultMales: Gonobase reduced, consisting of narrow sclerotized bands; penis valves slender, only weakly downcurved, without coarse setae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Allodapulodes) of Allodapula Based on AdultMales: Gonostylus variously shaped, not styluslike, with hairs as long as width of gonostylus and often robust (Fig. 908d); penis valve and projections from gonocoxite not exceeding gonostylus; convexities of roof of genital chamber strong, about as in Braunsapis,each half broad, folded or not

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Allodapulodes) of Allodapula Based on AdultMales: Gonobase of ordinary form; penis valves robust, strongly downcurved, with cluster of coarse setae on outer angle (Fig. 90-8d)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dalloapula) of Allodapula Based on AdultMales: Gonostylus variously shaped, not styluslike, with hairs as long as width of gonostylus and often robust (Fig. 908d); penis valve and projections from gonocoxite not exceeding gonostylus; convexities of roof of genital chamber strong, about as in Braunsapis,each half broad, folded or not

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dalloapula) of Allodapula Based on AdultMales: Labium with median apical projection; maxilla not bulbous; projections of body without basal shoulders or branches (Fig. 90-6n)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Allodapula s. str.) of Allodapula Based on AdultMales: Gonostylus variously shaped, not styluslike, with hairs as long as width of gonostylus and often robust (Fig. 908d); penis valve and projections from gonocoxite not exceeding gonostylus; convexities of roof of genital chamber strong, about as in Braunsapis,each half broad, folded or not

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Allodapula s. str.) of Allodapula Based on AdultMales: Gonobase reduced, consisting of narrow sclerotized bands; penis valves slender, only weakly downcurved, without coarse setae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dalloapula) of Allodapula Based on AdultMales: Gonostylus variously shaped, not styluslike, with hairs as long as width of gonostylus and often robust (Fig. 908d); penis valve and projections from gonocoxite not exceeding gonostylus; convexities of roof of genital chamber strong, about as in Braunsapis,each half broad, folded or not

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dalloapula) of Allodapula Based on AdultMales: Labium with median apical projection; maxilla not bulbous; projections of body without basal shoulders or branches (Fig. 90-6n)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Allodapula s. str.)and genus Eucondylops of Allodapula Based on AdultMales: Gonostylus variously shaped, not styluslike, with hairs as long as width of gonostylus and often robust (Fig. 908d); penis valve and projections from gonocoxite not exceeding gonostylus; convexities of roof of genital chamber strong, about as in Braunsapis,each half broad, folded or not

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Allodapula s. str.)and genus Eucondylops of Allodapula Based on AdultMales: Labium with median apical emargination; maxilla bulbous; several anterior projections of lateral and ventrolateral series with basal shoulders or branches (Fig. 906l, m)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Compsomelissa s. str.) of Compsomelissa: All tagmata with some yellow or white integument, or integument largely pale, but metasoma sometimes red

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Halterapis) of Compsomelissa: Pale areas limited to head, pronotal lobe and legs, but metasoma sometimes red

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Inquilina) of Exoneura: Female with scopa reduced to mass of short, dense hairs; mandible of female with ventral tooth reduced to mere convexity so that mandible is bidentate; face concave; middle and hind tibial spurs robust, in female strongly curved apically, less than one-half as long as basitarsi; anterior margin of pronotum in both sexes with a sharp angle or small spine at level of base of fore coxa

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Exoneura s. str.) of Exoneura: Female with ordinary tibial scopa; mandible of female three-toothed (as in Fig. 90-9b); face not noticeably concave; middle and hind tibial spurs slender, in female gently curved, one-half as long as basitarsi or longer; anterior margin of pronotum with an inconspicuous rounded angle at level of base of fore coxa

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Exoneura s. str.) of Exoneura: Vein Cu1 of forewing usually long and gradually tapering (Fig. 90-11a, b); clypeus usually widely separated from antennal sockets, subantennal suture thus about as long as diameter of socket; fore tarsus of male attenuate, ﬁrst two segments taken together longer than tibia; hind basitarsus of male dilated (scarcely so in species such as E. asimillima Rayment), nearly as wide as tibia (except in E. asimillima), not parallel-sided

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Brevineura) of Exoneura: Female with ordinary tibial scopa; mandible of female three-toothed (as in Fig. 90-9b); face not noticeably concave; middle and hind tibial spurs slender, in female gently curved, one-half as long as basitarsi or longer; anterior margin of pronotum with an inconspicuous rounded angle at level of base of fore coxa

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Brevineura) of Exoneura: Vein Cu1 of forewing a short stub, ending abruptly (as in Fig. 90-11c), although in some cases continued as a pigmented line; clypeus usually closely approaching antennal sockets, subantennal suture thus much shorter than diameter of socket; fore tarsus of male of ordinary form, ﬁrst two segments taken together shorter than or as long as tibia; hind basitarsus of male much more slender than tibia, parallel-sided

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Alboneuridia) of Exoneuridia: All tagmata richly marked with yellow; mandible of female with median tooth longer than others; maxillary palpus 5-segmented; gonobase of male nearly as long as midventral length of gonocoxite

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Exoneuridia s str.) of Exoneuridia: Body dark except for clypeus and limited pale marks elsewhere (thus coloration as in most Braunsapis); mandible of female with lower tooth longer than others; maxillary palpus 6-segmented; gonobase much shorter than midventral length of gonocoxite

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Kelita of the Brachynomadini(From Rozen, 1997a): Hind coxa normal, not expanded, with carina along mesal dorsal edge but without carina along outer dorsal edge; antennal scape, exclusive of basal bulb, shorter than twice maximum diameter; graduli of terga and sterna simple (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Trichonomada of the Brachynomadini(From Rozen, 1997a): Hind coxa broadly expanded laterally, with pronounced longitudinal carina along mesal dorsal edge and strong carina along outer dorsal edge, the two separated by strongly concave, mostly glabrous surface; antennal scape, exclusive of basal bulb, distinctly longer than twice maximum diameter; graduli of T2 to T4 and S2 to S4 and others produced as distinct, clear, thin, posteriorly directed lamellae (not just carinae) appressed against postgradular areas

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Trichonomada of the Brachynomadini(From Rozen, 1997a): Anterior mandibular articulation separated from eye by distance almost as great as ocellar diameter

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Trichonomada of the Brachynomadini(From Rozen, 1997a): Thorax not strongly ﬂattened, width about equal to depth; eyes with sparse setae about half as long as ocellar diameter; frons in front of ocelli punctate, not particularly shiny; scutal disc punctate; maxillary palpus ﬁvesegmented (counting minute segment l); S5 of female broadly rounded apically; clypeus of male with low lateral carina in addition to deep suture immediately above it, extending from anterior tentorial pit to anterior mandibular articulation (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paranomada of the Brachynomadini(From Rozen, 1997a): Hind coxa broadly expanded laterally, with pronounced longitudinal carina along mesal dorsal edge and strong carina along outer dorsal edge, the two separated by strongly concave, mostly glabrous surface; antennal scape, exclusive of basal bulb, distinctly longer than twice maximum diameter; graduli of T2 to T4 and S2 to S4 and others produced as distinct, clear, thin, posteriorly directed lamellae (not just carinae) appressed against postgradular areas

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paranomada of the Brachynomadini(From Rozen, 1997a): Anterior mandibular articulation separated from eye by distance almost as great as ocellar diameter

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Paranomada of the Brachynomadini(From Rozen, 1997a): Thorax strongly ﬂattened, width distinctly greater than depth; eyes with sparse minute setae, scarcely noticeable; frons in front of ocelli nearly glabarous, polished; scutal disc virtually glabrous, highly polished; maxillary palpus usually four-segmented (counting minute segment 1); S5 of female with apical margin produced as round, median, hairy projection; clypeus of male without lateral carina but with very deep suture from anterior tentorial pit to anterior mandibular articulation (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Brachynomada s. str.) of Brachynomada: Hind femur of male without basal thornlike projection or other modiﬁcation; S8 of male elongate, strongly produced distally, its apex broadening before ending abruptly (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Melanomada) of Brachynomada: Hind femur of male with thornlike projection ventrally and, in some species, with other modiﬁcations on ventral surface; S8 of male less elongate, not strongly produced, tapering to apex (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Brachynomada s. str.) of Brachynomada: Hind femur of male without basal thornlike projection or other modiﬁcation; S8 of male elongate, strongly produced distally, its apex broadening before ending abruptly (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thalestria of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Body largely covered by minute, appressed, plumose, scalelike, metallic blue or green hairs, and similar white hairs on metasoma limited to small lateral patches; eyes closest at upper ends, strongly converging above in male; T5 of female with apical transverse area densely covered with long, stiff, black hairs but without distinct pseudopygidial area; preoccipital carina behind vertex strong but on posterior surface of head much below level of ocelli (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Odyneropsis of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Body nonmetallic, usually with extensive areas of minute, appressed, plumose, white to pale-tan hairs on metasoma; eyes usually converging below (but in Odyneropsisslightly closer above than below in both sexes); T5 of female with apical area covered with short brown to white hairs (but long black hairs in Rhogepeolus), often well enough deﬁned to be called a pseudopygidial area; preoccipital carina behind vertex (upper sector, see Fig. 95-4) absent or at summit of posterior surface of head, little below level of ocelli................ 2 2(1). Inner margins of eyes subparallel, usually slightly closer above than below; metasoma without conspicuous areas of pale pubescence except sometimes on T1; stigma rather large, vein r arising near middle (Fig. 95-2a); marginal cell as long as three submarginal cells combined; T5 of female with small middorsal depressed area often surrounded by ridges (often hidden by T4) (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhogepeolus of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Scutellum with median longitudinal strip of appressed, pale setae between convexities; pseudopygidial area of female with apical margin strongly concave, with medioapical slit, apical margin fringed with relatively long, curved, simple setae; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment longer than second

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Doeringiella of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Scape length about twice width, forming subbasal angle on lateral surface (seen with antenna directed upward) so that only basal third or less tapers toward basal bulb; preoccipital carina complete or absent at upper corners of head; basitibial plate completely bordered by carina; first and second flagellar segments of about same length

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhinepeolus of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Supraclypeal area produced into bulbous protrusion with weak median carina; scutellum relatively flat but bearing two mammiform tubercles; pseudopygidial area with median longitudinal row of dark, stout setae, and with apical margin convex; preoccipital carina continuously curved, not angulate at upper corners of head

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudepeolus of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Scutum with longitudinal bands of appressed setae often reduced, usually restricted to anterior fourth; preoccipital carina absent at upper corners of head only

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Triepeolus of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Scutum almost always with elongate longitudinal bands of appressed setae reaching middle; preoccipital carina absent on upper corners of head or entire sector absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Epeolus of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Scutellum rarely with distinct median longitudinal strip of appressed setae; pseudopygidial area of female variable but apex rarely strongly concave, without median apical slit (except in T. roniGenaro); ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment not longer than second

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Epeolus of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Females

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Epeolus of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Processes of S6 spatulate, with apical principal setae indicated by small denticles (Fig. 95-3d); pseudopygidial area forming wide apical lunule of silvery setae (Fig. 953b); apical ventral surface of pygidial plate with two medial, flattened, rounded processes, sometimes very reduced

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Epeolus of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Scutellum rarely with distinct median longitudinal strip of appressed setae; pseudopygidial area of female variable but apex rarely strongly concave, without median apical slit (except in T. roniGenaro); ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment not longer than second

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Epeolus of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Females

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Epeolus of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Processes of S6 spatulate, with apical principal setae indicated by small denticles (Fig. 95-3d); pseudopygidial area forming wide apical lunule of silvery setae (Fig. 953b); apical ventral surface of pygidial plate with two medial, flattened, rounded processes, sometimes very reduced

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhinepeolus of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Supraclypeal area produced into bulbous protrusion with weak median carina; scutellum relatively flat but bearing two mammiform tubercles; pseudopygidial area with median longitudinal row of dark, stout setae, and with apical margin convex; preoccipital carina continuously curved, not angulate at upper corners of head

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Doeringiella of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Scape length about twice width, forming subbasal angle on lateral surface (seen with antenna directed upward) so that only basal third or less tapers toward basal bulb; preoccipital carina complete or absent at upper corners of head; basitibial plate completely bordered by carina; first and second flagellar segments of about same length

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Triepeolus of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Scutum almost always with elongate longitudinal bands of appressed setae reaching middle; preoccipital carina absent on upper corners of head or entire sector absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pseudepeolus of the Epeolini(part of this key is based on that of Rightmyer, 2004): Scutum with longitudinal bands of appressed setae often reduced, usually restricted to anterior fourth; preoccipital carina absent at upper corners of head only

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Groups Trophocleptria group of Epeolus: Scape, excluding basal bulb, 1.5 times as long as broad or little more; venter of mesothorax with anterior vertical part set off from horizontal part by a transverse carina, the lower part of omaular carinae continued across the venter, often irregular or broken medially and rarely weak; lateral angle of pronotum rounded but well developed, its anteroposterior length about equal to diameter of pronotal lobe (but if only moderately developed, then transverse ventral mesothoracic carina strong); scutellum coarsely punctate or reticulate, often produced to two posteriorly directed teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Groups Epeolus group of Epeolus: Scape, excluding basal bulb, twice as long as broad or nearly so; venter of mesothorax with anterior vertical part rounding onto horizontal part with no intervening transverse carina; lateral angle of pronotum weakly developed, its anteroposterior length much less than diameter of pronotal lobe; scutellum punctured, biconvex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Odyneropsis) s. str. of Odyneropsis: T5 of female with small oval middorsal depression surrounded by an apparent carina formed by short, blunt, multiridged setae; body length 14 mm or more

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera O. (Parammobates) of Odyneropsis: T5 of female with such middorsal depression not well defined, entirely open anteriorly; body length 11 mm or less

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ammobatoides of the Ammobatoidini: Body length 10 mm or more; eyes of male strongly converging above; inner orbits of female gently concave (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Aethammobates of the Ammobatoidini: Body length 7.5 mm or less; eyes of male diverging above; inner orbits of female straight or slightly convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Aethammobates of the Ammobatoidini: Pronotum with well-developed, horizontal dorsal collar surface extending across between dorsolateral angles; scutum without vertical anterior surface; T1 with anterior surface deeply concave, separated from dorsal surface by strongly arcuate carina that forms strong anterolateral tergal angles (Egypt)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Holcopasites of the Ammobatoidini: Body length 7.5 mm or less; eyes of male diverging above; inner orbits of female straight or slightly convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Holcopasites of the Ammobatoidini: Pronotum with dorsal surface of collar broadly interrupted medially, where scutum curves down to form vertical anterior surface; T1 with anterior surface shallowly to deeply concave, without or with only suggestion of carina between anterior and dorsal surfaces, anterolateral part of T1 rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Holcopasites of the Ammobatoidini: Male antenna 12-segmented; middle ﬂagellar segments broader than long; metasomal terga with graduli strong, shelﬂike, a deep transverse furrow immediately behind each gradulus on at least T2 to T4; clypeus and nearby structures dark (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Schmiedeknechtia of the Ammobatoidini: Body length 7.5 mm or less; eyes of male diverging above; inner orbits of female straight or slightly convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Schmiedeknechtia of the Ammobatoidini: Pronotum with dorsal surface of collar broadly interrupted medially, where scutum curves down to form vertical anterior surface; T1 with anterior surface shallowly to deeply concave, without or with only suggestion of carina between anterior and dorsal surfaces, anterolateral part of T1 rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Schmiedeknechtia of the Ammobatoidini: Male antenna 13-segmented; middle ﬂagellar segments as long as or longer than broad; metasomal terga with weaker graduli, not emphasized by furrow behind each gradulus; clypeus (at least lower margin), bases of mandibles, labrum, and antennal scape yellow (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhopalolemma of the Biastini: Mandible simple; T6 of female produced medially, with pygidial plate; gonostylus of female clubbed; scape 1.75 times as long as its maximum diameter (basal bulb excluded) (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Biastes of the Biastini: Mandible with preapical tooth; T6 of female without indication of pygidial plate, produced to sharp point at each side, the margin between lateral projections strongly, broadly concave, hairy; gonostylus of female thickened medially; scape about 1.5 times as long as its maximum diameter (basal bulb excluded)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Biastes of the Biastini: T5 of female with small, raised, semicircular, sloping pseudopygidial area covered with appressed pale hairs; metanotum with median elevation well above level of adjacent part of scutellum; second submarginal cell longer than ﬁrst (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Neopasites of the Biastini: Mandible with preapical tooth; T6 of female without indication of pygidial plate, produced to sharp point at each side, the margin between lateral projections strongly, broadly concave, hairy; gonostylus of female thickened medially; scape about 1.5 times as long as its maximum diameter (basal bulb excluded)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Neopasites of the Biastini: T5 with ill-deﬁned lunule of pale or black hairs, not raised, not sloping, and usually broader than semicircular; metanotum without median elevation, not or little above level of adjacent part of scutellum; second submarginal cell as long as or shorter than ﬁrst (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Micropasites) of Neopasites: Maxillary palpus shorter than or as long as greatest galeal width, oneor two-segmented; second submarginal cell about as long as ﬁrst; body length 3.5 to 6.0 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Neopasites s. str.) of Neopasites: Maxillary palpus much longer than greatest galeal width, four-segmented; second submarginal cell much shorter than ﬁrst; body length 6 to 8 mm.

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Neolarra s. str.) of Neolarra: Scutellum widest at or in front of middle; outer margin of axilla rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera N. (Phileremulus) of Neolarra: Scutellum widest behind middle; axilla produced to acute tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Parammobatodes of the Ammobatini: Mandibles in repose directed posteromesally, so that, except when badly worn, they cross one another well before their apices, their anterior margins forming angle of 90/H11034 to 145/H11034

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Parammobatodes of the Ammobatini: Vein Rs of hind wing transverse or directed basad from costal margin, discal cell (R) thus not extending distad from base of vein Rs; ﬁrst recurrent vein joining distal half of second submarginal cell, second medial cell thus greatly narrowed toward costa (palearctic, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodopsis of the Ammobatini: Mandibles in repose directed posteromesally, so that, except when badly worn, they cross one another well before their apices, their anterior margins forming angle of 90/H11034 to 145/H11034

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodopsis of the Ammobatini: Vein Rs of hind wing directed strongly distad, discal cell (R) thus extending beyond base of vein Rs; ﬁrst recurrent vein joining basal half of second submarginal cell, second medial cell thus not greatly narrowed toward costa

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Sphecodopsis of the Ammobatini: Labrum pointed apically, entirely exposed in front of crossed mandibles in repose; male without deﬁned pygidial plate; S5 of female without preapical collar of long hairs (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Oreopasites of the Ammobatini: Mandibles in repose directed posteromesally, so that, except when badly worn, they cross one another well before their apices, their anterior margins forming angle of 90/H11034 to 145/H11034

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Oreopasites of the Ammobatini: Vein Rs of hind wing directed strongly distad, discal cell (R) thus extending beyond base of vein Rs; ﬁrst recurrent vein joining basal half of second submarginal cell, second medial cell thus not greatly narrowed toward costa

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Oreopasites of the Ammobatini: Labrum truncate or broadly rounded apically, extend ing under and beyond crossed mandibles; male with pygidial plate; S5 of female with preapical Vor U-shaped collar of long hairs (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pasites of the Ammobatini: Mandibles in repose directed mesally, so that they overlap one another and cross, if at all, at extremely obtuse angle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pasites of the Ammobatini: S5 of female with posterior margin (curved up and sometimes around process of S6 and sting) unmodiﬁed, covered with ﬁne hairs; labrum not extending under or posterior to mandibles in repose (male antenna 12-segmented) (palearctic, oriental, Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Melanempis of the Ammobatini: Mandibles in repose directed mesally, so that they overlap one another and cross, if at all, at extremely obtuse angle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Melanempis of the Ammobatini: S5 of female with posterior margin bare at least medially, usually with median protuberance or troughlike projection that may look superﬁcially like another sternum; labrum commonly extending under and sometimes beyond mandibles in repose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Melanempis of the Ammobatini: Female with nearly circular, hairless pygidial plate margined by circular carina, on posterior subvertical surface of T6; jugal lobe of hind wing essentially absent; maxillary palpus absent; body length 15 to 18 mm; male antennae 12-segmented (Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Spinopasites of the Ammobatini: Mandibles in repose directed mesally, so that they overlap one another and cross, if at all, at extremely obtuse angle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Spinopasites of the Ammobatini: S5 of female with posterior margin bare at least medially, usually with median protuberance or troughlike projection that may look superﬁcially like another sternum; labrum commonly extending under and sometimes beyond mandibles in repose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Spinopasites of the Ammobatini: Female without circular pygidial plate; jugal lobe of hind wing present, but small as in most Nomadinae; maxillary palpus oneto six-segmented; body length 4 to 13 mm; male antenna 13-segmented (male unknown in Spinopasites)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Spinopasites of the Ammobatini: S6 of female ending in a single spine; S5 of female with posterior part bent upward and not visible from below, preapical concavity V-shaped and not deﬁned by hairy ridge (northwen Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ammobates of the Ammobatini: Mandibles in repose directed mesally, so that they overlap one another and cross, if at all, at extremely obtuse angle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ammobates of the Ammobatini: S5 of female with posterior margin bare at least medially, usually with median protuberance or troughlike projection that may look superﬁcially like another sternum; labrum commonly extending under and sometimes beyond mandibles in repose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ammobates of the Ammobatini: Female without circular pygidial plate; jugal lobe of hind wing present, but small as in most Nomadinae; maxillary palpus oneto six-segmented; body length 4 to 13 mm; male antenna 13-segmented (male unknown in Spinopasites)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ammobates of the Ammobatini: S6 of female bifurcate; S5 of female with posterior part not so strongly bent upward, visible from below, preapical concavity more U-shaped and deﬁned by hairy ridge (palearctic, oriental, southern Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Xerammobates) of Ammobates: Second submarginal crossvein meeting second recurrent vein (S5 of female with deep longitudinal channel, the apex deeply emarginate; maxillary palpus six-segmented; S8 of male with disc and spiculum forming triangle; apical process of S8 broad, membranous, sometimes spiculate, not cleft)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euphileremus) of Ammobates: Second submarginal crossvein distal to second recurrent vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Euphileremus) of Ammobates: T6 of female more or less rooﬂike with longitudinal median ridge, sides sloping, densely hairy; labrum relatively short, 1.5 times as long as its basal width

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ammobates s. str.) of Ammobates: Second submarginal crossvein distal to second recurrent vein

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Ammobates s. str.) of Ammobates: T6 of female ﬂat or convex, not longitudinally ridged, sparsely or at most only partially hairy, often with specialized median area, or posterior part bent down and vertical, or both; labrum more than twice as long as its basal width

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Pseudodichroa) of Sphecodopsis: S6 of female produced to a long, slender, median spine; S5 of female with midapical process that is truncate and longer than broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Sphecodopsis s. str.) of Sphecodopsis: S6 of female produced to a process with bifurcate apex; S5 with midapical projection rounded or truncate, much broader than long, sometimes scarcely recognizable, sometimes in emargination that is broader than projection

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Caenoprosopis of Caenoprosopidini: T otal length of marginal cell much greater than that of stigma, about as long as distance from its apex to wing tip (Fig. 101-1); second submarginal cell about two-thirds as long as ﬁrst; axillae and scutellum not spined, but with projecting convex lateral edges; middle ﬂagellar segments about as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Caenoprosopina of Caenoprosopidini: T otal length of marginal cell as long as stigma, much less than distance from its apex to wing tip; second submarginal cell less than half as long as ﬁrst; axillae and posterior lateral angles of scutellum produced to posteriorly directed spines; middle ﬂagellar segments much broader than long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Isepeolus of the Isepeolini(Modiﬁed from Roig-Alsina, 1991a): Vertex of head between lateral ocellus and eye slightly rounded to ﬂat as seen in frontal view, at most with shallow depression; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment of male conspicuously widened apically, as in female; sclerotized apex of female S6 with spinelike setae absent or short (Fig. 103-2a), barely visible at low magniﬁcation, lateral apical margin not expanded, not folded down; apex of female T5 without membranous rim; male S6 with large preapical tubercle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Parepeolus of the Osirini(Modiﬁed from Roig-Alsina, 1989a): Jugal lobe of hind wing rounded; basal vein of fore wing basal to cu-v or sometimes meeting it; lateral margin of clypeus not continued by paraocular carina above level of anterior mandibular articulation; labrum with pair of preapical tubercles or two to four teeth near middle of disc; ventral gonostylus of male biﬁd, dorsal gonostylus large, ﬂattened (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Osiris of the Osirini(Modiﬁed from Roig-Alsina, 1989a): Collar of pronotum dorsally bulging, with a distinct subhorizontal portion connecting swollen, rounded dorsolateral angles; inner margin of eye with shallow emargination near upper third; mandible with two subapical teeth; S6 of female usually exceeding T6 (Fig. 104-4c); apex of pygidial plate of female not reaching margin of tergum, a wide rim present apical to plate; pygidial plate of male reduced to sclerotization on tergal margin; male gonostylus simple (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protosiris of the Osirini(Modiﬁed from Roig-Alsina, 1989a): T ransverse middorsal part of pronotal collar short or absent, dorsolateral lobes or angles thus not connected by elevated collar; inner margin of eye almost straight; mandible with one subapical tooth or simple (an inner angle sometimes present); S6 of female not exceeding T6; apex of pygidial plate of female constituting apex of tergum; pygidial plate of male present; male gonostylus double, i.e., upper and lower gonostyli well separated

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Protosiris of the Osirini(Modiﬁed from Roig-Alsina, 1989a): Inner margins of eyes almost parallel; mandible long, strongly curved, outer basal width 0.33 to 0.35 times length of mandible; mesepisternum with hairs simple or at most with one or two basal barbs; legs slender; strigilar concavity 0.26 to 0.27 times length of basitarsus; scutum as long as intertegular distance (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Osirinus of the Osirini(Modiﬁed from Roig-Alsina, 1989a): T ransverse middorsal part of pronotal collar short or absent, dorsolateral lobes or angles thus not connected by elevated collar; inner margin of eye almost straight; mandible with one subapical tooth or simple (an inner angle sometimes present); S6 of female not exceeding T6; apex of pygidial plate of female constituting apex of tergum; pygidial plate of male present; male gonostylus double, i.e., upper and lower gonostyli well separated

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Osirinus of the Osirini(Modiﬁed from Roig-Alsina, 1989a): Inner margins of eyes convergent below; mandible short, outer basal width 0.40 to 0.45 times length of mandible; at least anterior part of mesepisternum with plumose hairs; legs short, stout; strigilar concavity shallow, 0.38 to 0.41 times length of basitarsus; scutum shorter than intertegular distance (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Ecclitodes) of Parepeolus: Propodeal triangle microstriate; posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell about twice as long as apical margin; maxillary palpus six-segmented; metasomal terga with apical bands of pale hairs; suprategular carina curved cephalad of tegula, following tegular margin, reaching mesoscutum-pronotal lobe boundary close to tegula

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Parepeolus s. str.) of Parepeolus: Propodeal triangle polished, smooth or with few scattered punctures; posterior margin of ﬁrst submarginal cell less than 1.5 times as long as apical margin (Fig. 1043b); maxillary palpus fourto ﬁve-segmented; metasomal terga black or variously patterned with pale hairs, an apical band, when present, appearing only on T1; suprategular carina slightly curved, directed anteriorly, diverging from tegular margin and reaching mesoscutum-pronotal lobe boundary near middle of that margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera T eratognatha of the Exomalopsini: Hind tibial and basitarsal scopa consisting of sparse, simple or sparsely branched hairs; mandible with preapical tooth that is sometimes minute; S7 of male with disc pentagonal (Fig. 106-3l), median apex separating two apical margins, apicolateral angle with short, robust process; male gonocoxite with apicolateral process from apex of which arises rather long gonostylus, the process and gonostylus sometimes appearing together as basally elbowed gonostylus (Fig. 106-3j) (subtribe T eratognathina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera T eratognatha of the Exomalopsini: Stigma broad, three times as long as prestigma; pronotal lobe produced to horizontal lamella in female, strong ridge in male, rounded as seen from above (Argentina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eremapis of the Exomalopsini: Hind tibial and basitarsal scopa consisting of sparse, simple or sparsely branched hairs; mandible with preapical tooth that is sometimes minute; S7 of male with disc pentagonal (Fig. 106-3l), median apex separating two apical margins, apicolateral angle with short, robust process; male gonocoxite with apicolateral process from apex of which arises rather long gonostylus, the process and gonostylus sometimes appearing together as basally elbowed gonostylus (Fig. 106-3j) (subtribe T eratognathina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eremapis of the Exomalopsini: Stigma small, less than twice as long as prestigma; pronotal lobe rounded (South America)..Chilimalopsis 3(1). Second medial cell of forewing about as long as second cubital; labrum and clypeus of female yellow; margin of T7 of male produced into a broad, sharp lamella, rounded as seen from above; S7 of male broadly trilobed; hind basitarsus of female without apical process and penicillus (Argentina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Anthophorula of the Exomalopsini: Basitibial plate of female small, with surface planar, or, if margins of plate raised and central area with velvety pilosity, then transverse carina of T1 of female absent; labrum and clypeus of male yellow or white [except dark inA. (Anthophorisca) levigata Timberlake and linsleyi Timberlake and in A. (Isomalopsis) niveata (Friese)]; outer side of penis valve without or with small lateral process (Fig. 106-3a, d, g); dorsal ﬂange of male gonocoxite absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exomalopsis of the Exomalopsini: Basitibial plate of female large, central area with velvety pilosity separated from raised margin by groove, and transverse carina of T1 of female present; labrum and clypeus of male entirely dark; outer side of penis valve with strong lateral process; dorsal ﬂange of male gonocoxite present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera T eratognatha of the Exomalopsini: Hind tibial and basitarsal scopa consisting of sparse, simple or sparsely branched hairs; mandible with preapical tooth that is sometimes minute; S7 of male with disc pentagonal (Fig. 106-3l), median apex separating two apical margins, apicolateral angle with short, robust process; male gonocoxite with apicolateral process from apex of which arises rather long gonostylus, the process and gonostylus sometimes appearing together as basally elbowed gonostylus (Fig. 106-3j) (subtribe T eratognathina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera T eratognatha of the Exomalopsini: Stigma broad, three times as long as prestigma; pronotal lobe produced to horizontal lamella in female, strong ridge in male, rounded as seen from above (Argentina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eremapis of the Exomalopsini: Hind tibial and basitarsal scopa consisting of sparse, simple or sparsely branched hairs; mandible with preapical tooth that is sometimes minute; S7 of male with disc pentagonal (Fig. 106-3l), median apex separating two apical margins, apicolateral angle with short, robust process; male gonocoxite with apicolateral process from apex of which arises rather long gonostylus, the process and gonostylus sometimes appearing together as basally elbowed gonostylus (Fig. 106-3j) (subtribe T eratognathina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eremapis of the Exomalopsini: Stigma small, less than twice as long as prestigma; pronotal lobe rounded (South America)..Chilimalopsis 3(1). Second medial cell of forewing about as long as second cubital; labrum and clypeus of female yellow; margin of T7 of male produced into a broad, sharp lamella, rounded as seen from above; S7 of male broadly trilobed; hind basitarsus of female without apical process and penicillus (Argentina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Anthophorula of the Exomalopsini: Basitibial plate of female small, with surface planar, or, if margins of plate raised and central area with velvety pilosity, then transverse carina of T1 of female absent; labrum and clypeus of male yellow or white [except dark inA. (Anthophorisca) levigata Timberlake and linsleyi Timberlake and in A. (Isomalopsis) niveata (Friese)]; outer side of penis valve without or with small lateral process (Fig. 106-3a, d, g); dorsal ﬂange of male gonocoxite absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera A. (Isomalopsis) of the Exomalopsini: Hind tibial and basitarsal scopa consisting of sparse, simple or sparsely branched hairs; mandible with preapical tooth that is sometimes minute; S7 of male with disc pentagonal (Fig. 106-3l), median apex separating two apical margins, apicolateral angle with short, robust process; male gonocoxite with apicolateral process from apex of which arises rather long gonostylus, the process and gonostylus sometimes appearing together as basally elbowed gonostylus (Fig. 106-3j) (subtribe T eratognathina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera A. (Isomalopsis) of the Exomalopsini: Stigma large, four times as long as prestigma, its inner breadth (i.e., not counting marginal veins) much greater than breadth of its marginal veins; yellow marks on clypeus of male absent or restricted to apical transverse line; S6 of male with two apicolateral ﬂanges that bear a series of spicules on their inner margins (Argentina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera A. (Anthophorula s. str.) of the Exomalopsini: Hind tibial and basitarsal scopa consisting of sparse, simple or sparsely branched hairs; mandible with preapical tooth that is sometimes minute; S7 of male with disc pentagonal (Fig. 106-3l), median apex separating two apical margins, apicolateral angle with short, robust process; male gonocoxite with apicolateral process from apex of which arises rather long gonostylus, the process and gonostylus sometimes appearing together as basally elbowed gonostylus (Fig. 106-3j) (subtribe T eratognathina)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera A. (Anthophorula s. str.) of the Exomalopsini: Stigma small, no more than three times as long as prestigma, its inner breadth (i.e., not counting marginal veins) as great as or less than breadth of its marginal veins; clypeus of male entirely yellow; S6 of male simple (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Stilbomalopsis) of Exomalopsis: Vertex in frontal view convex; area between lateral ocellus and eye not excavated (except in E. arcuata Timberlake) and lateral ocelli below level of summit of head; marginal zones of T1 and T2 of female smooth and glabrous; T2 to T4 of female with white apical fringes sometimes interrupted medially; S7 of male with apical sclerotization forming short transverse sclerite across apex of sternum and fused to arms of disc; S8 of male with apical process a single bare lobe (North and Central America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Diomalopsis) of Exomalopsis: Vertex in frontal view straight; area between lateral ocellus and eye excavated and/or lateral ocelli above level of summit of head; marginal zones of T1 and/or T2 of female punctate and pilose; T2 to T4 of female with apical fringes absent; S7 of male with apical process absent or complex and with two free basolateral lobes under ventral surface; S8 of male with apical process bearing two apical arms (short or long), or, if consisting of a single broad lobe, then lobe hairy (Fig. 106-4)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Diomalopsis) of Exomalopsis: Submarginal cells two (vertex of female, between ocellus and eye, not excavated; T1 of female with premarginal line not depressed; S6 of male entirely ﬂat; S7 and S8 of male with peglike setae)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Phanomalopsis) of Exomalopsis: Vertex in frontal view straight; area between lateral ocellus and eye excavated and/or lateral ocelli above level of summit of head; marginal zones of T1 and/or T2 of female punctate and pilose; T2 to T4 of female with apical fringes absent; S7 of male with apical process absent or complex and with two free basolateral lobes under ventral surface; S8 of male with apical process bearing two apical arms (short or long), or, if consisting of a single broad lobe, then lobe hairy (Fig. 106-4)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Phanomalopsis) of Exomalopsis: Submarginal cells three

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Phanomalopsis) of Exomalopsis: T1 of female with premarginal line depressed, forming tranverse sulcus, and marginal zone between dorsolateral convexities smooth and shining, comprising no more than two-thirds of dorsal surface of tergum; S6 of male entirely planar

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Exomalopsis s. str.) of Exomalopsis: Vertex in frontal view straight; area between lateral ocellus and eye excavated and/or lateral ocelli above level of summit of head; marginal zones of T1 and/or T2 of female punctate and pilose; T2 to T4 of female with apical fringes absent; S7 of male with apical process absent or complex and with two free basolateral lobes under ventral surface; S8 of male with apical process bearing two apical arms (short or long), or, if consisting of a single broad lobe, then lobe hairy (Fig. 106-4)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Exomalopsis s. str.) of Exomalopsis: Submarginal cells three

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E.
