Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Svastra (Anthedonia) of the Eucerini (Females)(Often, hairs must be removed to see the first characterin couplet 5(4). In Melissodes stearnsi Cockerell, al-though the tegula is shaped much as in other Melissodes,the relevant tegular margin is feebly convex; this speciesruns to couplet 19 and fails to agree with either alterna-tive.): Pale pubescent bands of metasomal terga with abundant, basally plumose, apically spatulate hairs; maxillary palpus four-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera T etraloniella (Loxoptilus) of the Eucerini (Females)(Often, hairs must be removed to see the first characterin couplet 5(4). In Melissodes stearnsi Cockerell, al-though the tegula is shaped much as in other Melissodes,the relevant tegular margin is feebly convex; this speciesruns to couplet 19 and fails to agree with either alterna-tive.): Minimum oculoclypeal distance much greater than minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment (Fig. 112-6f); clypeus strongly protuberant; stipes with long, dense, coarse, apically hooked or wavy hairs (Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Eucera (Synhalonia) of the Eucerini (Females)(Often, hairs must be removed to see the first characterin couplet 5(4). In Melissodes stearnsi Cockerell, al-though the tegula is shaped much as in other Melissodes,the relevant tegular margin is feebly convex; this speciesruns to couplet 19 and fails to agree with either alterna-tive.): Middle ocellus not as broad as ﬂagellum [or, in Eucera venusta (Cresson), as wide as ﬂagellum]; maxillary palpus six-segmented; pygidial plate rather broad, rounded apically, apicolateral margin convex (except in E. venustaand others)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Simanthedon of the Eucerini (Females)(Often, hairs must be removed to see the first characterin couplet 5(4). In Melissodes stearnsi Cockerell, al-though the tegula is shaped much as in other Melissodes,the relevant tegular margin is feebly convex; this speciesruns to couplet 19 and fails to agree with either alterna-tive.): Middle ocellus broader than ﬂagellum; maxillary palpus ﬁve-segmented; pygidial plate tapering and bluntly pointed apically, apicolateral margin concave (deserts of southwestern USA and Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Gaesischia (in part) of the Eucerini (Females)(Often, hairs must be removed to see the first characterin couplet 5(4). In Melissodes stearnsi Cockerell, al-though the tegula is shaped much as in other Melissodes,the relevant tegular margin is feebly convex; this speciesruns to couplet 19 and fails to agree with either alterna-tive.): Fore coxa with inner apical hairy spine (Fig. 112-13c) (tropical to Arizona)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera T etraloniella(in part) of the Eucerini (Females)(Often, hairs must be removed to see the first characterin couplet 5(4). In Melissodes stearnsi Cockerell, al-though the tegula is shaped much as in other Melissodes,the relevant tegular margin is feebly convex; this speciesruns to couplet 19 and fails to agree with either alterna-tive.): Basitibial plate with anterior and apical part of margin hidden, surface usually hairy; T6 with lateral parts of gradulus cariniform, never toothed if sublamelliform

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Gaesischia (in part) of the Eucerini (Females)(Often, hairs must be removed to see the first characterin couplet 5(4). In Melissodes stearnsi Cockerell, al-though the tegula is shaped much as in other Melissodes,the relevant tegular margin is feebly convex; this speciesruns to couplet 19 and fails to agree with either alterna-tive.): Fore coxa with inner apical hairy spine (Fig. 112-13c) (tropical to Arizona)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Syntrichalonia of the Eucerini (Females)(Often, hairs must be removed to see the first characterin couplet 5(4). In Melissodes stearnsi Cockerell, al-though the tegula is shaped much as in other Melissodes,the relevant tegular margin is feebly convex; this speciesruns to couplet 19 and fails to agree with either alterna-tive.): Vertex elevated, median ocellus thus below summit in facial view; hairs of upper and outer parts of scopa with abundant, uniform, short branches, mostly with ten or more branches on each side of rachis and often with as many as 15; apical part of rachis extending beyond last branch usually shorter than average length of branches (Mexico, southwestern USA)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Melissoptila of the Eucerini (Females)(Often, hairs must be removed to see the first characterin couplet 5(4). In Melissodes stearnsi Cockerell, al-though the tegula is shaped much as in other Melissodes,the relevant tegular margin is feebly convex; this speciesruns to couplet 19 and fails to agree with either alterna-tive.): Prestigma shorter than stigma (as in Fig. 112-4c); lateral hind coxal carina sharp, bent strongly posteriad basally to form a rounded angle of almost 90/H11034(Fig. 11215a); maxillary palpus twoor three-segmented (tropical to T exas)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Svastra of the Eucerini (Females)(Often, hairs must be removed to see the first characterin couplet 5(4). In Melissodes stearnsi Cockerell, al-though the tegula is shaped much as in other Melissodes,the relevant tegular margin is feebly convex; this speciesruns to couplet 19 and fails to agree with either alterna-tive.): Maxillary palpus usually four-segmented, but if ﬁve-segmented, then basal pubescent band of T2 with at least a few spatuloplumose hairs (Fig. 112-10b); lateral arms of gradulus of T6 lamelliform, often with a small tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Florilegus of the Eucerini (Females)(Often, hairs must be removed to see the first characterin couplet 5(4). In Melissodes stearnsi Cockerell, al-though the tegula is shaped much as in other Melissodes,the relevant tegular margin is feebly convex; this speciesruns to couplet 19 and fails to agree with either alterna-tive.): Basitibial plate with margin entirely exposed, surface often bare; T6 with lateral parts of gradulus lamelliform and ending in strong tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera T etraloniella(in part) of the Eucerini (Females)(Often, hairs must be removed to see the first characterin couplet 5(4). In Melissodes stearnsi Cockerell, al-though the tegula is shaped much as in other Melissodes,the relevant tegular margin is feebly convex; this speciesruns to couplet 19 and fails to agree with either alterna-tive.): Basitibial plate with anterior and apical part of margin hidden, surface usually hairy; T6 with lateral parts of gradulus cariniform, never toothed if sublamelliform

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Thygater of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Minimum length of malar area greater than minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment (Fig. 112-6e); pygidial plate unrecognizable or indicated by weak lateral carinae, mostly covered by long, appressed hairs, T7 bidentate apically; labrum at least three-fourths as long as broad (tropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Cemolobus of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Minimum length of malar area equal to or less than minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; pygidial plate prominent, exposed, with short hairs or bare, T7 truncate or rounded apically; labrum variable but usually less than three-fourths as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Cemolobus of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Clypeal margin trilobed, median lobe broad and often shallowly emarginate medially (Fig. 112-13d); ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment as long as second segment; S6 with large, laterally directed, lateral tooth (eastern and central USA)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Melissoptila of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Minimum length of malar area equal to or less than minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; pygidial plate prominent, exposed, with short hairs or bare, T7 truncate or rounded apically; labrum variable but usually less than three-fourths as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Melissoptila of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Clypeal margin truncate; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually shorter than second segment; S6 usually without lateral teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Melissoptila of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): T7 with lateral gradular tooth or strong angle on each side of pygidial plate, sometimes hidden in dense hair or by T6

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Melissoptila of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Stigma slightly longer than prestigma (Fig. 112-4c); maxillary palpus twoor three-segmented; lateral hind coxal carina prominent, curved (Fig. 112-15a) (tropical to T exas)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Florilegus of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Minimum length of malar area equal to or less than minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; pygidial plate prominent, exposed, with short hairs or bare, T7 truncate or rounded apically; labrum variable but usually less than three-fourths as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Florilegus of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Clypeal margin truncate; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually shorter than second segment; S6 usually without lateral teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Florilegus of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): T7 with lateral gradular tooth or strong angle on each side of pygidial plate, sometimes hidden in dense hair or by T6

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Florilegus of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Stigma small, usually as short as or shorter than prestigma (Fig. 112-4b); maxillary palpus usually fouror ﬁve-segmented, rarely three-segmented; lateral hind coxal carina reduced or absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Florilegus of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): S6 with prominent median convexity; fore femur broadest about one-fourth or one-third of its length from apex; maxillary palpus ﬁve-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Melissodes of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Minimum length of malar area equal to or less than minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; pygidial plate prominent, exposed, with short hairs or bare, T7 truncate or rounded apically; labrum variable but usually less than three-fourths as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Melissodes of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Clypeal margin truncate; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually shorter than second segment; S6 usually without lateral teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Melissodes of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): T7 with lateral gradular tooth or strong angle on each side of pygidial plate, sometimes hidden in dense hair or by T6

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Melissodes of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Stigma small, usually as short as or shorter than prestigma (Fig. 112-4b); maxillary palpus usually fouror ﬁve-segmented, rarely three-segmented; lateral hind coxal carina reduced or absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Melissodes of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): S6 ﬂat or with exceedingly shallow, longitudinal median depression; fore femur broadest basal to middle; maxillary palpus usually threeor four-segmented, rarely ﬁvesegmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Melissodes of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): T egula narrowed anteriorly, lateral margin slightly concave or straight in anterior one-half or one-third (Fig. 112-8a) (often hidden by hairs); clypeus little or moderately protruding, extending in front of eye by eye width or less as seen in lateral view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Peponapis (in part) of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): S6 with oblique lateral apical carina straight, sternum not toothed or angled laterally (Fig. 112-10d); antenna of moderate length, not reaching stigma in repose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Xenoglossa of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Minimum length of malar area equal to or less than minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; pygidial plate prominent, exposed, with short hairs or bare, T7 truncate or rounded apically; labrum variable but usually less than three-fourths as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Xenoglossa of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Clypeal margin truncate; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually shorter than second segment; S6 usually without lateral teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Xenoglossa of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): T7 without lateral teeth (occasionally S6 with lateral teeth that can be seen from above and may be confused with tergal teeth)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Xenoglossa of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): First ﬂagellar segment longer than second; inner margin of mandible with tooth near base (Fig. 112-13e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Simanthedon of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Minimum length of malar area equal to or less than minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; pygidial plate prominent, exposed, with short hairs or bare, T7 truncate or rounded apically; labrum variable but usually less than three-fourths as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Simanthedon of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Clypeal margin truncate; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment usually shorter than second segment; S6 usually without lateral teeth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Simanthedon of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): T7 without lateral teeth (occasionally S6 with lateral teeth that can be seen from above and may be confused with tergal teeth)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Simanthedon of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): First ﬂagellar segment no longer than second segment and often much shorter (longer in Peponapis timberlakei, Hurd and Lindsey); inner margin of mandible without tooth near base

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Simanthedon of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Clypeus strongly protuberant, abruptly beveled and snoutlike apically (Fig. 112-6g), its proﬁle forming distinct preapical angle and concave above angle (rare, southwestern deserts)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Martinapis of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): First ﬂagellar segment only slightly shorter than second (Fig. 112-8d); last ﬂagellar segment tapering to apex; ﬂagellum bright yellow (deserts of southwestern USA and Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Agapanthinus of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Last ﬂagellar segment with short, pointed, hooked apex twisted slightly laterad (Baja California, California)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Gaesischia of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Hind basitarsus ﬂattened, shining, largely hairless on outer surface; distal two ﬂagellar segments often slightly compressed (tropical to Arizona)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera T etraloniella(in part) of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Oculoclypeal distance extremely short (Fig. 1126b), not more than about one-fourth of minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Syntrichalonia of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): S1 with hairy median convexity (Fig. 112-10a), proﬁle thus convex; last ﬂagellar segment rounded apically (Mexico, southwestern USA)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Svastra (Anthedonia) of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): S1 relatively ﬂat, proﬁle straight and lacking prominent median eminence; last ﬂagellar segment tapering and acuminate apically

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Svastra of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Maxillary palpus usually four-segmented, but if ﬁve-segmented, then T2 with basal pubescent band at least a few hairs of which are basally plumose and apically spatulate (Fig. 112-10b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera T etraloniella (Loxoptilus) of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Blade of galea twice as long as eye or longer (Fig. 112-6a); clypeus strongly protuberant; lower part of paraocular carina prominent; antenna long, reaching stigma or beyond in repose (Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera T etraloniella(in part) of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Oculoclypeal distance extremely short (Fig. 1126b), not more than about one-fourth of minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Peponapis (in part) of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): S6 with oblique lateral apical carina straight, sternum not toothed or angled laterally (Fig. 112-10d); antenna of moderate length, not reaching stigma in repose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera Eucera (Synhalonia) of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Proﬁle of clypeus distinctly convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the North and Central American Genera T etraloniella (Pectinapis) of the Eucerini (Males)(Peponapis timberlakei Hurd and Linsley runs either toSvastra in couplet 14, except that the last antennal seg-ment is not tapering and acuminate, or to couplet 15, ex-cept that the last ﬂagellar segment is more than twice aslong as broad.): Proﬁle of clypeus nearly straight, in spite of rather strong protuberance (Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eucera (in part) of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 112-4a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eucera (in part) of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Maxillary palpus six-segmented, very rarely ﬁve-segmented; ﬁrst submarginal cell of front wing smaller than second (Fig. 112-4a), and distance from ﬁrst submarginal crossvein to ﬁrst recurrent vein greater than distance from second recurrent to second submarginal crossvein; ﬁrst segment of ﬂagellum of male short, 0.9 to 2.5 times as long as broad, second segment 1.7 to 5.0 times as long as ﬁrst; gradulus of S6 of male arcuate; medial area of S7 of male more or less ﬂat (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Cubitalia of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Forewing with two submarginal cells (Fig. 112-4a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Cubitalia of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Maxillary palpus threeor four-segmented; ﬁrst submarginal cell of front wing equal to second, and distance from ﬁrst submarginal crossvein to ﬁrst recurrent vein about equal to that from second recurrent to second submarginal crossvein; ﬁrst segment of ﬂagellum of male long, 3.3 to 4.0 times as long as broad, second segment 0.7 to 1.2 times as long as ﬁrst; gradulus of S6 of male sharply angulate to rear near lateral extremity (sometimes weakly so in subgenus Cubitalia s. str.); medial area of S7 of male produced downward posteriorly (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera T etralonia of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Forewing with three submarginal cells

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera T etralonia of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Maxillary palpus threeto four-segmented or with minute ﬁfth segment, often not longer than maximum width of galeal blade; keirotrichiate area of female apically at least half as wide as hind tibia and extending basad beyond middle of tibia; scopa consisting of sparse, strongly plumose hairs on outer surface of tibia, each arising from tubercle separated from its neighbors by full width of tubercle

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Notolonia of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Forewing with three submarginal cells

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Notolonia of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Maxillary palpus ﬁveor six-segmented, often longer than maximum width of galeal blade; keirotrichiate area and associated ﬁnely and closely punctate surface of female usually less than half as wide as hind tibia and extending basad only to middle of tibia, rarely absent; scopa consisting of denser hairs, often simple, if plumose, then arising from tubercles less widely separated from one another

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Notolonia of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Blade of galea more than twice as long as eye; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment of male much longer than scape and as long as second ﬂagellar segment, that of female about as long as scape and distinctly longer than second and third ﬂagellar segments taken together (T urkmenistan)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eucera (Synhalonia) of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Forewing with three submarginal cells

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eucera (Synhalonia) of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Maxillary palpus ﬁveor six-segmented, often longer than maximum width of galeal blade; keirotrichiate area and associated ﬁnely and closely punctate surface of female usually less than half as wide as hind tibia and extending basad only to middle of tibia, rarely absent; scopa consisting of denser hairs, often simple, if plumose, then arising from tubercles less widely separated from one another

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eucera (Synhalonia) of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Blade of galea shorter; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment of male shorter than scape and much shorter than second ﬂagellar segment, that of female shorter than scape and not or scarcely longer than second and third ﬂagellar segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Eucera (Synhalonia) of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: S6 of male with the two converging carinae each usually angulate near anterior end, forming lateral angle usually reﬂecting marginal sternal angle or lobe (Fig. 11210e), which is often strengthened by lateral branch carina arising at angle of converging carina, sometimes carinae absent except for branch and mesally directed anterior end of converging carina, together forming transverse carina directed anteromesally from marginal sternal angle or lobe; clypeus usually protuberant for width of eye or more as seen in lateral view; blade of galea 1.2 or more times length of eye; middle femur of male on undersurface commonly with area of dense, appressed, red-brown hair hiding surface

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera T etraloniella of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Forewing with three submarginal cells

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera T etraloniella of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Maxillary palpus ﬁveor six-segmented, often longer than maximum width of galeal blade; keirotrichiate area and associated ﬁnely and closely punctate surface of female usually less than half as wide as hind tibia and extending basad only to middle of tibia, rarely absent; scopa consisting of denser hairs, often simple, if plumose, then arising from tubercles less widely separated from one another

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera T etraloniella of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: Blade of galea shorter; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment of male shorter than scape and much shorter than second ﬂagellar segment, that of female shorter than scape and not or scarcely longer than second and third ﬂagellar segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera T etraloniella of the Eucerini of the EasternHemisphere: S6 of male with the two converging carinae each usually simple and more or less straight; clypeus usually protuberant for less than width of eye as seen in lateral view; blade of galea usually not much longer than length of eye; middle femur of male sometimes with area of sparse, appressed whitish hair not hiding surface, more commonly with unspecialized sloping or erect hair

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Megascirtetica) of Alloscirtetica: Claws of female simple; arolia unusually small; mandible with large, right-angular preapical tooth separated from apex by deep notch; head strongly elevated behind ocelli; body length over 15 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Alloscirtetica s. str.) of Alloscirtetica: Claws of female with inner tooth; arolia of ordinary size; mandible simple, preapical tooth vestigial or absent; head not or weakly elevated behind ocelli; body length 12 mm or less

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Opacula) of Cubitalia (Males Only): Postgradular area of S5 with two tufts of bristly hairs directed laterally; front basitarsus slightly curved, of normal length, about 1.8 times as long as three following segments taken together; gonostylus sharply curved medially, with pointed ventral lamellar projection; clypeus gently convex in proﬁle, lower part extended down and facing forward; middle tibia slightly curved

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Cubitalia s. str.) of Cubitalia (Males Only): Postgradular area of S5 more or less uniformly pubescent; front basitarsus straight, shortened, 1.2 to 1.5 times length of three following segments taken together; gonostylus broadened at apex, not bent medially, without ventral projection; clypeus obtusely angulate in proﬁle, lower part curved back and facing somewhat downward; middle tibia not curved

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Cubitalia s. str.) of Cubitalia (Males Only): Mandible longer than eye, bidentate, acetabular carina not forming preapical tooth; inner orbits diverging downward; antenna reaching propodeum; front margins of middle and hind basitarsi with broad excisions or emarginations; S7, as seen from beneath, with large convexity on each side of median carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Pseudeucera) of Cubitalia (Males Only): Postgradular area of S5 more or less uniformly pubescent; front basitarsus straight, shortened, 1.2 to 1.5 times length of three following segments taken together; gonostylus broadened at apex, not bent medially, without ventral projection; clypeus obtusely angulate in proﬁle, lower part curved back and facing somewhat downward; middle tibia not curved

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Pseudeucera) of Cubitalia (Males Only): Mandible shorter than eye, acetabular carina ending in preapical tooth, mandibular apex thus three-toothed; inner orbits parallel; antennae long, reaching metasoma; front margins of middle and hind basitarsi unmodiﬁed; S7 without large ventral convexities

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Synhalonia) of Eucera: Forewing with three submarginal cells (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Hetereucera) of Eucera: Forewing with two submarginal cells (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Hetereucera) of Eucera: Males

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Hetereucera) of Eucera: Gonostylus, as seen in lateral view, straight or gently arcuate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Euﬂorilegus) of Florilegus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Moure and Michener, 1955b): Hind tibia at least slightly contorted with band of dense hairs on otherwise largely bare inner surface; hind femur concave beneath; inner apical lobe of S7 much longer than broad, terminating in relatively short, sparse hairs (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Floriraptor) of Florilegus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Moure and Michener, 1955b): Hind tibia unmodiﬁed; hind femur convex beneath; inner apical lobe of S7 broader than long, terminating in fringe of long hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Floriraptor) of Florilegus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Moure and Michener, 1955b): Large black forms without pale fasciae on ﬁrst three metasomal terga; scutellum relatively ﬂat, its proﬁle nearly a continuation of that of scutum (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Florilegus s. str.) of Florilegus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Moure and Michener, 1955b): Hind tibia unmodiﬁed; hind femur convex beneath; inner apical lobe of S7 broader than long, terminating in fringe of long hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Florilegus s. str.) of Florilegus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Moure and Michener, 1955b): Smaller forms with pale fasciae (sometimes broken) on T2 and T3; scutellum more convex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera F . (Euﬂorilegus) of Florilegus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Moure and Michener, 1955b): Hind tibia at least slightly contorted with band of dense hairs on otherwise largely bare inner surface; hind femur concave beneath; inner apical lobe of S7 much longer than broad, terminating in relatively short, sparse hairs (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera G. (Gaesischiopsis) of Gaesischia (Males): S6 with pair of carinae converging posteriorly [except in Gaesischia patellicornis (Ducke)]; labral emargination shallow or occupying less than one-third of distal labral margin; middle femur without mass or tuft of dense hair; ﬂagellum little thicker than diameter of ocellus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera G. (Gaesischiopsis) of Gaesischia (Males): Maxillary palpus four-segmented; S5 with subapical row of long, bristle-like hairs (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera G. (Gaesischiana) of Gaesischia (Males): S6 with pair of carinae converging posteriorly [except in Gaesischia patellicornis (Ducke)]; labral emargination shallow or occupying less than one-third of distal labral margin; middle femur without mass or tuft of dense hair; ﬂagellum little thicker than diameter of ocellus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera G. (Gaesischiana) of Gaesischia (Males): Maxillary palpus ﬁveor six-segmented; S5 without long bristle-like hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera G. (Gaesischiana) of Gaesischia (Males): Posterior leg modiﬁed, femur enlarged with area of short, dense hairs near posterior margin of bare undersurface, basitarsus with row of long hairs on anterodistal margin; ﬂagellum tapering, last segment compressed and sometimes expanded (neotropical, Arizona)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera G. (Prodasyhalonia) of Gaesischia (Males): S6 without such carinae, but with elevated basal area or median lamella; labral emargination deep and occupying over one-third of distal labral margin; middle femur nearly bare beneath except sometimes for mass or tuft of short, dense hairs; ﬂagellum much thicker than diameter of ocellus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera G. (Prodasyhalonia) of Gaesischia (Males): S6 with longitudinal median lamella, ending posteriorly in a tooth; penultimate ﬂagellar segment more than twice as long as broad (Mexico)

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera G. (Dasyhalonia) of Gaesischia (Males): S6 with elevated basal area sometimes ending in a tooth, but without lamella; penultimate ﬂagellar segment less than twice as long as broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Martinapis s. str.) of Martinapis: Antenna of male rather short, reaching propodeum, entirely yellow, ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment over 0.7 times as long as second; last ﬂagellar segment of male tapering to blunt point (Fig. 112-8d) (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Svastropsis) of Martinapis: Antenna of male reaching beyond propodeum, black, ﬂagellum red-yellow beneath, ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment nearly 0.6 times as long as second; last ﬂagellar segment of male with ordinary rounded apex (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Apomelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus protuberant in front of eye for one-half to threefourths of eye width, as seen in lateral view and antenna long, minimum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment less than one-third maximum length of second segment; T2 to T5 fringed with narrow apical bands of appressed white pubescence, bands much narrower than basal areas (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Callimelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus usually not protruding in front of eye by as much as half of eye width, as seen in side view, or, if protruding by half of eye width or more, then minimum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment one-third or more of maximum length of second segment; terga often not fringed by apical pubescent bands, bands when present interrupted medially and/or preapical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Callimelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Posterior margin of S4 (and usually S3) broadly convex, or produced into a broad, thin, hyaline, colorless ﬂap (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Psilomelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus usually not protruding in front of eye by as much as half of eye width, as seen in side view, or, if protruding by half of eye width or more, then minimum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment one-third or more of maximum length of second segment; terga often not fringed by apical pubescent bands, bands when present interrupted medially and/or preapical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Psilomelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Posterior margins of S3 and S4 straight to slightly concave, never produced into ﬂaps

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Psilomelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus protuberant in front of eye by at least threefourths of width of eye, as seen in side view; maximum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment 0.4 or more of maximum length of second segment (nearctic)..M. (Heliomelissodes) —. Clypeus usually protruding one-half or less of width of eye, as seen in side view, or, if protruding more, then maximum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment less then 0.4 of maximum length of second segment

Title: Bees Of The World

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Psilomelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Maximum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment as great as or almost as great as maximum length of second segment and longer than third segment (antenna female-like); clypeus wholly black (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Psilomelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus usually not protruding in front of eye by as much as half of eye width, as seen in side view, or, if protruding by half of eye width or more, then minimum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment one-third or more of maximum length of second segment; terga often not fringed by apical pubescent bands, bands when present interrupted medially and/or preapical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Psilomelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus protruding in front of eye by less than half width of eye, as seen in lateral view, or, if protruding by as much as half width of eye, then inner orbits distinctly converging below and/or inner surface of hind basitarsus with hairs bright red to yellow (scopal hairs occasionally only weakly branched)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Psilomelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Scopal hairs weak, with few branches, not hiding outer surfaces of hind basitarsus and tibia; metasomal terga very sparsely and weakly punctate, dulled by dense, ﬁne shagreening and weakly banded with sparse pubescence; pygidial plate V-shaped with broadly rounded apex (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (T achymelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus usually not protruding in front of eye by as much as half of eye width, as seen in side view, or, if protruding by half of eye width or more, then minimum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment one-third or more of maximum length of second segment; terga often not fringed by apical pubescent bands, bands when present interrupted medially and/or preapical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (T achymelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus protruding in front of eye by less than half width of eye, as seen in lateral view, or, if protruding by as much as half width of eye, then inner orbits distinctly converging below and/or inner surface of hind basitarsus with hairs bright red to yellow (scopal hairs occasionally only weakly branched)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (T achymelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Scopal hairs strongly branched and hiding outer surfaces of hind basitarsus and tibia; or, if weak and with few branches, then terga coarsely punctate at least basally, or moderately shiny to shiny and strongly banded with abundant pubescence, or pygidial plate narrowly Ushaped

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (T achymelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): T2 to T4 with distal pale pubescent bands reaching apical margins of terga, of about same width across each tergum and subequal in width to one another, as narrow as or narrower than basal areas of dark pubescence (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melissodes s. str.) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus usually not protruding in front of eye by as much as half of eye width, as seen in side view, or, if protruding by half of eye width or more, then minimum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment one-third or more of maximum length of second segment; terga often not fringed by apical pubescent bands, bands when present interrupted medially and/or preapical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melissodes s. str.) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus protruding in front of eye by less than half width of eye, as seen in lateral view, or, if protruding by as much as half width of eye, then inner orbits distinctly converging below and/or inner surface of hind basitarsus with hairs bright red to yellow (scopal hairs occasionally only weakly branched)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melissodes s. str.) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Scopal hairs strongly branched and hiding outer surfaces of hind basitarsus and tibia; or, if weak and with few branches, then terga coarsely punctate at least basally, or moderately shiny to shiny and strongly banded with abundant pubescence, or pygidial plate narrowly Ushaped

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melissodes s. str.) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Maximum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment less than maximum length of second segment and distinctly less than that of third; clypeus usually pale, occasionally partly or wholly black

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melissodes s. str.) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Minimum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment half of maximum length of second segment or less; T2 to T5 with pale pubescent bands usually not all apical or not subequal in width, often interrupted medially and usually subapical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melissodes s. str.) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Median apical lobes of S7 without hairs on ventral surfaces, usually small, curled ventrally along an oblique axis to form half or more of an oblique cylinder or scroll (Fig. 112-9c), but often secondarily ﬂattened and expanded, or secondarily reduced in size

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Ecplectica) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus usually not protruding in front of eye by as much as half of eye width, as seen in side view, or, if protruding by half of eye width or more, then minimum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment one-third or more of maximum length of second segment; terga often not fringed by apical pubescent bands, bands when present interrupted medially and/or preapical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Ecplectica) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus protruding in front of eye by less than half width of eye, as seen in lateral view, or, if protruding by as much as half width of eye, then inner orbits distinctly converging below and/or inner surface of hind basitarsus with hairs bright red to yellow (scopal hairs occasionally only weakly branched)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Ecplectica) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Scopal hairs strongly branched and hiding outer surfaces of hind basitarsus and tibia; or, if weak and with few branches, then terga coarsely punctate at least basally, or moderately shiny to shiny and strongly banded with abundant pubescence, or pygidial plate narrowly Ushaped

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Ecplectica) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Maximum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment less than maximum length of second segment and distinctly less than that of third; clypeus usually pale, occasionally partly or wholly black

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Ecplectica) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Minimum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment half of maximum length of second segment or less; T2 to T5 with pale pubescent bands usually not all apical or not subequal in width, often interrupted medially and usually subapical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Ecplectica) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Median apical lobes of S7 thin, hyaline, with short to moderately long hairs on ventral surfaces, not curled ventrally, relatively large

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Ecplectica) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Gonostylus often less than half as long as gonocoxite, in lateral view at least twice as broad near base as near apex, narrowing abruptly near middle, not capitate; median lobes of S7 relatively small, with several short hairs ventrally (Fig. 112-9f) (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Heliomelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus usually not protruding in front of eye by as much as half of eye width, as seen in side view, or, if protruding by half of eye width or more, then minimum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment one-third or more of maximum length of second segment; terga often not fringed by apical pubescent bands, bands when present interrupted medially and/or preapical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Heliomelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus protruding anteriorly in front of eye by one-half to two-thirds width of eye, as seen in lateral view; inner orbits of eyes often parallel; inner surface of hind basitarsus with hairs dark brown to black (scopal hairs highly plumose, often yellowish) (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Psilomelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus usually not protruding in front of eye by as much as half of eye width, as seen in side view, or, if protruding by half of eye width or more, then minimum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment one-third or more of maximum length of second segment; terga often not fringed by apical pubescent bands, bands when present interrupted medially and/or preapical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Psilomelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus protruding in front of eye by less than half width of eye, as seen in lateral view, or, if protruding by as much as half width of eye, then inner orbits distinctly converging below and/or inner surface of hind basitarsus with hairs bright red to yellow (scopal hairs occasionally only weakly branched)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (T achymelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus protruding in front of eye by less than half width of eye, as seen in lateral view, or, if protruding by as much as half width of eye, then inner orbits distinctly converging below and/or inner surface of hind basitarsus with hairs bright red to yellow (scopal hairs occasionally only weakly branched)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (T achymelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Scopal hairs strongly branched and hiding outer surfaces of hind basitarsus and tibia; or, if weak and with few branches, then terga coarsely punctate at least basally, or moderately shiny to shiny and strongly banded with abundant pubescence, or pygidial plate narrowly Ushaped

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (T achymelissodes) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): T2 to T4 with distal pale pubescent bands reaching apical margins of terga, of about same width across each tergum and subequal in width to one another, as narrow as or narrower than basal areas of dark pubescence (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Callimelissodes, Ecplectica,  Eumelissodes, Melissodes s. str.) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus usually not protruding in front of eye by as much as half of eye width, as seen in side view, or, if protruding by half of eye width or more, then minimum length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment one-third or more of maximum length of second segment; terga often not fringed by apical pubescent bands, bands when present interrupted medially and/or preapical

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Callimelissodes, Ecplectica,  Eumelissodes, Melissodes s. str.) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Clypeus protruding in front of eye by less than half width of eye, as seen in lateral view, or, if protruding by as much as half width of eye, then inner orbits distinctly converging below and/or inner surface of hind basitarsus with hairs bright red to yellow (scopal hairs occasionally only weakly branched)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Callimelissodes, Ecplectica,  Eumelissodes, Melissodes s. str.) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): Scopal hairs strongly branched and hiding outer surfaces of hind basitarsus and tibia; or, if weak and with few branches, then terga coarsely punctate at least basally, or moderately shiny to shiny and strongly banded with abundant pubescence, or pygidial plate narrowly Ushaped

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Callimelissodes, Ecplectica,  Eumelissodes, Melissodes s. str.) of Melissodes (Males)(Modiﬁed from LaBerge, 1961): T2 to T4 with distal pale pubescent bands (at least on T2) not reaching apices of terga, or, ifreaching apices of terga, then diffuse over entire tergum or much wider than basal area of dark pubescence or of varying width across each tergum or between terga

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Anthedonia) of Svastra: Scopal hairs simple; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment of male as long as second, last segment tapering, attenuate (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Idiomelissodes) of Svastra: Scopal hairs plumose; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment of male much shorter than second, last segment cylindrical with rounded apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Idiomelissodes) of Svastra: Middle tibial spur hooked near apex (Fig. 112-15b); front tibial spur of male as long as basitarsus or slightly longer; posterior margin of male S5 with shallow lateral emargination bordered by long, posteriorly directed, hooked hairs overlying shallow, bare depression of S6 (Fig. 112-10c) (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera Brachymelissodes of Svastra: Scopal hairs plumose; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment of male much shorter than second, last segment cylindrical with rounded apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera Brachymelissodes of Svastra: Middle tibial spur not hooked; front tibial spur of male shorter than basitarsus; S5 of male without lateral emarginations, without hooked hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera Brachymelissodes of Svastra: Hairs of basal band of T2 and elsewhere plumose, spatuloplumose hairs absent; antenna of male scarcely reaching scutellum, undersurface of scape bright yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Svastra s. str.) of Svastra: Scopal hairs plumose; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment of male much shorter than second, last segment cylindrical with rounded apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Svastra s. str.) of Svastra: Middle tibial spur not hooked; front tibial spur of male shorter than basitarsus; S5 of male without lateral emarginations, without hooked hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Svastra s. str.) of Svastra: Spatuloplumose hairs present in basal band of T2 and elsewhere; antenna of male reaching beyond scutellum, scape without yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Svastra s. str.) of Svastra: Maxillary palpus ﬁve-segmented; scutoscutellar suture without, and basal band of T3 with, spatuloplumose hairs like those of T2; S6 of male with pair of converging carinae (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Epimelissodes) of Svastra: Scopal hairs plumose; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment of male much shorter than second, last segment cylindrical with rounded apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Epimelissodes) of Svastra: Middle tibial spur not hooked; front tibial spur of male shorter than basitarsus; S5 of male without lateral emarginations, without hooked hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Epimelissodes) of Svastra: Spatuloplumose hairs present in basal band of T2 and elsewhere; antenna of male reaching beyond scutellum, scape without yellow

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera S. (Epimelissodes) of Svastra: Maxillary palpus usually four-segmented; scutoscutellar suture with, and T3 without, spatuloplumose hairs like those of T2; S6 of male without pair of converging carinae, sometimes with ridges instead (North and Middle America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (T etralonia s. str.) of T etralonia: T7 of male with lateral tooth; male gonostylus gently arcuate in side view; maxillary palpus ﬁve-segmented, ﬁfth segment minute and indistinct; antenna of male reaching base of metasoma (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Eucara) of T etralonia: T7 of male without lateral tooth; male gonostylus elbowed as seen in lateral view; maxillary palpus threeto four-segmented; antenna of male reaching scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Eucara) of T etralonia: Lower clypeal margin mesal from mandibular articulation nearly transverse and rounding onto transverse or weakly concave median part of clypeal margin; lower lateral part of clypeus, as seen from beneath, curved back on either side of labrum in such a way that margins are at angle of about 45/H11034to long axis of body (Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Thygatina) of T etralonia: T7 of male without lateral tooth; male gonostylus elbowed as seen in lateral view; maxillary palpus threeto four-segmented; antenna of male reaching scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Thygatina) of T etralonia: Lower clypeal margin mesal from mandibular articulation diagonal, separated by distinct angle from transverse median part of clypeal margin; lower lateral part of clypeus, as seen from beneath, curved back on either side of labrum in such a way that margin at each side is nearly parallel to long axis of body (Africa, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Glazunovia) of T etraloniella: Gonostylus of male about three times as long as basal width, as seen in side view; basitibial plate of female almost bare, margin fully exposed and not at all raised but curving down to level of rest of tibia; claws of female with inner tooth minute, its axis parallel to that of distal part of claw (palearctic Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Pectinapis) of T etraloniella: Gonostylus of male ﬁve or more times as long as basal width; basitibial plate of female with small, more or less appressed hairs that usually hide part of margin, which is often minutely raised; claws of female with inner tooth larger, diverging from axis of distal part of claw

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Pectinapis) of T etraloniella: Clypeus of female broadly ﬂattened, covered with short, erect, robust hairs with hooked or wavy apices (Fig. 112-14c) (oculoclypeal distance of male 0.5 to 1.0 times minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment) (Mexico, T exas))

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Loxoptilus) of T etraloniella: Gonostylus of male ﬁve or more times as long as basal width; basitibial plate of female with small, more or less appressed hairs that usually hide part of margin, which is often minutely raised; claws of female with inner tooth larger, diverging from axis of distal part of claw

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Loxoptilus) of T etraloniella: Clypeus of female convex, with ordinary vestiture

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Loxoptilus) of T etraloniella: Maxillary stipes of female with longitudinal band of coarse bristles having hooked or wavy apices; oculoclypeal distance greater than minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment (Fig. 112-6a, f) (Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (T etraloniella s. str.) of T etraloniella: Gonostylus of male ﬁve or more times as long as basal width; basitibial plate of female with small, more or less appressed hairs that usually hide part of margin, which is often minutely raised; claws of female with inner tooth larger, diverging from axis of distal part of claw

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (T etraloniella s. str.) of T etraloniella: Clypeus of female convex, with ordinary vestiture

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (T etraloniella s. str.) of T etraloniella: Maxillary stipes without such bristles; oculoclypeal distance variable but often minute, less than one-fourth of minimum width of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment (holarctic and Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Thygater s. str.) of Thygater (Males)(Modiﬁed from Moure and Michener, 1955b): First ﬂagellar segment one-sixth as long as second or less; ﬂagellum reaching far beyond stigma, greatest breadth nearly equal to basal width of mandible; malar space onethird as long as wide or longer (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Nectarodiaeta) of Thygater (Males)(Modiﬁed from Moure and Michener, 1955b): First ﬂagellar segment one-fourth to one-third as long as second; ﬂagellum reaching stigma, greatest breadth about two-thirds basal width of mandible; malar space less than one-fourth as long as wide (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Thygater s. str.) of Thygater (Males)(Modiﬁed from Moure and Michener, 1955b): First ﬂagellar segment one-sixth as long as second or less; ﬂagellum reaching far beyond stigma, greatest breadth nearly equal to basal width of mandible; malar space onethird as long as wide or longer (neotropical)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Nectarodiaeta) of Thygater (Males)(Modiﬁed from Moure and Michener, 1955b): First ﬂagellar segment one-fourth to one-third as long as second; ﬂagellum reaching stigma, greatest breadth about two-thirds basal width of mandible; malar space less than one-fourth as long as wide (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Dithygater) of Trichocerapis(Males)(Modiﬁed from Moure and Michener, 1955b): Pygidial plate rounded posteriorly, marginal carina uniform; last ﬂagellar segment longer than any of the others, not broadened; submarginal cells two

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Trichocerapis s. str.) of Trichocerapis(Males)(Modiﬁed from Moure and Michener, 1955b): Pygidial plate narrowed subapically and ending in small upturned process, marginal carina elevated subapically; last ﬂagellar segment shorter than others except ﬁrst, broad and ﬂat; submarginal cells three

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Dithygater) of Trichocerapis(Males)(Modiﬁed from Moure and Michener, 1955b): Pygidial plate rounded posteriorly, marginal carina uniform; last ﬂagellar segment longer than any of the others, not broadened; submarginal cells two

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera T . (Trichocerapis s. str.) of Trichocerapis(Males)(Modiﬁed from Moure and Michener, 1955b): Pygidial plate narrowed subapically and ending in small upturned process, marginal carina elevated subapically; last ﬂagellar segment shorter than others except ﬁrst, broad and ﬂat; submarginal cells three

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Eoxenoglossa) of Xenoglossa: Eyes weakly diverging below, antennal socket closer to eye margin than to lateral ocellus; ocelli scarcely larger than antennal sockets

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Xenoglossa s. str.) of Xenoglossa: Eyes markedly diverging below, antennal socket farther from eye margin than from lateral ocellus; ocelli enlarged, much larger than antennal sockets

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Anthophora of the Anthophorini: First recurrent vein joining second submarginal cell near middle; third submarginal cell subquadrate, with front and rear margins of about equal length, and basal and distal margins of about equal length (Fig. 113-1a); male gonostylus usually less than one-third as long as gonocoxite (Fig. 113-2a, d), often not double, sometimes reduced to almost nothing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Anthophora of the Anthophorini: Arolia present (worldwide except Australian region)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Amegilla of the Anthophorini: First recurrent vein joining second submarginal cell near middle; third submarginal cell subquadrate, with front and rear margins of about equal length, and basal and distal margins of about equal length (Fig. 113-1a); male gonostylus usually less than one-third as long as gonocoxite (Fig. 113-2a, d), often not double, sometimes reduced to almost nothing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Amegilla of the Anthophorini: Arolia absent (Eastern Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pachymelus of the Anthophorini: First recurrent vein terminating at or near apex of second submarginal cell (Fig. 113-1b); third submarginal cell (except in Habrophorula) with front margin much shorter than rear margin because of curvature of third submarginal crossvein, such that distal margin of the cell is longer than basal margin; male gonostylus double, dorsal and ventral gonostyli usually both one-third as long as gonocoxite or more

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pachymelus of the Anthophorini: Stigma almost absent, represented by minute area broader than long; T2 to T5 or at least T3 with lateral, longitudinal parts of graduli strong, sometimes reaching posterior marginal zones of terga; pygidial plate of male present as a well-deﬁned apical process of T7, margined by carinae across apex and at sides, at least apically (Africa, Madagascar)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Deltoptila of the Anthophorini: First recurrent vein terminating at or near apex of second submarginal cell (Fig. 113-1b); third submarginal cell (except in Habrophorula) with front margin much shorter than rear margin because of curvature of third submarginal crossvein, such that distal margin of the cell is longer than basal margin; male gonostylus double, dorsal and ventral gonostyli usually both one-third as long as gonocoxite or more

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
