Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Deltoptila of the Anthophorini: Stigma at least as long as broad, usually much longer than broad (Fig. 113-1b); T2 to T5 commonly without lateral longitudinal parts of graduli; pygidial plate of male absent or indicated by smooth bare area margined by carina only across apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Deltoptila of the Anthophorini: Malar space at least twice as long as antennal pedicel; vein cu-v of hind wing nearly transverse, at angle of 50/H11034 or more to ﬁrst abscissa of M/H11001Cu (Mesoamerica)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Elaphropoda of the Anthophorini: First recurrent vein terminating at or near apex of second submarginal cell (Fig. 113-1b); third submarginal cell (except in Habrophorula) with front margin much shorter than rear margin because of curvature of third submarginal crossvein, such that distal margin of the cell is longer than basal margin; male gonostylus double, dorsal and ventral gonostyli usually both one-third as long as gonocoxite or more

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Elaphropoda of the Anthophorini: Stigma at least as long as broad, usually much longer than broad (Fig. 113-1b); T2 to T5 commonly without lateral longitudinal parts of graduli; pygidial plate of male absent or indicated by smooth bare area margined by carina only across apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Elaphropoda of the Anthophorini: Malar space linear to about as long as antennal pedicel; vein cu-v of hind wing usually conspicuously oblique, at angle of 45/H11034or less to ﬁrst abscissa of M /H11001Cu (except nearly transverse in Habrophorula) (holarctic and oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Elaphropoda of the Anthophorini: Mandible with two preapical teeth, thus tridentate; T7 and S6 of male somewhat attenuate apically, apices rounded or pointed (S7 of male weakly sclerotized, without transverse ridge at base of apical process; hind leg of male enlarged, trochanter with broad rounded projection) (oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habrophorula of the Anthophorini: First recurrent vein terminating at or near apex of second submarginal cell (Fig. 113-1b); third submarginal cell (except in Habrophorula) with front margin much shorter than rear margin because of curvature of third submarginal crossvein, such that distal margin of the cell is longer than basal margin; male gonostylus double, dorsal and ventral gonostyli usually both one-third as long as gonocoxite or more

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habrophorula of the Anthophorini: Stigma at least as long as broad, usually much longer than broad (Fig. 113-1b); T2 to T5 commonly without lateral longitudinal parts of graduli; pygidial plate of male absent or indicated by smooth bare area margined by carina only across apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habrophorula of the Anthophorini: Malar space linear to about as long as antennal pedicel; vein cu-v of hind wing usually conspicuously oblique, at angle of 45/H11034or less to ﬁrst abscissa of M /H11001Cu (except nearly transverse in Habrophorula) (holarctic and oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habrophorula of the Anthophorini: Mandible with one preapical tooth, thus bidentate; T7 and S6 of male not attenuate, apex of T6 nearly always bidentate or with emarginate apical truncation

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habrophorula of the Anthophorini: Third submarginal cell about as wide on anterior margin as on posterior margin; male with ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment about as broad as long and shorter than second; S7 of male weakly sclerotized, transverse, disc broader than long, without apical process (oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habropoda of the Anthophorini: First recurrent vein terminating at or near apex of second submarginal cell (Fig. 113-1b); third submarginal cell (except in Habrophorula) with front margin much shorter than rear margin because of curvature of third submarginal crossvein, such that distal margin of the cell is longer than basal margin; male gonostylus double, dorsal and ventral gonostyli usually both one-third as long as gonocoxite or more

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habropoda of the Anthophorini: Stigma at least as long as broad, usually much longer than broad (Fig. 113-1b); T2 to T5 commonly without lateral longitudinal parts of graduli; pygidial plate of male absent or indicated by smooth bare area margined by carina only across apex

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habropoda of the Anthophorini: Malar space linear to about as long as antennal pedicel; vein cu-v of hind wing usually conspicuously oblique, at angle of 45/H11034or less to ﬁrst abscissa of M /H11001Cu (except nearly transverse in Habrophorula) (holarctic and oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habropoda of the Anthophorini: Mandible with one preapical tooth, thus bidentate; T7 and S6 of male not attenuate, apex of T6 nearly always bidentate or with emarginate apical truncation

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Habropoda of the Anthophorini: Third submarginal cell with anterior margin much shorter than posterior margin; male with ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment much longer than broad and longer than second; S7 of male strongly sclerotized, disc giving rise to large apical process, base of which often bears transverse ridge (holarctic, oriental)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthophora s. str.) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Middle distitarsus with brush of dense hairs, middle basitarsus often with brush; apex of S7 with lateral margin forming two low lobes, one sometimes partly above the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthophora s. str.) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Basitibial plate absent; pygidial plate absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthophora s. str.) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Flabellum apically entire; S7 apically narrowed, elongate, apodemes at least 1.3 times as long as length of disc; apex of gonocoxite deeply bilobed (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Caranthophora) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Middle distitarsus with brush of dense hairs, middle basitarsus often with brush; apex of S7 with lateral margin forming two low lobes, one sometimes partly above the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Caranthophora) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Basitibial plate absent; pygidial plate absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Caranthophora) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Flabellum apically with ﬁngerlike projections (as in Fig. 113-4a-c); S7 apically broad, short, apodemes no more than 0.4 times as long as length of disc; apex of gonocoxite weakly trilobed (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Lophanthophora) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Middle distitarsus with brush of dense hairs, middle basitarsus often with brush; apex of S7 with lateral margin forming two low lobes, one sometimes partly above the other

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Lophanthophora) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Basitibial plate present; pygidial plate present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Lophanthophora) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Distal half of S6 with a pair of apically diverging oblique ridges; apex of gonocoxite simple, ﬂattened, hooked ventrad (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pyganthophora) (in part) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Basitibial plate present, and hind basitarsus simple, nearly parallel-sided; pygidial plate with margin carinate and not concave; gradular process of T7 sometimes present (holarctic, Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Clisodon) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Middle tarsus simple, without any brushes; apex of S7 laterally simple or with two lobes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Clisodon) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Mandible tridentate because of preapical convexity or tooth on lower margin in addition to usual preapical tooth on upper margin; gonostylus concolorous with apex of gonocoxite, perhaps absent; ﬂabellum apically simple (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthophoroides) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Middle tarsus simple, without any brushes; apex of S7 laterally simple or with two lobes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthophoroides) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Mandible bidentate or sometimes simple; gonostylus lightly sclerotized, thus clearly demarcated from gonocoxite; ﬂabellum apically with ﬁngerlike lobes (Fig. 1134a-c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthophoroides) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Mentum with submedian tooth on anterior surface; apex of S7 with one lateral lobe (Fig. 113-2c) (hind basitarsus with anterior tooth or strong ridge)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthophoroides) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Body length at most 13 mm; hind tibial spur arising near apex of an apical tibial spine; apex of gonocoxite heavily sclerotized with a distinct melanized demarcation (seen only in cleared preparations of genital capsule) between apex and base; face with white integumental markings (yellow in Anthophora vallorum Cockerell and californica Cresson) (North and Central America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melea) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Middle tarsus simple, without any brushes; apex of S7 laterally simple or with two lobes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melea) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Mandible bidentate or sometimes simple; gonostylus lightly sclerotized, thus clearly demarcated from gonocoxite; ﬂabellum apically with ﬁngerlike lobes (Fig. 1134a-c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melea) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Mentum with submedian tooth on anterior surface; apex of S7 with one lateral lobe (Fig. 113-2c) (hind basitarsus with anterior tooth or strong ridge)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melea) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Body length greater than 13 mm; hind tibia simple, without apical spine; apex of gonocoxite not more heavily sclerotized than base, no demarcation between the two; face with yellow integumental markings (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthomegilla) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Middle tarsus simple, without any brushes; apex of S7 laterally simple or with two lobes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthomegilla) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Mandible bidentate or sometimes simple; gonostylus lightly sclerotized, thus clearly demarcated from gonocoxite; ﬂabellum apically with ﬁngerlike lobes (Fig. 1134a-c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthomegilla) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Mentum without tooth near middle of anterior surface, or, if tooth present, then hind basitarsus simple, almost parallel-sided, and without anterior tooth or ridge; apex of S7 with two lateral lobes on each side, sometimes only weakly developed, or, if apex simple laterally or with one lobe, then body small (7.5-13.5 mm long) and/or S6 with thick pad of hair

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthomegilla) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Malar space more than one-third as long as wide; ﬂabellum elongate, apically entire or with numerous small apical lobes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthomegilla) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Flabellum apically entire, elongate, with apical twothirds narrowed; T7 of male with longitudinal median ridge not reaching apex, with two small, weakly developed, submedian projections; penis valve bridge short, basally emarginate (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhinomegilla) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Middle tarsus simple, without any brushes; apex of S7 laterally simple or with two lobes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhinomegilla) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Mandible bidentate or sometimes simple; gonostylus lightly sclerotized, thus clearly demarcated from gonocoxite; ﬂabellum apically with ﬁngerlike lobes (Fig. 1134a-c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhinomegilla) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Mentum without tooth near middle of anterior surface, or, if tooth present, then hind basitarsus simple, almost parallel-sided, and without anterior tooth or ridge; apex of S7 with two lateral lobes on each side, sometimes only weakly developed, or, if apex simple laterally or with one lobe, then body small (7.5-13.5 mm long) and/or S6 with thick pad of hair

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhinomegilla) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Malar space more than one-third as long as wide; ﬂabellum elongate, apically entire or with numerous small apical lobes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhinomegilla) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Flabellum apically with numerous small lobed divisions, broom-shaped, lateral margins almost parallel; T7 of male apicomedially, dorsoventrally ﬂattened with longitudinal median ridge reaching apex; penis valve bridge long, basally pointed (Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Heliophila) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Body length usually 7.5-13.5 mm and/or S6 with thick pad of hair (often hidden until sternum is relaxed and pulled apically); gradular process of T7 often prolonged into tooth when body size is small; apex of disc of T7 laterally simple, not with two lobes, lateral margins of disc usually parallel or apically converging, rarely narrowed medially (holarctic, Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Pyganthophora) (in part) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Basitibial plate present, and hind basitarsus simple, nearly parallel-sided; pygidial plate with margin carinate and not concave; gradular process of T7 sometimes present (holarctic, Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Paramegilla)(in part) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): T7 with two short submedian teeth, their bases separated by convex lamellate or angular apical margin, and median longitudinal carina often present; apical zone of T7, as seen from ventral view, narrow where bent ventroanteriad; hind basitarsus anteriorly with tooth, blunt process, or longitudinal ridge; apodemes of S7 almost always short, 0.34-0.78 as long as length of disc, lateral process absent; apex of gonocoxite in proﬁle simple to weakly bilobed (holarctic, Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Petalosternon) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): S8 with apicolateral margin angulate, spiculum projecting somewhat basally; S7 with apex shallowly emarginate, with two weakly developed apicolateral lobes, basal apodeme with lateral angle or process; apex of gonocoxite somewhat bilobed in proﬁle, lower lobe weakly developed, not carinate, sometimes with a tooth on lower inner margin of gonocoxite; face almost always with yellow markings (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Mystacanthophora) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): S8 with apicolateral margin prolonged and rounded, spiculum not easily visible from ventral aspect but projecting dorsally at a 90/H11034angle; S7 with apex distinctly emarginate, with two strong apicolateral lobes, basal apodeme without lateral process or angle; apex of gonocoxite complex in proﬁle with dorsoventral and lateral carinae; face with white markings (Western Hemisphere, palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Paramegilla)(in part) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): T7 with two short submedian teeth, their bases separated by convex lamellate or angular apical margin, and median longitudinal carina often present; apical zone of T7, as seen from ventral view, narrow where bent ventroanteriad; hind basitarsus anteriorly with tooth, blunt process, or longitudinal ridge; apodemes of S7 almost always short, 0.34-0.78 as long as length of disc, lateral process absent; apex of gonocoxite in proﬁle simple to weakly bilobed (holarctic, Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Dasymegilla) of Anthophora (Males)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): T7 with two long submedian teeth, their bases separated by rounded apical margin; apical zone of T7, as seen from ventral view, wide where bent ventroanteriad; hind basitarsus almost parallel-sided, anterior margin simple; apodemes of S7 long, 1.00-1.75 times as long as length of disc, lateral process present; apex of gonocoxite in proﬁle deeply bilobed (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Clisodon) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Apex of mandible with lower subapical tooth and thus tridentate; basitibial plate about twice as long as broad, tapering to pointed apex (ﬂabellum entire) (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthophora s. str.) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Apex of mandible without lower subapical tooth, bidentate; basitibial plate less slender, apex rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthophora s. str.) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Flabellum narrowly elongate, apically entire or with numerous short, small lobes; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment equal in length to next 3.2-4.0 segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthophora s. str.) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Malar area almost always short, rarely well developed, at most one-third as long as wide; ﬂabellum more or less parallel-sided or lanceolate, not attenuate in apical twothirds, apex entire; upper margin of hind tibia with scopal hairs plumose (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthomegilla) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Apex of mandible without lower subapical tooth, bidentate; basitibial plate less slender, apex rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthomegilla) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Flabellum narrowly elongate, apically entire or with numerous short, small lobes; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment equal in length to next 3.2-4.0 segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthomegilla) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Malar area more than one-third as long as wide; ﬂabellum elongate with apical two-thirds narrowed or ﬂabellum with numerous small apical lobes; upper margin of hind tibia with scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthomegilla) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Flabellum apically entire, elongate, with apical twothirds narrowed (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhinomegilla) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Apex of mandible without lower subapical tooth, bidentate; basitibial plate less slender, apex rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhinomegilla) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Flabellum narrowly elongate, apically entire or with numerous short, small lobes; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment equal in length to next 3.2-4.0 segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhinomegilla) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Malar area more than one-third as long as wide; ﬂabellum elongate with apical two-thirds narrowed or ﬂabellum with numerous small apical lobes; upper margin of hind tibia with scopal hairs simple

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Rhinomegilla) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Flabellum apically with numerous small lobes (Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melea) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Apex of mandible without lower subapical tooth, bidentate; basitibial plate less slender, apex rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melea) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Flabellum wide, with few long ﬁngerlike apical lobes (Fig. 113-4a-c); ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment equal in length to next 2.2-5.5 segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melea) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Mentum with a well-developed submedian tooth on anterior surface; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment equal in length to next 2.4-3.3 segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Melea) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Hind basitarsus with upper distal process acute; S6 with subapical tooth; upper margin of hind tibia with simple hair; body 13 mm long or longer (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthophoroides) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Apex of mandible without lower subapical tooth, bidentate; basitibial plate less slender, apex rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthophoroides) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Flabellum wide, with few long ﬁngerlike apical lobes (Fig. 113-4a-c); ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment equal in length to next 2.2-5.5 segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthophoroides) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Mentum with a well-developed submedian tooth on anterior surface; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment equal in length to next 2.4-3.3 segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Anthophoroides) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Hind basitarsus with upper distal process blunt; S6 without subapical tooth; upper margin of hind tibia with plumose hair; body no longer than 13 mm (North and Central America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Paramegilla)(in part) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Metasoma with apical bands of hair interrupted medially or surface covered evenly with appressed hair (holarctic, Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Heliophila) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Apex of mandible without lower subapical tooth, bidentate; basitibial plate less slender, apex rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Heliophila) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Flabellum wide, with few long ﬁngerlike apical lobes (Fig. 113-4a-c); ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment equal in length to next 2.2-5.5 segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Heliophila) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Mentum without tooth on anterior surface [rarely with tooth in old world species having upper zone of scopa plumose, e.g., Anthophora (Dasymegilla) excisaMorawitz]; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment equal in length to next 2.2-5.5 segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Heliophila) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Upper margin of hind tibia with simple hair; length 615 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Heliophila) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Face almost always with yellow to white integumental markings and body length 6-15 mm, but if face black, then length 11-13 mm and southern African in distribution (holarctic, Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Caranthophora)(in part) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Apex of mandible without lower subapical tooth, bidentate; basitibial plate less slender, apex rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Caranthophora)(in part) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Flabellum wide, with few long ﬁngerlike apical lobes (Fig. 113-4a-c); ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment equal in length to next 2.2-5.5 segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Caranthophora)(in part) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Mentum without tooth on anterior surface [rarely with tooth in old world species having upper zone of scopa plumose, e.g., Anthophora (Dasymegilla) excisaMorawitz]; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment equal in length to next 2.2-5.5 segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Caranthophora)(in part) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Upper margin of hind tibia with plumose hair; length 10-24 mm

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Caranthophora)(in part) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Clypeus with pale integumental marking in shape of inverted T , and ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment equal in length to next 2.2-3.0 segments taken together (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Paramegilla)(in part) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Metasoma with apical bands of hair interrupted medially or surface covered evenly with appressed hair (holarctic, Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Caranthophora[in part], Dasymegilla,  Lophanthophora, Mystacanthophora[in part],  Paramegilla[in part], Petalosternon, Pyganthophora) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Clypeus normal, without apically hooked or wavy hairs or basal pecten; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment equal in length to next 2.2-5.5 segments taken together

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Mystacanthophora)(in part) of Anthophora (Females)(Modiﬁed from Brooks, 1988): Clypeus ﬂattened, with hairs apically hooked or wavy, sometimes with a basal pecten; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment equal in length to next 2.2-3.4 segments taken together (Western Hemisphere, palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pachymelopsis) of Pachymelus: Arolia absent; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment shorter than scape; labrum with transverse preapical ridge, often broken; T2 with lateral gradulus reaching about middle of exposed part of tergum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Pachymelus s. str.) of Pachymelus: Arolia present; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment as long as or usually longer than scape; labrum without transverse preapical ridge; T2 with lateral gradulus usually strong and reaching posterior marginal zone of tergum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Epicharis of the Centridini: Marginal cell longer than distance from its apex to wing tip (Fig. 114-1b); a few long, whiplike setae arising from preoccipital ridge behind summit of eye and usually reaching anterior margin of tegula (but scarcely reaching anterior margin of scutum in subgenus Triepicharis)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Centris of the Centridini: Marginal cell shorter than distance from its apex to wing tip (Fig. 114-1a); whiplike setae arising behind summit of eye absent, or, ifpresent (subgenus Ptilotopus), then reaching only to anterior margin of scutum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ptilotopus) of Centris(By Ricardo Ayala): Scutellum with two lobes, tubercles, or convexities (except in males of Ptilocentis in which scutellum is convex with lobes not well deﬁned)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Ptilotopus) of Centris(By Ricardo Ayala): Hypoepimeral area with strong tubercle on anterior lower part (except in C. americanaKlug); scutellum, and sometimes scutum with glabrous areas; female with basitibial plate simple, clearly without secondary plate (body length 30-32 mm)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Schisthemisia) of Centris(By Ricardo Ayala): Scutellum with two lobes, tubercles, or convexities (except in males of Ptilocentis in which scutellum is convex with lobes not well deﬁned)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Schisthemisia) of Centris(By Ricardo Ayala): Hypoepimeral area without tubercle; scutellum, and scutum hairy, without glabrous areas except sometimes apices of scutellar tubercles; female with secondary basitibial plate on disc of primary plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Schisthemisia) of Centris(By Ricardo Ayala): Mandible of female 5-toothed, of male 4-toothed, the two basal teeth ﬂat and blunt; pygidial plate of female with apex notched

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Paracentris) of Centris(By Ricardo Ayala): Scutellum with two lobes, tubercles, or convexities (except in males of Ptilocentis in which scutellum is convex with lobes not well deﬁned)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Paracentris) of Centris(By Ricardo Ayala): Hypoepimeral area without tubercle; scutellum, and scutum hairy, without glabrous areas except sometimes apices of scutellar tubercles; female with secondary basitibial plate on disc of primary plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Paracentris) of Centris(By Ricardo Ayala): Mandible of female 4-toothed, of male 3-toothed, the basal teeth acute (sometimes robust) in female (in some Melacentrisbasal tooth obtuse, somewhat divided in two); pygidial plate of female with apex acute or obtuse, not notched

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera C. (Paracentris) of Centris(By Ricardo Ayala): Secondary basitibial plate and distad near posterior margin of plate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Hoplepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Female with secondary basitibial plate; male with obsolete pygidial plate, its margins more or less coextensive with margins of T7, its apex thin and bilobate or bidentate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Hoplepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Lateral margins of female pygidial plate nearly straight, apex narrowly truncate; female hind tibia longer than basitarsus; hind leg of male with long, scopa-like hairs and basitarsus with prominent tooth at basal one-third

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharis s. str.) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Female with secondary basitibial plate; male with obsolete pygidial plate, its margins more or less coextensive with margins of T7, its apex thin and bilobate or bidentate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharis s. str.) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Lateral margins of female pygidial plate distinctly concave as seen in dorsal view, apex broadly truncate; female hind tibia no longer than basitarsus; male without scopalike hairs on hind leg and hind basitarsus without tooth at basal one-third

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharis s. str.) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Female: Frontal carina ending more than diameter of anterior ocellus below that ocellus; apical pygidial truncation narrower than diameter of anterior ocellus; disc of T5 with short hairs mostly simple or barbed. Male: Mesosternal tubercles absent; hind basitarsus without carinate ridge on outer margin; hind trochanter and femur without ventral patch of short, dark, plumose setae (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharana) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Female with secondary basitibial plate; male with obsolete pygidial plate, its margins more or less coextensive with margins of T7, its apex thin and bilobate or bidentate

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharana) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Lateral margins of female pygidial plate distinctly concave as seen in dorsal view, apex broadly truncate; female hind tibia no longer than basitarsus; male without scopalike hairs on hind leg and hind basitarsus without tooth at basal one-third

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharana) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Female: Frontal carina to anterior ocellus ending less than diameter of anterior ocellus below that ocellus; apical pygidial truncation broader than diameter of anterior ocellus; disc of T5 with short hairs distinctly plumose. Male: T wo mesosternal tubercles or teeth projecting posteriorly between middle coxae; hind basitarsus with carinate ridge on outer margin, terminating in toothlike process; hind trochanter and femur with ventral patch of short, dark, plumose setae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Parepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Female without secondary basitibial plate; male with distinct, sharply margined pygidial plate, no more than one-half as wide as T7, its apex narrowly truncate or rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Parepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): First ﬂagellar segment of female equal to length of second to fourth segments combined, of male longer than scape and longer than following two segments combined; posterior margin of dorsal surface of scutellum deeply impressed in middle; maxillary palpus two-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Anepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Female without secondary basitibial plate; male with distinct, sharply margined pygidial plate, no more than one-half as wide as T7, its apex narrowly truncate or rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Anepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): First ﬂagellar segment short, in female usually no longer than second and third segments combined and always shorter than second to fourth combined, and in male shorter than scape; posterior margin of dorsal surface of scutellum not or weakly impressed in middle, or, if deeply impressed, then maxillary palpus three-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Anepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Lateral ridges of clypeal disc absent or, on basal onehalf or less of clypeus, weakly evident; male hind basitarsus with carinate ridge on inner margin, terminating in large tooth at about midlength

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Anepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Maxillary palpus two-segmented; ﬂagelliform preoccipital setae distinct and extending beyond anterior margin of mesoscutum; ocellocular distance in male less than diameter of lateral ocellus (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Triepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Female without secondary basitibial plate; male with distinct, sharply margined pygidial plate, no more than one-half as wide as T7, its apex narrowly truncate or rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Triepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): First ﬂagellar segment short, in female usually no longer than second and third segments combined and always shorter than second to fourth combined, and in male shorter than scape; posterior margin of dorsal surface of scutellum not or weakly impressed in middle, or, if deeply impressed, then maxillary palpus three-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Triepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Lateral ridges of clypeal disc absent or, on basal onehalf or less of clypeus, weakly evident; male hind basitarsus with carinate ridge on inner margin, terminating in large tooth at about midlength

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Triepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Maxillary palpus three-segmented; ﬂagelliform preoccipital setae short, not projecting beyond occipital hairs and scarcely reaching anterior margin of mesoscutum; ocellocular distance in male equal to diameter of lateral ocellus (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Cyphepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Female without secondary basitibial plate; male with distinct, sharply margined pygidial plate, no more than one-half as wide as T7, its apex narrowly truncate or rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Cyphepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): First ﬂagellar segment short, in female usually no longer than second and third segments combined and always shorter than second to fourth combined, and in male shorter than scape; posterior margin of dorsal surface of scutellum not or weakly impressed in middle, or, if deeply impressed, then maxillary palpus three-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Cyphepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Lateral ridges of clypeal disc strong and sharply deﬁned to near apical margin of clypeus; male hind basitarsus without carinate ridge or tooth on inner margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Cyphepicharis) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Dorsal surface of scutellum bigibbous; prepygidial ﬁmbria of female not preceded by shiny, glabrous area (Brazil)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharoides) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Female without secondary basitibial plate; male with distinct, sharply margined pygidial plate, no more than one-half as wide as T7, its apex narrowly truncate or rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharoides) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): First ﬂagellar segment short, in female usually no longer than second and third segments combined and always shorter than second to fourth combined, and in male shorter than scape; posterior margin of dorsal surface of scutellum not or weakly impressed in middle, or, if deeply impressed, then maxillary palpus three-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharoides) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Lateral ridges of clypeal disc strong and sharply deﬁned to near apical margin of clypeus; male hind basitarsus without carinate ridge or tooth on inner margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharoides) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Dorsal surface of scutellum ﬂat; prepygidial ﬁmbria of female preceded by a shiny, nearly glabrous area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharoides) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Jugal lobe of hind wing about one-half as long as vannal lobe, nearly attaining apex of cubital cell; female hind basitarsus about twice as long as broad, its posterior margin nearly straight; male pygidial plate broad, covering most of T7

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharitides) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Female without secondary basitibial plate; male with distinct, sharply margined pygidial plate, no more than one-half as wide as T7, its apex narrowly truncate or rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharitides) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): First ﬂagellar segment short, in female usually no longer than second and third segments combined and always shorter than second to fourth combined, and in male shorter than scape; posterior margin of dorsal surface of scutellum not or weakly impressed in middle, or, if deeply impressed, then maxillary palpus three-segmented

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharitides) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Lateral ridges of clypeal disc strong and sharply deﬁned to near apical margin of clypeus; male hind basitarsus without carinate ridge or tooth on inner margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharitides) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Dorsal surface of scutellum ﬂat; prepygidial ﬁmbria of female preceded by a shiny, nearly glabrous area

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera E. (Epicharitides) of Epicharis(Modiﬁed from Snelling, 1984): Jugal lobe of hind wing about one-third as long as vannal lobe, its apex well short of that of cubital cell; female hind basitarsus about one-third longer than broad, its posterior margin strongly curved; male pygidial plate narrow, covering less than half of T7

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Rhathymus of Rhathymini: Mesepisternum with large submedian tubercle; vein cu-v of hind wing strongly oblique and distinctly longer than second abscissa of M/H11001Cu; supraclypeal area strongly elevated, crested medially, not continuing convexity of clypeus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Nanorhathymus of Rhathymini: Mesepisternum without tubercle; vein cu-v of hind wing less strongly oblique and shorter than or subequal to second abscissa of M/H11001Cu; supraclypeal area with surface, in general, a continuation of convexity of clypeus although with small frontal tubercle at lower end of frontal line

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Acanthopus of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Third submarginal cell of forewing large, receiving both recurrent veins; hind tarsus very long, in male with dense brush of long, dark, plumose hairs; maxillary palpus absent (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Aglaomelissa of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Pronotum carinate between collar and lobe; omaulus lamellate; male antenna normal, not extending much beyond tegula

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ctenioschelus of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Pronotum not carinate between collar and lobe, lateral end of collar clearly deﬁned; omaulus abruptly rounded; male ﬂagellar segments greatly elongate, ﬂagellum extending well beyond apex of metasoma (Fig. 116-7a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ericrocis of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Second and third submarginal cells each receiving a recurrent vein, or ﬁrst recurrent vein and second submarginal crossvein meeting; hind tarsus without dense brush of long, dark, plumose hairs; maxillary palpus present, although sometimes very short

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ericrocis of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Juncture of anterior and dorsal surfaces of T1 evenly rounded, not subangulate (Fig. 116-6a); middle basitarsus almost always with distal, ﬂattened process on posterior margin, often continued basad as a raised, cariniform ridge (Fig. 116-3c); mandible usually with preapical tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ericrocis of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Middle and hind distitarsi with a group of appressed, black setae on each side (inner eye margins divergent above; male gonostylus without dorsal lobe or process)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Ericrocis of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Metasomal scales contrasting black and white (may be somewhat tawny); labrum with erect preapical median tubercle; scutellum without tubercles (nearctic, Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mesonychium of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Second and third submarginal cells each receiving a recurrent vein, or ﬁrst recurrent vein and second submarginal crossvein meeting; hind tarsus without dense brush of long, dark, plumose hairs; maxillary palpus present, although sometimes very short

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mesonychium of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Juncture of anterior and dorsal surfaces of T1 evenly rounded, not subangulate (Fig. 116-6a); middle basitarsus almost always with distal, ﬂattened process on posterior margin, often continued basad as a raised, cariniform ridge (Fig. 116-3c); mandible usually with preapical tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mesonychium of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Middle and hind distitarsi with a group of appressed, black setae on each side (inner eye margins divergent above; male gonostylus without dorsal lobe or process)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mesonychium of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Metasomal scales or hairs iridescent blue or green, with or without small, contrasting, whitish hair patches; labrum with transverse preapical ridge; scutellum with pair of mammiform tubercles (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Epiclopus of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Second and third submarginal cells each receiving a recurrent vein, or ﬁrst recurrent vein and second submarginal crossvein meeting; hind tarsus without dense brush of long, dark, plumose hairs; maxillary palpus present, although sometimes very short

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Epiclopus of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Juncture of anterior and dorsal surfaces of T1 evenly rounded, not subangulate (Fig. 116-6a); middle basitarsus almost always with distal, ﬂattened process on posterior margin, often continued basad as a raised, cariniform ridge (Fig. 116-3c); mandible usually with preapical tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Epiclopus of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Middle and hind distitarsi with normal setae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Epiclopus of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Eyes diverging above; scutellum not bituberculate (in E. gayi Spinola with median depression, thus weakly biconvex) (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mesoplia of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Second and third submarginal cells each receiving a recurrent vein, or ﬁrst recurrent vein and second submarginal crossvein meeting; hind tarsus without dense brush of long, dark, plumose hairs; maxillary palpus present, although sometimes very short

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mesoplia of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Juncture of anterior and dorsal surfaces of T1 evenly rounded, not subangulate (Fig. 116-6a); middle basitarsus almost always with distal, ﬂattened process on posterior margin, often continued basad as a raised, cariniform ridge (Fig. 116-3c); mandible usually with preapical tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mesoplia of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Middle and hind distitarsi with normal setae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mesoplia of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Eyes not diverging above, inner orbits usually more or less parallel; scutellum with two large tubercles

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Mesoplia of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Metasoma covered with minute blue-green scales, often with small patches of white or yellow pubescence

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hopliphora of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Second and third submarginal cells each receiving a recurrent vein, or ﬁrst recurrent vein and second submarginal crossvein meeting; hind tarsus without dense brush of long, dark, plumose hairs; maxillary palpus present, although sometimes very short

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hopliphora of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Juncture of anterior and dorsal surfaces of T1 evenly rounded, not subangulate (Fig. 116-6a); middle basitarsus almost always with distal, ﬂattened process on posterior margin, often continued basad as a raised, cariniform ridge (Fig. 116-3c); mandible usually with preapical tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hopliphora of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Middle and hind distitarsi with normal setae

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hopliphora of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Eyes not diverging above, inner orbits usually more or less parallel; scutellum with two large tubercles

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Hopliphora of the Ericrocidini(Modiﬁed from Snelling and Brooks, 1985): Metasoma black or faintly metallic, without patches of pale pubescence (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Mesoplia s. str.) of Mesoplia: Hind tibial spurs of male not reaching beyond basal third of basitarsus, sometimes only one spur present; hind tibia of male with inner distal patch of dense black hairs; pygidial plate of female broad, occupying exposed dorsal surface of T6, covered with hairs or scales

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Eumelissa) of Mesoplia: Hind tibial spurs of male both present, reaching to or beyond middle of basitarsus; hind tibia of male without inner distal hair patch; pygidial plate of female narrow, bare

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Brachymelecta of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Wings with two submarginal cells; metasoma densely and uniformly covered with appressed, cinereous pubescence

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Zacosmia of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Wings with three submarginal cells; metasoma all black with erect hair or with patches of appressed hair producing a pattern of pale spots or bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Zacosmia of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Marginal cell scarcely longer than stigma (Fig. 1173b); maxillary palpus oneto three-segmented; ﬂagellum of male greatly thickened, median segments thus more than twice as wide as long (Fig. 117-4); pygidial plate of male present; arolia absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeromelecta of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Wings with three submarginal cells; metasoma all black with erect hair or with patches of appressed hair producing a pattern of pale spots or bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeromelecta of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Marginal cell much longer than stigma (Fig. 117-3a); maxillary palpus fourto six-segmented; ﬂagellum of male not thickened, median segments at most twice as broad as long; pygidial plate of male usually absent; arolia present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeromelecta of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Inner ramus of claws of middle and posterior legs broad, vertically expanded, lobelike although subtruncate or pointed (Fig. 117-6d); T1 without or almost without long hair similar to that of thorax

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Melecta of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Wings with three submarginal cells; metasoma all black with erect hair or with patches of appressed hair producing a pattern of pale spots or bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Melecta of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Marginal cell much longer than stigma (Fig. 117-3a); maxillary palpus fourto six-segmented; ﬂagellum of male not thickened, median segments at most twice as broad as long; pygidial plate of male usually absent; arolia present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Melecta of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Inner ramus of claws of middle and posterior legs pointed, shaped somewhat like outer ramus (Fig. 1176b) (does not hold for species of the Eastern Hemisphere); T1 with long hair like that of thorax (except in subgenusMelectomimus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Brachymelecta of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Wings with two submarginal cells; metasoma densely and uniformly covered with appressed, cinereous pubescence

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Zacosmia of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Wings with three submarginal cells; metasoma all black with erect hair or with patches of appressed hair producing a pattern of pale spots or bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Zacosmia of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Marginal cell scarcely longer than stigma (Fig. 1173b); maxillary palpus oneto three-segmented; ﬂagellum of male greatly thickened, median segments thus more than twice as wide as long (Fig. 117-4); pygidial plate of male present; arolia absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeromelecta of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Wings with three submarginal cells; metasoma all black with erect hair or with patches of appressed hair producing a pattern of pale spots or bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeromelecta of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Marginal cell much longer than stigma (Fig. 117-3a); maxillary palpus fourto six-segmented; ﬂagellum of male not thickened, median segments at most twice as broad as long; pygidial plate of male usually absent; arolia present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Xeromelecta of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Inner ramus of claws of middle and posterior legs broad, vertically expanded, lobelike although subtruncate or pointed (Fig. 117-6d); T1 without or almost without long hair similar to that of thorax

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thyreomelecta of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Wings with three submarginal cells; metasoma all black with erect hair or with patches of appressed hair producing a pattern of pale spots or bands

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Thyreomelecta of the Melectini of the Western Hemisphere: Marginal cell longer than distance from its apex to wing tip; apical margin of labrum gently convex (Palearctic Asia and North Africa)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Acanthomelecta) of Afromelecta: Maxillary palpus six-segmented; scutellar spines as long as middorsal length of scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera A. (Afromelecta s. str.) of Afromelecta: Maxillary palpus minute, oneto two-segmented; scutellar spines at most half as long as middorsal length of scutellum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Pseudomelecta) of Melecta: S3 to S5 (sometimes also S2 and S6) of male with subapical fringes of strong, backward-directed, black bristles often forming dense brushes; T1 without long, erect pale hair either basally or laterally (middle and hind tarsal claws with inner rami shorter and broader than outer, often subtruncate)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Pseudomelecta) of Melecta: Marginal cell short, 2.2 to 3.0 times as long as broad; hind tibia of male unmodiﬁed; inner hind tibial spur of male straight or gently curved, not undulate, little if any longer than outer spur (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Paracrocisa) of Melecta: S3 to S5 (sometimes also S2 and S6) of male with subapical fringes of strong, backward-directed, black bristles often forming dense brushes; T1 without long, erect pale hair either basally or laterally (middle and hind tarsal claws with inner rami shorter and broader than outer, often subtruncate)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Paracrocisa) of Melecta: Marginal cell 3.3 to 4.0 times as long as broad; hind tibia of male expanded toward apex with spiculate ventroapical process extending laterally beyond bases of spurs; inner hind tibial spur of male much longer than outer, gently curved in different directions, thus weakly undulate (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Eupavlovskia) of Melecta: S2 to S6 of male without subapical brushes of black, posteriorly directed bristles, although often with abundant subapical hairs; T1 usually with long, erect pale hair, at least basolaterally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Eupavlovskia) of Melecta: Hind tibia of male expanded toward apex with strong ventroapical process extending laterally beyond bases of spurs; inner hind tibial spur of male much longer than outer, gently curved in different directions so as to be weakly undulate; hind basitarsus of male broadened distally, widest about two-thirds of distance from base to apex; S7 of male with disc slender, over twice as long as broad (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M, (Melectomimus) of Melecta: S2 to S6 of male without subapical brushes of black, posteriorly directed bristles, although often with abundant subapical hairs; T1 usually with long, erect pale hair, at least basolaterally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M, (Melectomimus) of Melecta: Hind tibia of male not or weakly expanded apically; inner hind tibial spur of male usually not modiﬁed [but in M. albifrons(Forster) and its relatives modiﬁed somewhat as in Eupavlovskia]; hind basitarsus less broadened [although somewhat so in group of M. albifrons(Forster)]; S7 of male with disc ordinarily less than twice as long as broad, often little longer than broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M, (Melectomimus) of Melecta: Male ﬂagellar segments about 1.5 times as long as broad; pygidial plate of female broadly triangular, occupying much of distal part of T6; metasoma without patches of white appressed hairs; T1 without long hairs like those of thorax (nearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melecta s. str.) of Melecta: S2 to S6 of male without subapical brushes of black, posteriorly directed bristles, although often with abundant subapical hairs; T1 usually with long, erect pale hair, at least basolaterally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melecta s. str.) of Melecta: Hind tibia of male not or weakly expanded apically; inner hind tibial spur of male usually not modiﬁed [but in M. albifrons(Forster) and its relatives modiﬁed somewhat as in Eupavlovskia]; hind basitarsus less broadened [although somewhat so in group of M. albifrons(Forster)]; S7 of male with disc ordinarily less than twice as long as broad, often little longer than broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Melecta s. str.) of Melecta: Male ﬂagellar segments mostly little longer than broad, often broader than long; pygidial plate of female narrowed apically, nearly parallel-sided to spatulate (but in M. megaeraLieftinck and aegyptiacaRadoszkowski about as in Melectomimus); metasoma usually with patches of appressed white pubescence; T1 usually with long pale hairs like those of thorax, often especially well developed laterally (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Xeromelecta s. str.) of Xeromelecta: Scutellum biconvex, with only the faintest suggestion of a posterior tooth on each convexity; maxillary palpus more than half as long as ﬁrst segment of labial palpus, six-segmented; body without patches of appressed pale pubescence; wings blackish

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Nesomelecta) of Xeromelecta: Scutellum convex, with two distinct, posteriorly directed teeth or spines; maxillary palpus less than half as long as ﬁrst segment of labial palpus, threeto ﬁve-segmented (possibly two-segmented); body with patches of appressed, pale pubescence; wings rather clear with apical dusky areas

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Nesomelecta) of Xeromelecta: Scutellar lobes each ending in acute spine or tooth; maxillary palpus three-segmented (possibly sometimes two-segmented), less than one-fourth as long as ﬁrst segment of labial palpus (Antilles)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Melectomorpha) of Xeromelecta: Scutellum convex, with two distinct, posteriorly directed teeth or spines; maxillary palpus less than half as long as ﬁrst segment of labial palpus, threeto ﬁve-segmented (possibly two-segmented); body with patches of appressed, pale pubescence; wings rather clear with apical dusky areas

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera X. (Melectomorpha) of Xeromelecta: Scutellar lobes each ending in approximately right-angular tooth; maxillary palpus fourto ﬁve-segmented, little less than one-half as long as ﬁrst segment of labial palpus

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exaerete of the Euglossini(Modiﬁed from Kimsey, 1987): Hind tibia three or more times as long as broad in both sexes (Fig. 118-4c); female hind tibia somewhat inﬂated, without corbicula; cleptoparasitic species

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Exaerete of the Euglossini(Modiﬁed from Kimsey, 1987): Hind femur swollen and usually denticulate ventrally (Fig. 118-4c); hind tibia curved and expanded apically; scutellum dorsally convex, with sublateral tubercle or welt (Fig. 118-4d)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Aglae of the Euglossini(Modiﬁed from Kimsey, 1987): Hind tibia three or more times as long as broad in both sexes (Fig. 118-4c); female hind tibia somewhat inﬂated, without corbicula; cleptoparasitic species

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Aglae of the Euglossini(Modiﬁed from Kimsey, 1987): Hind femur slender and unmodiﬁed; hind tibia straight and apically narrowed; scutellum ﬂat

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Euglossa of the Euglossini(Modiﬁed from Kimsey, 1987): Hind tibia twice as long as broad or less in females (Fig. 118-3) and most males (Fig. 118-4a, b); female hind tibia ﬂat and shieldlike with enormous corbicula (Fig. 118-3); nonparasitic species

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Euglossa of the Euglossini(Modiﬁed from Kimsey, 1987): Labrum whitish with two large, dark oval spots; male hind tibial slit short, not reaching apical margin of tibia, and basally curved (Fig. 118-4b); male middle tibia with two, or less commonly one or three, small felty patches in basal end of large patch (Fig. 118-9a); female usually with median, black scutellar tuft

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B (Psithyrus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella weakly or strongly sclerotized, inner corner near midpoint of its length, without any inwardly directed hooks, distal half of volsella thus usually nearly triangular (Fig. 119-9d); gonostylus without an inner basal process, or, ifprocess present, then associated with many long, branched hairs; apex of penis valve nearly straight in dorsal view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B (Psithyrus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella weakly sclerotized, yellowish in color; gonostylus with pronounced inner basal process associated with many long, branched hairs (Fig. 119-9d); apex of penis valve, as deﬁned by an outer lateral ridge, accounting for less than one-fourth of total length of penis valve, not strongly curved but shaped like slender arrowhead in lateral aspect (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Mendacibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella weakly or strongly sclerotized, inner corner near midpoint of its length, without any inwardly directed hooks, distal half of volsella thus usually nearly triangular (Fig. 119-9d); gonostylus without an inner basal process, or, ifprocess present, then associated with many long, branched hairs; apex of penis valve nearly straight in dorsal view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Mendacibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella strongly sclerotized, dark brown in color; gonostylus without inner basal process or hairs; apex of penis valve, as deﬁned by an outer lateral toothed ridge, accounting for nearly one-half of total length, ventrally curved and sabre-shaped in lateral aspect (Eurasian mountains)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Alpigenobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella always strongly sclerotized, inner corner usually much closer to apex than to base, forming an inner apical corner often bearing two inwardly directed hooks or a single inwardly directed process; gonostylus usually with distinct inner basal process or shelf, not associated with long hairs; apex of penis valve much modiﬁed, often curved strongly toward midline as sickle-shaped hook, otherwise curved outward in some individuals, but ifnearly straight in dorsal aspect, then volsella with pronounced inner hooks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Alpigenobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Apex of mandible with two preapical teeth (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Orientalibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella always strongly sclerotized, inner corner usually much closer to apex than to base, forming an inner apical corner often bearing two inwardly directed hooks or a single inwardly directed process; gonostylus usually with distinct inner basal process or shelf, not associated with long hairs; apex of penis valve much modiﬁed, often curved strongly toward midline as sickle-shaped hook, otherwise curved outward in some individuals, but ifnearly straight in dorsal aspect, then volsella with pronounced inner hooks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Orientalibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Apex of mandible with one preapical tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Orientalibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve narrow and pointed; ocellocular distance equal to 3.0 to 3.5 ocellar diameters; hind tibia bare on disc; second ﬂagellar segment 1.1 to 1.4 times as long as ﬁrst (Himalayas to Southeast Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Kallobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella always strongly sclerotized, inner corner usually much closer to apex than to base, forming an inner apical corner often bearing two inwardly directed hooks or a single inwardly directed process; gonostylus usually with distinct inner basal process or shelf, not associated with long hairs; apex of penis valve much modiﬁed, often curved strongly toward midline as sickle-shaped hook, otherwise curved outward in some individuals, but ifnearly straight in dorsal aspect, then volsella with pronounced inner hooks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Kallobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Apex of mandible with one preapical tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Kallobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): If penis valve narrow and pointed, then lateral ocellus much closer to eye, or hind tibia hairy, or, if with a small, bare disc, then second ﬂagellar segment about half as long as ﬁrst

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Kallobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve curved outward into a rounded, recurved hook; second and third ﬂagellar segments 1.2 and 1.5 times as long as ﬁrst segment, and middle and hind basitarsi without long fringes (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B.
