(Fraternobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella always strongly sclerotized, inner corner usually much closer to apex than to base, forming an inner apical corner often bearing two inwardly directed hooks or a single inwardly directed process; gonostylus usually with distinct inner basal process or shelf, not associated with long hairs; apex of penis valve much modiﬁed, often curved strongly toward midline as sickle-shaped hook, otherwise curved outward in some individuals, but ifnearly straight in dorsal aspect, then volsella with pronounced inner hooks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Fraternobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Apex of mandible with one preapical tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Fraternobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): If penis valve narrow and pointed, then lateral ocellus much closer to eye, or hind tibia hairy, or, if with a small, bare disc, then second ﬂagellar segment about half as long as ﬁrst

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Fraternobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve not curved outward into a recurved hook; second and third ﬂagellar segments relatively short (second shorter than ﬁrst) except in a few species with short basitarsal fringes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Fraternobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Second and third ﬂagellar segments 0.36 to 0.56 and 0.48 to 0.78 times as long as ﬁrst segment; penis valve narrow and pointed, or ﬁnger-shaped, only in one group curved inward with ﬂange on outside of curve; ocellocular distance one ocellar diameter or less

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Fraternobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve curved inward with small ﬂange on outside of curve; hind basitarsus with short dorsal fringe (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Confusibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella always strongly sclerotized, inner corner usually much closer to apex than to base, forming an inner apical corner often bearing two inwardly directed hooks or a single inwardly directed process; gonostylus usually with distinct inner basal process or shelf, not associated with long hairs; apex of penis valve much modiﬁed, often curved strongly toward midline as sickle-shaped hook, otherwise curved outward in some individuals, but ifnearly straight in dorsal aspect, then volsella with pronounced inner hooks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Confusibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Apex of mandible with one preapical tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Confusibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): If penis valve narrow and pointed, then lateral ocellus much closer to eye, or hind tibia hairy, or, if with a small, bare disc, then second ﬂagellar segment about half as long as ﬁrst

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Confusibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve not curved outward into a recurved hook; second and third ﬂagellar segments relatively short (second shorter than ﬁrst) except in a few species with short basitarsal fringes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Confusibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Second and third ﬂagellar segments 0.36 to 0.56 and 0.48 to 0.78 times as long as ﬁrst segment; penis valve narrow and pointed, or ﬁnger-shaped, only in one group curved inward with ﬂange on outside of curve; ocellocular distance one ocellar diameter or less

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Confusibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve pointed or ﬁnger-shaped; hind basitarsus with long dorsal fringe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Confusibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Gonostylus V-shaped in section, formed of two plates set at an angle and joined at outer edges; S7 crescentic but with rounded-triangular median process; S8 crescentic, little produced, apex subtruncate; hind tibia with fringe of long hairs (Europe)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombias) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella always strongly sclerotized, inner corner usually much closer to apex than to base, forming an inner apical corner often bearing two inwardly directed hooks or a single inwardly directed process; gonostylus usually with distinct inner basal process or shelf, not associated with long hairs; apex of penis valve much modiﬁed, often curved strongly toward midline as sickle-shaped hook, otherwise curved outward in some individuals, but ifnearly straight in dorsal aspect, then volsella with pronounced inner hooks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombias) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Apex of mandible with one preapical tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombias) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): If penis valve narrow and pointed, then lateral ocellus much closer to eye, or hind tibia hairy, or, if with a small, bare disc, then second ﬂagellar segment about half as long as ﬁrst

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombias) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve not curved outward into a recurved hook; second and third ﬂagellar segments relatively short (second shorter than ﬁrst) except in a few species with short basitarsal fringes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombias) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Second and third ﬂagellar segments 0.36 to 0.56 and 0.48 to 0.78 times as long as ﬁrst segment; penis valve narrow and pointed, or ﬁnger-shaped, only in one group curved inward with ﬂange on outside of curve; ocellocular distance one ocellar diameter or less

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombias) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve pointed or ﬁnger-shaped; hind basitarsus with long dorsal fringe

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombias) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Gonostylus not V-shaped in section, all angles rounded; S7 broadly triangular, apex feebly emarginate; S8 broadly triangular, apex deeply emarginate; hind tibia with fringe of very short hairs (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombus s. str.) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella always strongly sclerotized, inner corner usually much closer to apex than to base, forming an inner apical corner often bearing two inwardly directed hooks or a single inwardly directed process; gonostylus usually with distinct inner basal process or shelf, not associated with long hairs; apex of penis valve much modiﬁed, often curved strongly toward midline as sickle-shaped hook, otherwise curved outward in some individuals, but ifnearly straight in dorsal aspect, then volsella with pronounced inner hooks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombus s. str.) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Apex of mandible with one preapical tooth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombus s. str.) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): If penis valve narrow and pointed, then lateral ocellus much closer to eye, or hind tibia hairy, or, if with a small, bare disc, then second ﬂagellar segment about half as long as ﬁrst

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombus s. str.) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve not curved outward into a recurved hook; second and third ﬂagellar segments relatively short (second shorter than ﬁrst) except in a few species with short basitarsal fringes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombus s. str.) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Second and third ﬂagellar segments relatively longer and penis valve usually of a different shape, particularly if antenna approaches above description; ocellocular distance usually more than one ocellar diameter (although sometimes less, e.g., in Brachycephalibombus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombus s. str.) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve in form of wide sinuate vertical plate (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Brachycephalibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): S7 trapezoidal, apex broadly emarginate; S8 with apical process broadly emarginate; penis valve ending in broadened apex with acute point directed mesad (Mesoamerica)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Separatobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve ending in rounded hook, tip not acute; impression of gonocoxite wide but ill-deﬁned; third ﬂagellar segment shorter than ﬁrst; S7 trapeziform, apex feebly emarginate; S8 subtriangular (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Crotchiibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve ending in somewhat smaller hook, tip acute; impression of gonocoxite wide and well-deﬁned; third ﬂagellar segment longer than ﬁrst; S7 subcrescentic; S8 with parallel-sided, tongue-like projection (California, Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Sibiricobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Gonostylus considerably longer than broad, inner side emarginate; impression of gonocoxite strong, sharpedged; third ﬂagellar segment clearly shorter than ﬁrst (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Pyrobombus, Festivobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella scarcely projecting beyond gonostylus (more so in Festivobombus) (gonostylus small and rounded-triangular); ocellocular distance at least three ocellar diameters; S8 with parallel-sided, tongue-like projection

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Cullumanobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Gonostylus transverse with inner side emarginate; hind basitarsus with short or long fringe; malar area not longer than ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; ocellocular distance one and three-fourths to two and one-fourth ocellar diameters (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Ruﬁpedibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Gonostylus S-shaped, inner end pointed, almost the whole of it lying inside inner margin of gonocoxite; hind basitarsus with short fringe; malar area longer than ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; ocellocular distance two and one-half ocellar diameters (Southeast Asia to Java and Taiwan)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Dasybombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Gonostylus almost as long as gonocoxite, attaining midline of genitalia, directed mesad at right angle to gonocoxite, without lobe or process; volsella produced as slender, hairy ﬁngerlike apical projection almost as long as gonostylus (Mesoamerica)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Alpinobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve not curved inward or outward at apex, but with two external teeth, one of which is sometimes small; second ﬂagellar segment not much shorter than ﬁrst, third segment 1.25 times longer than ﬁrst; malar area in most species distinctly longer than ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment (arctic and alpine, holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Robustobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella weakly or strongly sclerotized, inner corner near midpoint of its length, without any inwardly directed hooks, distal half of volsella thus usually nearly triangular (Fig. 119-9d); gonostylus without an inner basal process, or, ifprocess present, then associated with many long, branched hairs; apex of penis valve nearly straight in dorsal view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Robustobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve curved inward at apex with serrate ﬂange on outside; gonostylus markedly transverse, widening inward, inner edge emarginate; volsella with rounded-angular projection on inner edge, inner corner of apex with long curved hook; S7 crescentic; S8 with tonguelike projection the sides of which converge posteriorly; malar area hardly more than half as long as ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; ocellocular distance equal to less than one ocellar diameter (Central and South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Rubicundobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella weakly or strongly sclerotized, inner corner near midpoint of its length, without any inwardly directed hooks, distal half of volsella thus usually nearly triangular (Fig. 119-9d); gonostylus without an inner basal process, or, ifprocess present, then associated with many long, branched hairs; apex of penis valve nearly straight in dorsal view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Rubicundobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve slightly curved inward at apex and with small inner tooth; gonostylus rounded-quadrangular with large subcircular inner emargination; volsella wide, posterior end with a short hook, apex with dense tuft of relatively long bristles; S7 transverse with central onefourth produced; S8 subtriangular; malar area a little shorter than ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; ocellocular distance equal to 1.5 ocellar diameters (western South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Coccineobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella weakly or strongly sclerotized, inner corner near midpoint of its length, without any inwardly directed hooks, distal half of volsella thus usually nearly triangular (Fig. 119-9d); gonostylus without an inner basal process, or, ifprocess present, then associated with many long, branched hairs; apex of penis valve nearly straight in dorsal view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Coccineobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Gonocoxite with strong impressions; volsella short, apex with small posteriorly directed hook (outer and ventral sides with dense short hairs); S7 transverse, apex biemarginate; S8 with long, parallel-sided midapical process; malar area slightly longer than ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; ocellocular distance equal to two ocellar diameters (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Senexibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella weakly or strongly sclerotized, inner corner near midpoint of its length, without any inwardly directed hooks, distal half of volsella thus usually nearly triangular (Fig. 119-9d); gonostylus without an inner basal process, or, ifprocess present, then associated with many long, branched hairs; apex of penis valve nearly straight in dorsal view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Senexibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Second ﬂagellar segment less than 0.7 times as long as ﬁrst; spatha very narrow (Malaysia to Philippines)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Tricornibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella weakly or strongly sclerotized, inner corner near midpoint of its length, without any inwardly directed hooks, distal half of volsella thus usually nearly triangular (Fig. 119-9d); gonostylus without an inner basal process, or, ifprocess present, then associated with many long, branched hairs; apex of penis valve nearly straight in dorsal view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Tricornibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella very wide, not extending far beyond outer part of gonostylus, on inner side proximally with very long acute hook, inner edge behind hook straight-truncate, somewhat serrate, with long bristles; gonostylus sclerotized, with elongate outer lobe set in oblique plane, on inner side at a lower level produced into two very long acute processes directed obliquely forward and backward respectively; penis valve with feebly serrate outer ﬂange apically, with a tooth beneath; malar area about as long as ﬁrst and second ﬂagellar segments combined (metasoma very closely punctured) (Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Laesobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella weakly or strongly sclerotized, inner corner near midpoint of its length, without any inwardly directed hooks, distal half of volsella thus usually nearly triangular (Fig. 119-9d); gonostylus without an inner basal process, or, ifprocess present, then associated with many long, branched hairs; apex of penis valve nearly straight in dorsal view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Laesobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella very long, broadly digitiform, inner side near center produced into strong, parallel-sided process with expanded end with sharp angles; gonostylus with large, outer part pale and submembranous, generally transverse but posteriorly produced on inside into rounded lobe, before this deeply emarginate and then produced into a large subcircular lobe (mainly in a vertical plane) with its dorsal edge serrate and the whole attached to gonostylus by narrow stalk; penis valve narrow, simply pointed at apex, not toothed beneath; malar area as long as second ﬂagellar segment (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Subterraneobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella weakly or strongly sclerotized, inner corner near midpoint of its length, without any inwardly directed hooks, distal half of volsella thus usually nearly triangular (Fig. 119-9d); gonostylus without an inner basal process, or, ifprocess present, then associated with many long, branched hairs; apex of penis valve nearly straight in dorsal view

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Subterraneobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Penis valve at end somewhat hooked inward, with two large teeth on outer side, midpoint beneath with biﬁd or triﬁd tooth (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Rhodobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella always strongly sclerotized, inner corner usually much closer to apex than to base, forming an inner apical corner often bearing two inwardly directed hooks or a single inwardly directed process; gonostylus usually with distinct inner basal process or shelf, not associated with long hairs; apex of penis valve much modiﬁed, often curved strongly toward midline as sickle-shaped hook, otherwise curved outward in some individuals, but ifnearly straight in dorsal aspect, then volsella with pronounced inner hooks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Rhodobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Mandible without beard; gonostylus on inside produced obliquely downward and backward as twisted anterior plate; volsella with apex produced on inside to small lobe with small tooth; volsellar region with no conspicuous bristles (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Fervidobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella always strongly sclerotized, inner corner usually much closer to apex than to base, forming an inner apical corner often bearing two inwardly directed hooks or a single inwardly directed process; gonostylus usually with distinct inner basal process or shelf, not associated with long hairs; apex of penis valve much modiﬁed, often curved strongly toward midline as sickle-shaped hook, otherwise curved outward in some individuals, but ifnearly straight in dorsal aspect, then volsella with pronounced inner hooks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Fervidobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Mandible with beard; gonostylus on inside usually produced into a vertical platelike anterior lamella and a wider, more dorsal, rounded process (details vary considerably among species); volsella with apex produced on inside to small hook or angular process; volsellar region with dense bristles (Western Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Thoracobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella always strongly sclerotized, inner corner usually much closer to apex than to base, forming an inner apical corner often bearing two inwardly directed hooks or a single inwardly directed process; gonostylus usually with distinct inner basal process or shelf, not associated with long hairs; apex of penis valve much modiﬁed, often curved strongly toward midline as sickle-shaped hook, otherwise curved outward in some individuals, but ifnearly straight in dorsal aspect, then volsella with pronounced inner hooks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Thoracobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella wide but not very long, apex more or less pointed, center of inner edge produced into spike or at least narrow, truncate process, pubescence widespread but not dense; penis valve variable but with central tooth beneath (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Mucidobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella always strongly sclerotized, inner corner usually much closer to apex than to base, forming an inner apical corner often bearing two inwardly directed hooks or a single inwardly directed process; gonostylus usually with distinct inner basal process or shelf, not associated with long hairs; apex of penis valve much modiﬁed, often curved strongly toward midline as sickle-shaped hook, otherwise curved outward in some individuals, but ifnearly straight in dorsal aspect, then volsella with pronounced inner hooks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Mucidobombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella with center of inner edge produced into wide lobe deﬁned at each end by small tooth; penis valve simply pointed; fringe of hind tibia long (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Eversmannibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella always strongly sclerotized, inner corner usually much closer to apex than to base, forming an inner apical corner often bearing two inwardly directed hooks or a single inwardly directed process; gonostylus usually with distinct inner basal process or shelf, not associated with long hairs; apex of penis valve much modiﬁed, often curved strongly toward midline as sickle-shaped hook, otherwise curved outward in some individuals, but ifnearly straight in dorsal aspect, then volsella with pronounced inner hooks

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Eversmannibombus) of Bombus (Males)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991): Volsella with inner edge straight or feebly concave, with no lobe or process; penis valve at end hardly acute, with slight outer, feebly serrate ﬂange; fringe of hind tibia short (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Psithyrus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): This key is based primarily on gynes and may not work for some workers.) 1. Hind tibia convex and hairy on outer surface, corbicula thus absent (Fig. 119-9b), and rastellum absent; hind basitarsus without auricle; apex of metasoma curved downward; S6 with lateral carina; worker caste absent (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Alpigenobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Alpigenobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Apex of mandible with six teeth; hind basitarsus proximally near ventral margin often with a number of bristles almost as long as corbicular bristles (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Mendacibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Mendacibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Apex of mandible with one or two small dorsal teeth and sometimes a small preapical notch setting off an apical tooth; hind basitarsus with no bristles as long as corbicular bristles (except in Mendacibombus and Pressibombus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Mendacibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Middle basitarsus with posterior apical angle obtuse, more or less rounded [except for some Sibiricobombus, most of which have ocellocular distance equal to about two ocellar diameters and differ further from Subterraneobombus, which they often most resemble, in having whole surface of auricle of hind basitarsus densely hairy; B. (Melanobombus) tanguticusMorawitz has apical angle of middle basitarsus produced but has a strong, bare subcircular boss on T6 such as is not found in alternative]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Mendacibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Outer surface of hind tibia densely reticulate, dull, some long bristles arising from upper half of corbicular disc; malar area very elongate; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment fully three times as long as median width (Eurasian mountains)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Sibiricobombus) (in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Sibiricobombus) (in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Apex of mandible with one or two small dorsal teeth and sometimes a small preapical notch setting off an apical tooth; hind basitarsus with no bristles as long as corbicular bristles (except in Mendacibombus and Pressibombus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Sibiricobombus) (in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Malar area very long; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment about four times as long as broad; auricle of hind basitarsus with dense brown pile even on surface not apposed to hind tibia (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Ruﬁpedibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Ruﬁpedibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Apex of mandible with one or two small dorsal teeth and sometimes a small preapical notch setting off an apical tooth; hind basitarsus with no bristles as long as corbicular bristles (except in Mendacibombus and Pressibombus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Ruﬁpedibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Middle basitarsus with posterior apical angle obtuse, more or less rounded [except for some Sibiricobombus, most of which have ocellocular distance equal to about two ocellar diameters and differ further from Subterraneobombus, which they often most resemble, in having whole surface of auricle of hind basitarsus densely hairy; B. (Melanobombus) tanguticusMorawitz has apical angle of middle basitarsus produced but has a strong, bare subcircular boss on T6 such as is not found in alternative]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Ruﬁpedibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Outer surface of hind tibia less coarsely reticulate, rarely if ever so dull, long bristles conﬁned to corbicular margins except very near base, or, if bristles more widespread in corbicula, then malar area transverse; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment nearly always shorter

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Ruﬁpedibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Malar area clearly shorter, or, if not, then ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment about 2.5 times as long as broad; middle basitarsus with posterior apical angle quite obtuse

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Ruﬁpedibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Corbicular hairs unusually dense, tibial surface between them covered throughout with rather sparse but quite distinct, very short feathered hairs (southeast Asia to Java and Taiwan)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Orientalibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Orientalibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Apex of mandible with one or two small dorsal teeth and sometimes a small preapical notch setting off an apical tooth; hind basitarsus with no bristles as long as corbicular bristles (except in Mendacibombus and Pressibombus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Orientalibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Middle basitarsus with posterior apical angle obtuse, more or less rounded [except for some Sibiricobombus, most of which have ocellocular distance equal to about two ocellar diameters and differ further from Subterraneobombus, which they often most resemble, in having whole surface of auricle of hind basitarsus densely hairy; B. (Melanobombus) tanguticusMorawitz has apical angle of middle basitarsus produced but has a strong, bare subcircular boss on T6 such as is not found in alternative]

This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Outer surface of hind tibia less coarsely reticulate, rarely if ever so dull, long bristles conﬁned to corbicular margins except very near base, or, if bristles more widespread in corbicula, then malar area transverse; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment nearly always shorter

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Orientalibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Malar area clearly shorter, or, if not, then ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment about 2.5 times as long as broad; middle basitarsus with posterior apical angle quite obtuse

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Orientalibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Corbicular hairs less dense, tibial surface between them without short feathered hairs [except in a few Melanobombus (couplet 8)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Orientalibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Frons with very large unpunctured areas, most of area for some distance in front of ocelli being unpunctured and only narrow band of punctures between ocelli and eyes; area immediately behind ocelli also unpunctured; ocellocular distance equal to three ocellar diameters (Himalayas to Southeast Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Melanobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Melanobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Corbicular hairs less dense, tibial surface between them without short feathered hairs [except in a few Melanobombus (couplet 8)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Melanobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Frons without large unpunctured area, especially in front of ocelli, or else densely punctured right up to ocelli posteriorly; ocelli closer to eyes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Melanobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): T6 with a bare, convex, more or less rounded boss not divided by furrow; hind tibia with dorsal apical inner corner not or rarely somewhat produced; hind basitarsus as a rule with unusually dense, short, feathery hairs (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Coccineobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Apex of mandible with one or two small dorsal teeth and sometimes a small preapical notch setting off an apical tooth; hind basitarsus with no bristles as long as corbicular bristles (except in Mendacibombus and Pressibombus)

This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Malar area clearly shorter, or, if not, then ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment about 2.5 times as long as broad; middle basitarsus with posterior apical angle quite obtuse

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Coccineobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Corbicular hairs less dense, tibial surface between them without short feathered hairs [except in a few Melanobombus (couplet 8)]

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Coccineobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Frons without large unpunctured area, especially in front of ocelli, or else densely punctured right up to ocelli posteriorly; ocelli closer to eyes

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Coccineobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): T6 without a bare, convex, rounded boss or with boss divided by furrow; hind tibia with dorsal apical inner corner more or less strongly, angulately produced [except in Kallobombusand a few Pyrobombus—e.g., Bombus pratorum (Linnaeus) and atrocinctus Smith]; hind basitarsus rarely so densely haired

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Coccineobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Whole corbicular surface of hind tibia with scattered but quite numerous, short, unbranched hairs; frons crossed by wide transverse band of microscopic punctures across unpunctured area; T6 with raised boss (almost as in Melanobombus) divided by deep, well-deﬁned furrow (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombus s. str.) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Ocellocular distance equal to three ocellar diameters, and corbicular surface of hind tibia entirely bare and shining; mandible with strong notch above apical tooth; clypeus strongly punctured on almost whole surface (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Separatobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Frons with rather strong, close punctures along inner margin of eye; clypeus elongate, impressions feeble, ﬁnely and closely punctured; labral furrow deep and wide, nearly as wide as length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Fraternobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Malar area clearly shorter than ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment, which is less than twice length of second; clypeus more coarsely though shallowly punctured, impressions weaker; labral tubercle more convex but less angular, furrow deep and wider than length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; corbicular hairs shorter than half tibial width and dense (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Crotchiibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Malar area clearly longer than ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment, which is nearly twice length of second; clypeus more ﬁnely punctured, impressions stronger; labral tubercle less raised but more angular at inner end, furrow deeper but much narrower than length of ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; corbicular hairs mostly longer than half tibial width and less dense (California, Mexico)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Rubicundobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Frons rather closely punctured, with large but welldeﬁned unpunctured areas and a band of ﬁne punctures along inner margin of eye; ocellocular distance equal to three ocellar diameters; ocelli a little in front of postocular tangent; clypeus swollen, with lower third ﬂattened, with numerous, mostly rather large punctures and apical impressions; labral furrow narrow; hind basitarsus not unusually bristly (western South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Robustobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Frons with large unpunctured or very sparsely punctured area in front of and around ocellus, without especially deﬁned unpunctured areas and without band of punctures along inner margin of eye; ocellocular distance equal to two ocellar diameters; ocelli well in front of postocular tangent; clypeus strongly swollen, sometimes somewhat ﬂattened ventrally, little or moderately punctured, apical impressions feeble; labral furrow wide or very wide; hind basitarsus with bristles on outer surface longer and more numerous than usual (Central and South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Alpinobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Malar area distinctly longer than broad, at least as long as combined lengths of pedicel and ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment, often as long as ﬁrst and second ﬂagellar segments taken together (arctic and alpine, holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Funebribombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Mandible with no notch above apical tooth but with ventral apical angle produced as small process (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Confusibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Malar area a little longer than broad and a little longer than ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; clypeus with wide ﬂattened disc; frons mostly closely and rather ﬁnely punctured, unpunctured areas well-deﬁned, a wide band of close ﬁne punctures along inner margin of eye (Europe)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Bombias) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Malar area roughly quadrate, about as long as ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; clypeus long, strongly swollen; frons moderately strongly and closely punctured, unpunctured areas large and ill-deﬁned, a narrow band of rather ﬁne sculpture along inner margin of eye (North America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Cullumanobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Cullumanobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Ocellocular distance somewhat or distinctly less than three ocellar diameters; ocelli well in front of postocular tangent (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Megabombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Megabombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): First ﬂagellar segment a little shorter than combined lengths of second and third segments (10.5:11.0); furrow between labral tubercles narrower; middle basitarsus acutely spinosely produced at apex (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Fervidobombus) (in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Fervidobombus) (in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Apex of mandible with one or two small dorsal teeth and sometimes a small preapical notch setting off an apical tooth; hind basitarsus with no bristles as long as corbicular bristles (except in Mendacibombus and Pressibombus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Fervidobombus) (in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Clypeus generally with closer and coarser punctures; middle basitarsus often not very distinctly produced; frons more punctured, with unpunctured areas smaller (Western Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Subterraneobombus)(in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Subterraneobombus)(in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Apex of mandible with one or two small dorsal teeth and sometimes a small preapical notch setting off an apical tooth; hind basitarsus with no bristles as long as corbicular bristles (except in Mendacibombus and Pressibombus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Subterraneobombus)(in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Clypeus swollen with no furrow or lines of punctures on upper third of midline; hind tibia with inner dorsal apical angle sharp, although projection rather broad (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Dasybombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Dasybombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Impunctate area of frons small, ill-deﬁned, punctured area reaching anterior margins of ocelli, a few coarse punctures between lateral ocellus and eye (Mesoamerica)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Brachycephalibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Brachycephalibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Impunctate area of frons larger, well-deﬁned, large area in front of ocelli impunctate, only few minute punctures between lateral ocellus and eye (Mesoamerica)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Laesobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Laesobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Frons with large unpunctured area separated from eye by narrow band of close, ﬁne punctures (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Eversmannibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Eversmannibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Middle basitarsus broadly produced at apex; band of ﬁne punctures along inner edge of eye not spreading over unpunctured area of frons; labral lamella not prominent; malar area with many ﬁne punctures (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Exilobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Exilobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Middle basitarsus spinosely produced at apex; band of ﬁne punctures along inner edge of eye spreading halfway across unpunctured area of frons; labral lamella considerably thickened; malar area unpunctured (northeastern Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Tricornibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Tricornibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Metasomal terga with very close, coarse punctures, except T6, which has coarse granules (Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Senexibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Senexibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Apex of mandible with one or two small dorsal teeth and sometimes a small preapical notch setting off an apical tooth; hind basitarsus with no bristles as long as corbicular bristles (except in Mendacibombus and Pressibombus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Senexibombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Frons with no band of close, ﬁne punctures along inner margin of eye (Malaysia to Philippines)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Sibiricobombus) (in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Malar area very long; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment about four times as long as broad; auricle of hind basitarsus with dense brown pile even on surface not apposed to hind tibia (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Diversobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Third ﬂagellar segment clearly longer than second, which is transverse rather than quadrate; hind basitarsus little produced apically (Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Rhodobombus) (in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Clypeus with dispersed, sparse, ﬁne punctures; middle basitarsus more spinosely produced; frons less punctured, with a larger unpunctured area in front of and at sides of ocelli (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Thoracobombus) (in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth

This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Apex of mandible with one or two small dorsal teeth and sometimes a small preapical notch setting off an apical tooth; hind basitarsus with no bristles as long as corbicular bristles (except in Mendacibombus and Pressibombus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Thoracobombus) (in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Malar area as long as combined lengths of ﬁrst and second ﬂagellar segments; apical impressions of clypeus rather strong, with close, moderately coarse punctures; labral tubercles ﬂattened, furrow shallow (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Mucidobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Mucidobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Apex of mandible with one or two small dorsal teeth and sometimes a small preapical notch setting off an apical tooth; hind basitarsus with no bristles as long as corbicular bristles (except in Mendacibombus and Pressibombus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Mucidobombus) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Malar area not quite as long as combined lengths of pedicel and ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment; apical impressions of clypeus weak, with narrow deeper strip of close, moderately coarse punctures; labral tubercles somewhat raised and angular at inner ends, furrow moderately deep (palearctic)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Subterraneobombus)(in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Hind tibia with corbicula (Fig. 119-9a) and rastellum; hind basitarsus with strong auricle; apex of metasoma not curved downward; S6 without carinae; worker caste usually present

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Subterraneobombus)(in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Apex of mandible with one or two small dorsal teeth and sometimes a small preapical notch setting off an apical tooth; hind basitarsus with no bristles as long as corbicular bristles (except in Mendacibombus and Pressibombus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Subterraneobombus)(in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Clypeus swollen with no furrow or lines of punctures on upper third of midline; hind tibia with inner dorsal apical angle sharp, although projection rather broad (holarctic)

Title: Bees Of The World

Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Rhodobombus) (in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991.
