Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Fervidobombus) (in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Apex of mandible with one or two small dorsal teeth and sometimes a small preapical notch setting off an apical tooth; hind basitarsus with no bristles as long as corbicular bristles (except in Mendacibombus and Pressibombus)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera B. (Fervidobombus) (in part) of Bombus (Females)(Modiﬁed from Richards, 1968, with additions based onWilliams, 1991. This key is based primarily on gynes andmay not work for some workers.): Clypeus generally with closer and coarser punctures; middle basitarsus often not very distinctly produced; frons more punctured, with unpunctured areas smaller (Western Hemisphere)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Trigonisca of the Meliponini: Base of marginal cell broad, basal angle (between stigmal margin and vein r, within marginal cell) slightly acute (not under 68/H11034) to right-angular (Fig. 120-1f); marginal cell, at apex of stigma, broader than submarginal cell area; forewing less, usually much less, than 4 mm long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Trichotrigona of the Meliponini: Base of marginal cell of usual shape, basal angle strongly acute (not over 50/H11034) (Fig. 120-1a-e) (except about 80% in Nogueirapis); marginal cell, at apex of stigma, little if any broader than submarginal cell area; forewing usually over 4 mm long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Trichotrigona of the Meliponini: Inner surface of hind tibia with strongly depressed, shining, upper marginal zone, which at least apically is usually about as broad as longitudinal median keirotrichiate ridge, and midway of tibial length is at least half as wide as keirotrichiate ridge (Fig. 120-10a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Trichotrigona of the Meliponini: Eyes hairy; rastellum reduced to tapering hairs (Brazil)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Oxytrigona of the Meliponini: Base of marginal cell of usual shape, basal angle strongly acute (not over 50/H11034) (Fig. 120-1a-e) (except about 80% in Nogueirapis); marginal cell, at apex of stigma, little if any broader than submarginal cell area; forewing usually over 4 mm long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Oxytrigona of the Meliponini: Inner surface of hind tibia with strongly depressed, shining, upper marginal zone, which at least apically is usually about as broad as longitudinal median keirotrichiate ridge, and midway of tibial length is at least half as wide as keirotrichiate ridge (Fig. 120-10a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Oxytrigona of the Meliponini: Eyes bare; rastellum strongly developed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Oxytrigona of the Meliponini: Face short and broad, minimum distance between eyes much greater than length of eye; clypeus less than twice as broad as long; malar space almost twice as long as ﬂagellar diameter; keirotrichiate zone on inner surface of worker hind tibia nearly twice as wide as depressed upper marginal zone at midlength of tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Cephalotrigona of the Meliponini: Base of marginal cell of usual shape, basal angle strongly acute (not over 50/H11034) (Fig. 120-1a-e) (except about 80% in Nogueirapis); marginal cell, at apex of stigma, little if any broader than submarginal cell area; forewing usually over 4 mm long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Cephalotrigona of the Meliponini: Inner surface of hind tibia with strongly depressed, shining, upper marginal zone, which at least apically is usually about as broad as longitudinal median keirotrichiate ridge, and midway of tibial length is at least half as wide as keirotrichiate ridge (Fig. 120-10a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Cephalotrigona of the Meliponini: Eyes bare; rastellum strongly developed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Cephalotrigona of the Meliponini: Face of ordinary shape, minimum distance between eyes little more than to less than length of eye; clypeus usually more than twice as broad as long; malar space little over 1.5 times as long as ﬂagellar diameter or usually much less; keirotrichiate zone on inner surface of worker hind tibia usually narrower (Fig. 120-10a), rarely over 1.5 times as wide as depressed upper marginal zone at mid length of tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Cephalotrigona of the Meliponini: Preoccipital carina strong and shining across full width behind vertex; lower face and genal area shining and coarsely punctate in contrast to dull, densely, minutely punctate upper face, genal area and scutum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Trigona of the Meliponini: Base of marginal cell of usual shape, basal angle strongly acute (not over 50/H11034) (Fig. 120-1a-e) (except about 80% in Nogueirapis); marginal cell, at apex of stigma, little if any broader than submarginal cell area; forewing usually over 4 mm long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Trigona of the Meliponini: Inner surface of hind tibia with strongly depressed, shining, upper marginal zone, which at least apically is usually about as broad as longitudinal median keirotrichiate ridge, and midway of tibial length is at least half as wide as keirotrichiate ridge (Fig. 120-10a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Trigona of the Meliponini: Eyes bare; rastellum strongly developed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Trigona of the Meliponini: Face of ordinary shape, minimum distance between eyes little more than to less than length of eye; clypeus usually more than twice as broad as long; malar space little over 1.5 times as long as ﬂagellar diameter or usually much less; keirotrichiate zone on inner surface of worker hind tibia usually narrower (Fig. 120-10a), rarely over 1.5 times as wide as depressed upper marginal zone at mid length of tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Trigona of the Meliponini: Preoccipital carina absent; lower face and genal area ﬁnely sculptured like upper part of head and scutum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Lestrimelitta of the Meliponini: Base of marginal cell of usual shape, basal angle strongly acute (not over 50/H11034) (Fig. 120-1a-e) (except about 80% in Nogueirapis); marginal cell, at apex of stigma, little if any broader than submarginal cell area; forewing usually over 4 mm long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Lestrimelitta of the Meliponini: Inner surface of hind tibia with depressed upper marginal zone more narrow (much less than half as wide as area with keirotrichia) or absent, keirotrichia extending to or close to margin (Fig. 120-10b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Lestrimelitta of the Meliponini: First ﬂagellar segment of worker nearly as long as second plus third taken together, of male nearly as long as second; outer surface of hind tibia convex, without corbicula, lower margin convex like upper margin; penicillum absent; rastellum consisting of tapering hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Melipona of the Meliponini: Base of marginal cell of usual shape, basal angle strongly acute (not over 50/H11034) (Fig. 120-1a-e) (except about 80% in Nogueirapis); marginal cell, at apex of stigma, little if any broader than submarginal cell area; forewing usually over 4 mm long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Melipona of the Meliponini: Inner surface of hind tibia with depressed upper marginal zone more narrow (much less than half as wide as area with keirotrichia) or absent, keirotrichia extending to or close to margin (Fig. 120-10b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Melipona of the Meliponini: First ﬂagellar segment of worker shorter than second plus third taken together, of male much shorter than second; outer surface of hind tibia of worker (and some males) ﬂat or concave at least distally, forming corbicula, lower margin gently convex to concave, unlike largely or wholly convex upper margin (Fig. 120-11); penicillum present (Fig. 120-11); rastellum variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Melipona of the Meliponini: Hamuli 9-14 (rarely 8); wings extending little if any beyond apex of metasoma; stigma with margin within marginal cell straight or weakly concave (Fig. 120-1a) (body apiform; basal propodeal area dull, hairy)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Nannotrigona of the Meliponini: Base of marginal cell of usual shape, basal angle strongly acute (not over 50/H11034) (Fig. 120-1a-e) (except about 80% in Nogueirapis); marginal cell, at apex of stigma, little if any broader than submarginal cell area; forewing usually over 4 mm long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Nannotrigona of the Meliponini: Inner surface of hind tibia with depressed upper marginal zone more narrow (much less than half as wide as area with keirotrichia) or absent, keirotrichia extending to or close to margin (Fig. 120-10b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Nannotrigona of the Meliponini: First ﬂagellar segment of worker shorter than second plus third taken together, of male much shorter than second; outer surface of hind tibia of worker (and some males) ﬂat or concave at least distally, forming corbicula, lower margin gently convex to concave, unlike largely or wholly convex upper margin (Fig. 120-11); penicillum present (Fig. 120-11); rastellum variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Nannotrigona of the Meliponini: Hamuli 5-7, rarely up to 9 or even 10; wings long, extending well beyond apex of metasoma; stigma with margin within marginal cell slightly convex (Fig. 120-1b-f)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Nannotrigona of the Meliponini: Anterior part of scutellum with shining, longitudinal Vor U-shaped median depression opening anteriorly into scutoscutellar fossa (Fig. 120-10d); preoccipital carina present, extending far down on each side of head

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Nannotrigona of the Meliponini: Head and thorax, or at least scutellum, with extremely coarse, cribriform punctation; posterior margin of scutellum notched or emarginate medially as seen from above; anterior margin of pronotal lobe with strong, transverse carina

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Scaptotrigona of the Meliponini: Base of marginal cell of usual shape, basal angle strongly acute (not over 50/H11034) (Fig. 120-1a-e) (except about 80% in Nogueirapis); marginal cell, at apex of stigma, little if any broader than submarginal cell area; forewing usually over 4 mm long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Scaptotrigona of the Meliponini: Inner surface of hind tibia with depressed upper marginal zone more narrow (much less than half as wide as area with keirotrichia) or absent, keirotrichia extending to or close to margin (Fig. 120-10b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Scaptotrigona of the Meliponini: First ﬂagellar segment of worker shorter than second plus third taken together, of male much shorter than second; outer surface of hind tibia of worker (and some males) ﬂat or concave at least distally, forming corbicula, lower margin gently convex to concave, unlike largely or wholly convex upper margin (Fig. 120-11); penicillum present (Fig. 120-11); rastellum variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Scaptotrigona of the Meliponini: Hamuli 5-7, rarely up to 9 or even 10; wings long, extending well beyond apex of metasoma; stigma with margin within marginal cell slightly convex (Fig. 120-1b-f)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Scaptotrigona of the Meliponini: Anterior part of scutellum with shining, longitudinal Vor U-shaped median depression opening anteriorly into scutoscutellar fossa (Fig. 120-10d); preoccipital carina present, extending far down on each side of head

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Scaptotrigona of the Meliponini: Head and thorax with ﬁne punctation; posterior margin of scutellum entire; anterior margin of pronotal lobe rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Paratrigona of the Meliponini: Mandible of worker with four apical teeth (lower two sometimes united by translucent septum but teeth still recognizable); scutellum, as seen in lateral view projecting posteriorly as thin shelf over median part of metanotum

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Partamona of the Meliponini: Hind tibia of worker greatly broadened, spoonshaped (Fig. 120-11b), about three times as wide as femur, outer surface largely occupied by corbicula, lower margin of tibia with distal one-half convex; basal area of propodeum densely hairy

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Meliwillea of the Meliponini: Malar space about one-ﬁfth as long as eye; upper margin of hind basitarsus strongly convex medially; yellow markings absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Plebeia of the Meliponini: Upper margin of inner surface of hind tibia strongly depressed, shiny, in sharp contrast to keirotrichiate area [except not depressed in apical third of tibia of Plebeia (Scaura) timida (Silvestri)]; concave surface of corbicula usually not occupying whole distal half of hind tibia

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Paratrigonoides of the Meliponini: Integument of head and thorax dull, microrecticulate; preoccipital carina lamellate across upper part of head, with row of coarse setae, branched apically; supraclypeal area expanded laterally, forming ﬂange partly covering antennal socket

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Genera Nogueirapis of the Meliponini: Integument largely shiny; preoccipital carina absent, without row of course setae; supraclypeal area not expanded laterally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Cleptotrigona of the Meliponini: Forewing length less than 3.5 mm; hind wing without closed cells (as in Fig. 120-1f), veins closing cells R and Cu, if visible at all, clear and unpigmented; forewing with submarginal crossveins almost always completely absent, thus indications of submarginal cells absent; at least distal part of cell second Cu of forewing undeﬁned or deﬁned by completely unpigmented vein traces; vein M of forewing terminating without bend at about position of anterior end of ﬁrst recurrent vein (as in Fig. 120-1f), which, however, is absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Cleptotrigona of the Meliponini: Outer surface of hind tibia of worker convex, without corbicula; penicillum absent; clypeus much more than twice as wide as long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Liotrigona of the Meliponini: Forewing length less than 3.5 mm; hind wing without closed cells (as in Fig. 120-1f), veins closing cells R and Cu, if visible at all, clear and unpigmented; forewing with submarginal crossveins almost always completely absent, thus indications of submarginal cells absent; at least distal part of cell second Cu of forewing undeﬁned or deﬁned by completely unpigmented vein traces; vein M of forewing terminating without bend at about position of anterior end of ﬁrst recurrent vein (as in Fig. 120-1f), which, however, is absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Liotrigona of the Meliponini: Distal part of outer surface of hind tibia of worker ﬂat or concave, margined by long hair, forming corbicula; penicillum present; clypeus twice as wide as long or less

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Liotrigona of the Meliponini: Upper apical part of hind tibia of worker forming distinct angle; gonostyli of worker much longer than broad, ﬂat, adjacent or separated by less than one gonostylar diameter, without setae but with minute hairs (as in Fig. 120-6e-g)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Hypotrigona of the Meliponini: Forewing length less than 3.5 mm; hind wing without closed cells (as in Fig. 120-1f), veins closing cells R and Cu, if visible at all, clear and unpigmented; forewing with submarginal crossveins almost always completely absent, thus indications of submarginal cells absent; at least distal part of cell second Cu of forewing undeﬁned or deﬁned by completely unpigmented vein traces; vein M of forewing terminating without bend at about position of anterior end of ﬁrst recurrent vein (as in Fig. 120-1f), which, however, is absent

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Hypotrigona of the Meliponini: Distal part of outer surface of hind tibia of worker ﬂat or concave, margined by long hair, forming corbicula; penicillum present; clypeus twice as wide as long or less

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Hypotrigona of the Meliponini: Upper apical part of hind tibia of worker rounded; gonostyli of worker minute, tuberculiform, separated by several gonostylar diameters, with setae but without minute hairs (as in Fig. 120-6c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Dactylurina of the Meliponini: Forewing length about 4 mm or more; hind wing commonly with cells R and Cu closed by at least weakly brownish veins; forewing with one or two submarginal crossveins usually weakly indicated, ﬁrst submarginal cell thus usually recognizable; cell second Cu of forewing completely indicated, at least by faint veins; vein M of forewing extending at least slightly beyond position of anterior end of ﬁrst recurrent vein and angulate at end of that vein (Fig. 120-1d, e; as in 120-1c), which is usually at least faintly visible

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Dactylurina of the Meliponini: Inner surface of hind tibia with strongly depressed, shining, upper marginal area nearly as broad apically as longitudinal median keirotrichiate ridge, and about half as wide as keirotrichiate ridge midway of tibial length; ﬁrst metasomal segment longer than broad

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Meliponula of the Meliponini: Forewing length about 4 mm or more; hind wing commonly with cells R and Cu closed by at least weakly brownish veins; forewing with one or two submarginal crossveins usually weakly indicated, ﬁrst submarginal cell thus usually recognizable; cell second Cu of forewing completely indicated, at least by faint veins; vein M of forewing extending at least slightly beyond position of anterior end of ﬁrst recurrent vein and angulate at end of that vein (Fig. 120-1d, e; as in 120-1c), which is usually at least faintly visible

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Meliponula of the Meliponini: Inner surface of hind tibia with depressed upper marginal area narrow (much less than half as wide as broad area with keirotrichia) or absent, keirotrichia extending to or close to margin; ﬁrst metasomal segment broader than long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Meliponula of the Meliponini: Hind tibia of worker rather spoon-shaped, upper apical angle rounded but with coarse, amber-colored to blackish bristles (posterior parapenicillum); sting stylet of worker distinct, acute (Fig. 120-6e, g)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Plebeina of the Meliponini: Forewing length about 4 mm or more; hind wing commonly with cells R and Cu closed by at least weakly brownish veins; forewing with one or two submarginal crossveins usually weakly indicated, ﬁrst submarginal cell thus usually recognizable; cell second Cu of forewing completely indicated, at least by faint veins; vein M of forewing extending at least slightly beyond position of anterior end of ﬁrst recurrent vein and angulate at end of that vein (Fig. 120-1d, e; as in 120-1c), which is usually at least faintly visible

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Plebeina of the Meliponini: Inner surface of hind tibia with depressed upper marginal area narrow (much less than half as wide as broad area with keirotrichia) or absent, keirotrichia extending to or close to margin; ﬁrst metasomal segment broader than long

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the African Genera Plebeina of the Meliponini: Hind tibia of worker slender, triangular with distinct up per apical angle supporting long, pale hairs (not especially coarse); sting stylet of worker a mere rounded con-vexity

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Trigona of the Meliponini of Asia and the Sunda Islands: Forewing length commonly (but not always) over 4 mm, wing venation usually not greatly reduced (for a meliponine), but if minute and with some of the wing reduction characters listed below, then upper margin of hind tibia with plumose hairs intermixed with simple ones (as in Fig. 120-11a); hind wing commonly with cells R and Cu closed by at least weakly brownish veins; forewing with one or two submarginal crossveins usually weakly indicated, ﬁrst submarginal cell usually recognizable; cell second Cu of forewing completely indicated at least by faint veins; vein M of forewing usually extending at least slightly beyond position of anterior end of ﬁrst recurrent vein and angulate at end of that vein (as in Fig. 120-1c), which is usually at least faintly visible

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pariotrigona of the Meliponini of Asia and the Sunda Islands: Forewing length less than 3 mm, wing venation greatly reduced; upper margin of hind tibia without plumose hairs; hind wing without closed cells, veins closing cells R and Cu, if visible at all, clear and unpigmented; forewing with submarginal crossveins almost always completely absent, thus without indications of submarginal cells; at least distal part of cell second Cu of forewing undeﬁned or deﬁned by completely unpigmented vein traces; vein M of forewing terminating without bend at about position of anterior end of ﬁrst recurrent vein which, however, is absent (as in Fig. 120-1f)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Pariotrigona of the Meliponini of Asia and the Sunda Islands: Malar space almost one-ﬁfth as long as eye, much longer than ﬂagellar diameter; gonostylus of worker with setae but without minute hairs

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Lisotrigona of the Meliponini of Asia and the Sunda Islands: Forewing length less than 3 mm, wing venation greatly reduced; upper margin of hind tibia without plumose hairs; hind wing without closed cells, veins closing cells R and Cu, if visible at all, clear and unpigmented; forewing with submarginal crossveins almost always completely absent, thus without indications of submarginal cells; at least distal part of cell second Cu of forewing undeﬁned or deﬁned by completely unpigmented vein traces; vein M of forewing terminating without bend at about position of anterior end of ﬁrst recurrent vein which, however, is absent (as in Fig. 120-1f)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Lisotrigona of the Meliponini of Asia and the Sunda Islands: Malar space shorter than ﬂagellar diameter; gonostylus of worker with many minute hairs, in addition to setae along outer and distal margins

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Genera Trigona of the Meliponini of Asia and the Sunda Islands: Forewing length commonly (but not always) over 4 mm, wing venation usually not greatly reduced (for a meliponine), but if minute and with some of the wing reduction characters listed below, then upper margin of hind tibia with plumose hairs intermixed with simple ones (as in Fig. 120-11a); hind wing commonly with cells R and Cu closed by at least weakly brownish veins; forewing with one or two submarginal crossveins usually weakly indicated, ﬁrst submarginal cell usually recognizable; cell second Cu of forewing completely indicated at least by faint veins; vein M of forewing usually extending at least slightly beyond position of anterior end of ﬁrst recurrent vein and angulate at end of that vein (as in Fig. 120-1c), which is usually at least faintly visible

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Meliponula s. str.) of Meliponula: Propodeal proﬁle largely vertical; corbicula occupying less than distal half of hind tibia; apical reﬂexed process of S6 of male short and rounded; metasomal terga dull, minutely sculptured

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Axestotrigona) of Meliponula: Propodeal proﬁle with slanting dorsal portion rounding onto vertical portion; corbicula occupying more than distal half of hind tibia; apical reﬂexed process of S6 of male longer than body of sternum; metasomal terga at least partly shining

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Axestotrigona) of Meliponula: Head and thorax without yellow markings; inner surface of worker hind tibia without well-deﬁned, shining, depressed upper margin, although keirotrichiate area does not reach margin at least distally

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Meliplebeia) of Meliponula: Propodeal proﬁle with slanting dorsal portion rounding onto vertical portion; corbicula occupying more than distal half of hind tibia; apical reﬂexed process of S6 of male longer than body of sternum; metasomal terga at least partly shining

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera M. (Meliplebeia) of Meliponula: Head and thorax with yellow markings; inner surface of worker hind tibia with shining upper margin, at least slightly depressed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Partamona s. str.) of Partamona: Cuticle of thorax shining with minute, widely separated punctures; yellow of face pale and inconspicuous; metasomal terga without yellow maculations; worker gonostylus a rounded tubercle with few setae (Fig. 120-6c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Parapartamona) of Partamona: Cuticle of thorax dull and minutely roughened; paraocular areas largely bright yellow; metasomal terga usually with yellow bands or lateral spots; worker gonostylus about 1.5 times as long as broad, and setose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Scaura) of Plebeia: Hind basitarsus thickened, nearly as broad as or broader than tibia (Fig. 120-13) (face without yellow markings)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Schwarziana) of Plebeia: Hind basitarsus ﬂat, much narrower than tibia (Fig. 120-10b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Schwarziana) of Plebeia: Body (including metasomal terga) dull, minutely and closely punctured; forewing length about 6 mm; S3 of male with enormous procurved band of erect hooked hairs, behind which is a concave membranous area with erect hairs (South America)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Plebeia s. str.) of Plebeia: Hind basitarsus ﬂat, much narrower than tibia (Fig. 120-10b)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Subgenera P . (Plebeia s. str.) of Plebeia: Body (or at least metasoma) shining; forewing length less than 5 mm, usually 4 mm or less; S3 of male unmodiﬁed

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Trigona s. str.) of Trigona: Mandible of worker with four or ﬁve teeth along distal margin (Fig. 119-5c); inner surface of hind basitarsus of males and workers with basal sericeous area (Fig. 12010a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Geotrigona) of Trigona: Mandible of worker with lower half or two-thirds of distal margin edentate, upper part of margin with one or usually two teeth; inner surface of hind basitarsus of males without basal sericeous area, that of workers, variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Geotrigona) of Trigona: Metasoma short, about as wide as thorax, dorsoventrally ﬂattened; upper margin of hind tibia of worker usually with few plumose hairs, most of them with only two to six scattered branches not concentrated toward apices; yellow markings absent; vein M of forewing dark almost to wing margin

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (T etragonisca) of Trigona: Mandible of worker with lower half or two-thirds of distal margin edentate, upper part of margin with one or usually two teeth; inner surface of hind basitarsus of males without basal sericeous area, that of workers, variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (T etragonisca) of Trigona: Metasoma usually narrower than thorax, often noticeably elongate; upper margin of hind tibia of worker with numerous strongly plumose hairs (Fig. 120-11a), usually with abundant branches toward apices; yellowish or reddish markings present on face of some species; vein M of forewing usually fading away near widest part of wing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (T etragonisca) of Trigona: Inner surface of hind basitarsus of worker with basal sericeous area covered with minute setae or sometimes lacking setae (Fig. 120-10a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Duckeola) of Trigona: Mandible of worker with lower half or two-thirds of distal margin edentate, upper part of margin with one or usually two teeth; inner surface of hind basitarsus of males without basal sericeous area, that of workers, variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Duckeola) of Trigona: Metasoma usually narrower than thorax, often noticeably elongate; upper margin of hind tibia of worker with numerous strongly plumose hairs (Fig. 120-11a), usually with abundant branches toward apices; yellowish or reddish markings present on face of some species; vein M of forewing usually fading away near widest part of wing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Duckeola) of Trigona: Inner surface of hind basitarsus of worker without basal sericeous area, rather uniformly setose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Duckeola) of Trigona: Posterior margin of vertex elevated as strong, hairy ridge between summits of eyes; upper distal angle of hind tibia of worker acute (Brazil)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Frieseomelitta) of Trigona: Mandible of worker with lower half or two-thirds of distal margin edentate, upper part of margin with one or usually two teeth; inner surface of hind basitarsus of males without basal sericeous area, that of workers, variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Frieseomelitta) of Trigona: Metasoma usually narrower than thorax, often noticeably elongate; upper margin of hind tibia of worker with numerous strongly plumose hairs (Fig. 120-11a), usually with abundant branches toward apices; yellowish or reddish markings present on face of some species; vein M of forewing usually fading away near widest part of wing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Frieseomelitta) of Trigona: Inner surface of hind basitarsus of worker without basal sericeous area, rather uniformly setose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Frieseomelitta) of Trigona: Posterior margin of vertex not elevated; upper distal angle of hind tibia of worker broadly rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Frieseomelitta) of Trigona: Labial palpi with large, sinuous setae on ﬁrst two segments (Fig. 120-12e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (T etragona) of Trigona: Mandible of worker with lower half or two-thirds of distal margin edentate, upper part of margin with one or usually two teeth; inner surface of hind basitarsus of males without basal sericeous area, that of workers, variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (T etragona) of Trigona: Metasoma usually narrower than thorax, often noticeably elongate; upper margin of hind tibia of worker with numerous strongly plumose hairs (Fig. 120-11a), usually with abundant branches toward apices; yellowish or reddish markings present on face of some species; vein M of forewing usually fading away near widest part of wing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (T etragona) of Trigona: Inner surface of hind basitarsus of worker without basal sericeous area, rather uniformly setose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (T etragona) of Trigona: Posterior margin of vertex not elevated; upper distal angle of hind tibia of worker broadly rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (T etragona) of Trigona: Labial palpi with setae no longer than palpal width and straight or nearly so (Fig. 120-12c)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Trigona s. str.) of Trigona: Mandible of worker with four or ﬁve teeth along distal margin (Fig. 119-5c); inner surface of hind basitarsus of males and workers with basal sericeous area (Fig. 12010a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Geotrigona) of Trigona: Mandible of worker with lower half or two-thirds of distal margin edentate, upper part of margin with one or usually two teeth; inner surface of hind basitarsus of males without basal sericeous area, that of workers, variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (T etragonisca) of Trigona: Inner surface of hind basitarsus of worker with basal sericeous area covered with minute setae or sometimes lacking setae (Fig. 120-10a)

Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Duckeola) of Trigona: Mandible of worker with lower half or two-thirds of distal margin edentate, upper part of margin with one or usually two teeth; inner surface of hind basitarsus of males without basal sericeous area, that of workers, variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Duckeola) of Trigona: Inner surface of hind basitarsus of worker without basal sericeous area, rather uniformly setose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Duckeola) of Trigona: Posterior margin of vertex elevated as strong, hairy ridge between summits of eyes; upper distal angle of hind tibia of worker acute (Brazil)

Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Frieseomelitta) of Trigona: Mandible of worker with lower half or two-thirds of distal margin edentate, upper part of margin with one or usually two teeth; inner surface of hind basitarsus of males without basal sericeous area, that of workers, variable

Author: Daniel C. Danforth

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Frieseomelitta) of Trigona: Inner surface of hind basitarsus of worker without basal sericeous area, rather uniformly setose

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Frieseomelitta) of Trigona: Posterior margin of vertex not elevated; upper distal angle of hind tibia of worker broadly rounded

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Frieseomelitta) of Trigona: Labial palpi with large, sinuous setae on ﬁrst two segments (Fig. 120-12e)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Lepidotrigona) of Trigona: Mandible of worker with lower half or two-thirds of distal margin edentate, upper part of margin with one or usually two teeth; inner surface of hind basitarsus of males without basal sericeous area, that of workers, variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Lepidotrigona) of Trigona: Head and thorax dull, with minute close punctures; propodeal dorsum ﬁnely reticulate; upper margin of hind tibia of worker without plumose hairs; scutum margined with whitish, densely plumose (“scale-like”) hairs (Southeast Asia)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Papuatrigona) of Trigona: Mandible of worker with lower half or two-thirds of distal margin edentate, upper part of margin with one or usually two teeth; inner surface of hind basitarsus of males without basal sericeous area, that of workers, variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Papuatrigona) of Trigona: Head and thorax shining, although with minute, rather close punctures; propodeal dorsum smooth, shining; upper margin of hind tibia of worker with plumose hairs among bristles on apical one-ﬁfth or one-sixth of margin; scutum without conspicuous plumose hairs (New Guinea)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Heterotrigona) of Trigona: Mandible of worker with lower half or two-thirds of distal margin edentate, upper part of margin with one or usually two teeth; inner surface of hind basitarsus of males without basal sericeous area, that of workers, variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Heterotrigona) of Trigona: Metasoma usually narrower than thorax, often noticeably elongate; upper margin of hind tibia of worker with numerous strongly plumose hairs (Fig. 120-11a), usually with abundant branches toward apices; yellowish or reddish markings present on face of some species; vein M of forewing usually fading away near widest part of wing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Heterotrigona) of Trigona: Inner surface of hind basitarsus of worker with basal sericeous area covered with minute setae or sometimes lacking setae (Fig. 120-10a)

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Homotrigona) of Trigona: Mandible of worker with lower half or two-thirds of distal margin edentate, upper part of margin with one or usually two teeth; inner surface of hind basitarsus of males without basal sericeous area, that of workers, variable

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Homotrigona) of Trigona: Metasoma usually narrower than thorax, often noticeably elongate; upper margin of hind tibia of worker with numerous strongly plumose hairs (Fig. 120-11a), usually with abundant branches toward apices; yellowish or reddish markings present on face of some species; vein M of forewing usually fading away near widest part of wing

Title: Bees Of The World
Author: Daniel C. Danforth
Text Content: Characteristics to the Neotropical Subgenera T . (Homotrigona) of Trigona: Inner surface of hind basitarsus of worker without basal sericeous area, rather uniformly setose (Southeast Asia)

Title: BOTW
Author: BOTWAuthor.
Image Description: Figure 7-2 from "Bees of the World" by Daniel C. Danforth illustrates the underground nest structures of the eucerine bee, Peponapis fervens, in Brazil. The figure presents a mature nest alongside newer nests, showcasing variations in nest architecture. The mature nest is depicted with obscured lateral burrows filled with earth, indicating the nest's evolutionary adaptation to protect its structure and contents. In contrast, the newer nests each feature a single, clearly visible lateral burrow, which is newly constructed and unprovisioned. This comparison highlights the developmental stages of the nest and the bee's method of expanding and securing its reproductive site. The diagram serves as a visual explanation of the nesting behavior of Peponapis fervens, emphasizing the strategic placement and construction of lateral burrows to optimize survival and reproduction.

Title: BOTW
Author: BOTWAuthor.
Image Description: Figure 7-3 from "Bees of the World" by Daniel C. Danforth illustrates the nesting structure of the colonial halictine bee, Halictus ligatus Say, as excavated in soil in Trinidad. This diagram specifically focuses on the arrangement of sessile cells within the nest. The figure effectively shows the spatial layout and developmental stages of the bee larvae within these cells. Key labeled components include cells marked with dots, which represent abandoned, earth-filled cells. Other cells are labeled to indicate their contents: 'e' for empty, 'E' for egg, 'SL' for small larva, 'ML' for medium-sized larva, and 'PP' for a large larva, usually in the prepupal stage. This detailed labeling helps in understanding the life cycle stages and nest occupancy, providing insights into the reproductive and developmental biology of Halictus ligatus. The diagram serves as a valuable visual aid for comprehending the complex life processes and nest architecture of this bee species.

Title: BOTW
Author: BOTWAuthor.
Image Description: Figure 7-5 from "Bees of the World" by Daniel C. Danforth illustrates the nests of Augochlorella striata (Provancher) excavated into soil. The figure features two main components: at the left, a cluster of cells exposed by digging, and at the center, a detailed view of a single nest. These components highlight the construction techniques of Augochlorella striata, showcasing the smooth earthen layers lining the cells and the application of a waxlike material. This figure effectively demonstrates the natural engineering skills of these bees, emphasizing their ability to modify and utilize soil materials to create protective environments for their offspring. The visual representation aids in understanding the text's discussion on the nesting behavior of soil-excavating bees and refutes earlier views that such sophisticated construction does not occur.

Title: BOTW
Author: BOTWAuthor.
Image Description: Figure 7-6 from "Bees of the World" by Daniel C. Danforth illustrates the nesting behavior of Heriades spiniscutis (Cameron) in dead, dry stems. This figure provides a visual comparison of three different nests, highlighting variations in construction techniques within the species. One nest, located on the right side of the figure, features thin partitions made of pith fragments between the cells, which are indicated by horizontal lines. The other two nests depicted do not have any partitions between the cells. This figure effectively demonstrates the variability in cell partitioning in Megachilidae bee nests, specifically showing how Heriades spiniscutis may or may not use partitions, which are crucial for understanding nesting ecology and behavior in this species. The figure underscores the adaptability and resource utilization of these bees in their natural habitat.

Title: BOTW
Author: BOTWAuthor.
Image Description: Figure 8-1 from "Bees of the World" by Daniel C. Danforth illustrates the proboscidial structures of parasitic and nonparasitic allodapine bees, focusing on the maxilla and labium. This figure compares the anatomical features of two parasitic species, Eucondylops reducta Michener and Nasutapis straussorum Michener (labeled as a and b), with those of a nonparasitic species, Allodapula melanopus (Cameron), labeled as c. The key components highlighted are the maxilla (left side of each pair) and the labium (right side of each pair), which are essential for feeding behaviors in bees. The illustration is scaled uniformly across all species to emphasize the morphological differences, particularly showing the reduction in size of these structures in the parasitic species compared to the nonparasitic species. This visual comparison underscores evolutionary adaptations linked to the bees' parasitic or nonparasitic lifestyles.
